question: Let $z \in C$ with $\operatorname{Im}(z)=10$ and it satisfies $\frac{2 z-n}{2 z+n}=2 i-1$ for some natural number $n$, then \\
solution:
Let $z=x+10 i$, as $\operatorname{Im}(z)=10$ (given)

Since $z$ satisfies,

$$
\begin{aligned}
\frac{2 z-n}{2 z+n} & =2 i-1, n \in N, \\
\therefore \quad(2 x+20 i-n) & =(2 i-1)(2 x+20 i+n) \\
\Rightarrow \quad(2 x-n)+20 i & =(-2 x-n-40)+(4 x+2 n-20) i
\end{aligned}
$$

On comparing real and imaginary parts, we get

$$
\begin{aligned}
& & 2 x-n & =-2 x-n-40 \text { and } 20=4 x+2 n-20 \\
\Rightarrow & & 4 x & =-40 \text { and } 4 x+2 n=40 \\
\Rightarrow & & x & =-10 \text { and }-40+2 n=40 \\
& \text { So, } & n & =40 \text { and } x=\operatorname{Re}(z)=-10
\end{aligned}
$$

question: All the points in the set $S=\frac{\alpha+i}{\alpha-i}: \alpha \in \mathbf{R} \quad(i=\sqrt{-1})$ lie on a
options: b) straight line whose slope is -1 .
d) straight line whose slope is 1 .
solution:
Let $x+i y=\frac{\alpha+i}{\alpha-i}$

$$
\Rightarrow x+i y=\frac{(\alpha+i)^{2}}{\alpha^{2}+1}=\frac{\left(\alpha^{2}-1\right)+(2 \alpha) i}{\alpha^{2}+1}=\frac{\alpha^{2}-1}{\alpha^{2}+1}+\frac{2 \alpha}{\alpha^{2}+1} i
$$

On comparing real and imaginary parts, we get

$$
x=\frac{\alpha^{2}-1}{\alpha^{2}+1} \text { and } y=\frac{2 \alpha}{\alpha^{2}+1}
$$

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \text { Now, } x^{2}+y^{2}={\frac{\alpha^{2}-1}{\alpha^{2}+1}}^{2}+{\frac{2 \alpha}{\alpha^{2}+1}}^{2} \\
& =\frac{\alpha^{4}+1-2 \alpha^{2}+4 \alpha^{2}}{\left(\alpha^{2}+1\right)^{2}}=\frac{\left(\alpha^{2}+1\right)^{2}}{\left(\alpha^{2}+1\right)^{2}}=1 \\
& \Rightarrow \quad x^{2}+y^{2}=1
\end{aligned}
$$

Which is an equation of circle with centre $(0,0)$ and radius 1 unit.

So, $S=\frac{\alpha+i}{\alpha-i} ; \alpha \in \mathbf{R}$ lies on a circle with radius 1 .

question: Let $z \in C$ be such that $|z|<1$. If $\omega=\frac{5+3 z}{5(1-z)}$, then\\
solution:
Given complex number


\begin{align*}
& \omega=\frac{5+3 z}{5(1-z)} \\
& \Rightarrow \quad 5 \omega-5 \omega z=5+3 z \\
& \Rightarrow \quad(3+5 \omega) z=5 \omega-5 \\
& \Rightarrow \quad|3+5 \omega||z|=\mid 5 \omega-5 \tag{i}
\end{align*}


[applying modulus both sides and $\left|z_{1} z_{2}\right|=\left|z_{1}\right|\left|z_{2}\right|$ ]

$$
\because \quad|z|<1
$$

$\therefore|3+5 \omega|>|5 \omega-5|$

\section*{Complex Numbers}
$$
\Rightarrow \quad \omega+\frac{3}{5}>|\omega-1|
$$

Let $\omega=x+i y$, then $x+\frac{3}{5}^{2}+y^{2}>(x-1)^{2}+y^{2}$

$\Rightarrow \quad x^{2}+\frac{9}{25}+\frac{6}{5} x>x^{2}+1-2 x$

$\Rightarrow \frac{16 x}{5}>\frac{16}{25} \Rightarrow x>\frac{1}{5} \Rightarrow 5 x>1$

$\Rightarrow \quad 5 \operatorname{Re}(\omega)>1$

question: Let $-2-\frac{1}{3} i^{3}=\frac{x+i y}{27}(i=\sqrt{-1})$, where $x$ and $y$ are real numbers, then $y-x$ equals\\
solution:
We have, $\frac{x+i y}{27}=-2-\frac{1}{3} i^{3}=\frac{-1}{3}(6+i)^{3}$

$$
\begin{aligned}
\Rightarrow \frac{x+i y}{27} & =-\frac{1}{27}\left(216+108 i+18 i^{2}+i^{3}\right) \\
& =-\frac{1}{27}(198+107 i)
\end{aligned}
$$

$\left[\because(a+b)^{3}=a^{3}+b^{3}+3 a^{2} b+3 a b^{2}, i^{2}=-1, i^{3}=-i\right]$

On equating real and imaginary part, we get

$$
\begin{gathered}
x=-198 \text { and } y=-107 \\
\Rightarrow \quad y-x=-107+198=91
\end{gathered}
$$

question: Let $A=\theta \in-\frac{\pi}{2}, \pi: \frac{3+2 i \sin \theta}{1-2 i \sin \theta}$ is purely imaginary Then, the sum of the elements in $A$ is \\
A value of $\theta$ for which $\frac{2+3 i \sin \theta}{1-2 i \sin \theta}$ is purely imaginary, is\\\\
solution:
Let $z=\frac{2+3 i \sin \theta}{1-2 i \sin \theta}$ is purely imaginary. Then, we have $\operatorname{Re}(z)=0$

Now, consider $z=\frac{2+3 i \sin \theta}{1-2 i \sin \theta}$

$$
\begin{aligned}
& =\frac{(2+3 i \sin \theta)(1+2 i \sin \theta)}{(1-2 i \sin \theta)(1+2 i \sin \theta)} \\
& =\frac{2+4 i \sin \theta+3 i \sin \theta+6 i^{2} \sin ^{2} \theta}{1^{2}-(2 i \sin \theta)^{2}} \\
& =\frac{2+7 i \sin \theta-6 \sin ^{2} \theta}{1+4 \sin ^{2} \theta} \\
& =\frac{2-6 \sin ^{2} \theta}{1+4 \sin ^{2} \theta}+i \frac{7 \sin \theta}{1+4 \sin ^{2} \theta} \\
\because \quad \frac{2-6 \sin ^2 \theta}{1+4 \sin ^2 \theta} & =0 \Rightarrow 2=6 \sin ^2 \theta \\
\Rightarrow \quad \sin ^2 \theta & =\frac{1}{3} \\
\Rightarrow \quad \sin ^2 \theta & = \pm \frac{1}{\sqrt{3}} \\
\Rightarrow \quad \theta & =\sin ^{-1}\left( \pm \frac{1}{\sqrt{3}}\right)= \pm \sin ^{-1}\left(\frac{1}{\sqrt{3}}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

question:
If $\left|\begin{array}{ccc}6 i & -3 i & 1 \\ 4 & 3 i & -1 \\ 20 & 3 & i\end{array}\right|=x+i y$, then
\\
solution:
Given, $\left|\begin{array}{rrr}6 i & -3 i & 1 \\ 4 & 3 i & -1 \\ 20 & 3 & i\end{array}\right|=x+i y$
$\Rightarrow \quad-3 i\left|\begin{array}{crr}6 i & 1 & 1 \\ 4 & -1 & -1 \\ 20 & i & i\end{array}\right|=x+i y$
$\Rightarrow \quad x+i y=0\left[\because C_2\right.$ and $C_3$ are identical $]$
$$
\Rightarrow \quad x=0, y=0
$$

question: The value of sum $\sum_{n=1}^{13}\left(i^{n}+i^{n+1}\right)$, where $i=\sqrt{-1}$, equals\\
solution:
$\sum_{n=1}^{13}\left(i^n+i^{n+1}\right)=\sum_{n=1}^{13} i^n(1+i)=(1+i) \sum_{n=1}^{13} i^n$
$$
\begin{aligned}
= & (1+i)\left(i+i^2+i^3+\ldots+i^{13}\right)=(1+i)\left[\frac{i-\left(1-i^{13}\right)}{1-i}\right] \\
= & (1+i)\left[\frac{i(1-i)}{1-i}\right]=(1+i) i=i-1
\end{aligned}
$$

Alternate Solution
Since, sum of any four consecutive powers of iota is zero.
$$
\begin{aligned}
\therefore \sum_{n=1}^{13}\left(i^n+i^{n+1}\right) & =\left(i+i^2+\ldots+i^{13}\right) \\
+ & \left(i^2+i^3+\ldots+i^{14}\right)=i+i^2=i-1
\end{aligned}
$$

question: The smallest positive integer $n$ for which $\frac{1+i}{1-i}{ }^{n}=1$, is\\
solution:
Since, $\left(\frac{1+i}{1-i}\right)^n=1 \Rightarrow\left(\frac{1+i}{1-i} \times \frac{1+i}{1+i}\right)^n=1$
$$
\begin{aligned}
\Rightarrow & & \left(\frac{2 i}{2}\right)^n & =1 \\
& \Rightarrow & i^n & =1
\end{aligned}
$$

The smallest positive integer $n$ for which $i^n=1$ is 4 .

$$
\therefore \quad n=4
$$

question: The equation $|z-i|=|z-1|, i=\sqrt{-1}$, represents
options: b) the line passing through the origin with slope 1
d) the line passing through the origin with slope -1\\
solution:
Let the complex number $z=x+i y$

Also given, $|z-i|=|z-1|$

$$
\Rightarrow|x+i y-i|=|x+i y-1|
$$

$$
\Rightarrow \sqrt{x^{2}+(y-1)^{2}}=\sqrt{(x-1)^{2}+y^{2}}
$$

$$
\left[\because|z|=\sqrt{(\operatorname{Re}(z))^{2}+(\operatorname{Im}(z))^{2}}\right]
$$

On squaring both sides, we get

$$
x^{2}+y^{2}-2 y+1=x^{2}+y^{2}-2 x+1
$$

$\Rightarrow y=x$, which represents a line through the origin with slope 1 .

question: If $a>0$ and $z=\frac{(1+i)^{2}}{a-i}$, has magnitude $\sqrt{\frac{2}{5}}$, then $\bar{z}$ is equal to
solution:
The given complex number $z=\frac{(1+i)^{2}}{a-i}$

$$
\begin{aligned}
& =\frac{(1-1+2 i)(a+i)}{a^{2}+1} \\
& =\frac{2 i(a+i)}{a^{2}+1}=\frac{-2+2 a i}{a^{2}+1} \\
& \because \quad|z|=\sqrt{2 / 5} \\
& \Rightarrow \quad \sqrt{\frac{4+4 a^{2}}{\left(a^{2}+1\right)^{2}}}=\sqrt{\frac{2}{5}} \Rightarrow \frac{2}{\sqrt{1+a^{2}}}=\sqrt{\frac{2}{5}} \\
& \Rightarrow \quad \frac{4}{1+a^{2}}=\frac{2}{5} \Rightarrow a^{2}+1=10 \\
& \Rightarrow \quad a^{2}=9 \Rightarrow a=3 \\
& {[\because a>0] \quad 1 \quad} \\
& \therefore \quad z=\frac{-2+6 i}{10} \\
& \text { So, } \bar{z}=\frac{-2+6 i}{10}=-\frac{1}{5}+\frac{3}{5} i \Rightarrow \bar{z}=-\frac{1}{5}-\frac{3}{5} i \\
& {[\because \text { if } z=x+i y \text {, then } \bar{z}=x-i y]}
\end{aligned}
$$

question: Let $z_{1}$ and $z_{2}$ be two complex numbers satisfying $\left|z_{1}\right|=9$ and $\left|z_{2}-3-4 i\right|=4$. Then, the minimum value of $\left|z_{1}-z_{2}\right|$ is\\
solution:
Clearly $\left|z_{1}\right|=9$, represents a circle having centre $C_{1}(0,0)$ and radius $r_{1}=9$.

and $\left|z_{2}-3-4 i\right|=4$ represents a circle having centre $C_{2}(3,4)$ and radius $r_{2}=4$.

The minimum value of $\left|z_{1}-z_{2}\right|$ is equals to minimum distance between circles $\left|z_{1}\right|=9$ and $\left|z_{2}-3-4 i\right|=4$.

$\because C_{1} C_{2}=\sqrt{(3-0)^{2}+(4-0)^{2}}=\sqrt{9+16}=\sqrt{25}=5$

and $\left|r_{1}-r_{2}\right| \neq 9-4\left|=5 \Rightarrow C_{1} C_{2} \# r_{1}-r_{2}\right|$

$\therefore$ Circles touches each other internally.

Hence, $\quad\left|z_{1}-z_{2}\right|_{\min }=0$\\

question: If $\frac{z-\alpha}{z+\alpha}(\alpha \in R)$ is a purely imaginary number and $|z|=2$, then a value of $\alpha$ is\\
solution:
Since, the complex number $\frac{z-\alpha}{z+\alpha}(\alpha \in R)$ is purely imaginary number, therefore

$$
\begin{array}{rlr} 
& \frac{z-\alpha}{z+\alpha}+\frac{\bar{z}-\alpha}{\bar{z}+\alpha}=0 & {[\because \alpha \in R]} \\
\Rightarrow & z \bar{z}-\alpha \bar{z}+\alpha z-\alpha^{2}+z \bar{z}-\alpha z+\alpha \bar{z}-\alpha^{2}=0 \\
\Rightarrow & 2|z|^{2}-2 \alpha^{2}=0 & {\left[\because z \bar{z}=|z|^{2}\right]} \\
\Rightarrow & \alpha^{2}=|z|^{2}=4 & {[|z|=2 \text { given }]} \\
\Rightarrow & \alpha= \pm 2 &
\end{array}
$$

question:
Let $z$ be a complex number such that $|z|+z=3+i$ (where $i=\sqrt{-1}$ ).

Then, $|z|$ is equal to\\
solution:
We have, $|z|+z=3+i$

$$
\begin{array}{lc}
\text { Let } & z=x+i y \\
\therefore & \sqrt{x^{2}+y^{2}}+x+i y=3+i \\
\Rightarrow & \left(x+\sqrt{x^{2}+y^{2}}\right)+i y=3+i \\
\Rightarrow & x+\sqrt{x^{2}+y^{2}}=3 \text { and } y=1 \\
\text { Now, } & \sqrt{x^{2}+1}=3-x \\
\Rightarrow & x^{2}+1=9-6 x+x^{2} \\
\Rightarrow & 6 x=8 \Rightarrow x=\frac{4}{3} \\
\therefore & z=\frac{4}{3}+i \\
\Rightarrow & |z|=\sqrt{\frac{16}{9}+1}=\sqrt{\frac{25}{9}} \Rightarrow|z|=\frac{5}{3}
\end{array}
$$

question:
A complex number $z$ is said to be unimodular, if $|z| \neq 1$. If $z_{1}$ and $z_{2}$ are complex numbers such that $\frac{z_{1}-2 z_{2}}{2-z_{1} \bar{z}_{2}}$ is unimodular and $z_{2}$ is not unimodular.

Then, the point $z_{1}$ lies on a
solution:
PLAN If $z$ is unimodular, then $|z|=1$. Also, use property of modulus i.e. $z \bar{z} \neq\left. z\right|^{2}$

Given, $z_{2}$ is not unimodular i.e. $\left|z_{2}\right| \neq 1$ and $\frac{z_{1}-2 z_{2}}{2-z_{1} \bar{z}_{2}}$ is unimodular.

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \Rightarrow \\
& \Rightarrow \quad\left(z_{1}-3 z_{2}\right)\left(\bar{z}_{1}-2 \bar{z}_{2}\right)=\left(2-z_{1} \bar{z}_{2}\right)\left(2-\bar{z}_{1} z_{2}\right) \quad\left[z \bar{z}=|z|^{2}\right] \\
& \Rightarrow\left|z_{1}\right|^{2}+4\left|z_{2}\right|^{2}-2 \bar{z}_{1} z_{2}-2 z_{1} \bar{z}_{2} \\
& \quad=4+\left|z_{1}\right|^{2}\left|z_{2}\right|^{2}-2 \bar{z}_{1} z_{2}-2 z_{1} \bar{z}_{2} \Rightarrow\left(\left|z_{2}\right|^{2}-1\right)\left(\left|z_{1}\right|^{2}-4\right)=0 \\
& \because \quad\left|z_{2}\right| \neq 1 \\
& \therefore \quad\left|z_{1}\right|=2 \\
& \text { Let } \quad z_{1}=x+i y \Rightarrow x^{2}+y^{2}=(2)^{2}
\end{aligned}
$$

$\therefore \quad$ Point $z_{1}$ lies on a circle of radius 2 .

question:
Let complex numbers $\alpha$ and $1 / \bar{\alpha}$ lies on circles $\left(x-x_{0}\right)^{2}+\left(y-y_{0}\right)^{2}=r^{2}$ and $\left(x-x_{0}\right)^{2}+\left(y-y_{0}\right)^{2}=4 r^{2}$, respectively.

If $z_{0}=x_{0}+i y_{0}$ satisfies the equation $2\left|z_{0}\right|^{2}=r^{2}+2$, then $|\alpha|$ is equal to\\
Let $z$ be a complex number such that the imaginary part of $z$ is non-zero and $a=z^{2}+z+1$ is real. Then, $a$ cannot take the value\\
solution:
PLAN If $a x^{2}+b x+c=0$ has roots $\alpha, \beta$, then

$$
\alpha, \beta=\frac{-b \pm \sqrt{b^{2}-4 a c}}{2 a}
$$

For roots to be real $b^{2}-4 a c \geq 0$.

Description of Situation As imaginary part of $z=x+i y$ is non-zero.

$\Rightarrow \quad y \neq 0$

Method I Let $z=x+i y$

\[
\begin{array}{lc}
\therefore & a=(x+i y)^{2}+(x+i y)+1 \\
\Rightarrow & \left(x^{2}-y^{2}+x+1-a\right)+i(2 x y+y)=0 \\
\Rightarrow & \left(x^{2}-y^{2}+x+1-a\right)+i y(2 x+1)=0 \tag{i}
\end{array}
\]

It is purely real, if $y(2 x+1)=0$

but imaginary part of $z$, i.e. $y$ is non-zero.

$$
\Rightarrow \quad 2 x+1=0 \text { or } x=-1 / 2
$$

From Eq. (i), $\frac{1}{4}-y^{2}-\frac{1}{2}+1-a=0$

$$
\Rightarrow \quad a=-y^{2}+\frac{3}{4} \Rightarrow a<\frac{3}{4}
$$

Method II Here, $z^{2}+z+(1-a)=0$

$$
\begin{array}{ll}
\therefore & z=\frac{-1 \pm \sqrt{1-4(1-a)}}{2 \times 1} \\
\Rightarrow & z=\frac{-1 \pm \sqrt{4 a-3}}{2}
\end{array}
$$

For $z$ do not have real roots, $4 a-3<0 \Rightarrow a<\frac{3}{4}$

question: Let $z=x+i y$ be a complex number where, $x$ and $y$ are integers. Then, the area of the rectangle whose vertices are the root of the equation $z \bar{z}^{3}+\bar{z} z^{3}=350$, is\\
solution:
Since,

$$
z \bar{z}\left(z^{2}+\bar{z}^{2}\right)=350
$$

$\Rightarrow \quad 2\left(x^{2}+y^{2}\right)\left(x^{2}-y^{2}\right)=350$

$\Rightarrow \quad\left(x^{2}+y^{2}\right)\left(x^{2}-y^{2}\right)=175$

Since, $x, y \in I$, the only possible case which gives integral solution, is


\begin{align*}
& x^{2}+y^{2}=25  \tag{i}\\
& x^{2}-y^{2}=7 \tag{ii}
\end{align*}


From Eqs. (i) and (ii),

$$
x^{2}=16, y^{2}=9 \Rightarrow x= \pm 4, y= \pm 3
$$

$\therefore$ Area of rectangle $=8 \times 6=48$

question: If $w=\alpha+i \beta$, where $\beta \neq 0$ and $z \neq 1$, satisfies the condition that $\frac{w-\bar{w} z}{1-z}$ is purely real, then the set of values of $z$ is\\
solution:
Let $z_{1}=\frac{w-\bar{w} z}{1-z}$ be purely real $\Rightarrow \quad z_{1}=\bar{z}_{1}$

$\therefore \quad \frac{w-\bar{w} z}{1-z}=\frac{\bar{w}-w \bar{z}}{1-\bar{z}}$

$\Rightarrow \quad w-w \bar{z}-\bar{w} z+\bar{w} z \cdot \bar{z}=\bar{w}-z \bar{w}-w \bar{z}+w z \cdot \bar{z}$

$\Rightarrow \quad(w-\bar{w})+(\bar{w}-w)|z|^{2}=0$

$\Rightarrow \quad(w-\bar{w})\left(1-|z|^{2}\right)=0$

$\Rightarrow \quad|z|^{2}=1 \quad$ as $w-\bar{w} \neq 0$, since $\beta \neq 0$ ]

$\Rightarrow \quad|z|=1$ and $z \neq 1$

question: For positive integers $n_{1}, n_{2}$ the value of expression $(1+i)^{n_{1}}+\left(1+i^{3}\right)^{n_{1}}+\left(1+i^{5}\right)^{n_{2}}+\left(1+i^{7}\right)^{n_{2}}$, here $i=\sqrt{-1}$ is a real number, if and only if\\
The complex numbers $\sin x+i \cos 2 x$ and $\cos x-i \sin 2 x$ are conjugate to each other, for\\
solution:
Since, $(\overline{\sin x+i \cos 2 x})=\cos x-i \sin 2 x$

$\Rightarrow \quad \sin x-i \cos 2 x=\cos x-i \sin 2 x$

$\Rightarrow \quad \sin x=\cos x$ and $\cos 2 x=\sin 2 x$

$\Rightarrow \quad \tan x=1$ and $\tan 2 x=1$

$\Rightarrow x=\pi / 4$ and $x=\pi / 8$ which is not possible at same time.

Hence, no solution exists.

$$
=i\left(\omega-\omega^{2}\right)=i(i \sqrt{3})=-\sqrt{3}

question: If $z$ is any complex number satisfying $|z-3-2 i| \leq 2$, then the maximum value of $|2 z-6+5 i|$ is
solution:
Given, $|z-3-2 i| \leq 2$

To find minimum of $|2 z-6+5 i|$

or $2\left|z-3+\frac{5}{2} i\right|$, using triangle inequality

i.e. ||$z_{1}|-| z_{2}|| \leq\left|z_{1}+z_{2}\right|$

$$
\begin{array}{rlrl}
\therefore & & \left|z-3+\frac{5}{2} i\right| & =\left|z-3-2 i+2 i+\frac{5}{2} i\right| \\
& =\left|(z-3-2 i)+\frac{9}{2} i\right| \\
& & \geq|| z-3-2 i\left|-\frac{9}{2}\right| \geq\left|2-\frac{9}{2}\right| \geq \frac{5}{2} \\
\Rightarrow & & \left|z-3+\frac{5}{2} i\right| \geq \frac{5}{2} \text { or }|2 z-6+5 i| \geq 5
\end{array}
$$

question: Let $z_{1}$ and $z_{2}$ be any two non-zero complex numbers such that $3\left|z_{1}\right|=4\left|z_{2}\right|$. If $z=\frac{3 z_{1}}{2 z_{2}}+\frac{2 z_{2}}{3 z_{1}}$, then\\
If $z$ is a complex number of unit modulus and argument $\theta$, then arg $\frac{1+z}{1+\bar{z}}$ is equal to\\
solution:
Given, $|z|=1, \arg z=\theta \therefore z=e^{i \theta}$

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \therefore \quad \bar{z}=e^{-i \theta} \Rightarrow \bar{z}=\frac{1}{z} \\
& \therefore \quad \arg \quad \frac{1+z}{1+\bar{z}}=\arg \frac{1+z}{1+\frac{1}{z}}=\arg (z)=\theta
\end{aligned}
$$

question: If $\arg (z)<0$, then $\arg (-z)-\arg (z)$ equals \\
solution:
Since, $\arg (z)<0 \Rightarrow \quad \arg (z)=-\theta$

\begin{center}
\includegraphics[max width=\textwidth]{2024_07_07_1585177dc772a224010eg-18}
\end{center}

$\Rightarrow \quad z=r \cos (-\theta)+i \sin (-\theta)$

$$
=r(\cos \theta-i \sin \theta)
$$

and $\quad-z=-r[\cos \theta-i \sin \theta]$

$$
=r[\cos (\pi-\theta)+i \sin (\pi-\theta)]
$$

$$
\therefore \quad \arg (-z)=\pi-\theta
$$

Thus, $\arg (-z)-\arg (z)$

$$
=\pi-\theta-(-\theta)=\pi
$$

\section*{Alternate Solution}
Reason $\arg (-z)-\arg z=\arg \frac{-z}{z}=\arg (-1)=\pi$ and also $\arg z-\arg (-z)=\arg \frac{z}{-z}=\arg (-1)=\pi$

question:

\\
solution:

$$
|z+i w|=|z-i \bar{w}|=2
$$

$\Rightarrow$

$\Rightarrow$

$\therefore z$ lies on the perpendicular bisector of the line joining $-i w$ and $-i \bar{w}$. Since, $-i \bar{w}$ is the mirror image of $-i w$ in the $X$-axis, the locus of $z$ is the $X$-axis.

Now, $\quad|z| \leq 1 \Rightarrow x^{2}+0^{2} \leq 1 \Rightarrow-1 \leq x \leq 1$.

Now, given relation

question: Let $z$ and $w$ be two non-zero complex numbers such that $|z|=|w|$ and $\arg (z)+\arg (w)=\pi$, then $z$ equals\\

If $z_{1}$ and $z_{2}$ are two non-zero complex numbers such that $\left|z_{1}+z_{2}\right|=\left|z_{1}\right|+\left|z_{2}\right|$, then $\arg \left(z_{1}\right)-\arg \left(z_{2}\right)$ is equal to\\
solution:
Given, $\left|z_{1}+z_{2}\right|=\left|z_{1}\right|+\left|z_{2}\right|$

On squaring both sides, we get

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \left|z_{1}\right|^{2}+\left|z_{2}\right|^{2}+2\left|z_{1}\right|\left|z_{2}\right| \cos \left(\arg z_{1}-\arg z_{2}\right) \\
& =\left|z_{1}\right|^{2}+\left|z_{2}\right|^{2}+2\left|z_{1}\right|\left|z_{2}\right| \\
& \Rightarrow \quad 2\left|z_{1}\right|\left|z_{2}\right| \cos \left(\arg z_{1}-\arg z_{2}\right)=2\left|z_{1}\right|\left|z_{2}\right| \\
& \Rightarrow \quad \cos \left(\arg z_{1}-\arg z_{2}\right)=1 \\
& \Rightarrow \quad \arg \left(z_{1}\right)-\arg \left(z_{2}\right)=0
\end{aligned}
$$

question: Let $z=\frac{\sqrt{3}}{2}+\frac{i}{2}^{5}+\frac{\sqrt{3}}{2}-\frac{i}{2}^{5}$. If $R(z)$ and $I(z)$ respectively denote the real and imaginary parts of $z$, then\\
solution:
Given, $z=\frac{\sqrt{3}}{2}+\frac{i}{2}^{5}+\frac{\sqrt{3}}{2}-\frac{i}{2}^{5}$

$\because$ Euler's form of

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \frac{\sqrt{3}}{2}+\frac{i}{2}=\cos \frac{\pi}{6}+i \sin \frac{\pi}{6}=e^{i(\pi / 6)} \\
& \text { and } \frac{\sqrt{3}}{2}-\frac{i}{2}=\cos \frac{-\pi}{6}+i \sin -\frac{\pi}{6}=e^{-i \pi / 6} \\
& \text { So, } \quad z=\left(e^{i \pi / 6}\right)^{5}+\left(e^{-i \pi / 6}\right)^{5}=e^{i \frac{5 \pi}{6}}+e^{-i \frac{5 \pi}{6}} \\
& =\cos \frac{5 \pi}{6}+i \sin \frac{5 \pi}{6}+\cos \frac{5 \pi}{6}-i \sin \frac{5 \pi}{6} \\
& =2 \cos \frac{5 \pi}{6} \quad\left[\because e^{i \theta}=\cos \theta+i \sin \theta\right] \\
& \therefore \quad I(z)=0 \text { and } R(z)=-2 \cos \frac{\pi}{6}=-\sqrt{3}<0 \\
& \because \cos \frac{5 \pi}{6}=\cos \pi-\frac{\pi}{6}=-\cos \frac{\pi}{6}
\end{aligned}
$$

question: A particle $P$ starts from the point $z_{0}=1+2 i$, where $i=\sqrt{-1}$. From $z_{1}$ the particle moves $\sqrt{2}$ units in the direction of the vector $\hat{\mathbf{i}}+\hat{\mathbf{j}}$ and then it moves through an angle $\frac{\pi}{2}$ in anti-clockwise direction on a circle with centre at origin, to reach a point $z_{2}$. The point $z_{2}$ is given by\\

From there, he walks a distance of 4 units towards the North-West $\left(\mathrm{N} 45^{\circ} \mathrm{W}\right)$ direction to reach a point $P$. Then, the position of $P$ in the Argand plane is\\
If $0<\alpha<\frac{\pi}{2}$ is a fixed angle. If $P=(\cos \theta, \sin \theta)$ and $Q=\{\cos (\alpha \stackrel{2}{-}), \sin (\alpha-\theta)\}$, then $Q$ is obtained from $P$ by
options: a) clockwise rotation around origin through an angle $\alpha$
b) anti-clockwise rotation around origin through an angle $\alpha$
c) reflection in the line through origin with slope $\tan \alpha$
d) reflection in the line through origin with slope $\tan \frac{\alpha}{2}$
solution:
In the Argand plane, $P$ is represented by $e^{i 0}$ and $Q$ is represented by $e^{i(\alpha-\theta)}$

Now, rotation about a line with angle $\alpha$ is given by $e^{\theta} \rightarrow e^{(\alpha-\theta)}$. Therefore, $Q$ is obtained from $P$ by reflection in the line making an angle $\alpha$ /2.

If $z$ and $w$ are two complex numbers such that $|z w|=1$ $\operatorname{and} \arg (z)-\arg (w)=\frac{\pi}{2}$, then\\
solution:
It is given that, there are two complex numbers $z$ and $w$, such that $|z w|=1$ and $\arg (z)-\arg (w)=\pi / 2$

$$
\begin{array}{ll}
\therefore \quad|z||w|=1 & {\left[\because\left|z_{1} z_{2}\right|=\left|z_{1}\right|\left|z_{2}\right|\right]} \\
\operatorname{and} \arg (z)=\frac{\pi}{2}+\arg (w) &
\end{array}
$$

Let $|z|=r$, then $|w|=\frac{1}{r}$

and $\operatorname{let} \arg (w)=\theta$, then $\arg (z)=\frac{\pi}{2}+\theta$

So, we can assume

$$
z=r e^{i(\pi / 2+\theta)}
$$

$[\because$ if $z=x+i y$ is a complex number, then it can be written as $z=r e^{i \theta}$ where, $r=|z|$ and $\left.\theta=\arg (z)\right]$


\begin{equation*}
\text { and } \quad w=\frac{1}{r} e^{i \theta} \tag{iv}
\end{equation*}


Now, $\quad \bar{z} \cdot w=r e^{-i(\pi / 2+\theta)} \cdot \frac{1}{r} e^{i \theta}$

$=e^{i(-\pi / 2-\theta+\theta)}=e^{-i(\pi / 2)}=-i \quad\left[\because e^{-i \theta}=\cos \theta-i \sin \theta\right]$

and $\quad z \bar{w}=r e^{i(\pi / 2+\theta)} \cdot \frac{1}{r} e^{-i \theta}$

$$
=e^{i(\pi / 2+\theta-\theta)}=e^{i(\pi / 2)}=i
$$

question: If $z=\frac{\sqrt{3}}{2}+\frac{i}{2}(i=\sqrt{-1})$, then $\left(1+i z+z^{5}+i z^{8}\right)^{9}$ is equal to \\

so, $\left(1+i z+z^{5}+i z^{8}\right)^{9}$

$=1+i e^{i \frac{\pi}{6}}+e^{i \frac{5 \pi}{6}}+i e^{i \frac{8 \pi}{6}}$

$$
=1+e^{i \frac{\pi}{2}} \cdot e^{i \frac{\pi}{6}}+e^{i \frac{5 \pi}{6}}+e^{i \frac{\pi}{2}} \cdot e^{i \frac{4 \pi}{3}} \quad \because i=e^{i \frac{\pi}{2}}
$$

$=1+e^{i \frac{2 \pi}{3}}+e^{i \frac{5 \pi}{6}}+e^{i \frac{11 \pi}{6}}$

$=1+\cos \frac{2 \pi}{3}+i \sin \frac{2 \pi}{3}+\cos \frac{5 \pi}{6}+i \sin \frac{5 \pi}{6}$

$$
+\cos \frac{11 \pi}{6}+i \sin \frac{11 \pi}{6}^{9}
$$

$=1-\frac{1}{2}+\frac{i \sqrt{3}}{2}-\frac{\sqrt{3}}{2}+\frac{1}{2} i+\frac{\sqrt{3}}{2}-\frac{i}{2}^{9}$

$=\frac{1}{2}+\frac{\sqrt{3} i}{2}^{9}=\cos \frac{\pi}{3}+i \sin \frac{\pi}{3}^{9}$

$=\cos 3 \pi+i \sin 3 \pi \quad[\because$ for any natural number ' $n$ ' $\left.(\cos \theta+i \sin \theta)^{n}=\cos (n \theta)+i \sin (n \theta)\right]$

$=-1$\\

question: Let $z_{0}$ be a root of the quadratic equation, $x^{2}+x+1=0$, If $z=3+6 i z_{0}^{81}-3 i z_{0}^{93}$, then $\arg z$ is equal to\\
solution:
Given, $x^{2}+x+1=0$

$$

$$

$$
\omega^{2}=\frac{-1-\sqrt{3} i}{2}
$$

are the cube roots of unity and $\omega, \omega^{2} \neq 1$ )

Now consider $z=3+6 i z_{0}^{81}-3 i z_{0}^{93}$

$$
\begin{aligned}
& =3+6 i-3 i \quad\left(\because \omega^{3 n}=\left(\omega^{2}\right)^{3 n}=1\right) \\
& =3+3 i=3(1+i)
\end{aligned}
$$

If ' $\theta$ ' is the argument of $z$, then

$$

\tan \theta & =\frac{\operatorname{Im}(z)}{\operatorname{Re}(z)} \quad[\because z \text { is in the first quadrant }] \\

question: Let $z=\cos \theta+i \sin \theta$. Then, the value of $\sum_{m=1}^{15} \operatorname{Im}\left(z^{2 m-1}\right)$ at $\theta=2^{\circ}$ is
The minimum value of $\left|a+b \omega+c \omega^{2}\right|$, where $a, b$ and c are all not equal integers and $\omega(\neq 1)$ is a cube root of unity, is\\
solution:
Let $z=\mid a+b \omega+c \omega^{2}$

$\Rightarrow z^{2}=\left|a+b \omega+c \omega^{2}\right|^{2}=\left(a^{2}+b^{2}+c^{2}-a b-b c-c a\right)$

or $z^{2}=\frac{1}{2}\left\{(a-b)^{2}+(b-c)^{2}+(c-a)^{2}\right\}$

Since, $a, b, c$ are all integers but not all simultaneously equal.

$\Rightarrow \quad$ If $a=b$ then $a \neq c$ and $b \neq c$

Because difference of integers = integer

$\Rightarrow(b-c)^{2} \geq 1$ \{as minimum difference of two consecutive integers is $( \pm 1)\}$ also $(c-a)^{2} \geq 1$

and we have taken $a=b \Rightarrow(a-b)^{2}=0$

From Eq. (i), $\quad z^{2} \geq \frac{1}{2}(0+1+1)$

$\Rightarrow \quad z^{2} \geq 1$

Hence, minimum value of $|z|$ is 1 .

question: If $\omega(\neq 1)$ be a cube root of unity and $\left(1+\omega^{2}\right)^{n}=\left(1+\omega^{4}\right)^{n}$, then the least positive value of $n$ is\\
solution:
Given, $\left(1+\omega^{2}\right)^{n}=\left(1+\omega^{4}\right)^{n}$

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \Rightarrow \quad(-\omega)^{n}=\left(-\omega^{2}\right)^{n} \quad\left[\because \omega^{3}=1 \text { and } 1+\omega+\omega^{2}=0\right] \\
& \Rightarrow \quad \omega^{n}=1 \\
& \Rightarrow \quad n=3 \text { is the least positive value of } n
\end{aligned}
$$

question: Let $\omega=-\frac{1}{2}+i \frac{\sqrt{3}}{2}$, then value of the determinant $\left|\begin{array}{ccc}1 & 1 & 1 \\ 1 & -1-\omega^{2} & \omega^{2} \\ 1 & \omega^{2} & \omega\end{array}\right|$ is\\
solution:
Let $\Delta=\left|\begin{array}{ccc}1 & 1 & 1 \\ 1 & -1-\omega^{2} & \omega^{2} \\ 1 & \omega^{2} & \omega\end{array}\right|$

Applying $R_{2} \rightarrow R_{2}-R_{1} ; R_{3} \rightarrow R_{3}-R_{1}$

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \begin{array}{lll}
1 & 1 & 1
\end{array} \\
& =0 \quad-2-\omega^{2} \quad \omega^{2}-1 \\
& 0 \quad \omega^{2}-1 \quad \omega-1 \\
& =\left(-2-\omega^{2}\right)(\omega-1)-\left(\omega^{2}-1\right)^{2} \\
& =-2 \omega+2-\omega^{3}+\omega^{2}-\left(\omega^{4}-2 \omega^{2}+1\right) \\
& =3 \omega^{2}-3 \omega=3 \omega(\omega-1) \quad\left[\because \omega^{4}=\omega\right]
\end{aligned}
$$

question: Let $z_{1}$ and $z_{2}$ be $n$th roots of unity which subtend a right angled at the origin, then $n$ must be of the form (where, $k$ is an integer)\\
If $i=\sqrt{-1}$, then $4+5\left(-\frac{1}{2}+\frac{i \sqrt{3}}{2}\right)^{334}+3\left(-\frac{1}{2}+\frac{i \sqrt{3}}{2}\right)^{365}$ is equal to\\
solution:
We know that,

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \omega=-\frac{1}{2}+\frac{\sqrt{3}}{2} i \\
& \therefore 4+5-\frac{1}{2}+\frac{i \sqrt{3}}{2}^{334}+3-\frac{1}{2}+\frac{i \sqrt{3}}{2}^{365} \\
& =4+5 \omega^{334}+3 \omega^{36} \\
& =4+5 \cdot\left(\omega^{3}\right)^{111} \cdot \omega+3 \cdot\left(\omega^{3}\right)^{121} \cdot \omega^{2} \\
& =4+5 \omega+3 \omega^{2} \quad\left[\because \omega^{3}=1\right] \\
& =1+3+2 \omega+3 \omega+3 \omega^{2} \\
& =1+2 \omega+3\left(1+\omega+\omega^{2}\right)=1+2 \omega+3 \times 0 \\
& =1+(-1+\sqrt{3} i)=\sqrt{3} i \\
& {\left[\because 1+\omega+\omega^{2}=0\right]}
\end{aligned}
$$

$$

question: If $\omega(\neq 1)$ is a cube root of unity and $(1+\omega)^{7}=A+B \omega$, then $A$ and $B$ are respectively\\
solution:
$(1+\omega)^{7}=(1+\omega)(1+\omega)^{6}$

\Rightarrow & A+B \omega=1+\omega \\
\Rightarrow & A=1, B=1
\end{array}
$$

question: The value of $\sum_{k=1}^{6} \sin \frac{2 \pi k}{7}-i \cos \frac{2 \pi k}{7}$ is\\
solution:
$\sum_{k=1}^{6} \sin \frac{2 k \pi}{7}-i \cos \frac{2 k \pi}{7}$

$$
\begin{aligned}
& =\sum_{k=1}^{6}-i \cos \frac{2 k \pi}{7}+i \sin \frac{2 k \pi}{7} \\
& =-i \sum_{k=1}^{6} e^{\frac{i 2 k \pi}{7}}=-i\left\{e^{i 2 \pi / 7}+e^{i 4 \pi / 7}+e^{i 6 \pi / 7}\right. \\
& \left.+e^{i 8 \pi / 7}+e^{i 10 \pi / 7}+e^{i 12 \pi / 7}\right\} \\
& =-i e^{i 2 \pi / 7} \frac{\left(1-e^{i 12 \pi / 7}\right)}{1-e^{i 2 \pi / 7}} \\
& =-i \frac{e^{i 2 \pi / 7}-e^{i 14 \pi / 7}}{1-e^{i 2 \pi / 7}} \quad\left[\because e^{i 14 \pi / 7}=1\right] \\
& =-i \frac{e^{i 2 \pi / 7}-1}{1-e^{i 2 \pi / 7}}=i
\end{aligned}
$$

The quadratic expression $a x^{2}+b x+c, x \in R$ is always positive,

if $a>0$ and $D<0$.

So, the quadratic expression

$(1+2 m) x^{2}-2(1+3 m) x+4(1+m), x \in R$ will be always positive, if $1+2 m>0$

and $D=4(1+3 m)^{2}-4(2 m+1) 4(1+m)<0$

question: If $\lambda$ be the ratio of the roots of the quadratic equation in $x, 3 m^{2} x^{2}+m(m-4) x+2=0$, then the least value of $m$ for which $\lambda+\frac{1}{\lambda}=1$, is\\
solution:
Let the given quadratic equation in $x$,

$3 m^{2} x^{2}+m(m-4) x+2=0, m \neq 0$ have roots $\alpha$ and $\beta$, then

$$
\alpha+\beta=-\frac{m(m-4)}{3 m^{2}} \text { and } \alpha \beta=\frac{2}{3 m^{2}}
$$

Also, let $\quad \frac{\alpha}{\beta}=\lambda$

Then, $\quad \lambda+\frac{1}{\lambda}=1 \Rightarrow \frac{\alpha}{\beta}+\frac{\beta}{\alpha}=1$

(given)

$$
\Rightarrow \quad \alpha^{2}+\beta^{2}=\alpha \beta
$$

$\Rightarrow \quad(\alpha+\beta)^{2}=3 \alpha \beta$

$\Rightarrow \quad \frac{m^{2}(m-4)^{2}}{9 m^{4}}=3 \frac{2}{3 m^{2}}$

$$
\Rightarrow \quad(m-4)^{2}=18
$$

$[\because m \neq 0]$

$$
\Rightarrow \quad m-4= \pm 3 \sqrt{2}
$$

$$
\Rightarrow \quad m=4 \pm 3 \sqrt{2}
$$

The least value of $m=4-3 \sqrt{2}$

question: If one real root of the quadratic equation $81 x^{2}+k x+256=0$ is cube of the other root, then a value of $k$ is\\
solution:
Given quadratic equation is

$$

$$

Let one root be $\alpha$, then other is $\alpha^{3}$.

Now, $\alpha+\alpha^{3}=-\frac{k}{81}$ and $\alpha \cdot \alpha^{3}=\frac{256}{81}$

$$
\left[\because \text { for } a x^{2}+b x+c=0, \text { sum of roots }=-\frac{b}{a}\right.
$$

$$
\text { and product of roots } \left.=\frac{c}{a}\right]
$$

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \Rightarrow \quad \alpha^{4}=\frac{4}{3}^{4} \Rightarrow \alpha= \pm \frac{4}{3} \\
& \therefore \quad k=-81\left(\alpha+\alpha^{3}\right) \\
& =-81 \alpha\left(1+\alpha^{2}\right) \\
& =-81 \quad \pm \frac{4}{3} \quad 1+\frac{16}{9}= \pm 300
\end{aligned}
$$

question: If $5,5 r, 5 r^{2}$ are the lengths of the sides of a triangle, then $r$ cannot be equal to\\
The value of $\lambda$ such that sum of the squares of the roots of the quadratic equation, $x^{2}+(3-\lambda) x+2=\lambda$ has the least value is\\
solution:
Given quadratic equation is

\[
\begin{array}{r}
x^{2}+(3-\lambda) x+2=\lambda \\
x^{2}+(3-\lambda) x+(2-\lambda)=0 \tag{i}
\end{array}
\]

Let Eq. (i) has roots $\alpha$ and $\beta$, then $\alpha+\beta=\lambda-3$ and $\alpha \beta=2-\lambda$

$$
\left[\because \text { For } a x^{2}+b x+c=0, \text { sum of roots }=-\frac{b}{a}\right.
$$

$$
\text { and product of roots } \left.=\frac{c}{a}\right]
$$

$$
\text { Now, } \begin{aligned}
\alpha^{2}+\beta^{2} & =(\alpha+\beta)^{2}-2 \alpha \beta \\
& =(\lambda-3)^{2}-2(2-\lambda) \\
& =\lambda^{2}-6 \lambda+9-4+2 \lambda \\
& =\lambda^{2}-4 \lambda+5=\left(\lambda^{2}-4 \lambda+4\right)+1 \\
& =(\lambda-2)^{2}+1
\end{aligned}
$$

Clearly, $a^{2}+\beta^{2}$ will be least when $\lambda=2$.

question: The number of all possible positive integral values of $\alpha$ for which the roots of the quadratic equation, $6 x^{2}-11 x+\alpha=0$ are rational numbers is\\
solution:
For the roots of quadratic equation $a x^{2}+b x+c=0$ to be rational $D=\left(b^{2}-4 a c\right)$ should be perfect square.

In the equation $6 x^{2}-11 x+\alpha=0$

$$
a=6, b=-11 \text { and } c=\alpha
$$

$\therefore$ For roots to be rational

$D=(-11)^{2}-4(6)(\alpha)$ should be a perfect square.

$\Rightarrow D(\alpha)=121-24 \alpha$ should be a perfect square

Now,

$D(1)=121-24=97$ is not a perfect square.

$D(2)=121-24 \times 2=73$ is not a perfect square.

$D(3)=121-24 \times 3=49$ is a perfect square.

$D(4)=121-24 \times 4=25$ is a perfect square.

$D(5)=121-24 \times 5=1$ is a perfect square.

and for $\alpha \geq 6, D(\alpha)<0$, hence imaginary roots.

$\therefore$ For 3 values of $\alpha(\alpha=3,4,5)$, the roots are rational.

question: Let $\alpha$ and $\beta$ be two roots of the equation $x^{2}+2 x+2=0$, then $\alpha^{15}+\beta^{15}$ is equal to\\
solution:
We have, $x^{2}+2 x+2=0$

$\Rightarrow x=\frac{-2 \pm \sqrt{4-8}}{2} \quad\left[\because\right.$ roots of $a x^{2}+b x+c=0$ are

$$
\text { given by } \left.x=\frac{-b \pm \sqrt{b^{2}-4 a c}}{2 a}\right]
$$

$\Rightarrow \quad x=-1 \pm i$

Let $\alpha=-1+i$ and $\beta=-1-i$.

Then, $\alpha^{15}+\beta^{15}=(-1+i)^{15}+(-1-i)^{15}$

$$
\begin{aligned}
& =-\left[(1-i)^{15}+(1+i)^{15}\right] \\
& =-\sqrt{2} \frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}-\frac{i}{\sqrt{2}} \quad+\sqrt{2} \frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}+\frac{i}{\sqrt{2}} \\
& =-\quad \sqrt{2} \cos \frac{\pi}{4}-i \sin \frac{\pi}{4} \\
& \quad+\sqrt{2} \cos \frac{\pi}{4}+i \sin \frac{\pi}{4} \\
& =-(\sqrt{2})^{15} \cos \frac{15 \pi}{4}-i \sin \frac{15 \pi}{4}+\cos \frac{15 \pi}{4}+i \sin \frac{15 \pi}{4}
\end{aligned}
$$

[using De' Moivre's theorem $\left.(\cos \theta \pm i \sin \theta)^{n}=\cos n \theta \pm i \sin n \theta, n \in Z\right]$

$=-(\sqrt{2})^{15} \quad 2 \cos \frac{15 \pi}{4}=-(\sqrt{2})^{15} 2 \times \frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}$

$$
\because \cos \frac{15 \pi}{4}=\cos 4 \pi-\frac{\pi}{4}=\cos \frac{\pi}{4}=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}
$$

$=-(\sqrt{2})^{16}=-2^{8}=-256$.

\section*{Alternate Method}
$$
\begin{aligned}
\alpha^{15}+\beta^{15} & =(-1+i)^{15}+(-1-i)^{15} \\
& =-\left[(1-i)^{15}+(1+i)^{15}\right] \\
& =-\frac{(1-i)^{16}}{1-i}+\frac{(1+i)^{16}}{1+i} \\
& =-\frac{\left[(1-i)^{2}\right]^{8}}{1-i}+\frac{\left[(1+i)^{2}\right]^{8}}{1+i}
\end{aligned}
$$

$$
\begin{aligned}
& =-\frac{\left[1+i^{2}-2 i\right]^{8}}{1-i}+\frac{\left[1+i^{2}+2 i\right]^{8}}{1+i} \\
& =-\frac{(-2 i)^{8}}{1-i}+\frac{(2 i)^{8}}{1+i} \\
& =-2^{8} \frac{1}{1-i}+\frac{1}{1+i} \quad \quad\left[\because i^{4 n}=1, n \in Z\right] \\
& =-256 \frac{2}{1-(i)^{2}}=-256 \frac{2}{2}=-256
\end{aligned}
$$

question: Let $S=\{x \in \mathbf{R}: x \geq 0$ and $2|\sqrt{x}-3|+\sqrt{x}(\sqrt{x}-6)+6=0$. Then, $S$
solution:
We have, $2|\sqrt{x}-3|+\sqrt{x}(\sqrt{x}-6)+6=0$

Let $\sqrt{x}-3=y$

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \Rightarrow \quad \sqrt{x}=y+3 \\
& \therefore \quad 2|y|+(y+3)(y-3)+6=0 \\
& \Rightarrow \quad 2|y|+y^{2}-3=0 \\
& \Rightarrow \quad|y|^{2}+2|y|-3=0 \\
& \Rightarrow \quad(|y|+3)(|y|-1)=0 \\
& \Rightarrow \quad|y| \neq-3 \Rightarrow|y|=1 \\
& \begin{aligned}
\Rightarrow & y & = \pm 1 & \Rightarrow \sqrt{x}-3= \pm 1 \\
\Rightarrow & \sqrt{x} & =4,2 & \Rightarrow x=16,4
\end{aligned}
\end{aligned}
$$

question: If $\alpha, \beta \in C$ are the distinct roots of the equation $x^{2}-x+1=0$, then $\alpha^{101}+\beta^{107}$ is equal to\\
solution:
We have, $\alpha, \beta$ are the roots of $x^{2}-x+1=0$

$\because$ Roots of $x^{2}-x+1=0$ are $-\omega,-\omega^{2}$

$\therefore \quad$ Let $\alpha=-\omega$ and $\beta=-\omega^{2}$

$$
\begin{array}{rlrl}
\Rightarrow \alpha^{101}+\beta^{107} & =(-\omega)^{101}+\left(-\omega^{2}\right)^{107}=-\left(\omega^{101}+\omega^{214}\right) \\
& =-\left(\omega^{2}+\omega\right) & {\left[\because \omega^{3}=1\right]} \\
& =-(-1) & {\left[\because 1+\omega+\omega^{2}=0\right]} \\
& =1
\end{array}
$$

question: For a positive integer $n$, if the quadratic equation, $x(x+1)+(x+1)(x+2)+\ldots \quad+(x+n-1)(x+n)=10 n$ has two consecutive integral solutions, then $n$ is equal to\\
solution:
Given quadratic equation is

$x(x+1)+(x+1)(x+2)+\ldots+(x+\overline{n-1})(x+n)=10 n$ $\Rightarrow\left(x^{2}+x^{2}+\ldots+x^{2}\right)+[(1+3+5+\ldots+(2 n-1)] x$

$$
+[(1 \cdot 2+2 \cdot 3+\ldots+(n-1) n]=10 n
$$

$$
\Rightarrow \quad n x^{2}+n^{2} x+\frac{n\left(n^{2}-1\right)}{3}-10 n=0
$$

$$
\Rightarrow \quad x^{2}+n x+\frac{n^{2}-1}{3}-10=0
$$

$=$

Let $\alpha$ and $\beta$ be the roots.

Since, $\alpha$ and $\beta$ are consecutive.

$$
\therefore \quad|\alpha-\beta|=1 \quad \Rightarrow \quad(\alpha-\beta)^{2}=1
$$

Again, $(\alpha-\beta)^{2}=(\alpha+\beta)^{2}-4 \alpha \beta$

$$
\begin{array}{ll}
\Rightarrow & 1=\frac{-3 n}{3} \\
\Rightarrow & -4 \frac{n^{2}-31}{3} \\
\Rightarrow & 1=n^{2}-\frac{4}{3}\left(n^{2}-31\right) \Rightarrow 3=3 n^{2}-4 n^{2}+124 \\
\therefore & n^{2}=121 \Rightarrow n= \pm 11 \\
\Rightarrow & n=11 \quad[\because n>0]
\end{array}
$$

question: The sum of all real values of $x$ satisfying the equation $\left(x^{2}-5 x+5\right)^{x^{2}+4 x-60}=1$ is\\
solution:
Given, $\left(x^{2}-5 x+5\right)^{x^{2}}+4 x-60=1$

Clearly, this is possible when\\
I. $x^{2}+4 x-60=0$ and $x^{2}-5 x+5 \neq 0$

Or

II. $x^{2}-5 x+5=1$

III. $x^{2}-5 x+5=-1$ and $x^{2}+4 x-60=$ Even integer.

$$
\begin{array}{lrl}
\text { Case I } & \text { When } x^{2}+4 x-60=0 \\
\Rightarrow & x^{2}+10 x-6 x-60=0 \\
\Rightarrow & x(x+10)-6(x+10)=0 \\
\Rightarrow & (x+10)(x-6)=0 \\
\Rightarrow & x=-10 \text { or } x=6
\end{array}
$$

Note that, for these two values of $x, x^{2}-5 x+5 \neq 0$

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \text { Case II When } \quad x^{2}-5 x+5=1 \\
& \Rightarrow \quad x^{2}-5 x+4=0 \\
& \Rightarrow \quad x^{2}-4 x-x+4=0 \\
& \Rightarrow \quad x(x-4)-1(x-4)=0 \\
& \Rightarrow \quad(x-4)(x-1)=0 \Rightarrow x=4 \text { or } x=1 \\
& \text { Case III When } \quad x^{2}-5 x+5=-1 \\
& \Rightarrow \quad x^{2}-5 x+6=0 \\
& \Rightarrow \quad x^{2}-2 x-3 x+6=0 \\
& \Rightarrow \quad x(x-2)-3(x-2)=0 \\
& \Rightarrow \quad(x-2)(x-3)=0 \\
& \Rightarrow \quad x=2 \text { or } x=3
\end{aligned}
$$

Now, when $x=2, x^{2}+4 x-60=4+8-60=-48$, which is an even integer.

When $x=3, x^{2}+4 x-60=9+12-60=-39$, which is not an even integer.

Thus, in this case, we get $x=2$.

Hence, the sum of all real values of

$$
x=-10+6+4+1+2=3
$$

question: Let $-\frac{\pi}{6}<\theta<-\frac{\pi}{12}$. Suppose $\alpha_{1}$ and $\beta_{1}$ are the roots of the equation $x^{2}-2 x \sec \theta+1=0$, and $\alpha_{2}$ and $\beta_{2}$ are the roots of the equation $x^{2}+2 x \tan \theta-1=0$. If $\alpha_{1}>\beta_{1}$ and $\alpha_{2}>\beta_{2}$, then $\alpha_{1}+\beta_{2}$ equals\\
solution:
Here, $x^{2}-2 x \sec \theta+1=0$ has roots $\alpha_{1}$ and $\beta_{1}$.

$$
\begin{aligned}
\therefore \quad \alpha_{1}, \beta_{1} & =\frac{2 \sec \theta \pm \sqrt{4 \sec ^{2} \theta-4}}{2 \times 1} \\
& =\frac{2 \sec \theta \pm 2|\tan \theta|}{2}
\end{aligned}
$$

Since, $\quad \theta \in-\frac{\pi}{6},-\frac{\pi}{12}$.

i.e. $\quad \theta \in \mathrm{IV}$ quadrant $=\frac{2 \sec \theta \mp 2 \tan \theta}{2}$

$\therefore \quad \alpha_{1}=\sec \theta-\tan \theta \operatorname{and} \beta_{1}=\sec \theta+\tan \theta\left[\operatorname{as} \alpha_{1}>\beta_{1}\right]$ and $x^{2}+2 x \tan \theta-1=0$ has roots $\alpha_{2}$ and $\beta_{2}$.

i.e.

$$
\alpha_{2}, \beta_{2}=\frac{-2 \tan \theta \pm \sqrt{4 \tan ^{2} \theta+4}}{2}
$$

$\therefore \quad \alpha_{2}=-\tan \theta+\sec \theta$

and $\quad \beta_{2}=-\tan \theta-\sec \theta$

$\left[\operatorname{as} \alpha_{2}>\beta_{2}\right]$

Thus, $\quad \alpha_{1}+\beta_{2}=-2 \tan \theta$

question: Let $\alpha$ and $\beta$ be the roots of equation $x^{2}-6 x-2=0$. If $a_{n}=\alpha^{n}-\beta^{n}$, for $n \geq 1$, then the value of $\frac{a_{10}-2 a_{8}}{2 a_{9}}$ is\\
solution:
Given, $\alpha$ and $\beta$ are the roots of the equation $x^{2}-6 x-2=0$.

$$
\begin{aligned}
\therefore \quad a_{n} & =\alpha^{n}-\beta^{n} \text { for } n \geq 1 \\
a_{10} & =\alpha^{10}-\beta^{10} \\
a_{8} & =\alpha^{8}-\beta^{8} \\
a_{9} & =\alpha^{9}-\beta^{9}
\end{aligned}
$$

Now, consider

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \frac{a_{10}-2 a_{8}}{2 a_{9}}= \frac{\alpha^{10}-\beta^{10}-2\left(\alpha^{8}-\beta^{8}\right)}{2\left(\alpha^{9}-\alpha^{9}\right)} \\
&= \frac{\alpha^{8}\left(\alpha^{2}-2\right)-\beta^{8}\left(\beta^{2}-2\right)}{2\left(\alpha^{9}-\beta^{9}\right)} \\
&= \frac{\alpha^{8} \cdot 6 \alpha-\beta^{8} 6 \beta}{2\left(\alpha^{9}-\beta^{9}\right)}=\frac{6 \alpha^{9}-6 \beta^{9}}{2\left(\alpha^{9}-6 \beta^{9}\right)}=\frac{6}{2}=3 \\
& \because \alpha \text { and } \beta \text { are the roots of } \\
& \Rightarrow \quad x^{2}-6 x-2=0 \text { or } x^{2}=6 x+2 \\
& \alpha^{2}=6 \alpha+2 \quad \alpha^{2}-2=6 \alpha \\
& \text { and } \beta^{2}=6 \beta+2 \quad \Rightarrow \quad \beta^{2}-2=6 \beta
\end{aligned}
$$

\section*{Alternate Solution}
Since, $\alpha$ and $\beta$ are the roots of the equation

$$
\begin{array}{ll} 
& x^{2}-6 x-2=0 \\
\text { or } & x^{2}=6 x+2 \\
\therefore & \alpha^{2}=6 \alpha+2 \\
\Rightarrow & \alpha^{10}=6 \alpha^{9}+2 \alpha^{8} \\
\text { Similarly, } & \beta^{10}=6 \beta^{9}+2 \beta^{8}
\end{array}
$$

On subtracting Eq. (ii) from Eq. (i), we get

$$
\begin{array}{rlrl} 
& \alpha^{10}-\beta^{10} & =6\left(\alpha^{9}-\beta^{9}\right)+2\left(\alpha^{8}-\beta^{8}\right) \quad\left(\because a_{n}=\alpha^{n}-\beta^{n}\right) \\
a_{10} & =6 a_{9}+2 a_{8} \\
\Rightarrow \quad a_{10}-2 a_{8} & =6 a_{9} \Rightarrow \frac{a_{10}-2 a_{8}}{2 a_{9}}=3
\end{array}
$$

question: In the quadratic equation $p(x)=0$ with real coefficients has purely imaginary roots. Then, the equation $p[p(x)]=0$ has
options: c) two real and two purely imaginary roots
d) neither real nor purely imaginary roots
solution:
If quadratic equation has purely imaginary roots, then coefficient of $x$ must be equal to zero.

Let $p(x)=a x^{2}+b$ with $a, b$ of same sign and $a, b \in R$. Then, $\quad p[p(x)]=a\left(a x^{2}+b\right)^{2}+b$

$p(x)$ has imaginary roots say $i x$.

Then, also $a x^{2}+b \in R$ and $\left(a x^{2}+b\right)^{2}>0$

$$
\therefore \quad a\left(a x^{2}+b\right)^{2}+b \neq 0, \forall x
$$

Thus,

$$
p[p(x)] \neq 0, \forall x
$$

question: Let $\alpha$ and $\beta$ be the roots of equation $p x^{2}+q x+r=0$, $p \neq 0$. If $p, q$ and $r$ are in AP and $\frac{1}{\alpha}+\frac{1}{\beta}=4$, then the value of $|\alpha-\beta|$ is\\
Let $\alpha$ and $\beta$ be the roots of $x^{2}-6 x-2=0$, with $\alpha>\beta$. If $a_{n}=\alpha^{n}-\beta^{n}$ for $n \geq 1$, then the value of $\frac{a_{10}-2 a_{8}}{2 a_{9}}$ is\\
solution:
$\frac{a_{10}-2 a_{8}}{2 a_{9}}=\frac{\left(\alpha^{10}-\beta^{10}\right)-2\left(\alpha^{8}-\beta^{8}\right)}{2\left(\alpha^{9}-\beta^{9}\right)}$

$$
=\frac{\alpha^{8}\left(\alpha^{2}-2\right)-\beta^{8}\left(\beta^{2}-2\right)}{2\left(\alpha^{9}-\beta^{9}\right)}
$$

$\because \alpha$ is root of $x^{2}-6 x-2=0 \quad \Rightarrow \quad \alpha^{2}-2=6 \alpha$

[and $\beta$ is root of $x^{2}-6 x-2=0 \quad \Rightarrow \quad \beta^{2}-2=6 \beta$ ]

$$
=\frac{\alpha^{8}(6 \alpha)-\beta^{8}(6 \beta)}{2\left(\alpha^{9}-\beta^{9}\right)}=\frac{6\left(\alpha^{9}-\beta^{9}\right)}{2\left(\alpha^{9}-\beta^{9}\right)}=3
$$

Sum of roots $=\frac{\alpha^{2}+\beta^{2}}{\alpha \beta}$ and product $=1$

Given, $\alpha+\beta=-p$ and $\alpha^{3}+\beta^{3}=q$

\[
\begin{array}{rlrl}
\Rightarrow & (\alpha+\beta)\left(\alpha^{2}-\alpha \beta+\beta^{2}\right) & =q \\
& \therefore & \alpha^{2}+\beta^{2}-\alpha \beta & =\frac{-q}{p} \\
& \text { and } & (\alpha+\beta)^{2} & =p^{2} \\
\Rightarrow & \alpha^{2}+\beta^{2}+2 \alpha \beta & =p^{2} \tag{ii}
\end{array}
\]

From Eqs. (i) and (ii), we get

$$
\alpha^{2}+\beta^{2}=\frac{p^{3}-2 q}{3 p} \text { and } \alpha \beta=\frac{p^{3}+q}{3 p}
$$

$\therefore$ Required equation is, $x^{2}-\frac{\left(p^{3}-2 q\right) x}{\left(p^{3}+q\right)}+1=0$

$\Rightarrow\left(p^{3}+q\right) x^{2}-\left(p^{3}-2 q\right) x+\left(p^{3}+q\right)=0$

question: Let $\alpha, \beta$ be the roots of the equation $x^{2}-p x+r=0$ and $\frac{\alpha}{2}, 2 \beta$ be the roots of the equation $x^{2}-q x+r=0$. Then, the value of $r$ is\\
solution:
The equation $x^{2}-p x+r=0$ has roots $\alpha, \beta$ and the equation $x^{2}-q x+r=0$ has roots $\frac{\alpha}{2}, 2 \beta$.

$\Rightarrow \quad r=\alpha \beta$ and $\alpha+\beta=p$,

and $\frac{\alpha}{2}+2 \beta=q \Rightarrow \beta=\frac{2 q-p}{3}$ and $\alpha=\frac{2(2 p-q)}{3}$

$\Rightarrow \quad \alpha \beta=r=\frac{2}{9}(2 q-p)(2 p-q)$

question: If $a, b, c$ are the sides of a triangle $A B C$ such that $x^{2}-2(a+b+c) x+3 \lambda(a b+b c+c a)=0$ has real roots, then\\
solution:
Since, roots are real, therefore $D \geq 0$

$$
\begin{array}{lc}
\Rightarrow & 4(a+b+c)^{2}-12 \lambda(a b+b c+c a) \geq 0 \\
\Rightarrow & (a+b+c)^{2} \geq 3 \lambda(a b+b c+c a) \\
\Rightarrow & a^{2}+b^{2}+c^{2} \geq(a b+b c+c a)(3 \lambda-2) \\
\Rightarrow & 3 \lambda-2 \leq \frac{a^{2}+b^{2}+c^{2}}{a b+b c+c a} \\
\text { Also, } & \cos A=\frac{b^{2}+c^{2}-a^{2}}{2 b c}<1
\end{array}
$$

\[
\begin{array}{ll}
\Rightarrow & b^{2}+c^{2}-a^{2}<2 b c \\
\text { Similarly, } & c^{2}+a^{2}-b^{2}<2 c a \\
\text { and } & a^{2}+b^{2}-c^{2}<2 a b \\
\Rightarrow & a^{2}+b^{2}+c^{2}<2(a b+b c+c a) \\
\Rightarrow & \frac{a^{2}+b^{2}+c^{2}}{a b+b c+c a}<2 \tag{ii}
\end{array}
\]

From Eqs. (i) and (ii), we get

$$
3 \lambda-2<2 \quad \Rightarrow \quad \lambda<\frac{4}{3}
$$

question: If one root is square of the other root of the equation $x^{2}+p x+q=0$, then the relation between $p$ and $q$ is
The set of all real numbers $x$ for which $x^{2}-|x+2|+x>0$ is\\
The number of solutions of $\log _{4}(x-1)=\log _{2}(x-3)$ is\\
solution:
Given, $\log _{4}(x-1)=\log _{2}(x-3)=\log _{4^{1 / 2}}(x-3)$

$$
\begin{array}{ll}
\Rightarrow & \log _{4}(x-1)=2 \log _{4}(x-3) \\
\Rightarrow & \log _{4}(x-1)=\log _{4}(x-3)^{2} \\
\Rightarrow & (x-3)^{2}=x-1 \\
\Rightarrow & x^{2}+9-6 x=x-1 \\
\Rightarrow & x^{2}-7 x+10=0 \\
\Rightarrow & (x-2)(x-5)=0 \\
\Rightarrow & x=2, \quad \text { or } x=5 \\
\Rightarrow & x=5 \quad[\because x=2 \text { makes log }(x-3) \text { undefined }] .
\end{array}
$$

Hence, one solution exists.

question: For the equation $3 x^{2}+p x+3=0, p>0$, if one of the root is square of the other, then $p$ is equal to\\
solution:
Let $\alpha, \alpha^{2}$ be the roots of $3 x^{2}+p x+3=0$

$$
\begin{array}{rlrl} 
& \text { Now, } & S & =\alpha+\alpha^{2}=-p / 3, \\
\Rightarrow & & =\alpha^{3}=1 \\
& & \alpha & =1, \omega, \omega^{2} \\
& & \alpha+\alpha^{2} & =-p / 3 \\
\Rightarrow & \omega+\omega^{2} & =-p / 3
\end{array}
$$

$$
\begin{array}{crl}
\Rightarrow & -1 & =-p / 3 \\
\Rightarrow & p & =3
\end{array}
$$

question: If $\alpha$ and $\beta(\alpha<\beta)$ are the roots of the equation $x^{2}+b x+c=0$, where $c<0<b$, then\\
solution:
Given, $c<0<b$

Since,

$\alpha+\beta=-b$

and

$\alpha \beta=c$

From Eq. (ii), $c<0 \Rightarrow \alpha \beta<0$

$\Rightarrow$ Either $\alpha$ is - ve, $\beta$ is - ve or $\alpha$ is + ve, $\beta$ is - ve.

From Eq. (i), $b>0 \Rightarrow-b<0 \Rightarrow \alpha+\beta<0 \Rightarrow$ the sum is negative.

$\Rightarrow$ Modulus of negative quantity is $>$ modulus of positive quantity but $\alpha<\beta$ is given.

Therefore, it is clear that $\alpha$ is negative and $\beta$ is positive and modulus of $\alpha$ is greater than modulus of $\beta$

$\Rightarrow$ $\alpha<0<\beta<|\alpha|$

NOTE This question is not on the theory of interval in which root lie, which appears looking at first sight. It is new type and first time asked in the paper. It is important for future. The actual type is interval in which parameter lie.

question: The equation $\sqrt{x+1}-\sqrt{x-1}=\sqrt{4 x-1}$ has
The equation $x^{\frac{3}{4}\left(\log _2 x\right)^2+\log _2 x-\frac{5}{4}}=\sqrt{2}$ has
solution:
Given, $x^{\frac{3}{4}\left(\log _{2} x\right)^{2}+\log _{2} x-\frac{5}{4}}=\sqrt{2}$

$\Rightarrow \quad \frac{3}{4}\left(\log _{2} x\right)^{2}+\log _{2} x-\frac{5}{4}=\log _{x} \sqrt{2}$

$\Rightarrow \quad \frac{3}{4}\left(\log _{2} x\right)^{2}+\log _{2} x-\frac{5}{4}=\frac{1}{2 \log _{2} x}$

$\Rightarrow \quad 3\left(\log _{2} x\right)^{3}+4\left(\log _{2} x\right)^{2}-5\left(\log _{2} x\right)-2=0$

Put $\quad \log _{2} x=y$

$\therefore \quad 3 y^{3}+4 y^{2}-5 y-2=0$

$\Rightarrow \quad(y-1)(y+2)(3 y+1)=0$

$\Rightarrow \quad y=1,-2,-1 / 3$

$\Rightarrow \quad \log _{2} x=1,-2,-1 / 3$

$\Rightarrow \quad x=2, \frac{1}{2^{1 / 3}}, \frac{1}{4}$

question: If $\alpha$ and $\beta$ are the roots of $x^{2}+p x+q=0$ and $\alpha^{4}, \beta^{4}$ are the roots of $x^{2}-r x+s=0$, then the equation $x^{2}-4 q x+2 q^{2}-r=0$ has always
options: d) one positive and one negative root
solution:
Since, $\alpha, \beta$ are the roots of $x^{2}+p x+q=0$ and $\alpha^{4}, \beta^{4}$ are the roots of $x^{2}-r x+s=0$.

$\Rightarrow \alpha+\beta=-p ; \alpha \beta=q ; \alpha^{4}+\beta^{4}=r$ and $\alpha^{4} \beta^{4}=s$

Let roots of $x^{2}-4 q x+\left(2 q^{2}-r\right)=0$ be $\alpha^{\prime}$ and $\beta$

Now, $\quad \alpha^{\prime} \beta^{\prime}=\left(2 q^{2}-r\right)=2(\alpha \beta)^{2}-\left(\alpha^{4}+\beta^{4}\right)$

$$
=-\left(\alpha^{4}+\beta^{4}-2 \alpha^{2} \beta^{2}\right)=-\left(\alpha^{2}-\beta^{2}\right)^{2}<0
$$

$\Rightarrow$ Roots are real and of opposite sign.

question: For real $x$, the function $\frac{(x-a)(x-b)}{(x-c)}$ will assume all real values provided\\
solution:
Let $y=\frac{x^{2}-(a+b) x+a b}{x-c}$

$\Rightarrow \quad y x-c y=x^{2}-(a+b) x+a b$

$\Rightarrow x^{2}-(a+b+y) x+(a b+c y)=0$

For real roots, $D \geq 0$

$\begin{array}{lrl}\Rightarrow & & (a+b+y)^{2}-4(a b+c y) \geq 0 \\ \Rightarrow & (a+b)^{2}+y^{2}+2(a+b) y-4 a b-4 c y \geq 0 \\ \Rightarrow & y^{2}+2(a+b-2 c) y+(a-b)^{2} \geq 0\end{array}$

which is true for all real values of $y$.

$$
\begin{array}{rlrl}
\therefore & & D & \leq 0 \\
& & 4(a+b-2 c)^{2}-4(a-b)^{2} & \leq 0 \\
& & 4(a+b-2 c+a-b)(a+b-2 c-a+b) & \leq 0 \\
\Rightarrow & & (2 a-2 c)(2 b-2 c) & \leq 0 \\
\Rightarrow & (a-c)(b-c) & \leq 0
\end{array}
$$

$\Rightarrow c$ must lie between $a$ and $b$ i.e. $a \leq c \leq b$ or $b \leq c \leq a$

question: The number of real solutions of the equation $|x|^{2}-3|x|+2=0$ is\\

Since, $|x|^{2}-3|x|+2=0$

$$

\Rightarrow & & |x| & =1,2 \\
\therefore & & x & =1,-1,2,-2

$$

Hence, four real solutions exist.

question: If $\alpha, \beta$ and $\gamma$ are three consecutive terms of a non-constant GP such that the equations $\alpha x^{2}+2 \beta x+\gamma=0$ and $x^{2}+x-1=0$ have a common root, then, $\alpha(\beta+\gamma)$ is equal to

A value of $b$ for which the equations $x^{2}+b x-1=0$, $x^{2}+x+b=0$ have one root in common is\\
solution:
If $a_{1} x^{2}+b_{1} x+c_{1}=0$

and $a_{2} x^{2}+b_{2} x+c_{2}=0$

have a common real root, then

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \Rightarrow \quad\left(a_{1} c_{2}-a_{2} c_{1}\right)^{2}=\left(b_{1} c_{2}-b_{2} c_{1}\right)\left(a_{1} b_{2}-a_{2} b_{1}\right) \\
& \therefore \quad x^{2}+b x-1=0 \text { have a common root. } \\
& \Rightarrow \quad(1+b)^{2}=\left(b^{2}+1\right)(1-b) \\
& \Rightarrow \quad b^{2}+2 b+1=b^{2}-b^{3}+1-b \\
& \Rightarrow \quad b^{3}+3 b=0 \\
& \therefore \quad b\left(b^{2}+3\right)=0 \\
& \Rightarrow \quad b=0, \pm \sqrt{3} i
\end{aligned}
$$

question: Let $P(4,-4)$ and $Q(9,6)$ be two points on the parabola, $y^{2}=4 x$ and let $X$ be any point on the arc $P O Q$ of this parabola, where $O$ is the vertex of this parabola, such that the area of $\triangle P X Q$ is maximum. Then, this maximum area (in sq units) is\\

question: If $a \in R$ and the equation $-3(x-[x])^{2}+2(x-[x])$ $+a^{2}=0$ (where, $[x]$ denotes the greatest integer $\leq x$ ) has no integral solution, then all possible values of $a$ lie in the interval\\
solution:
Put $t=x-[x]=\{X\}$, which is a fractional part function and lie between $0 \leq\{X\}<1$ and then solve it.

Given, $a \in R$ and equation is

$$
-3\{x-[x]\}^{2}+2\{x-[x]\}+a^{2}=0
$$

Let $t=x-[x]$, then equation is

$$
\begin{aligned}
& -3 t^{2}+2 t+a^{2}=0 \\
& \Rightarrow \quad t=\frac{1 \pm \sqrt{1+3 a^{2}}}{3} \\
& \because \quad t=x-[x]=\{X\} \quad \text { [fractional part] } \\
& \therefore \quad 0 \leq t \leq 1 \\
& 0 \leq \frac{1 \pm \sqrt{1+3 a^{2}}}{3} \leq 1
\end{aligned}
$$

Taking positive sign, we get

$$
\begin{aligned}
& 0 \leq \frac{1+\sqrt{1+3 a^{2}}}{3}<1 \\
& \Rightarrow \quad \sqrt{1+3 a^{2}}<2 \quad \Rightarrow \quad 1+3 a^{2}<4 \\
& \Rightarrow \quad a^{2}-1<0 \Rightarrow \quad(a+1)(a-1)<0
\end{aligned}
$$

$\therefore \quad a \in(-1,1)$, for no integer solution of $a$, we consider $(-1,0) \cup(0,1)$

question:
The number of real roots of the equation

$$
5+\left|2^{x}-1\right|=2^{x}\left(2^{x}-2\right) \text { is }
$$\\
solution:
Given equation $5+\left|2^{x}-1\right|=2^{x}\left(2^{x}-2\right)$

\section*{Case I}
If $2^{x}-1 \geq 0 \Rightarrow x \geq 0$, then $5+2^{x}-1=2^{x}\left(2^{x}-2\right)$

Put $2^{x}=t$, then

$$
5+t-1=t^{2}-2 t \quad \Rightarrow \quad t^{2}-3 t-4=0
$$

$\Rightarrow t^{2}-4 t+t-4=0 \quad \Rightarrow \quad t(t-4)+1(t-4)=0$

$\Rightarrow \quad t=4$ or $-1 \quad \Rightarrow \quad t=4 \quad\left(\because t=2^{x}>0\right)$

$\Rightarrow \quad 2^{x}=4 \Rightarrow x=2>0$

$\Rightarrow x=2$ is the solution.

\section*{Case II}
If $2^{x}-1<0 \Rightarrow x<0$, then $5+1-2^{x}=2^{x}\left(2^{x}-2\right)$

Put $2^{x}=y$, then $6-y=y^{2}-2 y$

$\Rightarrow \quad y^{2}-y-6=0 \quad \Rightarrow \quad y^{2}-3 y+2 y-6=0$

$\Rightarrow(y+2)(y-3)=0 \Rightarrow y=3$ or -2

$\Rightarrow$

$y=3$ (as $\left.y=2^{x}>0\right) \Rightarrow 2^{x}=3$

$\Rightarrow x=\log _{2} 3>0$

So, $x=\log _{2} 3$ is not a solution.

Therefore, number of real roots is one.

question: All the pairs $(x, y)$ that satisfy the inequality $2^{\sqrt{\sin ^{2} x-2 \sin x+5}} \cdot \frac{1}{4^{\sin ^{2} y}} \leq 1$ also satisfy the equation\\
solution:
Given, inequality is

$$
\begin{aligned}
& 2^{\sqrt{\sin ^{2} x-2 \sin x+5}} \cdot \frac{1}{4^{\sin ^{2} y}} \leq 1 \\
& \Rightarrow 2^{\sqrt{(\sin x-1)^{2}+4}} \cdot 2^{-2 \sin ^{2} y} \leq 1 \\
& \Rightarrow 2^{\sqrt{(\sin x-1)^{2}+4}} \leq 2^{2 \sin ^{2} y} \\
& \Rightarrow \sqrt{(\sin x-1)^{2}+4} \leq 2 \sin ^{2} y \\
& \because \quad \text { Range of } \sqrt{(\sin x-1)^{2}+4} \text { is }[2,2 \sqrt{2}] \\
& \text { and range of } 2 \sin ^{2} y \text { is }[0,2] .
\end{aligned}
$$

$\therefore$ The above inequality holds, iff

$\sqrt{(\sin x-1)^{2}+4}=2=2 \sin ^{2} y$

$\Rightarrow \sin x=1$ and $\sin ^{2} y=1$

$\Rightarrow \sin x=|\sin y|$

[from the options]

question: The sum of the solutions of the equation $|\sqrt{x}-2|+\sqrt{x}(\sqrt{x}-4)+2=0(x>0)$ is equal to\\
solution:
Key Idea Reduce the given equation into quadratic equation.

Given equation is

$$
\begin{aligned}
& |\sqrt{x}-2|+\sqrt{x}(\sqrt{x}-4)+2=0 \\
\Rightarrow & |\sqrt{x}-2|+x-4 \sqrt{x}+4=2 \\
\Rightarrow & |\sqrt{x}-2|+(\sqrt{x}-2)^{2}=2 \\
\Rightarrow & (|\sqrt{x}-2|)^{2}+|\sqrt{x}-2|-2=0
\end{aligned}
$$

Let $|\sqrt{x}-2|=y$, then above equation reduced to

$$
y^{2}+y-2=0 \Rightarrow y^{2}+2 y-y-2=0
$$

$\Rightarrow y(y+2)-1(y+2)=0 \Rightarrow(y+2)(y-1)=0$

$\Rightarrow \quad y=1,-2$

$\therefore \quad \quad \begin{aligned} y & =1 \quad[\because y=|\sqrt{x}-2| \geq 0]\end{aligned}$

$\Rightarrow \quad|\sqrt{x}-2|=1$

$\Rightarrow \quad \sqrt{x}-2= \pm 1$

$\Rightarrow \quad \sqrt{x}=3$ or 1

$\Rightarrow \quad x=9$ or 1

$\therefore$ Sum of roots $=9+1=10$

question: The real number $k$ for which the equation, $2 x^{3}+3 x+k=0$ has two distinct real roots in $[0,1]$\\
solution:
Let $f(x)=2 x^{3}+3 x+k$

On differentiating w.r.t. $x$, we get

$$
f^{\prime}(x)=6 x^{2}+3>0, \forall x \in R
$$

$\Rightarrow f(x)$ is strictly increasing function.

$\Rightarrow f(x)=0$ has only one real root, so two roots are not possible.

question: Let $a, b, c$ be real numbers, $a \neq 0$. If $\alpha$ is a root of $a^{2} x^{2}+b x+c=0, \beta$ is the root of $a^{2} x^{2}-b x-c=0$ and $0<\alpha<\beta$, then the equation $a^{2} x^{2}+2 b x+2 c=0$ has a root $\gamma$ that always satisfies\\
solution:
Since, $\alpha$ is a root of $a^{2} x^{2}+b x+c=0$

\[
\begin{array}{lr}
\Rightarrow & a^{2} \alpha^{2}+b \alpha+c=0 \\
\text { and } \beta \text { is a root of } & a^{2} x^{2}-b x-c=0 \\
\Rightarrow & a^{2} \beta^{2}-b \beta-c=0 \tag{ii}
\end{array}
\]

Let $\quad f(x)=a^{2} x^{2}+2 b x+2 c$

$\therefore \quad f(\alpha)=a^{2} \alpha^{2}+2 b \alpha+2 c$

$$
=a^{2} \alpha^{2}-2 a^{2} \alpha^{2}=-a^{2} \alpha^{2}
$$

[from Eq. (i)]

$$
\begin{array}{ll}
\text { and } & f(\beta)=\alpha^{2} \beta^{2}+2 b \beta+2 c \\
= & a^{2} \beta^{2}+2 a^{2} \beta^{2}=3 a^{2} \beta^{2} \text { [from Eq. (ii)] } \\
\Rightarrow \quad & f(\alpha) f(\beta)<0
\end{array}
$$

$f(x)$ must have a root lying in the open interval $(\alpha, \beta)$.

$\therefore \quad \alpha<\gamma<\beta$

question:
If $a+b+c=0$, then the quadratic equation

$3 a x^{2}+2 b x+c=0$ has
options: a) at least one root in $(0,1)$
b) one root in $(2,3)$ and the other in $(-2,-1)$
solution:
Let


\begin{equation*}
f(x)=a x^{3}+b x^{2}+c x+d \tag{i}
\end{equation*}


$$
\therefore \quad f(0)=d \text { and } f(1)=a+b+c+d=d
$$

$$
[\because a+b+c=0]
$$

$\therefore \quad f(0)=f(1)$

$f$ is continuous in the closed interval $[0,1]$ and $f$ is derivable in the open interval $(0,1)$.

Also, $\quad f(0)=f(1)$.

$\therefore$ By Rolle's theorem, $f^{\prime}(\alpha)=0$ for $0<\alpha<1$

Now,

$$
f^{\prime}(x)=3 a x^{2}+2 b x+c
$$

$\Rightarrow$

$$
f^{\prime}(\alpha)=3 a \alpha^{2}+2 b \alpha+c=0
$$

$\therefore$ Eq. (i) has exist atleast one root in the interval $(0,1)$. Thus, $f^{\prime}(x)$ must have root in the interval $(0,1)$ or $3 a x^{2}+2 b x+c=0$ has root $\in(0,1)$.

question:
The largest interval for which

$x^{12}-x^{9}+x^{4}-x+1>0$ is\\
solution:
Given, $x^{12}-x^{9}+x^{4}-x+1>0$

Here, three cases arises:

Case I When $x \leq 0 \Rightarrow x^{12}>0,-x^{9}>0, x^{4}>0,-x>0$

$\therefore \quad x^{12}-x^{9}+x^{4}-x+1>0, \forall x \leq 0$

Case II When $0<x \leq 1$

\[
\begin{array}{rrr}
x^{9}<x^{4} \text { and } \quad x<1 \Rightarrow-x^{9}+x^{4}>0 & \text { and } & 1-x>0 \\
\therefore \quad x^{12}-x^{9}+x^{4}-x+1>0, \forall 0<x \leq 1 & & \ldots \text { (ii) } \tag{ii}
\end{array}
\]

Case III When $x>1 \Rightarrow x^{12}>x^{9}$ and $x^{4}>x$

$\therefore \quad x^{12}-x^{9}+x^{4}-x+1>0, \forall x>1$

From Eqs. (i), (ii) and (iii), the above equation holds for all $x \in R$.

question:
Let $a, b, c$ be non-zero real numbers such that

$$
\begin{aligned}
\int_{0}^{1}\left(1+\cos ^{8} x\right)\left(a x^{2}\right. & +b x+c) d x \\
& =\int_{0}^{2}\left(1+\cos ^{8} x\right)\left(a x^{2}+b x+c\right) d x
\end{aligned}
$$

Then, the quadratic equation $a x^{2}+b x+c=0$ has\\
solution:
Consider,

$$
f(x)=\int_{0}^{1}\left(1+\cos ^{8} x\right)\left(a x^{2}+b x+c\right) d x
$$

Obviously, $f(x)$ is continuous and differentiable in the interval $[1,2]$.

Also, $\quad f(1)=f(2) \quad$ [given]

$\therefore$ By Rolle's theorem, there exist atleast one point $k \in(1,2)$, such that $f^{\prime}(k)=0$.

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \text { Now, } \begin{aligned}
f^{\prime}(x) & =\left(1+\cos ^{8} x\right)\left(a x^{2}+b x+c\right) \\
f^{\prime}(k) & =0 \\
\Rightarrow \quad\left(1+\cos ^{8} k\right)\left(a k^{2}+b k+c\right) & =0 \\
\Rightarrow \quad a k^{2}+b k+c & =0 \quad\left[\operatorname{as}\left(1+\cos ^{8} k\right) \neq 0\right] \\
\therefore \quad x=k \text { is root of } a x^{2}+b x+c & =0,
\end{aligned} \\
& \text { where } \quad k \in(1,2)
\end{aligned}
$$

question: If $a_{1}, a_{2}, a_{3}, \ldots, a_{n}$ are in AP and $a_{1}+a_{4}+a_{7}+\ldots+a_{16}$ $=114$, then $a_{1}+a_{6}+a_{11}+a_{16}$ is equal to\\
solution:
Key Idea Use $n$th term of an AP i.e. $a_{n}=a+(n-1) d$, simplify the given equation and use result.

Given AP is $a_{1}, a_{2}, a_{3}, \ldots, a_{n}$

$=6 a_{1}+(3+6+9+12+15) d$

$$
\therefore 6 a_{1}+45 d=114
$$

(given)


\begin{equation*}
\Rightarrow \quad 2 a_{1}+15 d=38 \tag{i}
\end{equation*}


Now, $a_{1}+a_{6}+a_{11}+a_{16}$

$$
=a_{1}+\left(a_{1}+5 d\right)+\left(a_{1}+10 d\right)+\left(a_{1}+15 d\right)
$$

$$
\begin{aligned}
& =4 a_{1}+30 d=2\left(2 a_{1}+15 d\right) \\
& =2 \times 38=76
\end{aligned}
$$

question: If 19th term of a non-zero AP is zero, then its (49th term) : (29th term) is\\
For any three positive real numbers $a, b$ and $c$, if $9\left(25 a^{2}+b^{2}\right)+25\left(c^{2}-3 a c\right)=15 b(3 a+c)$, then
options: a) $b, c$ and $a$ are in GP
b) $b, c$ and $a$ are in AP
c) $a, b$ and $c$ are in AP
d) $a, b$ and $c$ are in GP
solution:
We have,

$$
\begin{aligned}
& 225 a^{2}+9 b^{2}+25 c^{2}-75 a c-45 a b-15 b c=0 \\
\Rightarrow & (15 a)^{2}+(3 b)^{2}+(5 c)^{2}-(15 a)(5 c)-(15 a)(3 b) \\
\Rightarrow \quad & \frac{1}{2}\left[(15 a-3 b)^{2}+(3 b-5 c)^{2}+(5 c-15 a)^{2}\right]=0
\end{aligned}
$$

$\Rightarrow 15 a=3 b, 3 b=5 c$ and $5 c=15 a$

$\therefore 15 a=3 b=5 c$

\[
\begin{array}{ll}
\Rightarrow \quad \frac{a}{1}=\frac{b}{5}=\frac{c}{3}=\lambda  \tag{say}\\
\Rightarrow \quad a=\lambda, b=5 \lambda, c=3 \lambda
\end{array}
\]

$\therefore b, c, a$ are in AP.

question: If $T_{r}$ is the $r$ th term of an AP, for $r=1,2,3, \ldots$. If for some positive integers $m$ and $n$, we have $T_{m}=\frac{1}{n}$ and $T_{n}=\frac{1}{m}$, then $T_{m n}$ equals\\
The sides of a right angled triangle are in arithmetic progression. If the triangle has area 24 , then what is the length of its smallest side?
solution:
Let the sides are $a-d, a$ and $a+d$. Then,

$$
\begin{array}{rlrl} 
& & a(a-d) & =48 \\
& \text { and } a^{2}-2 a d+d^{2}+a^{2} & =a^{2}+2 a d+d^{2} \\
\Rightarrow & a^{2} & =4 a d \\
\Rightarrow & a & =4 d \\
& \text { Thus, } \quad a & =8, d=2 \\
& \text { Hence, } \quad a-d & =6
\end{array}
$$

\section*{Topic 2 Sum of $\boldsymbol{n}$ Terms of an AP}

question: If $a_{1}, a_{2}, a_{3}, \ldots$ are in AP such that $a_{1}+a_{7}+a_{16}=40$, then the sum of the first 15 terms of this AP is\\
Let $S_{n}$ denote the sum of the first $n$ terms of an AP. If $S_{4}=16$ and $S_{6}=-48$, then $S_{10}$ is equal to\\
solution:
Given $S_{n}$ denote the sum of the first $n$ terms of an AP.

Let first term and common difference of the AP be ' $a$ ' and ' $d$ ', respectively.

\[
\begin{array}{lc}
\therefore & S_{4}=2[2 a+3 d]=16 \\
& \because S_{n}=\frac{n}{2}[2 a+(n-1) d] \\
\Rightarrow & \text { (given) } \\
\text { and } & S_{6}=3[2 a+5 d]=-48 \tag{given}
\end{array}
\]

On subtracting Eq. (i) from Eq. (ii), we get

$$
\begin{array}{rlrl} 
& & 2 d & =-24 \\
\Rightarrow & d & =-12
\end{array}
$$

So, $\quad 2 a=44 \quad$ [put $d=-12$ in Eq. (i)]

$$
\text { Now, } \quad \begin{aligned}
S_{10} & =5[2 a+9 d] \\
& =5[44+9(-12)]=5[44-108]
\end{aligned}
$$

$$
=5 \times(-64)=-320
$$

question:
For $x \in R$, let $[x]$ denote the greatest integer $\leq x$, then the sum of the series

$$
-\frac{1}{3}+-\frac{1}{3}-\frac{1}{100}+-\frac{1}{3}-\frac{2}{100}+\ldots+-\frac{1}{3}-\frac{99}{100} \text { is }
$$
solution:
Given series is

$$
-\frac{1}{3}+-\frac{1}{3}-\frac{1}{100}+-\frac{1}{3}-\frac{2}{100}+\ldots \ldots+-\frac{1}{3}-\frac{99}{100}
$$

[where, $[x]$ denotes the greatest integer $\leq x$ ]

Now,

$$
-\frac{1}{3},-\frac{1}{3}-\frac{1}{100},-\frac{1}{3}-\frac{2}{100}, \ldots+-\frac{1}{3}-\frac{66}{100}
$$

all the term have value -1

and $-\frac{1}{3}-\frac{67}{100},-\frac{1}{3}-\frac{68}{100}, \ldots,-\frac{1}{3}-\frac{99}{100}$ all the term have value -2 .

So, $-\frac{1}{3}+-\frac{1}{3}-\frac{1}{100}+-\frac{1}{3}-\frac{2}{100}+\ldots+-\frac{1}{3}-\frac{66}{100}$ $=-1-1-1-1 \ldots 67$ times .

$=(-1) \times 67=-67$

and $-\frac{1}{3}-\frac{67}{100}+-\frac{1}{3}-\frac{68}{100}+\ldots+-\frac{1}{3}-\frac{99}{100}$

$=-2-2-2-2 \ldots 33$ times

$=(-2) \times 33=-66$\\
$\therefore-\frac{1}{3}+-\frac{1}{3}-\frac{1}{100}+-\frac{1}{3}-\frac{2}{100}+\ldots+-\frac{1}{3}-\frac{99}{100}$ $=(-67)+(-66)=-133$.

\section*{Alternate Solution}
$\because[-x]=-[x]-1$, if $x \notin$ Integer,

and $[x]+x+\frac{1}{n}+x+\frac{2}{n}+\ldots+x+\frac{n-1}{n}=[n x]$, $n \in N$.

So given series

$$
\begin{aligned}
& -\frac{1}{3}+-\frac{1}{3}-\frac{1}{100}+-\frac{1}{3}-\frac{2}{100}+\ldots \ldots+\frac{-1}{3}-\frac{99}{100} \\
& =-\frac{1}{3}-1+-\frac{1}{3}+\frac{1}{100}-1 \\
& \quad+-\frac{1}{3}+\frac{2}{100}-1+\ldots+-\frac{1}{3}+\frac{99}{100}-1 \\
& =(-1) \times 100-\frac{1}{3} \times 100=-100-33=-133
\end{aligned}
$$

question: If the sum and product of the first three terms in an AP are 33 and 1155 , respectively, then a value of its 11 th term is\\
solution:
Let first three terms of an AP as $a-d, a, a+d$.

$$
\text { So, } \quad 3 a=33 \Rightarrow a=11
$$

[given sum of three terms $=33$ and product of terms $=1155$ ]

$$
\begin{array}{cc}
\Rightarrow & (11-d) 11(11+d)=1155 \\
\Rightarrow & 11^{2}-d^{2}=105 \\
\Rightarrow & d^{2}=121-105=16 \\
\Rightarrow & d= \pm 4
\end{array}
$$

So the first three terms of the AP are either $7,11,15$ or $15,11,7$.

So, the 11 th term is either $7+(10 \times 4)=47$ or $15+(10 \times(-4))=-25$.

question: Let the sum of the first n terms of a non-constant AP $a_{1}, a_{2}, a_{3} \ldots$. be $50 n+\frac{n(n-7)}{2} A$, where $A$ is a constant. If $d$ is the common difference of this AP, then the ordered pair $\left(d, a_{50}\right)$ is equal to \\
solution:
Key Idea Use the formula of sum of first $n$ terms of AP, i.e $S_{n}=\frac{n}{2}[2 a+(n-1) d]$

Given $\mathrm{AP}$, is
$a_{1}, a_{2}, a_{3}, \ldots$ having sum of first $n$-terms

$$
=\frac{n}{2}\left[2 a_{1}+(n-1) d\right]
$$

[where, $d$ is the common difference of AP]


\begin{equation*}
=50 n+\frac{n(n-7)}{2} A \tag{given}
\end{equation*}


$\Rightarrow \quad \frac{1}{2}\left[2 a_{1}+(n-1) d\right]=50+\frac{n-7}{2} A$

$\Rightarrow \quad \frac{1}{2}\left[2 a_{1}+n d-d\right]=50-\frac{7}{2} A+\frac{n}{2} A$

$$
\Rightarrow \quad a_{1}-\frac{d}{2}+\frac{n d}{2}=50-\frac{7}{2} A+\frac{n}{2} A
$$
On comparing corresponding term, we get
$$
\begin{aligned}
& d=A \text { and } a_1-\frac{d}{2}=50-\frac{7}{2} \mathrm{~A} \\
& \Rightarrow \quad a_1-\frac{A}{2}=50-\frac{7}{2} A \quad[\because d=A] \\
& \Rightarrow \quad a_1=50-3 A \\
&
\end{aligned}
$$

So
$$
\begin{aligned}
a_{50} & =a_1+49 d \\
& =(50-3 A)+49 A \\
& =50+46 A
\end{aligned}
$$
$$
[\because d=A]
$$

Therefore, $\left(d, a_{50}\right)=(A, 50+46 A)$

question:
The sum of all two digit positive numbers which when divided by 7 yield 2 or 5 as remainder is
\\
solution:
Clearly, the two digit number which leaves remainder 2 when divided by 7 is of the form $N=7 k+2$ [by Division Algorithm]
For,
$$
\begin{gathered}
k=2, N=16 \\
k=3, N=23 \\
\vdots \\
k=13, N=93
\end{gathered}
$$
$\therefore 12$ such numbers are possible and these numbers forms an AP.
Now,
$$
\begin{aligned}
& S=\frac{12}{2}[16+93]= 654 \\
&\left(\because S_n=\frac{n}{2}(a+l)\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

Similarly, the two digit number which leaves remainder 5 when divided by 7 is of the form $N=7 k+5$
For $k=1, \quad N=12$
$$
\begin{aligned}
& k=2, N=19 \\
& \vdots \\
& k=13, N=96
\end{aligned}
$$
$\therefore 13$ such numbers are possible and these numbers also forms an AP.
Now,
$$
\begin{aligned}
& S^{\prime}=\frac{13}{2}[12+96]=702 \\
& \quad\left(\because S_n=\frac{n}{2}(a+l)\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

Total sum $=S+S^{\prime}=654+702=1356$

question: Let $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots . a_{30}$ be an AP, $S=\sum_{i=1}^{30} a_{i}$ and $T=\sum_{i=1}^{15} a_{(2 i-1)}$. If $a_{5}=27$ and $S-2 T=75$, then $a_{10}$ is equal to\\
solution:
We have, $S=a_1+a_2+\ldots+a_{30}$
$$
=15\left[2 a_1+29 d\right]
$$
(where $d$ is the common difference)
$$
\left[\because S_n=\frac{n}{2}[2 a+(n-1) d]\right]
$$
and
$$
\begin{aligned}
T & =a_1+a_3+\ldots+a_{29} \\
& \left.=\frac{15}{2}\left[2 a_1+14 \times 2 d\right)\right]
\end{aligned}
$$
( $\because$ common difference is $2 d$ )
$$
\Rightarrow \quad 2 T=15\left[2 a_1+28 d\right]
$$

From Eqs. (i) and (ii), we get
$$
S-2 T=15 d=75 \quad[\because S-2 T=75]
$$

$$
\Rightarrow \quad d=5
$$

Now, $\quad a_{10}=a_{5}+5 d$

$$
=27+25=52
$$

question: Let $b_{i}>1$ for $i=1,2, \ldots, 101$. Suppose $\log _{e} b_{1}, \log _{e} b_{2}$, $\ldots, \log _{e} b_{101}$ are in AP with the common difference $\log _{e} 2$ . Suppose $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{101}$ are in AP, such that $a_{1}=b_{1}$ and $a_{51}=b_{51}$. If $\quad t=b_{1}+b_{2}+\ldots+b_{51} \quad$ and $s=a_{1}+a_{2}+\ldots+a_{51}$, then\\
If the sum of first $n$ terms of an AP is $c n^{2}$, then the sum of squares of these $n$ terms is\\
If the sum of the first $2 n$ terms of the AP series $2,5,8, \ldots$, is equal to the sum of the first $n$ terms of the AP series $57,59,61, \ldots$, then $n$ equals\\
solution:
According to given condition,

$$
\begin{array}{rlrl} 
& & S_{2 n} & =S_{n}^{\prime} \\
\Rightarrow & \frac{2 n}{2}[2 \times 2+(2 n-1) \times 3] & =\frac{n}{2}[2 \times 57+(n-1) \times 2] \\
\Rightarrow & & (4+6 n-3) & =\frac{1}{2}(114+2 n-2)
\end{array}
$$

$$
\begin{array}{cc}
\Rightarrow & 6 n+1=57+n-1 \Rightarrow \\
\therefore & n=11
\end{array}
$$

question: Suppose that all the terms of an arithmetic progression are natural numbers. If the ratio of the sum of the first seven terms to the sum of the first eleven terms is $6: 11$ and the seventh term lies in between 130 and 140, then the common difference of this AP is
solution:
Given, $\frac{S_{7}}{S_{11}}=\frac{6}{11}$ and $130<t_{7}<140$


\begin{align*}
& \Rightarrow \quad \frac{\frac{7}{2}[2 a+6 d]}{\frac{11}{2}[2 a+10 d]}=\frac{6}{11} \Rightarrow \frac{7(2 a+6 d)}{(2 a+10 d)}=6 \\
& \Rightarrow \quad a=9 d  \tag{i}\\
& \text { Also, } \quad 130<t_{7}<140 \\
& \Rightarrow \quad 130<a+6 d<140 \\
& \Rightarrow \quad 130<9 d+6 d<140 \quad \text { [from Eq. (i)] } \\
& \Rightarrow \quad 130<15 d<140 \\
& \Rightarrow \quad \frac{26}{3}<d<\frac{28}{3} \quad \text { [since, } d \text { is a natural number] } \\
& \therefore \quad d=9
\end{align*}

question: A pack contains $n$ cards numbered from 1 to $n$. Two consecutive numbered cards are removed from the pack and the sum of the numbers on the remaining cards is 1224. If the smaller of the numbers on the removed cards is $k$, then $k-20$ is equal to
solution:
Let number of removed cards be $k$ and $(k+1)$.

$$
\begin{array}{rlrl} 
& \therefore & \frac{n(n+1)}{2}-k-(k+1) & =1224 \\
\Rightarrow & & n^{2}+n-4 k & =2450 \Rightarrow n^{2}+n-2450=4 k \\
\Rightarrow & & (n+50)(n-49) & =4 k \\
& & n & >49 \\
& \therefore & n & =50 \\
\Rightarrow & 100 & =4 k \\
& \text { Now } & k & =25 \\
& k-20 & =5
\end{array}
$$

question: Let $a_{1}, a_{2}, a_{3}, \ldots, a_{100}$ be an arithmetic progression with $a_{1}=3$ and $S_{p}=\sum_{i=1}^{p} a_{i}, 1 \leq p \leq 100$. For any integer $n$ with $1 \leq n \leq 20$, let $m=5 n$. If $\frac{S_{m}}{S_{n}}$ does not depend on $n$, then $a_{2}$ is equal to ......
solution:
Given, $a_{1}=3, m=5 n$ and $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots$, is an AP.

$\therefore \quad \frac{S_{m}}{S_{n}}=\frac{S_{5 n}}{S_{n}}$ is independent of $n$.

$$
=\frac{\frac{5 n}{2}[2 \times 3+(5 n-1) d]}{\frac{n}{2}[2 \times 3+(n-1) d]}=\frac{5\{(6-d)+5 n\}}{(6-d)+n}
$$

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \text { If } \quad 6-d=0 \Rightarrow d=6 \\
& \therefore \quad a_{2}=a_{1}+d=3+6=9
\end{aligned}
$$

independent of $n$

or If $d=0$, then $\frac{S_{m}}{S_{n}}$ is independent of $n$.

$\therefore a_{2}=9$

question:
Let $a_{1}, a_{2}, a_{3}, \ldots, a_{11}$ be real numbers satisfying $a_{1}=15$, $27-2 a_{2}>0$ and $a_{k}=2 a_{k-1}-a_{k-2}$ for $k=3,4, \ldots, 11$.


If $\frac{a_{1}^{2}+a_{2}^{2}+\ldots+a_{11}^{2}}{11}=90$, then the value of

$\frac{a_{1}+a_{2}+\ldots+a_{11}}{11}$ is.....
solution:
$a_{k}=2 a_{k-1}-a_{k-2}$

$\Rightarrow a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{11}$ are in an AP.

$\therefore \quad \frac{a_{1}^{2}+a_{2}^{2}+\ldots+a_{11}^{2}}{11}=\frac{11 a^{2}+35 \times 11 d^{2}+10 a d}{11}=90$

$\Rightarrow 225+35 d^{2}+150 d=90$

$\Rightarrow 35 d^{2}+150 d+135=0 \Rightarrow d=-3,-\frac{9}{7}$

Given, $\quad a_{2}<\frac{27}{2}$

$\therefore d=-3$ and $d \neq-\frac{9}{7}$

$\Rightarrow \quad \frac{a_{1}+a_{2}+\ldots+a_{11}}{11}=\frac{11}{2}[30-10 \times 3]=0$

\section*{Topic 3 Geometric Progression (GP)}

question: Let $a, b$ and $c$ be in GP with common ratio $r$, where $a \neq 0$ and $0<r \leq \frac{1}{2}$. If $3 a, 7 b$ and $15 c$ are the first three terms of an AP , then the 4 th term of this AP is\\
solution:
Key Idea Use $n^{\text {th }}$ term of AP i.e., $a_{n}=a+(n-1) d$, If $a, A, b$ are in $\mathrm{AP}$, then $2 A=a+b$ and $n^{\text {th }}$ term of G.P. i.e., $a_{n}=a r^{n-1}$.

It is given that, the terms $a, b, c$ are in GP with common ratio $r$, where $a \neq 0$ and $0<r \leq \frac{1}{2}$.

So, let, $b=a r$ and $c=a r^{2}$

Now, the terms $3 a, 7 b$ and $15 c$ are the first three terms of an AP, then

$$
\begin{aligned}
& 2(7 b)=3 a+15 c \\
& \Rightarrow \quad 14 a r=3 a+15 a r^{2} \quad\left[\text { as } b=a r, c=a r^{2}\right] \\
& \Rightarrow \quad 14 r=3+15 r^{2} \quad[\text { as } a \neq 0] \\
& \Rightarrow \quad 15 r^{2}-14 r+3=0 \\
& \Rightarrow \quad 15 r^{2}-5 r-9 r+3=0 \\
& \Rightarrow 5 r(3 r-1)-3(3 r-1)=0 \\
& \Rightarrow \quad(3 r-1)(5 r-3)=0 \\
& \Rightarrow \quad r=\frac{1}{3} \text { or } \frac{3}{5}
\end{aligned}
$$

Now, the common difference of $\mathrm{AP}=7 b-3 a$

$$
=7 a r-3 a=a \frac{7}{3}-3=-\frac{2 a}{3}
$$

So, $4^{\text {th }}$ term of $\mathrm{AP}=3 a+3 \frac{-2 a}{3}=a$

question: If three distinct numbers $a, b$ and $c$ are in GP and the equations $a x^{2}+2 b x+c=0$ and $d x^{2}+2 e x+f=0$ have a common root, then which one of the following statements is correct?\\
options: a) $d, e$ and $f$ are in GP\\
solution:
(b) Given, three distinct numbers $a, b$ and $c$ are in GP. $\therefore \quad b^{2}=a c$ and the given quadratic equations


\begin{align*}
& a x^{2}+2 b x+c=0  \tag{ii}\\
& d x^{2}+2 e x+f=0
\end{align*}


For quadratic Eq. (ii), the discriminant $D=(2 b)^{2}-4 a c$

$$
=4\left(b^{2}-a c\right)=0
$$

$\Rightarrow$ Quadratic Eq. (ii) have equal roots, and it is equal to $x=-\frac{b}{a}$, and it is given that quadratic Eqs. (ii) and (iii) have a common root, so

$$
\begin{array}{rrr} 
& d-\frac{b}{a} & \\
\Rightarrow & d b^{2}-2 e b a+\frac{b}{a}+f=0 & \\
\Rightarrow & d(a c)-2 e a b+a^{2} f=0 & \\
\Rightarrow & d c-2 e b+a f=0 & {\left[\because b^{2}=a c\right]} \\
\Rightarrow & 2 e b=d c+a f & {[\because a \neq 0]} \\
\Rightarrow & 2 \frac{e}{b}=\frac{d c}{b^{2}}+\frac{a f}{b^{2}} &
\end{array}
$$

[dividing each term by $b^{2}$ ]

$$
\Rightarrow \quad 2 \frac{e}{b}=\frac{d}{a}+\frac{f}{c} \quad\left[\because b^{2}=a c\right]
$$

So, $\frac{d}{a}, \frac{e}{b}, \frac{f}{c}$ are in AP.

\section*{Alternate Solution}
Given, three distinct numbers $a, b$ and $c$ are in GP. Let $a=a, b=\alpha r, c=a r^{2}$ are in GP, which satisfies $a x^{2}+2 b x+c=0$

$$
\begin{array}{lrl}
\therefore & a x^{2}+2(a r) x+a r^{2}=0 \\
\Rightarrow & x^{2}+2 r x+r^{2}=0 \\
\Rightarrow & (x+r)^{2}=0 \Rightarrow x=-r .
\end{array} \quad[\because a \neq 0]
$$

According to the question, $a x^{2}+2 b x+c=0$ and $d x^{2}+2 e x+f=0$ have a common root.

So, $x=-r$ satisfies $d x^{2}+2 e x+f=0$

$$
\begin{array}{lr}
\therefore & d(-r)^{2}+2 e(-r)+f=0 \\
\Rightarrow & d r^{2}-2 e r+f=0 \\
\Rightarrow & d \frac{c}{a}-2 e \frac{c}{b}+f=0 \\
\Rightarrow & \frac{d}{a}-\frac{2 e}{b}+\frac{f}{c}=0 \\
\Rightarrow & \frac{d}{a}+\frac{f}{c}=\frac{2 e}{b}
\end{array}
$$

$[\because c \neq 0]$

question: The product of three consecutive terms of a GP is 512. If 4 is added to each of the first and the second of these terms, the three terms now form an AP. Then, the sum of the original three terms of the given GP is\\
solution:
Let the three consecutive terms of a GP are $\frac{a}{r}, a$ and $a r$.

Now, according to the question, we have

\[
\begin{array}{lc} 
& \frac{a}{r} \cdot a \cdot a r=512 \\
\Rightarrow & a^{3}=512 \\
\Rightarrow & a=8 \tag{i}
\end{array}
\]

Also, after adding 4 to first two terms, we get

$\frac{8}{r}+4,8+4,8 r$ are in $\mathrm{AP}$

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \Rightarrow \quad 2(12)=\frac{8}{2}+4+8 r \\
& \Rightarrow \quad 24=\frac{8}{r}+8 r+4 \quad \Rightarrow \quad 20=4 \frac{2}{r}+2 r \\
& \Rightarrow \quad 5=\frac{2}{r}+2 r \quad \Rightarrow \quad 2 r^{2}-5 r+2=0 \\
& \Rightarrow \quad 2 r^{2}-4 r-r+2=0 \\
& \Rightarrow 2 r(r-2)-1(r-2)=0 \\
& \Rightarrow \quad(r-2)(2 r-1)=0 \\
& \Rightarrow \quad r=2, \frac{1}{2}
\end{aligned}
$$

Thus, the terms are either $16,8,4$ or $4,8,16$. Hence, required sum $=28$.

question: Let $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{10}$ be a GP. If $\frac{a_{3}}{a_{1}}=25$, then $\frac{a_{9}}{a_{5}}$ equals\\
solution:
Let $r$ be the common ratio of given GP, then we have the following sequence $a_{1}, a_{2}=a_{1} r, a_{3}=a_{1} r^{2}, \ldots, a_{10}=a_{1} r^{9}$

$$
\begin{array}{llrl}
\text { Now, } & a_{3} & =25 a_{1} \\
\Rightarrow & a_{1} r^{2} & =25 a_{1} \\
\Rightarrow & r^{2} & =25
\end{array}
$$

Consider, $\frac{a_{9}}{a_{5}}=\frac{a_{1} r^{8}}{a_{1} r^{4}}=r^{4}=(25)^{2}=5^{4}$

question: Let $a, b$ and $c$ be the 7th, 11th and 13th terms respectively of a non-constant AP. If these are also the three consecutive terms of a GP, then $\frac{a}{c}$ is equal to\\
solution:
Let $A$ be the Ist term of $\mathrm{AP}$ and $d$ be the common difference.

$$
\therefore \quad 7 \text { th term }=a=A+6 d
$$

$[\because n$th term $=A+(n-1) d]$\\
11 th term $=b=A+10 d$

13 th term $=c=A+12 d$

$\because a, b, c$ are also in GP

$\therefore b^{2}=a c$

$\Rightarrow(A+10 d)^{2}=(A+6 d)(A+12 d)$

$\Rightarrow A^{2}+20 A d+100 d^{2}=A^{2}+18 A d+72 d^{2}$

$\Rightarrow 2 A d+28 d^{2}=0$

$\Rightarrow 2 d(A+14 d)=0$

$\Rightarrow d=0$ or $A+14 d=0$

But $d \neq 0$

$[\because$ the series is non constant AP]

$\Rightarrow \quad A=-14 d$

$\therefore \quad a=A+6 d=-14 d+6 d=-8 d$

and $\quad c=A+12 d=-14 d+12 d=-2 d$

$\Rightarrow \quad \frac{a}{c}=\frac{-8 d}{-2 d}=4$

question: If $a, b$ and $c$ be three distinct real numbers in GP and $a+b+c=x b$, then $x$ cannot be\\
solution:
Let $b=a r$ and $c=a r^{2}$, where $r$ is the common ratio.

Then,

$$
a+b+c=x b
$$

$\Rightarrow \quad a+a r+a r^{2}=x a r$

$\Rightarrow \quad 1+r+r^{2}=x r \quad$... (i) $[\because a \neq 0]$

$\Rightarrow \quad x=\frac{1+r+r^{2}}{r}=1+r+\frac{1}{r}$

We know that, $r+\frac{1}{r} \geq 2$ (for $r>0$ )

and $\quad r+\frac{1}{r} \leq-2($ for $r<0)[$ using $\mathrm{AM} \geq \mathrm{GM}]$

$\therefore \quad 1+r+\frac{1}{r} \geq 3$

or $\quad 1+r+\frac{1}{r} \leq-1$

$\Rightarrow \quad x \geq 3$ or $x \leq-1$

$\Rightarrow \quad x \in(-\infty,-1] \cup[3, \infty)$

Hence, $x$ cannot be 2 .

\section*{Alternate Method}
From Eq. (i), we have

$$
\Rightarrow \quad r^{2}+(1-x) r+1=0
$$

For real solution of $r, D \geq 0$.

$$
\begin{array}{lll}
\Rightarrow & (1-x)^{2}-4 \geq 0 & \\
\Rightarrow & x^{2}-2 x-3 \geq 0 & \\
\Rightarrow & (x-3)(x+1) \geq 0 & \\
& -1 & 3
\end{array}
$$

\begin{center}
\includegraphics[max width=\textwidth]{2024_07_07_2dde8fd41ae9e87c5267g-13}
\end{center}

$\Rightarrow x \in(-\infty,-1] \cup[3, \infty)$

$\therefore x$ cannot be 2 .

question: If the 2nd, 5th and 9 th terms of a non-constant AP are in GP, then the common ratio of this GP is\\
solution:
Let $a$ be the first term and $d$ be the common difference. Then, we have $a+d, a+4 d, a+8 d$ in GP,

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \text { i.e. } \quad(a+4 d)^{2}=(a+d)(a+8 d) \\
& \Rightarrow \quad a^{2}+16 d^{2}+8 a d=a^{2}+8 a d+a d+8 d^{2} \\
& \Rightarrow \quad 8 d^{2}=a d \\
& \Rightarrow \quad 8 d=a \quad[\because d \neq 0]
\end{aligned}
$$

Now, common ratio,

$$
r=\frac{a+4 d}{a+d}=\frac{8 d+4 d}{8 d+d}=\frac{12 d}{9 d}=\frac{4}{3}
$$

question:
Let $f(x)=a x^{2}+b x+c, a \neq 0$ and $\Delta=b^{2}-4 a c$. If $\alpha+\beta$, $\alpha^{2}+\beta^{2}$ and $\alpha^{3}+\beta^{3}$ are in GP, then


$(2005,1 M)$\\
solution:
Since, $(\alpha+\beta),\left(\alpha^{2}+\beta^{2}\right),\left(\alpha^{3}+\beta^{3}\right)$ are in GP.

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \Rightarrow \quad\left(\alpha^{2}+\beta^{2}\right)^{2}=(\alpha+\beta)\left(\alpha^{3}+\beta^{3}\right) \\
& \Rightarrow \quad \alpha^{4}+\beta^{4}+2 \alpha^{2} \beta^{2}=\alpha^{4}+\beta^{4}+\alpha \beta^{3}+\beta \alpha^{3} \\
& \Rightarrow \quad \alpha \beta\left(\alpha^{2}+\beta^{2}-2 \alpha \beta\right)=0 \\
& \Rightarrow \quad \alpha \beta(\alpha-\beta)^{2}=0 \\
& \Rightarrow \quad \alpha \beta=0 \quad \text { or } \quad \alpha=\beta \\
& \Rightarrow \quad \frac{c}{a}=0 \text { or } \quad \Delta=0 \\
& \Rightarrow \quad c \Delta=0
\end{aligned}
$$

question: Let $a, b, c$ be in an AP and $a^{2}, b^{2}, c^{2}$ be in GP. If $a<b<c$ and $a+b+c=\frac{3}{2}$, then the value of $a$ is\\
solution:
Since, $a, b$ and $c$ are in an AP.

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \text { Let } \quad a=A-D, b=A, c=A+D \\
& \text { Given, } \quad a+b+c=\frac{3}{2} \\
& \Rightarrow \quad(A-D)+A+(A+D)=\frac{3}{2} \\
& \Rightarrow \quad 3 A=\frac{3}{2} \Rightarrow A=\frac{1}{2}
\end{aligned}
$$

$\therefore$ The number are $\frac{1}{2}-D, \frac{1}{2}, \frac{1}{2}+D$.

Also, $\frac{1}{2}-D^{2}, \frac{1}{4}, \frac{1}{2}+D^{2}$ are in GP.

$\therefore \quad \frac{1}{4}^{2}=\frac{1}{2}-D^{2} \frac{1}{2}+D^{2} \Rightarrow \frac{1}{16}=\frac{1}{4}-D^{2}{ }^{2}$

$\Rightarrow \quad \frac{1}{4}-D^{2}= \pm \frac{1}{4} \Rightarrow D^{2}=\frac{1}{2} \Rightarrow D= \pm \frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}$

$\therefore \quad a=\frac{1}{2} \pm \frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}$

So, out of the given values, $a=\frac{1}{2}-\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}$ is the right choice.

$$

question: Let $\alpha, \beta$ be the roots of $x^{2}-x+p=0$ and $\gamma, \delta$ be the roots of $x^{2}-4 x+q=0$. If $\alpha, \beta, \gamma, \delta$ are in GP, then the integer values of $p$ and $q$ respectively are\\
solution:
\begin{aligned}
\alpha+\beta & =1 \\
\alpha \beta & =p
