question: Of the three independent events $E_{1}, E_{2}$ and $E_{3}$, the probability that only $E_{1}$ occurs is $\alpha$, only $E_{2}$ occurs is $\beta$ and only $E_{3}$ occurs is $\gamma$. Let the probability $p$ that none of events $E_{1}, E_{2}$ or $E_{3}$ occurs satisfy the equations
solution:
PLAN

Forthe events to be independent

$$
\begin{aligned}
P\left(E_{1} \cap E_{2} \cap E_{3}\right) & =P\left(E_{1}\right) \cdot P\left(E_{2}\right) \cdot P\left(E_{3}\right) \\
P\left(E_{1} \cap \bar{E}_{2} \cap \bar{E}_{3}\right) & =P\left(\text { only } E_{1} \text { occurs }\right) \\
& =P\left(E_{1}\right) \cdot\left(1-P\left(E_{2}\right)\right)\left(1-P\left(E_{3}\right)\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

Let $x, y$ and $z$ be probabilities of $E_{1}, E_{2}$ and $E_{3}$, respectively.


\begin{align*}
& \therefore \quad \alpha=x(1-y)(1-z)  \tag{i}\\
& \beta=(1-x) \cdot y(1-z)  \tag{ii}\\
& \mathrm{Y}=(1-x)(1-y) z  \tag{iii}\\
& \Rightarrow \quad p=(1-x)(1-y)(1-z)  \tag{iv}\\
& \text { Given, }(\alpha-2 \beta) p=\alpha \beta \text { and }(\beta-3 \gamma) p=2 \beta \gamma \tag{v}
\end{align*}


From above equations, $x=2 y$ and $y=3 z$

$$
\begin{array}{ll}
\therefore & x=6 z \\
\Rightarrow & \frac{x}{z}=6
\end{array}
$$

For an initial screening of an admission test, a candidate is given fifty problems to solve. If the probability that the candidate can solve any problem is $\frac{4}{5}$, then the probability that he is unable to solve less than two problem is\\
solution:
Given that, there are 50 problems to solve in an admission test and probability that the candidate can solve any problem is $\frac{4}{5}=q$ (say). So, probability that the candidate cannot solve a problem is $p=1-q=1-\frac{4}{5}=\frac{1}{5}$.

Now, let $X$ be a random variable which denotes the number of problems that the candidate is unable to solve. Then, $X$ follows binomial distribution with parameters $n=50$ and $p=\frac{1}{5}$.

Now, according to binomial probability distribution concept

$$
P(X=r)={ }^{50} C_{r} \frac{1}{5}^{r} \quad \frac{4}{5}^{50-r}, r=0,1, \ldots, 50
$$

$\therefore$ Required probability

$$
\begin{aligned}
& =P(X<2)=P(X=0)+P(X=1) \\
& ={ }^{50} C_{0} \frac{4}{5}^{50}+{ }^{50} C_{1} \frac{4^{49}}{(5)^{50}}=\frac{4}{5}{ }^{49} \frac{4}{5}+\frac{50}{5}=\frac{54}{5} \frac{4}{5}^{49}
\end{aligned}
$$

question: Let a random variable $X$ have a binomial distribution with mean 8 and variance 4 . If $P(X \leq 2)=\frac{k}{2^{16}}$, then $k$ is equal to\\
solution:
Let for the given random variable ' $X$ ' the binomial probability distribution have $n$-number of independent trials and probability of success and failure are $p$ and $q$ respectively. According to the question, Mean $=n p=8$ and variance $=n p q=4$


\begin{align*}
& \therefore \quad q=\frac{1}{2} \Rightarrow p=1-q=\frac{1}{2} \\
& \text { Now, } n \times \frac{1}{2}=8 \Rightarrow n=16 \\
& P(X=r){ }^{16} C_{r} \frac{1}{2}^{16} \\
& \therefore \quad P(X \leq 2)=P(X=0)+P(X=1)+P(X=2) \\
& ={ }^{16} C_{0} \frac{1}{2}{ }^{16}+{ }^{16} C_{1} \frac{1}{2}{ }^{16}+{ }^{16} C_{2} \frac{1}{2}{ }^{16} \\
& =\frac{1+16+120}{2^{16}}=\frac{137}{2^{16}}=\frac{k}{2^{16}}  \tag{given}\\
& \Rightarrow \quad k=137
\end{align*}

question: Minimum number of times a fair coin must be tossed so that the probability of getting atleast one head is more than $99 \%$ is\\
The minimum number of times one has to toss a fair coin so that the probability of observing atleast one head is atleast $90 \%$ is\\
solution:
The required probability of observing atleast one head

$$
\begin{aligned}
& =1-P \text { (no head) } \\
& =1-\frac{1}{2^{n}} \quad[\text { let number of toss are } n] \\
& \because P(\text { Head })=P(\text { Tail })=\frac{1}{2}
\end{aligned}
$$

According to the question, $1-\frac{1}{2^{n}} \geq \frac{90}{100}$

$\Rightarrow \frac{1}{2^{n}} \leq \frac{1}{10} \Rightarrow 2^{n} \geq 10 \quad \Rightarrow \quad n \geq 4$

So, minimum number of times one has to toss a fair coin so that the probability of observing atleast one head is atleast $90 \%$ is 4 .

question: In a game, a man wins ₹ 100 if he gets 5 or 6 on a throw of a fair die and loses ₹ 50 for getting any other number on the die. If he decides to throw the die either till he gets a five or a six or to a maximum of three throws, then his expected gain/loss (in rupees) is\\
solution:
Let $p$ and $q$ represents the probability of success and failure in a trial respectively. Then,

$p=P(5$ or 6$)=\frac{2}{6}=\frac{1}{3}$ and $q=1-p=\frac{4}{6}=\frac{2}{3}$.

Now, as the man decides to throw the die either till he gets a five or a six or to a maximum of three throws, so he can get the success in first, second and third throw or not get the success in any of the three throws.

So, the expected gain/loss (in ₹)

$$
\begin{aligned}
& =(p \times 100)+q p(-50+100) \\
& \quad+q^{2} p(-50-50+100)+q^{3}(-50-50-50) \\
& =\frac{1}{3} \times 100+\frac{2}{3} \times \frac{1}{3}(50)+\frac{2}{3}^{2}{ }^{\frac{1}{3}}(0)+\frac{2}{3}^{3}
\end{aligned}
$$

\section*{Probability 125}
$=\frac{100}{3}+\frac{100}{9}+0-\frac{1200}{27}$

$=\frac{900+300-1200}{27}=\frac{1200-1200}{27}=0$

question: If the probability of hitting a target by a shooter in any shot, is $\frac{1}{3}$, then the minimum number of independent shots at the target required by him so that the probability of hitting the target at least once is greater than $\frac{5}{6}$, is\\
solution:
The probability of hitting a target at least once $=1-$ (probability of not hitting the target in any trial) $=1-{ }^{n} C_{0} p^{0} q^{n}$

where $n$ is the number of independent trials and $p$ and $q$ are the probability of success and failure respectively.

[by using binomial distribution]

Here, $\quad p=\frac{1}{3}$ and $\quad q=1-p=1-\frac{1}{3}=\frac{2}{3}$

According to the question, $1-{ }^{n} C_{0} \frac{1}{3}^{0} \quad \frac{2}{3}{ }^{n}>\frac{5}{6}$

$\Rightarrow \frac{2}{3}^{n}<1-\frac{5}{6} \Rightarrow \frac{2}{3}^{n}<\frac{1}{6}$

Clearly, minimum value of $n$ is 5 .

question: Two cards are drawn successively with replacement from a well shuffled deck of 52 cards. Let $X$ denote the random variable of number of aces obtained in the two drawn cards. Then, $P(X=1)+P(X=2)$ equals\\
solution:
Let $p=$ probability of getting an ace in a draw $=$ probability of success

and $q=$ probability of not getting an ace in a draw $=$ probability of failure

Then, $\quad p=\frac{4}{52}=\frac{1}{13}$

and $\quad q=1-p=1-\frac{1}{13}=\frac{12}{13}$

Here, number of trials, $n=2$

Clearly, $X$ follows binomial distribution with parameter $n=2$ and $p=\frac{1}{13}$.

Now, $\quad P(X=x)={ }^{2} C_{x} \frac{1}{13}^{x} \quad \frac{12}{13}{ }^{2-x}, x=0,1,2$

$$
\therefore \quad P(X=1)+P(X=2)
$$

$$
\begin{aligned}
& ={ }^{2} C_{1} \frac{1}{13}^{1} \frac{12}{13}+{ }^{2} C_{2} \frac{1}{13}^{2} \frac{12}{13}^{0} \\
& =2 \frac{12}{169}+\frac{1}{169} \\
& =\frac{24}{169}+\frac{1}{169}=\frac{25}{169}
\end{aligned}
$$

question: A box contains 15 green and 10 yellow balls. If 10 balls are randomly drawn one-by-one with replacement, then the variance of the number of green balls drawn is\\
solution:
Given box contains 15 green and 10 yellow balls.

$\therefore$ Total number of balls $=15+10=25$

$P($ green balls $)=\frac{15}{25}=\frac{3}{5}=p=$ Probability of success

$P($ yellow balls $)=\frac{10}{25}=\frac{2}{5}=q=$ Probability of unsuccess and $n=10=$ Number of trials.

$\therefore$ Variance $=n p q=10 \times \frac{3}{5} \times \frac{2}{5}=\frac{12}{5}$

question:
India plays two matches each with West Indies and Australia. In any match the probabilities of India getting points 0,1 and 2 are $0.45,0.05$ and 0.50 , respectively. Assuming that the outcomes are independent. The probability of India getting at least 7 points, is
\\
solution:
India play 4 matches and getting at least 7 points. It can answers $={ }^{5} C_{4} \frac{1}{3}{ }^{4} \cdot \frac{2}{3}+{ }^{5} C_{5} \frac{1}{3}{ }^{5}=5 \cdot \frac{2}{3^{5}}+\frac{1}{3^{5}}=\frac{11}{3^{5}}$ only be possible in $W W W D$ or $W W W W$ position, where $W$ represents two points and $D$ represents one point.

Therefore, the probability of the required event

$$
\begin{aligned}
& ={ }^{4} C_{3}(0.05)(0.5)^{3}+{ }^{4} C_{4}(0.5)^{4} \\
& =[4(0.05)+0.5](0.5)^{3}=0.0875
\end{aligned}
$$

question: One hundred identical coins, each with probability $p$, of showing up heads are tossed once. If $0<p<1$ and the probability of heads showing on 50 coins is equal to that of heads showing on 51 coins, then the value of $p$ is\\
solution:
Let $X$ be the number of coins showing heads. Let $X$ be a binomial variate with parameters $n=100$ and $p$.

Since,

$P(X=50)=P(X=51)$

$\Rightarrow \quad{ }^{100} C_{50} p^{50}(1-p)^{50}={ }^{100} C_{51}(p)^{51}(1-p)^{49}$

$\Rightarrow \quad \frac{(100)!}{(50!)(50!)} \cdot \frac{(51!) \times(49!)}{100!}=\frac{p}{1-p} \Rightarrow \frac{p}{1-p}=\frac{51}{50}$

$$
\Rightarrow \quad p=\frac{51}{101}
$$

Let $A=\left[\begin{array}{cc}\cos \alpha & -\sin \alpha \\ \sin \alpha & \cos \alpha\end{array}\right],(\alpha \in R) \quad$ such that $A^{32}=\left[\begin{array}{cc}0 & -1 \\ 1 & 0\end{array}\right]$. Then, a value of $\alpha$ is
solution:
Given, matrix $A=\begin{array}{cc}\cos \alpha & -\sin \alpha \\ \sin \alpha & \cos \alpha\end{array}$

$\therefore A^{2}=\begin{array}{cccc}\cos \alpha & -\sin \alpha & \cos \alpha & -\sin \alpha \\ \sin \alpha & \cos \alpha & \sin \alpha & \cos \alpha\end{array}$

$=\cos ^{2} \alpha-\sin ^{2} \alpha \quad-\cos \alpha \sin \alpha-\sin \alpha \cos \alpha$

$=\sin \alpha \cos \alpha+\cos \alpha \sin \alpha \quad-\sin ^{2} \alpha+\cos ^{2} \alpha$

$=\begin{array}{cc}\cos 2 \alpha & -\sin 2 \alpha \\ \sin 2 \alpha & \cos 2 \alpha\end{array}$

Similarly,

$$
A^{n}=\begin{array}{cc}
\cos (n \alpha) & -\sin (n \alpha) \\
\sin (n \alpha) & \cos (n \alpha)
\end{array}, n \in N
$$

$\Rightarrow A^{32}=\begin{array}{ll}\cos (32 \alpha) & -\sin (32 \alpha) \\ \sin (32 \alpha) & \cos (32 \alpha)\end{array}=\begin{array}{cc}0 & -1 \\ 1 & 0\end{array}$ (given)

So, $\cos (32 \alpha)=0$ and $\sin (32 \alpha)=1$

$\Rightarrow \quad 32 \alpha=\frac{\pi}{2} \Rightarrow \alpha=\frac{\pi}{64}$

question: Let $z=\frac{-1+\sqrt{3} i}{2}$, where $i=\sqrt{-1}$, and $r, s \in\{1,2,3\}$. Let $P=\begin{array}{cc}(-z)^{r} & z^{2 s} \\ z^{2 s} & z^{r}\end{array}$ and $I$ be the identity matrix of order 2 . Then, the total number of ordered pairs $(r, s)$ for which $P^{2}=-I$ is

A value of $\theta \in(0, \pi / 3)$, for which

$\left|\begin{array}{ccc}1+\cos ^{2} \theta & \sin ^{2} \theta & 4 \cos 6 \theta \\ \cos ^{2} \theta & 1+\sin ^{2} \theta & 4 \cos 6 \theta \\ \cos ^{2} \theta & \sin ^{2} \theta & 1+4 \cos 6 \theta\end{array}\right|=0$, is \\
solution:
Let $\Delta=\left|\begin{array}{ccc}1+\cos ^{2} \theta & \sin ^{2} \theta & 4 \cos 6 \theta \\ \cos ^{2} \theta & 1+\sin ^{2} \theta & 4 \cos 6 \theta \\ \cos ^{2} \theta & \sin ^{2} \theta & 1+4 \cos 6 \theta\end{array}\right|=0$

Applying $C_{1} \rightarrow C_{1}+C_{2}$, we get

$$
\Delta=\left|\begin{array}{ccc}
2 & \sin ^{2} \theta & 4 \cos 6 \theta \\
2 & 1+\sin ^{2} \theta & 4 \cos 6 \theta \\
1 & \sin ^{2} \theta & 1+4 \cos 6 \theta
\end{array}\right|=0
$$

Applying $R_{1} \rightarrow R_{1}-2 R_{3}$ and $R_{2} \rightarrow R_{2}-2 R_{3}$, we get

$$
\Delta=\left|\begin{array}{ccc}
0 & -\sin ^{2} \theta & -2-4 \cos 6 \theta \\
0 & 1-\sin ^{2} \theta & -2-4 \cos 6 \theta \\
1 & \sin ^{2} \theta & 1+4 \cos 6 \theta
\end{array}\right|=0
$$

On expanding w.r.t. $C_{1}$, we get

$\Rightarrow \sin ^{2} \theta(2+4 \cos 6 \theta)+(2+4 \cos 6 \theta)\left(1-\sin ^{2} \theta\right)=0$

$$
\Rightarrow 2+4 \cos 6 \theta=0 \Rightarrow \cos 6 \theta=-\frac{1}{2}=\cos \frac{2 \pi}{3}
$$

$$
\Rightarrow \quad 6 \theta=\frac{2 \pi}{3} \Rightarrow \theta=\frac{\pi}{9} \quad \because \theta \in 0, \frac{\pi}{3}
$$

question: The sum of the real roots of the equation $\left|\begin{array}{ccc}x & -6 & -1 \\ 2 & -3 x & x-3 \\ -3 & 2 x & x+2\end{array}\right|=0$, is equal to\\
solution:
Given equation

$$
\left|\begin{array}{ccc}
x & -6 & -1 \\
2 & -3 x & x-3 \\
-3 & 2 x & x+2
\end{array}\right|=0
$$

On expansion of determinant along $R_{1}$, we get

$$
\begin{aligned}
& x[(-3 x)(x+2)-2 x(x-3)]+6[2(x+2)+3(x-3)] \\
& \Rightarrow \\
& \Rightarrow \quad x\left[-3 x^{2}-6 x-2 x^{2}+6 x\right]+6[2 x+4+3 x-9] \\
& \Rightarrow \quad x\left(-5 x^{2}\right)+6(5 x-5 x]-1(-5 x)=0 \\
& \Rightarrow \quad-1[4 x-9 x) \\
& \Rightarrow \quad-5 x^{3}+30 x-30+5 x=0 \\
& \Rightarrow \quad 5 x^{3}-35 x+30=0 \quad \Rightarrow \quad x^{3}-7 x+6=0 .
\end{aligned}
$$

Since all roots are real

$$
\therefore \text { Sum of roots }=-\frac{\text { coefficient of } x^{2}}{\text { coefficient of } x^{3}}=0
$$

question: If $\Delta_{1}=\left|\begin{array}{ccc}x & \sin \theta & \cos \theta \\ -\sin \theta & -x & 1 \\ \cos \theta & 1 & x\end{array}\right|$ and $\Delta_{2}=\left|\begin{array}{ccc}x & \sin 2 \theta & \cos 2 \theta \\ -\sin 2 \theta & -x & 1 \\ \cos 2 \theta & 1 & x\end{array}\right|, x \neq 0$, then for all $\theta \in 0, \frac{\pi}{2}$
solution:
Given determinants are

$$
\Delta_{1}=\left|\begin{array}{ccc}
x & \sin \theta & \cos \theta \\
-\sin \theta & -x & 1 \\
\cos \theta & 1 & x
\end{array}\right|
$$

$$
\begin{aligned}
& =-x^{3}+\sin \theta \cos \theta-\sin \theta \cos \theta+x \cos ^{2} \theta-x+x \sin ^{2} \theta \\
& =-x^{3}
\end{aligned}
$$

and $\Delta_{2}=\left|\begin{array}{ccc}x & \sin 2 \theta & \cos 2 \theta \\ -\sin 2 \theta & -x & 1 \\ \cos 2 \theta & 1 & x\end{array}\right|, x \neq 0$ $=-x^{3}\left(\right.$ similarly as $\left.\Delta_{1}\right)$

So, according to options, we get $\Delta_{1}+\Delta_{2}=-2 x^{3}$

question: If \left[\begin{array}{ll}1 & 1 \\ 0 & 1\end{array}\right] \cdot\left[\begin{array}{ll}1 & 2 \\ 0 & 1\end{array}\right] \cdot\left[\begin{array}{ll}1 & 3 \\ 0 & 1\end{array}\right] \cdots\left[\begin{array}{cc}1 & n-1 \\ 0 & 1\end{array}\right]=\left[\begin{array}{cc}1 & 78 \\ 0 & 1\end{array}\right]$,then the inverse of \left[\begin{array}{ll}1 & n \\ 0 & 1\end{array}\right] is

Let $\alpha$ and $\beta$ be the roots of the equation $x^{2}+x+1=0$. Then, for $y \neq 0$ in $\mathbf{R}$,

$\left|\begin{array}{ccc}y+1 & \alpha & \beta \\ \alpha & y+\beta & 1 \\ \beta & 1 & y+\alpha\end{array}\right|$ is equal to\\
solution:
Given, quadratic equation is $x^{2}+x+1=0$ having roots $\alpha, \beta$.

Then, $\alpha+\beta=-1$ and $\alpha \beta=1$

Now, given determinant

$$
\Delta=\left|\begin{array}{ccc}
y+1 & \alpha & \beta \\
\alpha & y+\beta & 1 \\
\beta & 1 & y+\alpha
\end{array}\right|
$$

On applying $R_{1} \rightarrow R_{1}+R_{2}+R_{3}$, we get

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \Delta=\left|\begin{array}{ccc}
y+1+\alpha+\beta & y+1+\alpha+\beta & y+1+\alpha+\beta \\
\alpha & y+\beta & 1 \\
\beta & 1 & y+\alpha
\end{array}\right| \\
&=\left|\begin{array}{ccc}
y & y & y \\
\alpha & y+\beta & 1 \\
\beta & 1 & y+\alpha
\end{array}\right| \\
& \quad[\because \alpha+\beta=-1]
\end{aligned}
$$

On applying $C_{2} \rightarrow C_{2}-C_{1}$ and $C_{3} \rightarrow C_{3}-C_{1}$, we get

$$
\begin{aligned}
\Delta & =\left|\begin{array}{ccc}
y & 0 & 0 \\
\alpha & y+\beta-\alpha & 1-\alpha \\
\beta & 1-\beta & y+\alpha-\beta
\end{array}\right| \\
& =y[(y+(\beta-\alpha))(y-(\beta-\alpha))-(1-\alpha)(1-\beta)]
\end{aligned}
$$

[expanding along $R_{1}$ ]

$=y\left[y^{2}-(\beta-\alpha)^{2}-(1-\alpha-\beta+\alpha \beta)\right]$

$=y\left[y^{2}-\beta^{2}-\alpha^{2}+2 \alpha \beta-1+(\alpha+\beta)-\alpha \beta\right]$

$=y\left[y^{2}-(\alpha+\beta)^{2}+2 \alpha \beta+2 \alpha \beta-1+(\alpha+\beta)-\alpha \beta\right]$

$=y\left[y^{2}-1+3-1-1\right]=y^{3} \quad[\because \alpha+\beta=-1$ and $\alpha \beta=1]$

question: If $A=\begin{array}{ccc}1 & \sin \theta & 1 \\ -1 & 1 & \sin \theta \\ -\sin \theta & 1\end{array}$; then for all $\theta \in \frac{3 \pi}{4}, \frac{5 \pi}{4}$, $\operatorname{det}(A)$ lies in the interval\\
solution:
Given matrix $A=-\sin \theta \quad 1 \quad \sin \theta$


\begin{align*}
& \left.\Rightarrow \operatorname{det}(A) \neq A|=| \begin{array}{ccc}
-1 & -\sin \theta & 1 \\
1 & \sin \theta & 1 \\
-\sin \theta & 1 & \sin \theta \\
-1 & -\sin \theta & 1
\end{array} \right\rvert\, \\
& =1\left(1+\sin ^{2} \theta\right)-\sin \theta(-\sin \theta+\sin \theta)+1\left(\sin ^{2} \theta+1\right) \\
& \Rightarrow|A|=2\left(1+\sin ^{2} \theta\right)
\end{align*}


As we know that, for $\theta \in \frac{3 \pi}{4}, \frac{5 \pi}{4}$

$$
\sin \theta \in-\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}, \frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}
$$

$\Rightarrow \quad \sin ^{2} \theta \in 0, \frac{1}{2} \quad \Rightarrow 1+\sin ^{2} \theta \in 0+1, \frac{1}{2}+1$

$\Rightarrow 1+\sin ^{2} \theta \in 1, \frac{3}{2}$

$\Rightarrow 2\left(1+\sin ^{2} \theta\right) \in[2,3) \Rightarrow|A| \in[2,3) \subset \frac{3}{2}, 3$

question:

  $$
  \left|\begin{array}{ccc}

$=(a+b+c)(x+a+b+c)^{2}, x \neq 0$ and $a+b+c \neq 0$, then $x$ is equal to\\
solution:

Applying $R_{1} \rightarrow R_{1}+R_{2}+R_{3}$, we get

$$

a+b+c & R_{1}+R_{2}+R_{3}, \text { we get } \\

& \quad=(a+b+c)\left|\begin{array}{ccc}
1 & 1 & 1 \\

Now, expanding along $R_{1}$, we get

$$

=(a+b+c)^{3}=(a+b+c)(x+a+b+c)^{2} \text { (given) }

$[\because x \neq 0]$

value of $\frac{\operatorname{det}(A)}{b}$ is\\

Let $d \in R$, and

  $$
  A=\left[\begin{array}{ccc}
  -2 & 4+d & (\sin \theta)-2 \\
  1 & (\sin \theta)+2 & d \\
  5 & (2 \sin \theta)-d & (-\sin \theta)+2+2 d
  \end{array}\right], \theta \in[\theta, 2 \pi]
  $$

the minimum value of $\operatorname{det}(\mathrm{A})$ is 8 , then a value of $d$ is\\
solution:
Given,

$$
A=\begin{array}{ccc}
-2 & 4+d & (\sin \theta)-2 \\
1 & (\sin \theta)+2 & d \\
5 & (2 \sin \theta)-d & (-\sin \theta)+2+2 d
\end{array}
$$

\section*{142 Matrices and Determinants}
$$
\begin{aligned}
\therefore|A| & =\left|\begin{array}{ccc}
-2 & 4+d & (\sin \theta)-2 \\
1 & (\sin \theta)+2 & d \\
5 & (2 \sin \theta)-d & (-\sin \theta)+2+2 d
\end{array}\right| \\
& =\left|\begin{array}{ccc}
-2 & 4+d & (\sin \theta)-2 \\
1 & (\sin \theta)+2 & d \\
1 & 0 & 0
\end{array}\right| \\
& =1[(4+d) d-(\sin \theta+2)(\sin \theta-2)] \\
& =\left(d^{2}+4 d-\sin ^{2} \theta+4\right)\left(\text { expanding along } R_{3}\right) \\
& =\left(d^{2}+4 d+4\right)-\sin ^{2} \theta \\
& =(d+2)^{2}-\sin ^{2} \theta
\end{aligned}
$$

Note that $|A|$ will be minimum if $\sin ^{2} \theta$ is maximum i.e. if $\sin ^{2} \theta$ takes value 1 .

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \because \quad|A|_{\min }=8, \\
& \text { therefore } \quad(d+2)^{2}-1=8 \\
& \Rightarrow \quad(d+2)^{2}=9 \\
& \Rightarrow \quad d+2= \pm 3 \\
& \Rightarrow \quad d=1,-5
\end{aligned}
$$

question:
If $2 x \quad x-4 \quad 2 x=(A+B x)(x-A)^{2}$, then the $2 x \quad 2 x \quad x-4$

ordered pair $(A, B)$ is equal to\\
solution:
Given,

$$
\begin{aligned}
& x-4 \quad 2 x \quad 2 x \\
& 2 x \quad x-4 \quad 2 x=(A+B x)(x-A)^{2} \\
& 2 x \quad 2 x \quad x-4 \\
& \Rightarrow \text { Apply } C_{1} \rightarrow C_{1}+C_{2}+C_{3} \\
& 5 x-4 \quad 2 x \quad 2 x \\
& 5 x-4 \quad x-4 \quad 2 x=(A+B x)(x-A)^{2} \\
& 5 x-4 \quad 2 x \quad x-4
\end{aligned}
$$

Taking common $(5 x-4)$ from $C_{1}$, we get

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \begin{array}{ccc}
1 & 2 x & 2 x
\end{array} \\
& (5 x-4) 1 \quad x-4 \quad 2 x \quad=(A+B x)(x-A)^{2} \\
& 1 \quad 2 x \quad x-4
\end{aligned}
$$

Apply $R_{2} \rightarrow R_{2}-R_{1}$ and $R_{3} \rightarrow R_{3}-R_{1}$

$$
\therefore(5 x-4) \begin{array}{ccc}
1 & 2 x & 0 \\
0 & -x-4 & 0 \\
0 & 0 & -x-4
\end{array}=(A+B x)(x-A)^{2}
$$

Expanding along $C_{1}$, we get

$$
(5 x-4)(x+4)^{2}=(A+B x)(x-A)^{2}
$$

Equating, we get, $A=-4$ and $B=5$

question: Let $\omega$ be a complex number such that $2 \omega+1=z$, where $z=\sqrt{-3}$. If $\left|\begin{array}{ccc}1 & 1 & 1 \\ 1 & -\omega^{2}-1 & \omega^{2} \\ 1 & \omega^{2} & \omega^{7}\end{array}\right|=3 k$, then $k$ is equal to\\
solution:
Given, $2 \omega+1=z$

$$
\begin{aligned}
\Rightarrow & 2 \omega+1 & =\sqrt{-3} & \\
\Rightarrow & \omega & =\frac{-1+\sqrt{3} i}{2} &
\end{aligned}
$$

Since, $\omega$ is cube root of unity.

$$
\therefore \quad \omega^{2}=\frac{-1-\sqrt{3} i}{2} \text { and } \omega^{3 n}=1
$$

$$
\text { Now, }\left|\begin{array}{ccc}
1 & 1 & 1 \\
1 & -\omega^{2}-1 & \omega^{2} \\
1 & \omega^{2} & \omega^{7}
\end{array}\right|=3 k
$$

$$
\Rightarrow \quad\left|\begin{array}{ccc}
1 & 1 & 1 \\
1 & \omega & \omega^{2} \\
1 & \omega^{2} & \omega
\end{array}\right|=3 k
$$

$$
\left[\because 1+\omega+\omega^{2}=0 \text { and } \omega^{7}=\left(\omega^{3}\right)^{2} \cdot \omega=\omega\right]
$$

On applying $R_{1} \rightarrow R_{1}+R_{2}+R_{3}$, we get

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \left|\begin{array}{ccc}
3 & 1+\omega+\omega^{2} & 1+\omega+\omega^{2} \\
1 & \omega & \omega^{2} \\
1 & \omega^{2} & \omega
\end{array}\right|=3 k \\
& \Rightarrow \quad\left|\begin{array}{ccc}
3 & 0 & 0 \\
1 & \omega & \omega^{2} \\
1 & \omega^{2} & \omega
\end{array}\right|=3 k \\
& \Rightarrow \quad 3\left(\omega^{2}-\omega^{4}\right)=3 k \\
& \Rightarrow \quad\left(\omega^{2}-\omega\right)=k \\
& \therefore \quad k=\frac{-1-\sqrt{3} i}{2}-\frac{-1+\sqrt{3} i}{2}=-\sqrt{3} i=-z
\end{aligned}
$$

\\

Since,

$$

$$

question: The number of distinct real roots of $\left|\begin{array}{lll}\sin x & \cos x & \cos x \\ \cos x & \sin x & \cos x \\ \cos x & \cos x & \sin x\end{array}\right|=0$ in the interval $-\frac{\pi}{4} \leq x \leq \frac{\pi}{4}$ is\\
solution:
Given, $\begin{array}{lll}\sin x & \cos x & \cos x \\ \cos x & \sin x & \cos x=0\end{array}$ $\cos x \quad \cos x \quad \sin x$

Applying $C_{1} \rightarrow C_{1}+C_{2}+C_{3}$

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \sin x+2 \cos x \quad \cos x \quad \cos x \\
& =\sin x+2 \cos x \sin x \quad \cos x \\
& \sin x+2 \cos x \quad \cos x \quad \sin x \\
& =(2 \cos x+\sin x) \begin{array}{lll}
1 & \cos x & \cos x \\
1 & \sin x & \cos x=0
\end{array}=0 \\
& 1 \cos x \sin x
\end{aligned}
$$

Applying $R_{2} \rightarrow R_{2}-R_{1}, R_{3} \rightarrow R_{3}-R_{1}$

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \Rightarrow(2 \cos x+\sin x) \begin{array}{ccc}
1 & \cos x & \cos x \\
0 & \sin x-\cos x & 0 \\
0 & 0 & \sin x-\cos x
\end{array}=0 \\
& \Rightarrow \quad(2 \cos x+\sin x)(\sin x-\cos x)^{2}=0 \\
& \Rightarrow \quad 2 \cos x+\sin x=0 \text { or } \sin x-\cos x=0 \\
& \Rightarrow \quad 2 \cos x=-\sin x \text { or } \sin x=\cos x \\
& \Rightarrow \cot x=-1 / 2 \text { gives no solution in }-\frac{\pi}{4} \leq x \leq \frac{\pi}{4} \\
& \text { and } \sin x=\cos x \Rightarrow \tan x=1 \Rightarrow x=\pi / 4
\end{aligned}
$$

question:
If $f(x)=\left|\begin{array}{ccc}1 & x & x+1 \\ 2 x & x(x-1) & (x+1) x \\ 3 x(x-1) & x(x-1)(x-2) & (x+1) x(x-1)\end{array}\right|$,

then $f(100)$ is equal to\\
solution:
Given,

$$
f(x)=\begin{array}{ccc}
1 & x & x+1 \\
2 x & x(x-1) & (x+1) x \\
3 x(x-1) & x(x-1)(x-2) & (x+1) x(x-1)
\end{array}
$$

Applying $C_{3} \rightarrow C_{3}-\left(C_{1}+C_{2}\right)$

$$
\begin{aligned}
& =\begin{array}{ccc}
1 & x & 0 \\
2 x & x(x-1) & 0 \\
3 x(x-1) & x(x-1)(x-2) & 0
\end{array}=0 \\
& \therefore \quad f(x)=0 \Rightarrow f(100)=0
\end{aligned}
$$

question:
The parameter on which the value of the determinant $\left|\begin{array}{ccc}1 & a & a^{2} \\ \cos (p-d) x & \cos p x & \cos (p+d) x \\ \sin (p-d) x & \sin p x & \sin (p+d) x\end{array}\right|$

does not depend upon, is\\
solution:
Let $\Delta=\cos (p-d) x \cos p x \cos (p+d) x$ $\sin (p-d) x \quad \sin p x \quad \sin (p+d) x$

Applying $C_{1} \rightarrow C_{1}+C_{3}$

$\Rightarrow \Delta=\left|\begin{array}{ccc}1+a^{2} & a & a^{2} \\ \cos (p-d) x+\cos (p+d) x & \cos p x & \cos (p+d) x \\ \sin (p-d) x+\sin (p+d) x & \sin p x & \sin (p+d) x\end{array}\right|$

$\Rightarrow \Delta=\left|\begin{array}{ccc}1+a^{2} & a & a^{2} \\ 2 \cos p x \cos d x & \cos p x & \cos (p+d) x \\ 2 \sin p x \cos d x & \sin p x & \sin (p+d) x\end{array}\right|$

Applying $C_{1} \rightarrow C_{1}-2 \cos d x C_{2}$

$\Rightarrow \Delta=\begin{array}{ccc}1+a^{2}-2 a \cos d x & a & a^{2} \\ 0 & \cos p x & \cos (p+d) x \\ 0 & \sin p x & \sin (p+d) x\end{array}$

$\Rightarrow \Delta=\left(1+a^{2}-2 a \cos d x\right)[\sin (p+d) x \cos p x$ $-\sin p x \cos (p+d) x]$

$\Rightarrow \quad \Delta=\left(1+a^{2}-2 a \cos d x\right) \sin d x$

which is independent of $p$.

question: The determinant $\left|\begin{array}{ccc}x p+y & x & y \\ y p+z & y & z \\ 0 & x p+y & y p+z\end{array}\right|=0$, if\\
options: a) $x, y, z$ are in AP\\
b) $x, y, z$ are in GP\\
c) $x, y, z$ are in HP\\
d) $x y, y z, z x$ are in AP
solution:
Given, $\left|\begin{array}{ccc}x p+y & x & y \\ y p+z & y & z \\ 0 & x p+y & y p+z\end{array}\right|=0$

Applying $C_{1} \rightarrow C_{1}-\left(p C_{2}+C_{3}\right)$

$$
\begin{array}{l|ccc}
\Rightarrow & \left|\begin{array}{ccc}
0 & x & y \\
0 & y & z \\
-\left(x p^{2}+y p+y p+z\right) & x p+y & y p+z
\end{array}\right|=0 \\
\Rightarrow & -\left(x p^{2}+2 y p+z\right)\left(x z-y^{2}\right)=0 \\
\therefore & & \text { Either } x p^{2}+2 y p+z=0 \text { or } y^{2}=x z \\
\Rightarrow & x, y, z \text { are in GP. }
\end{array}
$$

options: b) $B$ has as many elements as $C$

solution:

Also, $B$ is the subset of $A$ consisting of all determinants with value 1 .

[since, if we interchange any two rows or columns,

then among themself sign changes]

question: The total number of distincts $x \in R$ for which $\left|\begin{array}{ccc}x & x^{2} & 1+x^{3} \\ 2 x & 4 x^{2} & 1+8 x^{3} \\ 3 x & 9 x^{2} & 1+27 x^{3}\end{array}\right|=10$ is

If $B=\left[\begin{array}{ccc}5 & 2 \alpha & 1 \\ 0 & 2 & 1 \\ \alpha & 3 & -1\end{array}\right]$ is the inverse of a $3 \times 3$ matrix $A$, then the sum of all values of $\alpha$ for which $\operatorname{det}(A)+1=0$, is \\
solution:
Given matrix $B$ is the inverse matrix of $3 \times 3$ matrix $A$,

$$
\text { where } B=\begin{array}{ccc}
5 & 2 \alpha & 1 \\
0 & 2 & 1 \\
\alpha & 3 & -1
\end{array}
$$

We know that,

$$
\operatorname{det}(A)=\frac{1}{\operatorname{det}(B)} \quad \because \operatorname{det}\left(A^{-1}\right)=\frac{1}{\operatorname{det}(A)}
$$

Since, $\quad \operatorname{det}(A)+1=0$

\[
\begin{array}{rlrl} 
& & \frac{1}{\operatorname{det}(B)}+1=0  \tag{given}\\
\Rightarrow & \operatorname{det}(B)=-1 \\
\Rightarrow & 5(-2-3)-2 \alpha(0-\alpha)+1(0-2 \alpha)=-1 \\
\Rightarrow & & -25+2 \alpha^{2}-2 \alpha=-1 \\
\Rightarrow & & 2 \alpha^{2}-2 \alpha-24 & =0 \\
\Rightarrow & & \alpha^{2}-\alpha-12 & =0 \\
\Rightarrow & & (\alpha-4)(\alpha+3) & =0 \\
\Rightarrow & & \alpha & =-3,4
\end{array}
\]

So, required sum of all values of $\alpha$ is $4-3=1$\\

question: $A=\left[\begin{array}{ccc}e^{t}  & e^{t} \cos t & e^{-t} \sin t \\ e^{-t} & -e^{-t} \cos t -e^{-t} \sin t & -e^{-t} \sin t + e^{-t} \cos t \\ -e^{t}  & -2 e^{-t} \sin t & -2 e^{-t} \cos t\end{array}\right]$
options: c) not invertible for any $t \in R$
solution:
$\begin{aligned}|A| & =\left|\begin{array}{ccc}e^{t} & e^{-t} \cos t & e^{-t} \sin t \\ e^{t} & -e^{-t} \cos t-e^{-t} \sin t & -e^{-t} \sin t+e^{-t} \cos t \\ e^{t} & 2 e^{-t} \sin t & -2 e^{-t} \cos t\end{array}\right| \\ & =\left(e^{t}\right)\left(e^{-t}\right)\left(e^{-t}\right)\left|\begin{array}{ccc}1 & \cos t & \sin t \\ 1 & -\cos t-\sin t & -\sin t+\cos t \\ 1 & 2 \sin t & -2 \cos t\end{array}\right|\end{aligned}$ (taking common from each column)

Aplying $R_{2} \rightarrow R_{2}-R_{1}$ and $R_{3} \rightarrow R_{3}-R_{1}$, we get

$$
\begin{aligned}
& =e^{-t}\left|\begin{array}{ccc}
1 & \cos t & \sin t \\
0 & -2 \cos t-\sin t & -2 \sin t+\cos t \\
0 & 2 \sin t-\cos t & -2 \cos t-\sin t
\end{array}\right| \\
& =e^{-t}\left((2 \cos t+\sin t)^{2}+(2 \sin t-\cos t)^{2}\right) \\
& =e^{-t}\left(5 \cos ^{2} t+5 \sin ^{2} t\right) \\
& =5 e^{-t} \quad\left(\because \cos ^{2} t+\sin ^{2} t=1\right) \\
\Rightarrow|A| & =5 e^{-t} \neq 0 \\
\therefore A & \text { for all } t \in R \\
\therefore &
\end{aligned}
$$

$[\because$ If $|A| \neq 0$, then $A$ is invertible $]$

question: Let $A$ and $B$ be two invertible matrices of order $3 \times 3$. If $\operatorname{det}\left(A B A^{T}\right)=8$ and $\operatorname{det}\left(A B^{-1}\right)=8$, then $\operatorname{det}\left(B A^{-1} B^{T}\right)$ is equal to\\

If $A=\left[\begin{array}{cc}2 & -3 \\ -4 & 1\end{array}\right]$, then adj $\left(3 A^{2}+12 A\right)$ is equal to\\
If $A=\left[\begin{array}{cc}5 a & -b \\ 3 & 2\end{array}\right]$ and $A$ adj $A=A A^{T}$, then $5 a+b$ is equal to\\
solution:
Given, $A=\begin{array}{cc}5 a & -b \\ 3 & 2\end{array}$ and $A$ adj $A=A A^{T}$

Clearly, $A(\operatorname{adj} A)=|A| I_{2}$

$[\because$ if $A$ is square matrix of order $n$, then $A(\operatorname{adj} A)=(\operatorname{adj} A) \cdot A=|A| I_{n}$ ]


\begin{align*}
& =\left|\begin{array}{cc}
5 a & -b \\
3 & 2
\end{array}\right| I_{2}=(10 a+3 b) I_{2} \\
& =(10 a+3 b) \begin{array}{ll}
1 & 0 \\
0 & 1
\end{array} \\
& =\begin{array}{cc}
10 a+3 b & 0 \\
0 & 10 a+3 b
\end{array} \tag{i}
\end{align*}


and $\quad A A^{T}=\begin{array}{cccc}5 a & -b & 5 a & 3 \\ 3 & 2 & -b & 2\end{array}$

\[
=\begin{array}{cc}
25 a^{2}+b^{2} & 15 a-2 b  \tag{ii}\\
15 a-2 b & 13
\end{array}
\]

$\because \quad A(\operatorname{adj} A)=A A^{T}$

$\therefore \begin{array}{cc}10 a+3 b & 0 \\ 0 & 10 a+3 b\end{array}=\begin{array}{cc}25 a^{2}+b^{2} & 15 a-2 b \\ 15 a-2 b & 13\end{array}$

[using Eqs. (i) and (ii)]

\[
\begin{array}{lr}
\Rightarrow & 15 a-2 b=0 \\
\Rightarrow & a=\frac{2 b}{15} \tag{iii}
\end{array}
\]

and $\quad 10 a+3 b=13$

On substituting the value of ' $\alpha$ ' from Eq. (iii) in Eq. (iv), we get

$$
\begin{aligned}
& 10 \cdot \frac{2 b}{15}+3 b & =13 \\
\Rightarrow & \frac{20 b+45 b}{15} & =13 \\
\Rightarrow & \frac{65 b}{15} & =13 \\
\Rightarrow & b & =3
\end{aligned}
$$

Now, substituting the value of $b$ in Eq. (iii), we get $5 a=2$

Hence, $\quad 5 a+b=2+3=5$

question: If $A$ is a $3 \times 3$ non-singular matrix such that $A A^{T}=A^{T} A$ and $B=A^{-1} A^{T}$, then $B B^{T}$ is equal to\\
solution:
PLAN Use the following properties of transpose

$(A B)^{\top}=B^{\top} A^{\top},\left(A^{\top}\right)^{\top}=A$ and $A^{-1} A=1$ and simplify. If $A$ is non-singular matrix, then $|A| \neq 0$.

Given, $A A^{T}=A^{T} A$ and $B=A^{-1} A^{T}$

$$
\begin{array}{rlr}
B B^{T} & =\left(A^{-1} A^{T}\right)\left(A^{-1} A^{T}\right)^{T} \\
& =A^{-1} A^{T} A\left(A^{-1}\right)^{T} & {\left[\because(A B)^{T}=B^{T} A^{T}\right]} \\
& =A^{-1} A A^{T}\left(A^{-1}\right)^{T} & {\left[\because A A^{T}=A^{T} A\right]} \\
& =I A^{T}\left(A^{-1}\right)^{T} & {\left[\because A^{-1} A=I\right]} \\
& =A^{T}\left(A^{-1}\right)^{T}=\left(A^{-1} A\right)^{T} \\
& =I^{T}=I & {\left[\because(A B)^{T}=B^{T} A^{T}\right]}
\end{array}
$$

$\begin{array}{lll}1 & \propto & 3\end{array}$

question: If $P=\left[\begin{array}{lll}1 & \alpha & 3 \\1 & 3 & 3 \\ 2 & 4 & 4 \end{array}\right]$ is the adjoint of a $3 \times 3$ matrix $A$ and $|A|=4$, then $\alpha$ is equal to\\
solution:
Given, $P=1 \quad 3 \quad 3$

$\begin{array}{lll}2 & 4 & 4\end{array}$

$\therefore \quad|P|=1(12-12)-\alpha(4-6)+3(4-6)=2 \alpha-6$

$\because \quad P=\operatorname{adj}(A) \quad$ [given]

$\therefore \quad|P|=|\operatorname{adj} A|=|A|^{2}=16 \quad\left[\because|\operatorname{adj} A|=|A|^{n-1}\right]$

$\therefore \quad 2 \alpha-6=16$

$\Rightarrow \quad 2 \alpha=22$

$\Rightarrow \quad \alpha=11$

question: If $P$ is a $3 \times 3$ matrix such that $P^{T}=2 P+I$, where $P^{T}$ is the transpose of $P$ and $I$ is the $3 \times 3$ identity matrix, then there exists a column matrix, $X=y \neq 0$ such that\\
solution:
Given, $P^{T}=2 P+I$


\begin{align*}
\therefore & \left(P^{T}\right)^{T} & =(2 P+I)^{T}=2 P^{T}+I  \tag{i}\\
\Rightarrow & P & =2 P^{T}+I \\
\Rightarrow & P & =2(2 P+I)+I \\
\Rightarrow & P & =4 P+3 I \text { or } 3 P=-3 I \\
\Rightarrow & P X & =-I X=-X
\end{align*}

question: Let $\omega \neq 1$ be a cube root of unity and $S$ be the set of all non-singular matrices of the form $\begin{array}{ccc}1 & a & b \\ \omega & 1 & c \\ \omega^{2} & \omega & 1\end{array}$, where each of $a, b$ and $c$ is either $\omega$ or $\omega^{2}$. Then, the number of distinct matrices in the set $S$ is\\
solution:
$|A| \neq 0$, as non-singular $\left|\begin{array}{lll}1 & a & b \\ \omega & 1 & c \\ \omega^{2} & \omega & 1\end{array}\right| \neq 0$

$$
\Rightarrow \quad 1(1-c \omega)-a\left(\omega-c \omega^{2}\right)+b\left(\omega^{2}-\omega^{2}\right) \neq 0
$$

$\Rightarrow 1-c \omega-a \omega+a c \omega^{2} \neq 0$

$\Rightarrow \quad(1-c \omega)(1-a \omega) \neq 0 \Rightarrow \quad \alpha \neq \frac{1}{\omega}, c \neq \frac{1}{\omega}$

$\Rightarrow \quad a=\omega, c=\omega$ and $b \in\left\{\omega, \omega^{2}\right\} \Rightarrow 2$ solutions

question: Let $M$ and $N$ be two $3 \times 3$ non-singular skew-symmetric matrices such that $M N=N M$. If $P^{T}$ denotes the transpose of $P$, then $M^{2} N^{2}\left(M^{T} N\right)^{-1}\left(M N^{-1}\right)^{T}$ is equal to\\
solution:
Given, $M^{T}=-M, N^{T}=-N$ and $M N=N M$

\[
\begin{array}{ll}
\therefore & M^{2} N^{2}\left(M^{T} N\right)^{-1}\left(M N^{-1}\right)^{T}  \tag{i}\\
\Rightarrow & M^{2} N^{2} N^{-1}\left(M^{T}\right)^{-1}\left(N^{-1}\right)^{T} \cdot M^{T} \\
\Rightarrow & M^{2} N\left(N N^{-1}\right)(-M)^{-1}\left(N^{T}\right)^{-1}(-M) \\
\Rightarrow & M^{2} N I\left(-M^{-1}\right)(-N)^{-1}(-M) \\
\Rightarrow & -M^{2} N M^{-1} N^{-1} M \\
\Rightarrow & -M \cdot(M N) M^{-1} N^{-1} M=-M(N M) M^{-1} N^{-1} M \\
\Rightarrow & -M N\left(N M^{-1}\right) N^{-1} M=-M\left(N N^{-1}\right) M \Rightarrow-M^{2} \\
\text { NOTE } & \text { Here, non-singular word should not be used, since there } \\
& \text { is no non-singular } 3 \times 3 \text { skew-symmetric matrix. }
\end{array}
\]

question:
If $A=0 \quad 1 \quad 1,6 A^{-1}=A^{2}+c A+d I$, then $(c, d)$ is $\begin{array}{lll}0 & -2 & 4\end{array}$
\\
solution:
Every square matrix satisfied its characteristic equation,


\begin{align*}
& \text { i.e. }|A-\lambda I|=0 \Rightarrow\left|\begin{array}{ccc}
1-\lambda & 0 & 0 \\
0 & 1-\lambda & 1 \\
0 & -2 & 4-\lambda
\end{array}\right|=0 \\
& \Rightarrow \quad(1-\lambda)\{(1-\lambda)(4-\lambda)+2\}=0 \\
& \Rightarrow \quad \lambda^{3}-6 \lambda^{2}+11 \lambda-6=0 \\
& \Rightarrow \quad A^{3}-6 A^{2}+11 A-6 I=O \tag{i}
\end{align*}


Given, $6 A^{-1}=A^{2}+c A+d I$, multiplying both sides by $A$, we get

$6 I=A^{3}+c A^{2}+d A \Rightarrow A^{3}+c A^{2}+d A-6 I=O$

On comparing Eqs. (i) and (ii), we get

$$
c=-6 \text { and } d=11
$$

$$
\begin{array}{lll}
3 & -1 & -2
\end{array}
$$

question:
Let $k$ be a positive real number and let

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  & A=\left[\begin{array}{ccc}
  2 k-1 & 2 \sqrt{k} & 2 \sqrt{k} \\
  2 \sqrt{k} & 1 & -2 k \\
  -2 \sqrt{k} & 2 k & -1
  \end{array}\right] \text { and } \\
  & B=\left[\begin{array}{ccc}
  0 & 2 k-1 & \sqrt{k} \\
  1-2 k & 0 & 2 \sqrt{k} \\
  -\sqrt{k} & -2 \sqrt{k} & 0
  \end{array}\right]
  \end{aligned}
  $$

If $\operatorname{det}(\operatorname{adj} A)+\operatorname{det}(\operatorname{adj} B)=10^6$, then $[k]$ is equal to.....\\
If $[x]$ denotes the greatest integer $\leq x$, then the system of liner equations $[\sin \theta] x+[-\cos \theta] y=0$, $[\cot \theta] x+y=0$
options: a) have infinitely many solutions if $\left(\theta \in \frac{\pi}{2}, \frac{2 \pi}{3}\right)$ and has a unique solution if $\left(\theta \in \pi, \frac{7 \pi}{6}\right)$.
b) has a unique solution if $ \left(\theta \in \frac{\pi}{2}, \frac{2 \pi}{3} \cup \pi, \frac{7 \pi}{6}\right)$
c) has a unique solution if $\left(\theta \in \frac{\pi}{2}, \frac{2 \pi}{3}\right)$ and have infinitely many solutions if $\left(\theta \in \pi, \frac{7 \pi}{6}\right)$
d) have infinitely many solutions if $\theta \in \left(\frac{\pi}{2}, \frac{2 \pi}{3} \right)\cup \left(\pi, \frac{7 \pi}{6}\right)$
solution:
Given system of linear equations is


\begin{equation*}
[\sin \theta] x+[-\cos \theta] y=0 \tag{i}
\end{equation*}


and $\quad[\cot \theta] x+y=0$

where, $[x]$ denotes the greatest integer $\leq x$.

$$
\text { Here, } \quad \Delta=\left|\begin{array}{cc}
{[\sin \theta]} & {[-\cos \theta]} \\
{[\cot \theta]} & 1
\end{array}\right|
$$

$\Rightarrow \Delta=[\sin \theta]-[-\cos \theta][\cot \theta]$

When

$$
\theta \in \frac{\pi}{2}, \frac{2 \pi}{3}
$$

$$
\sin \theta \in \frac{\sqrt{3}}{2}, 1
$$

\[
\begin{array}{rlrl}
\Rightarrow & & {[\sin \theta]=0} \\
& & -\cos \theta \in 0, \frac{1}{2} \\
& & & \\
\text { and } & & \cos \theta]=0 \\
\Rightarrow & \cot \theta & \in-\frac{1}{\sqrt{3}}, 0  \tag{v}\\
& \text { So, } & {[\cot \theta]} & =-1 \\
& & \Delta & =[\sin \theta]-[-\cos \theta][\cot \theta]
\end{array}
\]

$$
-(0 \times(-1))=0 \quad \text { [from Eqs. (iii), (iv) and (v)] }
$$

Thus, for $\theta \in \frac{\pi}{2}, \frac{2 \pi}{3}$, the given system have infinitely many solutions.

When $\quad \theta \in \pi, \frac{7 \pi}{6}, \sin \theta \in-\frac{1}{2}, 0$

$\Rightarrow \quad[\sin \theta]=-1$

$$
-\cos \theta \in \frac{\sqrt{3}}{2}, 1 \Rightarrow[\cos \theta]=0
$$

and $\quad \cot \theta \in(\sqrt{3}, \infty) \Rightarrow[\cot \theta]=n, n \in N$.

So, $\quad \Delta=-1-(0 \times n)=-1$

Thus, for $\theta \in \pi, \frac{7 \pi}{6}$, the given system has a unique solution.

question:
Let $\lambda$ be a real number for which the system of linear equations

$x+y+z=6,4 x+\lambda y-\lambda z=\lambda-2$ and

$3 x+2 y-4 z=-5$

has infinitely many solutions. Then $\lambda$ is a root of the quadratic equation\\

If the system of linear equations

$x+y+z=5$

$x+2 y+2 z=6$

$x+3 y+\lambda z=\mu,(\lambda, \mu \in R), \quad$ has infinitely many solutions, then the value of $\lambda+\mu$ is\\
solution:
Given system of linear equations


\begin{gather*}
x+y+z=5  \tag{i}\\
x+2 y+2 z=6  \tag{ii}\\
x+3 y+\lambda z=\mu \tag{iii}
\end{gather*}


$(\lambda, \mu \in R)$

The above given system has infinitely many solutions, then the plane represented by these equations intersect each other at a line, means $(x+3 y+\lambda z-\mu)$

$$
\begin{aligned}
& =p(x+y+z-5)+q(x+2 y+2 z-6) \\
& =(p+q) x+(p+2 q) y+(p+2 q) z-(5 p+6 q)
\end{aligned}
$$

On comparing, we get

$$
\begin{array}{lc} 
& p+q=1, p+2 q=3, p+2 q=\lambda \\
\text { and } & 5 p+6 q=\mu \\
\text { So, } & (p, q)=(-1,2) \\
\Rightarrow & \lambda=3 \text { and } \mu=7 \\
\Rightarrow & \lambda+\mu=3+7=10
\end{array}
$$

question: If the system of equations $2 x+3 y-z=0, x+k y-2 z=0$ and $2 x-y+z=0$ has a non-trivial solution $(x, y, z)$, then $\frac{x}{y}+\frac{y}{z}+\frac{z}{x}+k$ is equal to\\
solution:
Given system of linear equations

$$
\begin{aligned}
& 2 x+3 y-z=0, \\
& x+k y-2 z=0
\end{aligned}
$$

and $2 x-y+z=0$ has a non-trivial solution $(x, y, z)$.

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \therefore \Delta=0 \Rightarrow \begin{array}{rrr}
2 & 3 & -1 \\
1 & k & -2
\end{array}=0 \\
& \begin{array}{lllll}
2 & -1 & 1 &
\end{array} \\
& 2(k-2)-3(1+4)-1(-1-2 k)=0 \\
& \Rightarrow \quad 2 k-4-15+1+2 k=0 \\
& \Rightarrow \quad 4 k=18 \Rightarrow k=\frac{9}{2}
\end{aligned}
$$

So, system of linear equations is

\[
\begin{array}{r}
2 x+3 y-z=0 \\
2 x+9 y-4 z=0 \\
2 x-y+z=0 \tag{iii}
\end{array}
\]

and

From Eqs. (i) and (ii), we get

$$
6 y-3 z=0, \frac{y}{z}=\frac{1}{2}
$$

From Eqs. (i) and (iii), we get

$$
4 x+2 y=0 \Rightarrow \frac{x}{y}=-\frac{1}{2}
$$

So, $\frac{x}{z}=\frac{x}{y} \times \frac{y}{z}=-\frac{1}{4} \Rightarrow \frac{z}{x}=-4 \quad \because \frac{y}{z}=\frac{1}{2}$ and $\frac{x}{y}=-\frac{1}{2}$

$\therefore \frac{x}{y}+\frac{y}{z}+\frac{z}{x}+k=-\frac{1}{2}+\frac{1}{2}-4+\frac{9}{2}=\frac{1}{2}$.

question: If the system of linear equations $x-2 y+k z=1, \quad 2 x+y+z=2,3 x-y-k z=3$ has a solution $(x, y, z), z \neq 0$, then $(x, y)$ lies on the straight line whose equation is \\
solution:
Given system of linear equations

\[
\text { and } \quad \begin{gather*}
x-2 y+k z=1 \\
2 x+y+z=2  \tag{ii}\\
3 x-y-k z=3
\end{gather*}
\]

has a solution $(x, y, z), z \neq 0$.

On adding Eqs. (i) and (iii), we get

$$
\begin{array}{rlrl} 
& & x-2 y+k z+3 x-y-k z & =1+3 \\
\Rightarrow & & 4 x-3 y & =4 \\
\Rightarrow & 4 x-3 y-4 & =0
\end{array}
$$

This is the required equation of the straight line in which point $(x, y)$ lies.

question:
The greatest value of $c \in R$ for which the system of linear equations $x-c y-c z=0, c x-y+c z=0$, $c x+c y-z=0$ has a non-trivial solution, is
\\

The set of all values of $\lambda$ for which the system of linear equations $x-2 y-2 z=\lambda x, x+2 y+z=\lambda y$ and $-x-y=\lambda z$

has a non-trivial solution
options: b) contains more than two elements.
solution:
The given system of linear equations is

$$
\begin{aligned}
x-2 y-2 z & =\lambda x \\
x+2 y+z & =\lambda y \\
-x-y-\lambda z & =0
\end{aligned}
$$

which can be rewritten as

$$
\begin{aligned}
(1-\lambda) x-2 y-2 z & =0 \\
x+(2-\lambda) y+z & =0 \\
x+y+\lambda z & =0
\end{aligned}
$$

Now, for non-trivial solution, we should have

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \quad\left|\begin{array}{ccc}
1-\lambda & -2 & -2 \\
1 & 2-\lambda & 1 \\
1 & 1 & \lambda
\end{array}\right|=0 \\
& {\left[\because \text { If } a_{1} x+b_{1} y+c_{1} z=0 ; a_{2} x+b_{2} y+c_{2} z=0\right.} \\
& \left.a_{3} x+b_{3} y+c_{3} z=0\right] \\
& \Rightarrow \quad(1-\lambda)[(2-\lambda) \lambda-1]+2[\lambda-1]-2[1-2+\lambda]=0 \\
& \Rightarrow \quad(\lambda-1)\left[\lambda^{2}-2 \lambda+1+2-2\right]=0 \\
& \Rightarrow \quad\left(\left.\begin{array}{lll}
b_{1} & c_{1} \\
a_{2} & b_{2} & c_{2} \\
a_{3} & b_{3} & c_{3}
\end{array} \right\rvert\,=0\right. \\
& \Rightarrow \quad \lambda-1)^{3}=0 \\
& \lambda \\
& \lambda=1
\end{aligned}
$$

question:
An ordered pair $(\alpha, \beta)$ for which the system of linear equations

$$
\begin{aligned}
& (1+\alpha) x+\beta y+z=2 \\
& \alpha x+(1+\beta) y+z=3 \\
& a x+\beta y+2 z=2
\end{aligned}
$$

has a unique solution, is\\
solution:
Given system of linear equations,

$(1+\alpha) x+\beta y+z=2$

$\alpha x+(1+\beta) y+z=3$

$$
\alpha x+\beta y+2 z=2
$$

has a unique solution, if

$$
\left|\begin{array}{ccc}
1+\alpha & \beta & 1 \\
\alpha & (1+\beta) & 1 \\
\alpha & \beta & 2
\end{array}\right| \neq 0
$$

Apply $R_{1} \rightarrow R_{1}-R_{3}$ and $R_{2} \rightarrow R_{2}-R_{3}$

$$
\left|\begin{array}{ccc}
1 & 0 & -1 \\
0 & 1 & -1 \\
\sim & \Omega & \partial
\end{array}\right| \neq 0
$$


\begin{align*}
& \Rightarrow \quad 1(2+\beta)-0(0+\alpha)-1(0-\alpha) \neq 0 \\
& \Rightarrow \quad \alpha+\beta+2 \neq 0 \tag{i}
\end{align*}


Note that, only $(2,4)$ satisfy the Eq. (i).

question:
If the system of linear equations

$$
\begin{aligned}
& 2 x+2 y+3 z=a \\
& 3 x-y+5 z=b \\
& x-3 y+2 z=c
\end{aligned}
$$

where $a, b, c$ are non-zero real numbers, has more than one solution, then\\
solution:
We know that, if the system of equations

$$
\begin{aligned}
& a_{1} x+b_{1} y+c_{1} z=d_{1} \\
& a_{2} x+b_{2} y+c_{2} z=d_{2} \\
& a_{3} x+b_{3} y+c_{3} z=d_{3}
\end{aligned}
$$

has more than one solution, then $D=0$ and $D_{1}=D_{2}=D_{3}=0$. In the given problem,

$$
\begin{aligned}
& D_{1}=0 \Rightarrow\left|\begin{array}{ccc}
a & 2 & 3 \\
b & -1 & 5 \\
c & -3 & 2
\end{array}\right|=0 \\
& \Rightarrow a(-2+15)-2(2 b-5 c)+3(-3 b+c)=0 \\
& \Rightarrow \quad 13 a-4 b+10 c-9 b+3 c=0 \\
& \Rightarrow \quad a-b+c=0 \Rightarrow b-a-c=0
\end{aligned}
$$

question:
The number of values of $\theta \in(0, \pi)$ for which the system of linear equations

$$
\begin{aligned}
& x+3 y+7 z=0 \\
& -x+4 y+7 z=0 \\
& (\sin 3 \theta) x+(\cos 2 \theta) y+2 z=0
\end{aligned}
$$

has a non-trivial solution, is\\
solution:
We know that,

the system of linear equations

$$
\begin{aligned}
& a_{1} x+b_{1} y+c_{1} z=0 \\
& a_{2} x+b_{2} y+c_{2} z=0 \\
& a_{3} x+b_{3} y+c_{3} z=0
\end{aligned}
$$

has a non-trivial solution, if

$$
\left|\begin{array}{lll}
a_{1} & b_{1} & c_{1} \\
a_{2} & b_{2} & c_{2} \\
a_{3} & b_{3} & c_{3}
\end{array}\right|=0
$$

Now, if the given system of linear equations

$$
\begin{aligned}
x+3 y+7 z & =0 \\
-x+4 y+7 z & =0
\end{aligned}
$$

and $(\sin 3 \theta) x+(\cos 2 \theta) y+2 z=0$

has non-trivial solution, then

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \left|\begin{array}{ccc}
1 & 3 & 7 \\
-1 & 4 & 7 \\
\sin 3 \theta & \cos 2 \theta & 2
\end{array}\right|=0 \\
& \Rightarrow 1(8-7 \cos 2 \theta)-3(-2-7 \sin 3 \theta) \\
& \Rightarrow 8-7(-\cos 2 \theta-4 \sin 3 \theta)=0 \\
& \Rightarrow-6+21 \sin 3 \theta \\
& \Rightarrow-7 \sin 3 \theta-14 \cos 2 \theta+14=0 \\
& \Rightarrow-7\left(3 \sin \theta-4 \sin ^{3} \theta\right)-14\left(1-2 \sin ^{2} \theta\right)+14=0 \\
& \quad\left[\because \sin 3 A=3 \sin A-4 \sin ^{3} A\right. \text { and } \\
& \Rightarrow 28 \sin 3 \theta+28 \sin ^{2} \theta-21 \sin \theta-14+14=0 \\
& \Rightarrow 7 \sin \theta\left[4 \sin ^{2} \theta+4 \sin \theta-3\right]=0 \\
& \Rightarrow \sin \theta[4 \sin 2 \theta+6 \sin \theta-2 \sin \theta-3]=0 \\
& \Rightarrow \sin \theta[2 \sin \theta(2 \sin \theta+3)-1(2 \sin \theta+3)]=0 \\
& \Rightarrow(\sin \theta)(2 \sin \theta-1)(2 \sin \theta+3)=0 \\
& \text { Now, either } \sin \theta=0 \text { or } \frac{1}{2}
\end{aligned}
$$

$$
\because \sin \theta \neq-\frac{3}{2} \text { as }-1 \leq \sin \theta \leq 1
$$

In given interval $(0, \pi)$,

$$
\begin{aligned}
\sin \theta & =\frac{1}{2} \\
\Rightarrow \quad \theta & =\frac{\pi}{6}, \frac{5 \pi}{6} \quad[\because \sin \theta \neq 0, \theta \in(0, \pi)]
\end{aligned}
$$

Hence, 2 solutions in $(0, \pi)$

question:
If the system of equations

$$
\begin{array}{rr}
x+y+z=5 & x+2 y+3 z=9 \\
x+3 y+\alpha z=\beta &
\end{array}
$$

has infinitely many solutions, then $\beta-\alpha$ equals\\
solution:
Since, the system of equations has infinitely many solution, therefore $D=D_{1}=D_{2}=D_{3}=0$ Here,

$$
\begin{aligned}
D & =\left|\begin{array}{lll}
1 & 1 & 1 \\
1 & 2 & 3 \\
1 & 3 & \alpha
\end{array}\right|=1(2 \alpha-9)-1(\alpha-3)+1(3-2) \\
& =\alpha-5 \\
\text { and } D_{3} & =\left|\begin{array}{lll}
1 & 1 & 5 \\
1 & 2 & 9 \\
1 & 3 & \beta
\end{array}\right|=1(2 \beta-27)-1(\beta-9)+5(3-2)
\end{aligned}
$$

$=\beta-13$

$$
\begin{array}{lrl}
\text { Now, } & D=0 \\
\Rightarrow & \alpha-5 & =0 \Rightarrow \alpha=5 \\
\text { and } & D_{3} & =0 \Rightarrow \beta-13=0 \\
\Rightarrow & \beta & =13 \\
\therefore & \beta-\alpha & =13-5=8
\end{array}
$$

question:
If the system of linear equations

$$
x-4 y+7 z=g, 3 y-5 z=h,-2 x+5 y-9 z=k
$$

is consistent, then\\
solution:
(a) Here, $D=\left|\begin{array}{ccc}1 & -4 & 7 \\ 0 & 3 & -5 \\ -2 & 5 & -9\end{array}\right|$

$$
=1(-27+25)+4(0-10)+7(0+6)
$$

[expanding along $R_{1}$ ]

$$
=-2-40+42=0
$$

$\therefore$ The system of linear equations have infinite many solutions.

$[\because$ system is consistent and does not have unique solution as $D=0$ ]

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \Rightarrow \quad D_{1}=D_{2}=D_{3}=0 \\
& \text { Now, } \quad D_{1}=0 \Rightarrow\left|\begin{array}{ccc}
g & -4 & 7 \\
h & 3 & -5 \\
k & 5 & -9
\end{array}\right|=0 \\
& \Rightarrow g(-27+25)+4(-9 h+5 k)+7(5 h-3 k)=0 \\
& \Rightarrow-2 g-36 h+20 k+35 h-21 k=0 \\
& \Rightarrow-2 g-h-k=0 \Rightarrow 2 g+h+k=0
\end{aligned}
$$

options: a) has infinitely many solutions for $a=4$
c) has a unique solution for $|a|=\sqrt{3}$
solution:
According to Cramer's rule, here

$$
D=\left|\begin{array}{ccc}
1 & 1 & 1 \\
2 & 3 & 2 \\
2 & 3 & a^{2}-1
\end{array}\right|=\left|\begin{array}{ccc}
1 & 0 & 0 \\
2 & 1 & 0 \\
2 & 1 & a^{2}-3
\end{array}\right|
$$

(Applying $C_{2} \rightarrow C_{2}-C_{1}$ and $C_{3} \rightarrow C_{3}-C_{1}$ )

$$
\text { and } D_{1}=\left|\begin{array}{ccc}
2 & 1 & 1 \\
5 & 3 & 2 \\
a+1 & 3 & a^{2}-1
\end{array}\right|=\left|\begin{array}{ccc}
2 & 1 & 0 \\
5 & 3 & -1 \\
a+1 & 3 & a^{2}-1-3
\end{array}\right|
$$

(Expanding along $R_{1}$ )

(Applying $C_{3} \rightarrow C_{3}-C_{2}$ )

$$
=\left|\begin{array}{ccc}
2 & 0 & 0 \\
5 & 3-\frac{5}{2} & -1 \\
a+1 & 3-\frac{(a+1)}{2} & a^{2}-1-3
\end{array}\right|
$$

$$
=\left|\begin{array}{ccc}
2 & 0 & 0 \\
5 & \frac{1}{2} & -1 \\
a+1 & \frac{5}{2}-\frac{a}{2} & a^{2}-4
\end{array}\right| \quad \text { (Applying } C_{2} \rightarrow C_{2}-\frac{1}{2} C_{1} \text { ) }
$$

$=2 \frac{1}{2}\left(a^{2}-4\right)+\frac{5}{2}-\frac{a}{2}$

[Expanding along $R_{1}$ ]

$=2 \frac{a^{2}}{2}-2+\frac{5}{2}-\frac{a}{2}=a^{2}-4+5-a=a^{2}-a+1$

Clearly, when $a=4$, then $D=13 \neq 0 \Rightarrow$ unique solution and

when $|a|=\sqrt{3}$, then $D=0$ and $D_{1} \neq 0$.

$\therefore$ When $|a|=\sqrt{3}$, then the system has no solution i.e. system is inconsistent.

question:
If the system of linear equations

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  x+k y+3 z & =0,3 x+k y-2 z=0 \\
  2 x+4 y-3 z & =0
  \end{aligned}
  $$

has a non-zero solution $(x, y, z)$, then $\frac{x z}{y^{2}}$ is equal to\\
solution:
We have,

$x+k y+3 z=0 ; 3 x+k y-2 z=0 ; 2 x+4 y-3 z=0$

System of equation has non-zero solution, if


\begin{align*}
& 1 k 3 \quad \begin{array}{lll}
1 & 3 & 1
\end{array} \\
& 3 \quad k-2=0 \\
& \begin{array}{llllll}
2 & 4 & -3 &
\end{array} \\
& \Rightarrow(-3 k+8)-k(-9+4)+3(12-2 k)=0 \\
& \Rightarrow \quad-3 k+8+9 k-4 k+36-6 k=0 \\
& \Rightarrow \quad-4 k+44=0 \Rightarrow k=11 \\
& \text { Let } z=\lambda \text {, then we get } \\
& x+11 y+3 \lambda=0  \tag{i}\\
& 3 x+11 y-2 \lambda=0  \tag{ii}\\
& 2 x+4 y-3 \lambda=0 \tag{iii}
\end{align*}


Solving Eqs. (i) and (ii), we get

$$
x=\frac{5 \lambda}{2}, y=\frac{-\lambda}{2}, z=\lambda \Rightarrow \frac{x z}{y^{2}}=\frac{5 \lambda^{2}}{2 \times-\frac{\lambda}{2}}{ }^{2}=10
$$

question: The system of linear equations $x+\lambda y-z=0 ; \lambda x-y-z=0 ; x+y-\lambda z=0$ has a non-trivial solution for\\
solution:
Given, system of linear equation is

$$
x+\lambda y-z=0 ; \lambda x-y-z=0 ; x+y-\lambda z=0
$$

Note that, given system will have a non-trivial solution only if determinant of coefficient matrix is zero,

$$
\begin{array}{cc} 
& \left|\begin{array}{ccc}
1 & \lambda & -1 \\
\lambda & -1 & -1 \\
1 & 1 & -\lambda
\end{array}\right|=0 \\
\Rightarrow & 1(\lambda+1)-\lambda\left(-\lambda^{2}+1\right)-1(\lambda+1)=0 \\
\Rightarrow & \lambda+1+\lambda^{3}-\lambda-\lambda-1=0 \\
\Rightarrow & \lambda^{3}-\lambda=0 \Rightarrow \lambda\left(\lambda^{2}-1\right)=0 \\
\Rightarrow & \lambda=0 \text { or } \lambda= \pm 1
\end{array}
$$

Hence, given system of linear equation has a non-trivial solution for exactly three values of $\lambda$.

question: The set of all values of $\lambda$ for which the system of linear equations $2 x_{1}-2 x_{2}+x_{3}=\lambda x_{1}, 2 x_{1}-3 x_{2}+2 x_{3}=\lambda x_{2}$ and $-x_{1}+2 x_{2}=\lambda x_{3}$ has a non-trivial solution
options: d) contains more than two elements

question:
The number of value of $k$, for which the system of equation

$$
(k+1) x+8 y=4 y \quad \Rightarrow \quad k x+(k+3) y=3 k-1
$$

has no solution, is\\
solution:
Given equations can be written in matrix form $A X=B$

where, $A=\begin{array}{cc}k+1 & 8 \\ k & k+3\end{array}, X=\frac{x}{y}$ and $B=\frac{4 k}{3 k-1}$

For no solution, $|A|=0$ and (adj $A) B \neq 0$

Now, $|A|=\begin{array}{cc}k+1 & 8 \\ k & k+3\end{array}=0$

$\Rightarrow \quad\left(k^{2}+1\right)(k+3)-8 k=0$

$$
k^{2}+4 k+3-8 k=0
$$

$$
\begin{aligned}
\Rightarrow & k^{2}-4 k \times 3 & =0 \\
\Rightarrow & (k-1)(k-3) & =0 \\
\Rightarrow & k=1, k & =3,
\end{aligned}
$$

Now $\quad$ adj $A=\begin{array}{cc}k+3 & -8 \\ -k & k+1\end{array}$

Now, $\quad(\operatorname{adj} A) B=\begin{array}{lll}k+3 & -8 & 4 k \\ -k & k+1 & 3 k+1\end{array}$

$=\begin{aligned} & (k+3)(4 k)-8(3 k-1) \\ & -4 k^{2}+(k+1)(3 k-1)\end{aligned}$

$$
=\begin{array}{r}
4 k^{2}-12 k+8 \\
-k^{2}+2 k-1
\end{array}
$$

Put $k=1$

$$
(\operatorname{adj} A) B=\begin{gathered}
4-12+8 \\
-1+2-1
\end{gathered}=\begin{aligned}
& 0 \\
& 0
\end{aligned} \text { not true }
$$

Put $k=3$

$$
(\operatorname{adj} A) B={ }_{-9}^{36-36+8-1}={ }_{-4}^{8} \neq 0 \text { true }
$$

Hence, required value of $k$ is 3 .

\section*{Alternate Solution}
Condition for the system of equations has no solution is

$$
\begin{array}{rlrl}
\frac{a_{1}}{a_{2}} & =\frac{b_{1}}{b_{2}} \neq \frac{c_{1}}{c_{2}} \\
\therefore \quad & \frac{k+1}{k} & =\frac{8}{k+3} \neq \frac{4 k}{3 k-1}
\end{array}
$$

Take $\frac{k+1}{k}=\frac{8}{k+3}$

$\Rightarrow \quad k^{2}+4 k+3=8 k$

$\Rightarrow \quad k^{2}-4 k+3$

$\Rightarrow \quad(k-1)(k-3)=0$

$$
k=1,3
$$

If $k-1$, then $\frac{8}{1+3} \neq \frac{4.1}{2}$, false

And, if $k=3$, then $\frac{8}{6} \neq \frac{4.3}{9-1}$, true

Therefore, $k=3$

Hence, only one value of $k$ exist.

$$
x \quad 1
$$

question: The number of $3 \times 3$ matrices $A$ whose entries are either 0 or 1 and for which the system $A\left[\begin{array}{l}x \\ y \\ z\end{array}\right]=\left[\begin{array}{l}1 \\ 0 \\ 0\end{array}\right]$ has exactly two distinct solutions, is\\

z \quad 0

and that could have only unique, no solution or infinitely many solution.

Hence, number of matrices $A$ is zero.

question: Given, $2 x-y+2 z=2, x-2 y+z=-4, \quad x+y+\lambda z=4$, then the value of $\lambda$ such that the given system of equations has no solution, is\\
solution:
Since, given system has no solution.

$\therefore \Delta=0$ and any one amongst $\Delta_{x}, \Delta_{y}, \Delta_{z}$ is non-zero.

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \text { Let } \begin{array}{rrrr}
2 & -1 & 2 \\
1 & -2 & 1 \\
& 1 & 1 & \lambda
\end{array}=0 \text { and } \Delta_{z}=\begin{array}{rrr}
2 & -1 & 2 \\
1 & -2 & -4 \\
1 & 1 & 4
\end{array}=6 \neq 0 \\
& \Rightarrow \quad \lambda=1
\end{aligned}
$$

  $$

$$

question:
Let $M$ be a $3 \times 3$ matrix satisfying $M\left[\begin{array}{l}0 \\ 1 \\ 0\end{array}\right]=\left[\begin{array}{c}-1 \\ 2 \\ 3\end{array}\right]$, $M\left[\begin{array}{c}1 \\ -1 \\ 0\end{array}\right]=\left[\begin{array}{c}1 \\ 1 \\ -1\end{array}\right]$, and $M\left[\begin{array}{l}1 \\ 1 \\ 1\end{array}\right]=\left[\begin{array}{c}0 \\ 0 \\ 12\end{array}\right]$,\\
Then, the sum of the diagonal entries of $M$ is ...\\
solution:
\begin{aligned}
& \therefore \quad M\left[\begin{array}{l}
0 \\
1 \\
0
\end{array}\right]=\left[\begin{array}{r}
-1 \\
2 \\
3
\end{array}\right] \Rightarrow M\left[\begin{array}{r}
1 \\
-1 \\
0
\end{array}\right]=\left[\begin{array}{r}
1 \\
1 \\
-1
\end{array}\right] \\
& M \cdot\left[\begin{array}{l}
1 \\
1 \\
1
\end{array}\right]=\left[\begin{array}{r}
0 \\
0 \\
12
\end{array}\right] \\
& \Rightarrow\left[\begin{array}{l}
a_2 \\
b_2 \\
c_2
\end{array}\right]=\left[\begin{array}{r}
-1 \\
2 \\
3
\end{array}\right],\left[\begin{array}{l}
a_1-a_2 \\
b_1-b_2 \\
c_1-c_2
\end{array}\right]=\left[\begin{array}{r}
1 \\
1 \\
-1
\end{array}\right], \\
& {\left[\begin{array}{l}
a_1+a_2+a_3 \\
b_1+b_2+b_3 \\
c_1+c_2+c_3
\end{array}\right]=\left[\begin{array}{r}
0 \\
0 \\
12
\end{array}\right]} \\
& \Rightarrow \quad a_2=-1, b_2=2, c_2=3, a_1-a_2=1 \text {, } \\
& b_1-b_2=1, c_1-c_2=-1 \\
& \Rightarrow a_1+a_2+a_3=0, b_1+b_2+b_3=0 \\
& c_1+c_2+c_3=12 \\
& \therefore \quad a_1=0, b_2=2, c_3=7 \\
&
\end{aligned}
$$
$\Rightarrow \quad$ Sum of diagonal elements $=0+2+7=9$

question:

$$
f(x)=\frac{1}{4-x^{2}}+\log _{10}\left(x^{3}-x\right) \text { is }

Let $f(x)=a^{x}(a>0)$ be written as $f(x)=f_{1}(x)+f_{2}(x)$, where $f_{1}(x)$ is an even function and $f_{2}(x)$ is an odd function. Then $f_{1}(x+y)+f_{1}(x-y)$ equals\\
solution:
Given, function $f(x)=a^{x}, a>0$ is written as sum of an even and odd functions $f_{1}(x)$ and $f_{2}(x)$ respectively.

Clearly, $f_{1}(x)=\frac{a^{x}+a^{-x}}{2}$ and $f_{2}(x)=\frac{a^{x}-a^{-x}}{2}$

So, $f_{1}(x+y)+f_{1}(x-y)$

$=\frac{1}{2}\left[a^{x+y}+a^{-(x+y)}\right]+\frac{1}{2}\left[a^{x-y}+a^{-(x-y)}\right]$

$=\frac{1}{2} a^{x} a^{y}+\frac{1}{a^{x} a^{y}}+\frac{a^{x}}{a^{y}}+\frac{a^{y}}{a^{x}}$

$=\frac{1}{2} a^{x} a^{y}+\frac{1}{a^{y}}+\frac{1}{a^{x}} \frac{1}{a^{y}}+a^{y}$

$$
\begin{gathered}
=\frac{1}{2} a^{x}+\frac{1}{a^{x}} a^{y}+\frac{1}{a^{y}} \\
=2 \frac{a^{x}+a^{-x}}{2} \quad \frac{a^{y}+a^{-y}}{2}=2 f_{1}(x) \cdot f_{1}(y)
\end{gathered}
$$

question: The domain of definition of $f(x)=\frac{\log _{2}(x+3)}{x^{2}+3 x+2}$ is
solution:

For numerator, $x+3>0$

From Eqs. (i) and (ii),

question: The domain of definition of the function $y(x)$ is given by the equation $2^{x}+2^{y}=2$, is\\
solution:
Given, $2^{x}+2^{y}=2, \forall x, y \in R$

But $\quad 2^{x}, 2^{y}>0, \forall x, y \in R$

Therefore, $2^{x}=2-2^{y}<2 \Rightarrow 0<2^{x}<2$

Taking log on both sides with base 2 , we get

$$
\log _{2} 0<\log _{2} 2^{x}<\log _{2} 2 \Rightarrow-\infty<x<1
$$

question: Let $f(\theta)=\sin \theta(\sin \theta+\sin 3 \theta)$. Then, $f(\theta) \\
solution:
It is given,

$$
\begin{aligned}
f(\theta) & =\sin \theta(\sin \theta+\sin 3 \theta) \\
& =\left(\sin \theta+3 \sin \theta-4 \sin ^{3} \theta\right) \sin \theta \\
& =\left(4 \sin \theta-4 \sin ^{3} \theta\right) \sin \theta=\sin ^{2} \theta\left(4-4 \sin ^{2} \theta\right) \\
& =4 \sin ^{2} \theta \cos ^{2} \theta=(2 \sin \theta \cos \theta)^{2} \\
& =(\sin 2 \theta)^{2} \geq 0
\end{aligned}
$$

which is true for all $\theta$.

Let $f(x)=x^{2}, x \in R$. For any $A \subseteq R$, define $g(A)=\{x \in R: f(x) \in A\}$. If $S=[0,4]$, then which one of the following statements is not true?\\
solution:
Given, functions $f(x)=x^{2}, x \in R$

and $g(A)=\{x \in R: f(x) \in A\} ; A \subseteq R$

Now, for $S=[0,4]$

$$
\begin{array}{ll} 
& g(S)=\{x \in R: f(x) \in S=[0,4]\} \\
= & \left\{x \in R: x^{2} \in[0,4]\right\} \\
= & \{x \in R: x \in[-2,2]\} \\
& g(S)=[-2,2] \\
\text { So, } & f(g(S))=[0,4]=S \\
\text { Now, } f(S)= & \left\{x^{2}: x \in S=[0,4]\right\}=[0,16] \\
g(f(S))= & \{x \in R: f(x) \in f(S)=[0,16]\} \\
& =\{x \in R: f(x) \in[0,16]\} \\
& =\left\{x \in R: x^{2} \in[0,16]\right\} \\
& =\{x \in R: x \in[-4,4]\}=[-4,4]
\end{array}
$$

From above, it is clear that $g(f(S))=g(S)$.

question: If $f(x)=\log _{e} \frac{1-x}{1+x},|x|<1$, then $f \frac{2 x}{1+x^{2}}$ is equal to\\

question: For $x \in R-\{0,1\}$, let $f_{1}(x)=\frac{1}{x}, f_{2}(x)=1-x \quad$ and $f_{3}(x)=\frac{1}{1-x}$ be three given functions. If a function, $J(x)$ satisfies $\left(f_{2} \circ J \circ f_{1}\right)(x)=f_{3}(x)$, then $J(x)$ is equal to\\
solution:
We have,

$$
f_{1}(x)=\frac{1}{x}, f_{2}(x)=1-x \text { and } f_{3}(x)=\frac{1}{1-x}
$$

Also, we have $\left(f_{2} \circ J\right.$ o $\left.f_{1}\right)(x)=f_{3}(x)$

$$
\begin{array}{cc}
\Rightarrow & f_{2}\left(\left(J o f_{1}\right)(x)\right)=f_{3}(x) \\
\Rightarrow & f_{2}\left(J\left(f_{1}(x)\right)=f_{3}(x)\right. \\
\Rightarrow & 1-J\left(f_{1}(x)\right)=\frac{1}{1-x} \\
\Rightarrow & {\left[\because f_{2}(x)=1-x \text { and } f_{3}(x)=\frac{1}{1-x}\right]} \\
\Rightarrow & 1-J \frac{1}{x}=\frac{1}{1-x} \quad\left[\because f_{1}(x)=\frac{1}{x}\right] \\
& J \frac{1}{x}=1-\frac{1}{1-x} \\
& =\frac{1-x-1}{1-x}=\frac{-x}{1-x}
\end{array}
$$

Now, put $\frac{1}{x}=X$, then

$$
\begin{aligned}
J(X) & =\frac{\frac{-1}{X}}{1-\frac{1}{X}} \\
& =\frac{-1}{X-1}=\frac{1}{1-X}
\end{aligned}
$$

$\Rightarrow \quad J(X)=f_{3}(X)$ or $J(x)=f_{3}(x)$

question: Let $a, b, c \in R$. If $f(x)=a x^{2}+b x+c$ be such that $a+b+c=3$ and $f(x+y)=f(x)+f(y)+x y, \forall x, y \in R$, then $\sum_{n=1}^{10} f(n)$ is equal to\\
solution:
We have, $f(x)=a x^{2}+b x+c$

Now, $f(x+y)=f(x)+f(y)+x y$

Put $\quad y=0 \Rightarrow f(x)=f(x)+f(0)+0$

$$
\Rightarrow \quad f(0)=0
$$

$$
\Rightarrow \quad c=0
$$

Again, put $\quad y=-x$

$$
\begin{aligned}
\therefore & f(0) & =f(x)+f(-x)-x^{2} \\
\Rightarrow & 0 & =a x^{2}+b x+a x^{2}-b x-x^{2}
\end{aligned}
$$

$$
\begin{array}{lr}
\Rightarrow & 2 a x^{2}-x^{2}=0 \\
\Rightarrow & a=\frac{1}{2}
\end{array}
$$

Also, $a+b+c=3$

$$
\Rightarrow \quad \frac{1}{2}+b+0=3 \Rightarrow b=\frac{5}{2}
$$

$$
\therefore \quad f(x)=\frac{x^{2}+5 x}{2}
$$

Now, $\quad f(n)=\frac{n^{2}+5 n}{2}=\frac{1}{2} n^{2}+\frac{5}{2} n$

$$
\begin{aligned}
\therefore \quad \sum_{n=1}^{10} f(n) & =\frac{1}{2} \sum_{n=1}^{10} n^{2}+\frac{5}{2} \sum_{n=1}^{10} n \\
& =\frac{1}{2} \cdot \frac{10 \times 11 \times 21}{6}+\frac{5}{2} \times \frac{10 \times 11}{2} \\
& =\frac{385}{2}+\frac{275}{2}=\frac{660}{2}=330
\end{aligned}
$$

question: Let $A=\{x \in R: x$ is not a positive integer $\}$. Define a function $f: A \rightarrow R$ as $f(x)=\frac{2 x}{x-1}$, then $f$ is
solution:
We have a function $f: A \rightarrow R$ defined as, $f(x)=\frac{2 x}{x-1}$

One-one Let $x_{1}, x_{2} \in A$ such that

$$
\begin{aligned}
& & f\left(x_{1}\right) & =f\left(x_{2}\right) \\
& & \frac{2 x_{1}}{x_{1}-1} & =\frac{2 x_{2}}{x_{2}-1} \\
\Rightarrow & & 2 x_{1} x_{2}-2 x_{1} & =2 x_{1} x_{2}-2 x_{2} \\
\Rightarrow & & x_{1} & =x_{2}
\end{aligned}
$$

Thus, $f\left(x_{1}\right)=f\left(x_{2}\right)$ has only one solution, $x_{1}=x_{2}$

$\therefore f(x)$ is one-one (injective)

Onto Let $x=2$, then $f(2)=\frac{2 \times 2}{2-1}=4$

But $x=2$ is not in the domain, and $f(x)$ is one-one function

$\therefore f(x)$ can never be 4 .

Similarly, $f(x)$ can not take many values.

Hence, $f(x)$ is into (not surjective).

$\therefore f(x)$ is injective but not surjective.

question: If $f:[0, \infty) \rightarrow[0, \infty)$ and $f(x)=\frac{x}{1+x}$, then $f$ is\\
solution:
Given, $f:[0, \infty) \rightarrow[0, \infty)$

Here, domain is $[0, \infty)$ and codomain is $[0, \infty)$. Thus, to check one-one

Since, $f(x)=\frac{x}{1+x} \Rightarrow \quad f^{\prime}(x)=\frac{1}{(1+x)^{2}}>0, \forall x \in[0, \infty)$

$\therefore f(x)$ is increasing in its domain. Thus, $f(x)$ is one-one in its domain. To check onto (we find range)

$$
\begin{array}{rlrl} 
& \text { Again, } & y & =f(x)=\frac{x}{1+x} \\
\Rightarrow & & y+y x & =x \\
\Rightarrow & x & =\frac{y}{1-y} \Rightarrow \frac{y}{1-y} \geq 0
\end{array}
$$

Since, $x \geq 0$, therefore $0 \leq y<1$

i.e. Range $\neq$ Codomain

$\therefore f(x)$ is one-one but not onto.

question: If $f(x)=\sin x+\cos x, g(x)=x^{2}-1$, then $g\{f(x)\}$ is invertible in the domain\\
solution:
By definition of composition of function,

$g(f(x))=(\sin x+\cos x)^{2}-1$, is invertible (i.e. bijective)

$$
\Rightarrow \quad g\{f(x)\}=\sin 2 x \text { is bijective. }
$$

We know, $\sin x$ is bijective, only when $x \in-\frac{\pi}{2}, \frac{\pi}{2}$.

Thus, $g\{f(x)\}$ is bijective, if $-\frac{\pi}{2} \leq 2 x \leq \frac{\pi}{2}$

$$
\Rightarrow \quad-\frac{\pi}{4} \leq x \leq \frac{\pi}{4}
$$

question: Suppose $f(x)=(x+1)^{2}$ for $x \geq-1$. If $g(x)$ is the function whose graph is reflection of the graph of $f(x)$ with respect to the line $y=x$, then $g(x)$ equals\\
solution:
It is only to find the inverse.

$$
\begin{aligned}
\text { Let } & & y & =f(x)=(x+1)^{2}, \text { for } x \geq-1 \\
\Rightarrow & & \pm \sqrt{y} & =x+1, \quad x \geq-1 \\
\Rightarrow & & \sqrt{y} & =x+1 \quad \Rightarrow \quad y \geq 0, x+1 \geq 0 \\
\Rightarrow & & x & =\sqrt{y}-1 \\
\Rightarrow & & f^{-1}(y) & =\sqrt{y}-1 \\
& & f^{-1}(x) & =\sqrt{x}-1 \Rightarrow x \geq 0
\end{aligned}
$$

question: If $f:[1, \infty) \rightarrow[2, \infty)$ is given by $f(x)=x+\frac{1}{x}$, then $f^{-1}(x)$ equals\\
solution:
Let $y=x+\frac{1}{x} \quad \Rightarrow \quad y=\frac{x^{2}+1}{x}$

$\Rightarrow x y=x^{2}+1$

$\Rightarrow \quad x^{2}-x y+1=0 \quad \Rightarrow \quad x=\frac{y \pm \sqrt{y^{2}-4}}{2}$

$\Rightarrow \quad f^{-1}(y)=\frac{y \pm \sqrt{y^{2}-4}}{2}$

$$
\Rightarrow \quad f^{-1}(x)=\frac{x \pm \sqrt{x^{2}-4}}{2}
$$

Since, the range of the inverse function is $[1, \infty)$, then

we take

$$
f^{-1}(x)=\frac{x+\sqrt{x^{2}-4}}{2}
$$

If we consider $f^{-1}(x)=\frac{x-\sqrt{x^{2}-4}}{2}$, then $f^{-1}(x)>1$

This is possible only if $(x-2)^{2}>x^{2}-4$

$$
\begin{array}{lc}
\Rightarrow & x^{2}+4-4 x>x^{2}-4 \\
\Rightarrow & 8>4 x \\
\Rightarrow & x<2, \text { where } x>2
\end{array}
$$

Therefore, (a) is the answer.

question: If the function $f:[1, \infty) \rightarrow[1, \infty)$ is defined by $f(x)=2^{x(x-1)}$, then $f^{-1}(x)$ is\\
solution:
Let $y=2^{x(x-1)}$, where $y \geq 1$ as $x \geq 1$

Taking $\log _{2}$ on both sides, we get

$$
\begin{array}{rlrl} 
& & \log _{2} y & =\log _{2} 2^{x(x-1)} \\
\Rightarrow & \log _{2} y & =x(x-1) \\
\Rightarrow & x^{2}-x-\log _{2} y & =0 \\
\Rightarrow & & x & =\frac{1 \pm \sqrt{1+4 \log _{2} y}}{2}
\end{array}
$$

For $y \geq 1, \log _{2} y \geq 0 \Rightarrow 4 \log _{2} y \geq 0 \Rightarrow 1+4 \log _{2} y \geq 1$

$$
\begin{array}{lc}
\Rightarrow & \sqrt{1+4 \log _{2} y} \geq 1 \\
\Rightarrow & -\sqrt{1+4 \log _{2} y} \leq-1 \\
\Rightarrow & 1-\sqrt{1+4 \log _{2} y} \leq 0
\end{array}
$$

But $\quad x \geq 1$

So, $x=1-\sqrt{1+4 \log _{2} y}$ is not possible.

Therefore, we take $x=\frac{1}{2}\left(1+\sqrt{1+4 \log _{2} y}\right)$

$$
\begin{array}{ll}
\Rightarrow & f^{-1}(y)=\frac{1}{2}\left(1+\sqrt{1+4 \log _{2} y}\right) \\
\Rightarrow & f^{-1}(x)=\frac{1}{2}\left(1+\sqrt{1+4 \log _{2} x}\right)
\end{array}
$$

question: $\lim _{x \rightarrow 0} \frac{x+2 \sin x}{\sqrt{x^{2}+2 \sin x+1}-\sqrt{\sin ^{2} x-x+1}}$ is\\
solution:
Let

$P=\lim _{x \rightarrow 0} \frac{x+2 \sin x}{\sqrt{x^{2}+2 \sin x+1}-\sqrt{\sin ^{2} x-x+1}} \quad \frac{0}{0}$ form

On rationalization, we get


\begin{align*}
& P=\lim _{x \rightarrow 0} \frac{(x+2 \sin x)}{x^{2}+2 \sin x+1-\sin ^{2} x+x-1} \\
& \times\left(\sqrt{x^{2}+2 \sin x+1}+\sqrt{\sin ^{2} x-x+1}\right) \\
& =\lim _{x \rightarrow 0}\left(\sqrt{x^{2}+2 \sin x+1}+\sqrt{\sin ^{2} x-x+1}\right) \\
& \times \lim _{x \rightarrow 0} \frac{x+2 \sin x}{x^{2}-\sin ^{2} x+2 \sin x+x} \\
& =2 \times \lim _{x \rightarrow 0} \frac{x+2 \sin x}{x^{2}-\sin ^{2} x+2 \sin x+x} \tag{0}
\end{align*}


Now applying the L' Hopital's rule, we get

$$
\begin{aligned}
& P=2 \times \lim _{x \rightarrow 0} \frac{1+2 \cos x}{2 x-\sin 2 x+2 \cos x+1} \\
& =2 \frac{(1+2)}{0-0+2+1} \\
& =2 \times \frac{3}{3}=2 \\
& \Rightarrow \lim _{x \rightarrow 0} \frac{x+2 \sin x}{\sqrt{x^{2}+2 \sin x+1}-\sqrt{\sin ^{2} x-x+1}}=2
\end{aligned}
$$

question: If $\lim _{x \rightarrow 1} \frac{x^{2}-a x+b}{x-1}=5$, then $a+b$ is equal to\\
solution:
It is given that $\lim _{x \rightarrow 1} \frac{x^{2}-a x+b}{x-1}=5$

Since, limit exist and equal to 5 and denominator is zero at $x=1$, so numerator $x^{2}-a x+b$ should be zero at $x=1$,

So $\quad 1-a+b=0 \quad \Rightarrow \quad a=1+b$

On putting the value of ' $a$ ' from Eq. (ii) in Eq. (i), we get


\begin{align*}
\lim _{x \rightarrow 1} \frac{x^{2}-(1+b) x+b}{x-1} & =5 \Rightarrow \lim _{x \rightarrow 1} \frac{\left(x^{2}-x\right)-b(x-1)}{x-1}=5 \\
\Rightarrow \quad \lim _{x \rightarrow 1} \frac{(x-1)(x-b)}{x-1} & =5 \Rightarrow \lim _{x \rightarrow 1}(x-b)=5 \\
\Rightarrow \quad 1-b & =5 \\
\Rightarrow \quad b & =-4 \tag{iii}
\end{align*}


On putting value of ' $b$ ' from Eq. (iii) to Eq. (ii), we get

$$
\begin{aligned}
a & =-3 \\
\text { So, } \quad a+b & =-7
\end{aligned}
$$

question: $\lim _{y \rightarrow 0} \frac{\sqrt{1+\sqrt{1+y^{4}}}-\sqrt{2}}{y^{4}}$
solution:
Clearly,

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \lim _{y \rightarrow 0} \frac{\sqrt{1+\sqrt{1+y^{4}}}-\sqrt{2}}{y^{4}} \\
& =\lim _{y \rightarrow 0} \frac{\sqrt{1+\sqrt{1+y^{4}}}-\sqrt{2}}{y^{4}} \times \frac{\sqrt{1+\sqrt{1+y^{4}}}+\sqrt{2}}{\sqrt{1+\sqrt{1+y^{4}}}+\sqrt{2}}
\end{aligned}
$$

[rationalising the numerator] $=\lim _{y \rightarrow 0} \frac{\left(1+\sqrt{1+y^{4}}\right)-2}{y^{4}\left(\sqrt{1+\sqrt{1+y^{4}}}+\sqrt{2}\right)}\left[\because(a+b)(a-b)=a^{2}-b^{2}\right]$

$=\lim _{y \rightarrow 0} \frac{\sqrt{1+y^{4}}-1}{y^{4}\left(\sqrt{1+\sqrt{1+y^{4}}}+\sqrt{2}\right)} \times \frac{\sqrt{1+y^{4}}+1}{\sqrt{1+y^{4}}+1}$

[again, rationalising the numerator]

$=\lim _{y \rightarrow 0} \frac{y^{4}}{y^{4}\left(\sqrt{1+\sqrt{1+y^{4}}}+\sqrt{2}\right)\left(\sqrt{1+y^{4}}+1\right)}$

$=\frac{1}{2 \sqrt{2} \times 2}$

(by cancelling $y^{4}$ and then by direct substitution). $=\frac{1}{4 \sqrt{2}}$.

\begin{array}{lr}
\therefore & \lim _{x \rightarrow \infty} \frac{x^{2}+x+1}{x+1}-a x-b=4 \\
\Rightarrow & \lim _{x \rightarrow \infty} \frac{x^{2}+x+1-a x^{2}-a x-b x-b}{x+1}=4 \\
\Rightarrow \quad \lim _{x \rightarrow \infty} \frac{x^{2}(1-a)+x(1-a-b)+(1-b)}{x+1}=4
\end{array}
$$

Here, we make degree of numerator

$=$ degree of denominator

$$
\begin{aligned}
\therefore & & 1-a=0 \quad \Rightarrow \quad a & =1 \\
& \text { and } & \lim _{x \rightarrow \infty} \frac{x(1-a-b)+(1-b)}{x+1} & =4 \\
\Rightarrow & & 1-a-b & =4 \\
\Rightarrow & & b & =-4 \quad[\because(1-a)=0]
\end{aligned}
$$

question: $\lim _{h \rightarrow 0} \frac{f\left(2 h+2+h^{2}\right)-f(2)}{f\left(h-h^{2}+1\right)-f(1)}$, given that $f^{\prime}(2)=6$ and $f^{\prime}(1)=4$,\\
solution:
Here, $\lim _{h \rightarrow 0} \frac{f\left(2 h+2+h^{2}\right)-f(2)}{f\left(h-h^{2}+1\right)-f(1)}$

$$
\left[\because f^{\prime}(2)=6 \text { and } f^{\prime}(1)=4, \text { given }\right]
$$

Applying L'Hospital's rule,

$$
\begin{aligned}
& =\lim _{h \rightarrow 0} \frac{\left\{f^{\prime}\left(2 h+2+h^{2}\right)\right\} \cdot(2+2 h)-0}{\left\{f^{\prime}\left(h-h^{2}+1\right)\right\} \cdot(1-2 h)-0}=\frac{f^{\prime}(2) \cdot 2}{f^{\prime}(1) \cdot 1} \\
& =\frac{6 \cdot 2}{4 \cdot 1}=3 \quad\left[\text { using } f^{\prime}(2)=6 \text { and } f^{\prime}(1)=4\right]
\end{aligned}
$$

question: If $\lim _{x \rightarrow 0} \frac{\{(a-n) n x-\tan x\} \sin n x}{x^{2}}=0$, where $n$ is non-zero real number, then $\alpha$ is equal to\\
The integer $n$ for which $\lim _{x \rightarrow 0} \frac{(\cos x-1)\left(\cos x-e^{x}\right)}{x^{n}}$ is a finite non-zero number, is\\
solution:
$\lim _{x \rightarrow 0} \frac{(\cos x-1)\left(\cos x-e^{x}\right)}{x^{n}}$

$$
\begin{aligned}
& 1-\frac{x^{2}}{2!}+\frac{x^{4}}{4!}-\ldots \\
& -1+x+\frac{x^{2}}{2!}+\frac{x^{3}}{3!}+\ldots \\
& =\lim _{x \rightarrow 0} \longrightarrow x^{n} \\
& =\lim _{x \rightarrow 0} \frac{-2 \sin ^{2} \frac{x}{2} \quad-x-\frac{2 x^{2}}{2!}-\frac{x^{3}}{3!}-\ldots}{4 \frac{x^{2}}{2} x^{n-2}} \\
& =\lim _{x \rightarrow 0} \frac{\sin ^{2} \frac{x}{2} 1+x+\frac{x^{2}}{3!}+\ldots}{2 \frac{x^{2}}{2} x^{n-3}}
\end{aligned}
$$

Above limit is finite, if $n-3=0$, i.e. $n=3$.

question: The value of $\lim _{x \rightarrow 0} \frac{\sqrt{\frac{1}{2}\left(1-\cos ^{2} x\right)}}{x}$ is\\
solution:
$\lim _{x \rightarrow 0} \frac{\sqrt{\frac{1}{2}\left(1-\cos ^{2} x\right)}}{x}=\lim _{x \rightarrow 0} \frac{1}{\sqrt{2}} \cdot \frac{|\sin x|}{x}$

At

$x=0$

$$

and

Here, $\quad \mathrm{RHL} \neq \mathrm{LHL}$

solution:
