question: If $G(x)=-\sqrt{25-x^{2}}$, then $\lim _{x \rightarrow 1} \frac{G(x)-G(1)}{x-1}$ has the value\\\\
Let $\alpha, \beta \in R$ be such that $\lim _{x \rightarrow 0} \frac{x^{2} \sin (\beta x)}{\alpha x-\sin x}=1$. Then, $6(\alpha+\beta)$ equals
solution:
Here, $\lim _{x \rightarrow 0} \frac{x^{2} \sin (\beta x)}{\alpha x-\sin x}=1$

$$
\Rightarrow \quad \lim _{x \rightarrow 0} \frac{x^{2} \beta x-\frac{(\beta x)^{3}}{3!}+\frac{(\beta x)^{5}}{5!}-\ldots}{\alpha x-x-\frac{x^{3}}{3!}+\frac{x^{5}}{5!}-\ldots}=1
$$

$$
\Rightarrow \quad \lim _{x \rightarrow 0} \frac{x^{3} \beta-\frac{\beta^{3} x^{2}}{3!}+\frac{\beta^{5} x^{4}}{5!}-\ldots}{(\alpha-1) x+\frac{x^{3}}{3!}+\frac{x^{5}}{5!}-\ldots}=1
$$

Limit exists only, when $\alpha-1=0$


\begin{align*}
& \Rightarrow \quad \alpha=1  \tag{i}\\
& \therefore \quad \lim _{x \rightarrow 0} \frac{x^{3} \beta-\frac{\beta^{3} x^{2}}{3!}+\frac{\beta^{5} x^{4}}{5!}-\ldots}{x^{3} \frac{1}{3!}-\frac{x^{2}}{5!}-\ldots}=1 \\
& \Rightarrow \quad 6 \beta=1 \tag{ii}
\end{align*}


From Eqs. (i) and (ii), we get

$$
\begin{aligned}
6(\alpha+\beta) & =6 \alpha+6 \beta \\
& =6+1=7
\end{aligned}
$$

question: Let $m$ and $n$ be two positive integers greater than 1 . If $\lim _{\alpha \rightarrow 0} \frac{e^{\cos \left(\alpha^{n}\right)}-e}{\alpha^{m}}=-\frac{e}{2}$, then the value of $\frac{m}{n}$ is
solution:
Given, $\lim _{\alpha \rightarrow 0} \frac{e^{\cos \left(\alpha^{n}\right)}-e}{\alpha^{m}}=-\frac{e}{2}$

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \Rightarrow \quad \lim _{\alpha \rightarrow 0} \frac{e\left\{e^{\cos \left(\alpha^{n}\right)-1}-1\right\}}{\cos \left(\alpha^{n}\right)-1} \cdot \frac{\cos \left(\alpha^{n}\right)-1}{\alpha^{m}}=\frac{-e}{2} \\
& \Rightarrow \quad \lim _{\alpha \rightarrow 0} e \frac{e^{\cos \left(\alpha^{n}\right)-1}-1}{\cos \left(\alpha^{n}\right)-1} \cdot \lim _{\alpha \rightarrow 0} \frac{-2 \sin ^{2} \frac{\alpha^{n}}{2}}{\alpha^{m}}=-e / 2
\end{aligned}
$$

$$
\Rightarrow \quad e \times 1 \times(-2) \lim _{\alpha \rightarrow 0} \frac{\sin ^{2} \frac{\alpha^{n}}{2}}{\frac{\alpha^{2 n}}{4}} \cdot \frac{\alpha^{2 n}}{4 \alpha^{m}}=\frac{-e}{2}
$$

$$
\Rightarrow \quad e \times 1 \times-2 \times 1 \times \lim _{\alpha \rightarrow 0} \frac{\alpha^{2 n-m}}{4}=\frac{-e}{2}
$$

For this to be exists, $2 n-m=0$

$$
\Rightarrow \quad \frac{m}{n}=2
$$

question: Let $f: R \rightarrow R$ be a differentiable function satisfying $f^{\prime}(3)+f^{\prime}(2)=0$. Then $\lim _{x \rightarrow 0} \frac{1+f(3+x)-f(3)}{1+f(2-x)-f(2)}^{\frac{1}{x}}$ is equal to\\
solution:
Let $l=\lim _{x \rightarrow 0} \frac{1+f(3+x)-f(3)}{1+f(2-x)-f(2)}^{\frac{1}{x}}$ $\left[1^{\infty}\right.$ form $]$

$$
\begin{aligned}
\Rightarrow \quad l & =e^{\lim _{x \rightarrow 0} \frac{1}{x} 1-\frac{1+f(3+x)-f(3)}{1+f(2-x)-f(2)}} \\
& =e^{\lim _{x \rightarrow 0} \frac{1+f(2-x)-f(2)-1-f(3+x)+f(3)}{x(1+f(2-x)-f(2))}} \\
& =e^{\lim _{x \rightarrow 0} \frac{f(2-x)-f(3+x)+f(3)-f(2)}{x(1+f(2-x)-f(2))}}
\end{aligned}
$$

On applying L'Hopital rule, we get

$$
l=e^{\lim _{x \rightarrow 0} \frac{f^{\prime}(2-x)-f^{\prime}(3+x)}{1-x f^{\prime}(2-x)+f(2-x)-f(2)}}
$$

On applying limit, we get

$$
l=e^{\frac{f^{\prime}(2)-f^{\prime}(3)}{1-0+f(2)-f(2)}}=e^{0}=1
$$

So, $\lim _{x \rightarrow 0} \frac{1+f(3+x)-f(3)}{1+f(2-x)-f(2)}^{\frac{1}{x}}=1$

question: $\lim _{x \rightarrow 1_{-}} \frac{\sqrt{\pi}-\sqrt{2 \sin ^{-1} x}}{\sqrt{1-x}}$ is equal to\\
solution:
Let $L=\lim _{x \rightarrow 1^{-}} \frac{\sqrt{\pi}-\sqrt{2 \sin ^{-1} x}}{\sqrt{1-x}}$, then

$$
L=\lim _{x \rightarrow 1^{-}} \frac{\sqrt{\pi}-\sqrt{2 \sin ^{-1} x}}{\sqrt{1-x}} \times \frac{\sqrt{\pi}+\sqrt{2 \sin ^{-1} x}}{\sqrt{\pi}+\sqrt{2 \sin ^{-1} x}}
$$

[on rationalization]

$=\lim _{x \rightarrow 1^{-}} \frac{\pi-2 \sin ^{-1} x}{\sqrt{1-x}} \times \frac{1}{\sqrt{\pi}+\sqrt{2 \sin ^{-1} x}}$

$=\lim _{x \rightarrow 1^{-}} \frac{\pi-2 \frac{\pi}{2}-\cos ^{-1} x}{\sqrt{1-x}} \times \frac{1}{\sqrt{\pi}+\sqrt{2 \sin ^{-1} x}}$

$$
\because \sin ^{-1} x+\cos ^{-1} x=\frac{\pi}{2}
$$

$=\lim _{x \rightarrow 1^{-}} \frac{2 \cos ^{-1} x}{\sqrt{1-x}} \times \lim _{x \rightarrow 1^{-}} \frac{1}{\sqrt{\pi}+\sqrt{2 \sin ^{-1} x}}$

$=\frac{1}{2 \sqrt{\pi}} \lim _{x \rightarrow 1^{-}} \frac{2 \cos ^{-1} x}{\sqrt{1-x}} \quad \because \lim _{x \rightarrow 1^{-}} \sin ^{-1} x=\frac{\pi}{2}$

Put $x=\cos \theta$, then as $x \rightarrow 1^{-}$, therefore $\theta \rightarrow 0^{+}$

Now, $L=\frac{1}{2 \sqrt{\pi}} \lim _{\theta \rightarrow 0^{+}} \frac{2 \theta}{\sqrt{1-\cos } \theta}$

$=\frac{1}{2 \sqrt{\pi}} \lim _{0^{+}} \frac{2 \theta}{\sqrt{2} \sin \frac{\theta}{2}} \quad \because 1-\cos \theta=2 \sin ^{2} \frac{\theta}{2}$

$=\frac{1}{2 \sqrt{\pi}} \cdot \sqrt{2} \lim _{\theta \rightarrow 0^{+}} \frac{2 \cdot \frac{\theta}{2}}{\sin \frac{\theta}{2}}$

$=\frac{1}{2 \sqrt{\pi}} 2 \sqrt{2}=\sqrt{\frac{2}{\pi}} \quad \because \lim _{x \rightarrow 0^{+}} \frac{\theta}{\sin \theta}=1$

question:
Let $[x]$ denote the greatest integer less than or equal to $x$. Then,

$$
\lim _{x \rightarrow 0} \frac{\tan \left(\pi \sin ^{2} x\right)+(|x|-\sin (x[x]))^{2}}{x^{2}}
$$\\
solution:
Key Idea $\lim _{x \rightarrow a} f(x)$ exist iff

$$
\lim _{x \rightarrow a^{+}} f(x)=\lim _{x \rightarrow a^{-}} f(x)
$$

At $x=0$,

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathrm{RHL} & =\lim _{x \rightarrow 0^{+}} \frac{\tan \left(\pi \sin ^{2} x\right)+(|x|-\sin (x[x]))^{2}}{x^{2}} \\
& =\lim _{x \rightarrow 0^{+}} \frac{\tan \left(\pi \sin ^{2} x\right)+(x-\sin (x \cdot 0))^{2}}{x^{2}}
\end{aligned}
$$

$\because|x|=x$ for $x>0$ and $[x]=0$ for $0<x<1$

$$
\begin{aligned}
& =\lim _{x \rightarrow 0^{+}} \frac{\tan \left(\pi \sin ^{2} x\right)+x^{2}}{x^{2}} \\
& =\lim _{x \rightarrow 0^{+}} \frac{\tan \left(\pi \sin ^{2} x\right)}{\pi \sin ^{2} x} \cdot \frac{\pi \sin ^{2} x}{x^{2}}+1
\end{aligned}
$$

$$
\begin{array}{ll}
=\pi \lim _{x \rightarrow 0^{+}} \frac{\tan \left(\pi \sin ^{2} x\right)}{\pi \sin ^{2} x} \cdot \lim _{x \rightarrow 0^{+}} \frac{\sin ^{2} x}{x^{2}}+1 \\
=\pi+1 & \because \quad \lim _{x \rightarrow 0} \frac{\tan x}{x}=1 \\
& \text { and } \lim _{x \rightarrow 0} \frac{\sin x}{x}=1
\end{array}
$$

and $\mathrm{LHL}$

$$
\begin{aligned}
& =\lim _{x \rightarrow 0^{-}} \frac{\tan \left(\pi \sin ^{2} x\right)+\left(|x|-\sin (x[x])^{2}\right.}{x^{2}} \\
& =\lim _{x \rightarrow 0^{-}} \frac{\tan \left(\pi \sin ^{2} x\right)+\left(-x-\sin (x(-1))^{2}\right.}{x^{2}} \\
& \because|x|=-x \text { for } x<0 \\
& \text { and }[x]=-1 \text { for }-1<x<0 \\
& =\lim _{x \rightarrow 0^{-}} \frac{\tan \left(\pi \sin ^{2} x\right)+(x+\sin (-x))^{2}}{x^{2}} \\
& =\lim _{x \rightarrow 0^{-}} \frac{\tan \left(\pi \sin ^{2} x\right)+(x-\sin x)^{2}}{x^{2}} \\
& {[\because \sin (-\theta)=-\sin \theta]} \\
& =\lim _{x \rightarrow 0^{-}} \frac{\tan \left(\pi \sin ^{2} x\right)+x^{2}+\sin ^{2} x-2 x \sin x}{x^{2}} \\
& =\lim _{x \rightarrow 0^{-}} \frac{\tan \left(\pi \sin ^{2} x\right)}{x^{2}}+1+\frac{\sin ^{2} x}{x^{2}}-\frac{2 x \sin x}{x^{2}} \\
& =\lim _{x \rightarrow 0^{-}} \frac{\tan \left(\pi \sin ^{2} x\right)}{\pi \sin ^{2} x} \cdot \frac{\pi \sin ^{2} x}{x^{2}}+1+\frac{\sin ^{2} x}{x^{2}}-2 \frac{\sin x}{x} \\
& =\lim _{x \rightarrow 0^{-}} \frac{\tan \left(\pi \sin ^{2} x\right)}{\pi \sin ^{2} x} \cdot \lim _{x \rightarrow 0^{-}} \frac{\pi \sin ^{2} x}{x^{2}}+ \\
& 1+\lim _{x \rightarrow 0^{-}} \frac{\sin ^{2} x}{x^{2}}-2 \lim _{x \rightarrow 0^{-}} \frac{\sin x}{x}
\end{aligned}
$$

$\because \mathrm{RHL} \neq \mathrm{LHL}$

$\therefore$ Limit does not exist

question:
For each $t \in R$, let $[t]$ be the greatest integer less than or equal to $t$. Then,

$$
\lim _{x \rightarrow 1+} \frac{(1-|x|+\sin |1-x|) \sin \frac{\pi}{2}[1-x]}{|1-x|[1-x]}
$$\\
solution:
Given,

$$
\lim _{x \rightarrow 1^{+}} \frac{(1-|x|+\sin |1-x|) \sin \frac{\pi}{2}[1-x]}{|1-x|[1-x]}
$$

Put $x=1+h$, then

$x \rightarrow 1^{+} \Rightarrow h \rightarrow 0^{+}$

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \therefore \lim _{x \rightarrow 1^{+}} \frac{(1-|x|+\sin |1-x|) \sin \frac{\pi}{2}[1-x]}{|1-x|[1-x]} \\
& =\lim _{h \rightarrow 0^{+}} \frac{(1-|h+1|+\sin |-h|) \sin \frac{\pi}{2}[-h]}{|-h|[-h]} \\
& =\lim _{h \rightarrow 0^{+}} \frac{(1-(h+1)+\sin h) \sin \frac{\pi}{2}[-h]}{h[-h]} \\
& (\because|-h|=h \text { and }|h+1|=h+1 \text { as } h>0)
\end{aligned}
$$

$=\lim _{h \rightarrow 0^{+}} \frac{(-h+\sin h) \sin \frac{\pi}{2}(-1)}{h(-1)}$

$\left(\because[x]=-1\right.$ for $-1<x<0$ and $\left.\left.h \rightarrow 0^{+} \Rightarrow-h \rightarrow 0\right\urcorner\right)$

$=\lim _{h \rightarrow 0^{+}} \frac{(-h+\sinh )}{-h} \sin \frac{-\pi}{2}$

$=\lim _{h \rightarrow 0^{+}} \frac{\sin h}{h}-\lim _{h \rightarrow 0^{+}} \frac{h}{h}$

$=\lim _{h \rightarrow 0^{+}} \frac{\sin h}{h}-\lim _{h \rightarrow 0^{+}} \frac{h}{h}=1-1=0 \because \lim _{h \rightarrow 0^{+}} \frac{\sin h}{h}=1$

question:
For each $x \in R$, let $[x]$ be the greatest integer less than or equal to $x$. Then,

$\lim _{x \rightarrow 0^{-}} \frac{x([x]+|x|) \sin [x]}{|x|}$ is equal to\\
solution:
$\lim _{x \rightarrow 0^{-}} \frac{x([x]+|x|) \sin [x]}{|x|}=\lim _{x \rightarrow 0^{-}} \frac{x([x]-x) \sin [x]}{-x}$

$$
\begin{aligned}
& =\lim _{x \rightarrow 0^{-}} \frac{x(-1-x) \sin (-1)}{-x} \quad\left(\because \lim _{x \rightarrow 0^{-}}[x]=-1\right) \\
& =\lim _{x \rightarrow 0^{-}} \frac{-x(x+1) \sin (-1)}{-x}=\lim _{x \rightarrow 0^{-}}(x+1) \sin (-1) \\
& =(0+1) \sin (-1) \text { (by direct substitution) } \\
& =-\sin 1 \quad(\because \sin (-\theta)=-\sin \theta)
\end{aligned}
$$

question:
For each $t \in \mathbf{R}$, let $[t]$ be the greatest integer less than or equal to $t$. Then,

$$
\lim _{x \rightarrow 0^{+}} x \frac{1}{x}+\frac{2}{x}+\ldots+\frac{15}{x}
$$\\
solution:
Key Idea Use property of greatest integer function $[x]=x-\{x\}$.

$$
\lim _{x \rightarrow 0^{+}} x \frac{1}{x}+\frac{2}{x}+\ldots+\frac{15}{x}
$$

We know, $[x]=x-\{x\}$

$$
\therefore \quad \frac{1}{x}=\frac{1}{x}-\frac{1}{x}
$$

Similarly, $\quad \frac{n}{x}=\frac{n}{x}-\frac{n}{x}$

$\therefore$ Given limit $=\lim _{x \rightarrow 0^{+}} x \frac{1}{x}-\frac{1}{x}+\frac{2}{x}-\frac{2}{x}+\ldots \frac{15}{x}-\frac{15}{x}$

$=\lim _{x \rightarrow 0^{+}}(1+2+3+\ldots+15)-x \frac{1}{x}+\frac{2}{x}+\ldots+\frac{15}{x}$

$=120-0=120$

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \because 0 \leq \frac{n}{x}<1, \text { therefore } \\
& 0 \leq x \frac{n}{x} \quad<x \Rightarrow \lim _{x \rightarrow 0^{+}} x \frac{n}{x}=0
\end{aligned}
$$

question:
Let $f(x)=\frac{1-x(1+|1-x|)}{|1-x|} \cos \frac{1}{1-x}$

for $x \neq 1$. Then
solution:
$f(x)=\frac{1-x(1+|1-x|)}{|1-x|} \cos \frac{1}{1-x}$

Now, $\lim _{x \rightarrow 1^{-}} f(x)=\lim _{x \rightarrow 1^{-}} \frac{1-x(1+1-x)}{1-x} \cos \frac{1}{1-x}$

$$
=\lim _{x \rightarrow 1^{-}}(1-x) \cos \frac{1}{1-x}=0
$$

and $\lim _{x \rightarrow 1^{+}} f(x)=\lim _{x \rightarrow 1^{+}} \frac{1-x(1-1+x)}{x-1} \cos \frac{1}{1-x}$

$$
=\lim _{x \rightarrow 1^{+}}-(x+1) \cdot \cos \frac{1}{x+1}, \text { which does not exist. }
$$

question: Let $p=\lim _{x \rightarrow 0^{+}}\left(1+\tan ^{2} \sqrt{x}\right)^{1 / 2 x}$, then $\log p$ is $\underset{\text { }}{\text { equal to }}$\\

Let $\alpha(a)$ and $\beta(a)$ be the roots of the equation $(\sqrt[3]{1+a}-1) x^{2}-(\sqrt{1+a}-1) x+(\sqrt[6]{1+a}-1)=0$, where $a>-1$. Then, $\lim _{a \rightarrow 0^{+}} \alpha(a)$ and $\lim _{a \rightarrow 0^{+}} \beta(a)$ are
\\
solution:
PLAN To make the quadratic into simple form we should eliminate radical sign.

Description of Situation As for given equation, when $a \rightarrow 0$ the equation reduces to identity in $x$. i.e. $a x^{2}+b x+c=0, \forall x \in R$ or $a=b=c \rightarrow 0$

Thus, first we should make above equation independent from coefficients as 0 .

Let $a+1=t^{6}$. Thus, when $a \rightarrow 0, t \rightarrow 1$.

$$
\begin{array}{rlrl}
\therefore & & \left(t^{2}-1\right) x^{2}+\left(t^{3}-1\right) x+(t-1) & =0 \\
\Rightarrow & (t-1)\left\{(t+1) x^{2}+\left(t^{2}+t+1\right) x+1\right\} & =0, \text { as } t \rightarrow 1 \\
\Rightarrow & 2 x^{2}+3 x+1 & =0 \\
\Rightarrow & 2 x^{2}+2 x+x+1 & =0 \\
& & (2 x+1)(x+1) & =0
\end{array}
$$

Thus,

$x=-1,-1 / 2$

$$
\text { or } \quad \lim _{a \rightarrow 0^{+}} \alpha(a)=-1 / 2
$$

$$
\text { and } \quad \lim _{a \rightarrow 0^{+}} \beta(a)=-1
$$

Let $f: R \rightarrow R$ be such that $f(1)=3$ and $f^{\prime}(1)=6$. Then, $\lim _{x \rightarrow 0} \frac{f(1+x)}{f(1)}^{1 / x}$ equals\\
solution:
Let $y=\frac{f(1+x)}{f(1)}{ }^{1 / x} \Rightarrow \log y=\frac{1}{x}[\log f(1+x)-\log f(1)]$

$\Rightarrow \quad \lim _{x \rightarrow 0} \log y=\lim _{x \rightarrow 0} \frac{1}{f(1+x)} \cdot f^{\prime}(1+x)$

$$
=\frac{f(1)}{f(1)}=\frac{6}{3}
$$

$\Rightarrow \log \lim _{x \rightarrow 0} y=2 \Rightarrow \quad \lim _{x \rightarrow 0} y=e^{2}$

question: For $x \in R, \lim _{x \rightarrow \infty} \frac{x-3}{x+2} \quad$ is equal to\\
solution: For $x \in R, \lim _{x \rightarrow \infty} \frac{x-3}{x+2}=\lim _{x \rightarrow \infty} \frac{(1-3 / x)^{x}}{(1+2 / x)^{x}}=\frac{e^{-3}}{e^{2}}=e^{-5}$

question: The largest value of the non-negative integer $a$ for which $\lim _{x \rightarrow 1} \frac{-a x+\sin (x-1)+a}{x+\sin (x-1)-1}{ }^{\frac{1-x}{1-\sqrt{x}}}=\frac{1}{4}$ is
solution:
PLAN $\lim _{x \rightarrow 0} \frac{\sin x}{x}=1$

Given, $\lim _{x \rightarrow 1} \frac{\sin (x-1)+a(1-x)}{(x-1)+\sin (x-1)} \frac{(1+\sqrt{x})(1-\sqrt{x})}{1-\sqrt{x}}=\frac{1}{4}$

$$
\begin{array}{ll} 
& \lim _{x \rightarrow 1} \frac{\frac{\sin (x-1)}{(x-1)}-a}{1+\frac{\sin (x-1)}{(x-1)}}=\frac{1}{4} \\
\Rightarrow \quad & \frac{1-a^{2}}{2}{ }^{2}=\frac{1}{4} \Rightarrow(a-1)^{2}=1 \\
\Rightarrow \quad & a=2 \text { or } 0
\end{array}
$$

Hence, the maximum value of $a$ is 2 .

question:
For each positive integer $n$, let

$$
y_{n}=\frac{1}{n}((n+1)(n+2) \ldots(n+n))^{\frac{1}{n}}
$$

For $x \in R$, let $[x]$ be the greatest integer less than or equal to $x$. If $\lim _{n \rightarrow \infty} y_{n}=L$, then the value of $[L]$ is
solution:
We have,

$$
\begin{aligned}
& y_{n}=\frac{1}{n}[(n+1)(n+2) \ldots(n+n)]^{1 / n} \\
& \text { and } \lim _{n \rightarrow \infty} y_{n}=L \\
& \Rightarrow \quad L=\lim _{n \rightarrow \infty} \frac{1}{n}[(n+1)(n+2)(n+3) \ldots(n+n)]^{1 / n} \\
& \Rightarrow \quad L=\lim _{n \rightarrow \infty} 1+\frac{1}{n} \quad 1+\frac{2}{n} \quad 1+\frac{3}{n} \ldots 1+\frac{n}{n}{ }^{\frac{1}{n}} \\
& \Rightarrow \log L=\lim _{n \rightarrow \infty} \frac{1}{n} \log 1+\frac{1}{n}+\log 1+\frac{2}{n} \ldots \log 1+\frac{n}{n} \\
& \Rightarrow \log L=\lim _{n \rightarrow \infty} \frac{1}{n} \sum_{r=1}^{n} \log 1+\frac{r}{n} \\
& \Rightarrow \log L=\int_{0}^{1} \frac{1}{I I} \times \log (l+x) d x \\
& \Rightarrow \log L=(x \cdot \log (1+x))_{0}^{1}-\int_{0}^{1} \frac{d}{d x}\left(\log (1+x) \int d x d x\right.
\end{aligned}
$$

[by using integration by parts]

$\Rightarrow \log L=[x \log (1+\mathrm{x})]_{0}^{1}-\int_{0}^{1} \frac{\mathrm{x}}{1+\mathrm{x}} d x$

$\Rightarrow \log L=\log 2-\int_{0}^{1} \frac{x+1}{x+1}-\frac{1}{x+1} d x$

$\Rightarrow \log \mathrm{L}=\log 2-[\mathrm{x}]_{0}^{1}+[\log (\mathrm{x}+1)]_{0}^{1}$

$\Rightarrow \log \mathrm{L}=\log 2-1+\log 2-0$

$\Rightarrow \log L=\log 4-\log e=\log \frac{4}{e} \Rightarrow L=\frac{4}{e} \Rightarrow$

$[L]=\frac{4}{e}=1$

question: The function $f(x)=[x]^{2}-\left[x^{2}\right]$ (where, $[x]$ is the greatest integer less than or equal to $x$ ), is discontinuous at\\
solution:
NOTE All integers are critical point for greatest integer function. Case I When $x \in I$

$$
f(x)=[x]^{2}-\left[x^{2}\right]=x^{2}-x^{2}=0
$$

Case II When $x \notin I$

If

$0<x<1$, then $[x]=0$\\
and

$$
0<x^{2}<1, \text { then }\left[x^{2}\right]=0
$$

Next, if

$$
1 \leq x^{2}<2 \Rightarrow 1 \leq x<\sqrt{2}
$$

$$
\Rightarrow \quad[x]=1 \quad \text { and } \quad\left[x^{2}\right]=1
$$

Therefore, $f(x)=[x]^{2}-\left[x^{2}\right]=0$, if $1 \leq x<\sqrt{2}$

Therefore, $f(x)=0$, if $0 \leq x<\sqrt{2}$

This shows that $f(x)$ is continuous at $x=1$.

Therefore, $f(x)$ is discontinuous in $(-\infty, 0) \cup[\sqrt{2}, \infty)$ on many other points. Therefore, (b) is the answer.

solution:

$$

\Rightarrow & \tan \left(-45^{\circ}\right)<\tan x<\tan \left(45^{\circ}\right) \\
\Rightarrow & -\tan 45^{\circ}<\tan x<\tan \left(45^{\circ}\right) \\
\Rightarrow & -1<\tan x<1 \\
\Rightarrow & 0<\tan ^{2} x<1 \\
\Rightarrow & {\left[\tan ^{2} x\right]=0}
\end{array}
$$

i.e. $f(x)$ is zero for all values of $x$ from $x=-45^{\circ}$ to $45^{\circ}$. Thus, $f(x)$ exists when $x \rightarrow 0$ and also it is continuous at $x=0$. Also, $f(x)$ is differentiable at $x=0$ and has a value of zero.

Therefore, (b) is the answer.

& \because \frac{d}{d x} \int_{\varphi_{1}(x)}^{\varphi_{2}(x)} f(t) d t=f\left(\varphi_{2}(x)\right), \varphi_{2}^{\prime}(x)-f\left(\varphi_{1}(x)\right) \cdot \varphi_{1}^{\prime}(x)

On applying limit, we get

$$

$$

question:
Let $f:[-1,3] \rightarrow R$ be defined as

$$
f(x)=\begin{array}{cc}
|x|+[x], & -1 \leq x<1 \\
x+|x|, & 1 \leq x<2 \\
x+[x], & 2 \leq x \leq 3
\end{array}
$$

where, $[t]$ denotes the greatest integer less than or equal to $t$. Then, $f$ is discontinuous at \\
solution:
Given function $f:[-1,3] \rightarrow R$ is defined as

$$
f(x)=\begin{array}{cc}
|x|+[x], & -1 \leq x<1 \\
x+|x|, & 1 \leq x<2 \\
x+[x], & 2 \leq x \leq 3
\end{array}
$$

$$
\begin{array}{cc}
-x-1, & -1 \leq x<0 \\
x, & 0 \leq x<1 \\
2 x, & 1 \leq x<2 \\
x+2, & 2 \leq x<3 \\
6, & x=3
\end{array}
$$

$\begin{array}{lll} & {[\because \text { if } n \leq x<n+1, \forall n \in \text { Integer, }[x]=n]} \\ \because & \lim _{x \rightarrow 0^{-}} f(x)=-1 \neq f(0) & {[\because f(0)=0]} \\ \because & \lim _{x \rightarrow 1^{-}} f(x)=1 \neq f(1) & {[\because f(1)=2]} \\ \because & \lim _{x \rightarrow 2^{-}} f(x)=4=f(2)=\lim _{x \rightarrow 2^{+}} f(x)=4 & {[\because f(2)=4]} \\ \text { and } & \lim _{x \rightarrow 3^{-}} f(x)=5 \neq f(3) & {[\because f(3)=6]}\end{array}$

$\therefore$ Function $f(x)$ is discontinuous at points 0,1 and 3 .

question:
Let $f: R \rightarrow R$ be a function defined as

  $$
  f(x)=\begin{array}{ccc}
  5, & \text { if } & x \leq 1 \\
  a+b x, & \text { if } & 1<x<3 \\
  b+5 x, & \text { if } & 3 \leq x<5 \\
  30, & \text { if } & x \geq 5
  \end{array}
  $$

Then, $f$ is
options: d) not continuous for any values of $a$ and $b$
solution:
Key Idea A function is said to be continuous if it is continuous at each point of the domain.

We have,

$$
f(x)=\begin{array}{ccc}
5 & \text { if } & x \leq 1 \\
a+b x & \text { if } & 1<x<3 \\
b+5 x & \text { if } & 3 \leq x<5 \\
30 & \text { if } & x \geq 5
\end{array}
$$

Clearly, for $f(x)$ to be continuous, it has to be continuous at $x=1, x=3$ and $x=5$

$[\because$ In rest portion it is continuous everywhere]


\begin{gather*}
\lim _{x \rightarrow 1^{+}}(a+b x)=a+b=5  \tag{i}\\
{\left[\because \lim _{x \rightarrow 1^{-}} f(x)=\lim _{x \rightarrow 1^{+}} f(x)=f(1)\right]} \\
\lim _{x \rightarrow 5^{-}}(b+5 x)=b+25=30  \tag{ii}\\
{\left[\because \lim _{x \rightarrow 5^{-}} f(x)=\lim _{x \rightarrow 5^{+}} f(x)=f(5)\right]}
\end{gather*}


On solving Eqs. (i) and (ii), we get $b=5$ and $a=0$

Now, let us check the continuity of $f(x)$ at $x=3$.

Here,

$$
\lim _{x \rightarrow 3^{-}}(a+b x)=a+3 b=15
$$

and

$$
\lim _{x \rightarrow 3^{+}}(b+5 x)=b+15=20
$$

Hence, for $a=0$ and $b=5, f(x)$ is not continuous at $x=3$ $\therefore f(x)$ cannot be continuous for any values of $a$ and $b$.

question: If $f(x)=\frac{1}{2} x-1$, then on the interval $[0, \pi]$
options: a) $\tan [f(x)]$ and $1 / f(x)$ are both continuous
b) $\tan [f(x)]$ and $1 / f(x)$ are both discontinuous
d) $\tan [f(x)]$ is continuous but $1 / f(x)$ is not continuous
solution:
Given, $f(x)=\frac{1}{2} x-1$ for $0 \leq x \leq \pi$

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \therefore \quad[f(x)]=\begin{array}{cc}
-1, & 0 \leq x<2 \\
0, & 2 \leq x \leq \pi
\end{array} \\
& \Rightarrow \quad \tan [f(x)]=\begin{array}{cc}
\tan (-1), & 0 \leq x<2 \\
\tan 0, & 2 \leq x \leq \pi
\end{array} \\
& \therefore \quad \lim _{x \rightarrow 2^{-}} \tan [f(x)]=-\tan 1
\end{aligned}
$$

and $\quad \lim _{x \rightarrow 2^{+}} \tan [f(x)]=0$

So, $\tan f(x)$ is not continuous at $x=2$.

Now, $f(x)=\frac{1}{2} x-1 \Rightarrow f(x)=\frac{x-2}{2} \Rightarrow \frac{1}{f(x)}=\frac{2}{x-2}$

Clearly, 1 If $(x)$ is not continuous at $x=2$.

So, $\tan [f(x)]$ and $\frac{1}{f(x)}$ are both discontinuous at $x=2$.

question: Let $f(x)=\begin{array}{cc}-1, & -2 \leq x<0 \\ x^{2}-1, & 0 \leq x \leq 2\end{array}$ and $g(x)=|f(x)|+f(|x|)$. Then, in the interval $(-2,2), g$ is
options: a) not differentiable at one point
b) not differentiable at two points
solution:
Key Idea This type of problem can be solved graphically.\\
We have, $f(x)=\begin{array}{cc}-1, & -2 \leq x<0 \\ x^{2}-1, & 0 \leq x \leq 2\end{array}$

and $g(x)=|f(x)|+f(|x|)$

$$

1, & -2 \leq x<0 \\

x^{2}-1, \quad 1 \leq x \leq

=x^{2}-1, & |x| \leq 2 \\
=x^{2}-1, & -2 \leq x \leq 2

[Here, $y=2\left(x^{2}-1\right)$ or $x^{2}=\frac{1}{2}(y+2)$ represent a parabola with vertex $(0,-2)$ and it open upward]

Note that there is a sharp edge at $x=1$ only, so $g(x)$ is not differentiable at $x=1$ only.

Let $f$ be a differentiable function from $R$ to $R$ such that $|f(x)-f(y)| \leq 2|x-y|^{\frac{3}{2}}$, for all $x, y \in R$. If $f(0)=1$, then 1

$\int_{0} f^{2}(x) d x$ is equal to\\
solution:
Given, $|f(x)-f(y)| \leq 2|x-y|^{\frac{3}{2}}, \forall x, y \in R$

$$
\Rightarrow \quad \frac{|f(x)-f(y)|}{|x-y|} \leq 2|x-y|^{\frac{1}{2}}
$$

(dividing both sides by $|x-y|$ )

Put $x=x+h$ and $y=x$, where $h$ is very close to zero.

$\Rightarrow \lim _{h \rightarrow 0}\left|\frac{f(x+h)-f(x)}{(x+h)-x}\right| \leq \lim _{h \rightarrow 0} 2|(x+h)-x|^{\frac{1}{2}}$

$\Rightarrow \lim _{h \rightarrow 0}\left|\frac{f(x+h)-f(x)}{h}\right| \leq \lim _{h \rightarrow 0} 2|h|^{\frac{1}{2}}$

$\Rightarrow\left|\lim _{h \rightarrow 0} \frac{f(x+h)-f(x)}{h}\right| \leq 0$

[substituting limit directly on right hand side and using $\lim _{x \rightarrow a}|f(x)|=\left|\lim _{x \rightarrow a} f(x)\right|$

$\Rightarrow\left|f^{\prime}(x)\right| \leq 0$

$$
\because \lim _{h \rightarrow 0} \frac{f(x+h)-f(x)}{h}=f^{\prime}(x)
$$

$\Rightarrow\left|f^{\prime}(x)\right|=0$

$\left(\because\left|f^{\prime}(x)\right|\right.$ can not be less than zero)

$\Rightarrow \quad f^{\prime}(x)=0$

$[\because|x|=0 \Leftrightarrow x=0]$

$\Rightarrow f(x)$ is a constant function.

Since, $f(0)=1$, therefore $f(x)$ is always equal to 1 .

Now, $\int_{0}^{1}(f(x))^{2} d x=\int_{0}^{1} d x=[x]_{0}^{1}=(1-0)=1$

question: Let $S=\left(t \in \mathbf{R}: f(x) \quad=|x-\pi| \cdot\left(e^{|x|}-1\right) \sin |x|\right.$ is not differentiable at $t\}$. Then, the set $S$ is equal to\\
solution:
We have,

$$
\begin{gathered}
f(x)=|x-\pi| \cdot\left(e^{|x|}-1\right) \sin |x| \\
(x-\pi)\left(e^{-x}-1\right) \sin x, \quad x<0 \\
f(x)=-(x-\pi)\left(e^{x}-1\right) \sin x, \quad 0 \leq x<\pi \\
(x-\pi)\left(e^{x}-1\right) \sin x, \quad x \geq \pi
\end{gathered}
$$

We check the differentiability at $x=0$ and $\pi$. We have,

$$
\begin{aligned}
& (x-\pi)\left(e^{-x}-1\right) \cos x+\left(e^{-x}-1\right) \sin x \\
& \quad+(x-\pi) \sin x e^{-x}(-1), x<0
\end{aligned}
$$

$f^{\prime}(x)=-\left[(x-\pi)\left(e^{x}-1\right) \cos x+\left(e^{x}-1\right) \sin x\right.$ $\left.+(x-\pi) \sin x e^{x}\right], 0<x<\pi$

$(x-\pi)\left(e^{x}-1\right) \cos x+\left(e^{x}-1\right) \sin x$

$$
+(x-\pi) \sin x e^{x}, x>\pi
$$

Clearly,

$$
\lim _{x \rightarrow 0^{-}} f^{\prime}(x)=0=\lim _{x \rightarrow 0^{+}} f^{\prime}(x)
$$

and

$$
\lim _{x \rightarrow \pi^{-}} f^{\prime}(x)=0=\lim _{x \rightarrow \pi^{+}} f^{\prime}(x)
$$

$\therefore f$ is differentiable at $x=0$ and $x=\pi$

Hence, $f$ is differentiable for all $x$.

question: For $x \in R, f(x)=|\log 2-\sin x|$ and $g(x)=f(f(x))$, then
solution:
We have, $f(x)=|\log 2-\sin x|$ and $g(x)=f(f(x)), x \in R$

Note that, for $x \rightarrow 0, \log 2>\sin x$

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \therefore \quad f(x)=\log 2-\sin x \\
& \Rightarrow \quad g(x)=\log 2-\sin (f(x)) \\
& =\log 2-\sin (\log 2-\sin x)
\end{aligned}
$$

Clearly, $g(x)$ is differentiable at $x=0$ as $\sin x$ is differentiable.

$$
\text { Now, } \begin{aligned}
& & g^{\prime}(x) & =-\cos (\log 2-\sin x)(-\cos x) \\
& & & =\cos x \cdot \cos (\log 2-\sin x) \\
\Rightarrow \quad & & g^{\prime}(0) & =1 \cdot \cos (\log 2)
\end{aligned}
$$

question: If $f$ and $g$ are differentiable functions in $(0,1)$ satisfying $f(0)=2=g(1), \quad g(0)=0$ and $f(1)=6$, then for some $c$ Є $0,1[$\\
solution:
Given, $f(0)=2=g(1), g(0)=0$ and $f(1)=6$ $f$ and $g$ are differentiable in $(0,1)$.

Let $\quad h(x)=f(x)-2 g(x)$

and


\begin{align*}
& h(0)=f(0)-2 g(0)=2-0=2  \tag{i}\\
& h(1)=f(1)-2 g(1)=6-2(2)=2 \\
& h(0)=h(1)=2
\end{align*}


Hence, using Rolle's theorem,

$$
h^{\prime}(c)=0 \text {, such that } c \in(0,1)
$$

Differentiating Eq. (i) at $c$, we get

$$
\begin{aligned}
\Rightarrow & f^{\prime}(c)-2 g^{\prime}(c) & =0 \\
\Rightarrow & f^{\prime}(c) & =2 g^{\prime}(c)
\end{aligned}
$$

question: Let $f(x)=\underset{0,}{x^{2}}\left|\cos \frac{\pi}{x}\right|, x \neq 0, x \in R$, then $f$ is
options: a) differentiable both at $x=0$ and at $x=2$
b) differentiable at $x=0$ but not differentiable at $x=2$
c) not differentiable at $x=0$ but differentiable at $x=2$
d) differentiable neither at $x=0$ nor at $x=2$
solution:
PLAN To check differentiability at a point we use RHD and LHD at a point and if RHD $=\mathrm{LHD}$, then $f(x)$ is differentiable at the point.

\section*{Description of Situation}
$$
\begin{array}{ll}
\text { As, } & R\left\{f^{\prime}(x)\right\}=\lim _{h \rightarrow 0} \frac{f(x+h)-f(x)}{h} \\
\text { and } & L\left\{f^{\prime}(x)\right\}=\lim _{h \rightarrow 0} \frac{f(x-h)-f(x)}{-h}
\end{array}
$$

Here, students generally gets confused in defining modulus. To check differentiable at $x=0$,

$$
\begin{aligned}
R\left\{f^{\prime}(0)\right\} & =\lim _{h \rightarrow 0} \frac{f(0+h)-f(0)}{h} \\
& =\lim _{h \rightarrow 0} \frac{h^{2}\left|\cos \frac{\pi}{h}\right|-0}{h}=\lim _{h \rightarrow 0} h \cdot\left|\cos \frac{\pi}{h}\right|=0 \\
L\left\{f^{\prime}(0)\right\} & =\lim _{h \rightarrow 0} \frac{f(0-h)-f(0)}{-h}=\lim _{h \rightarrow 0} \frac{h^{2}\left|\cos -\frac{\pi}{h}\right|-0}{-h}=0
\end{aligned}
$$

So, $f(x)$ is differentiable at $x=0$.

To check differentiability at $x=2$,

$$
\begin{aligned}
& R\left\{f^{\prime}(2)\right\}=\lim _{h \rightarrow 0} \frac{f(2+h)-f(2)}{h} \\
& =\lim _{h \rightarrow 0} \frac{(2+h)^{2}\left|\cos \frac{\pi}{2+h}\right|-0}{h}=\lim _{h \rightarrow 0} \frac{(2+h)^{2} \cdot \cos \frac{\pi}{2+h}}{h} \\
& =\lim _{h \rightarrow 0} \frac{(2+h)^{2} \cdot \sin \frac{\pi}{2}-\frac{\pi}{2+h}}{h} \\
& =\lim _{h \rightarrow 0} \frac{(2+h)^{2} \cdot \sin \frac{\pi h}{2(2+h)}}{h \cdot \frac{\pi}{2(2+h)}} \cdot \frac{\pi}{2(2+h)}=\pi \\
& \text { and } \quad L\left\{f^{\prime}(2)\right\}=\lim _{h \rightarrow 0} \frac{f(2-h)-f(2)}{-h} \\
& =\lim _{h \rightarrow 0} \frac{(2-h)^{2} \cdot\left|\cos \frac{\pi}{2-h}\right|-2^{2} \cdot\left|\cos \frac{\pi}{2}\right|}{-h} \\
& =\lim _{h \rightarrow 0} \frac{(2-h)^{2}--\cos \frac{\pi}{2-h}-0}{-h} \\
& =\lim _{h \rightarrow 0} \frac{-(2-h)^{2} \cdot \sin \frac{\pi}{2}-\frac{\pi}{2-h}}{h} \\
& =\lim _{h \rightarrow 0} \frac{(2-h)^{2} \cdot \sin -\frac{\pi h}{2(2-h)}}{h \times \frac{-\pi}{2(2-h)}} \times \frac{-\pi}{2(2-h)}=-\pi
\end{aligned}
$$

Thus, $f(x)$ is differentiable at $x=0$ but not at $x=2$.

question: Let $g(x)=\frac{(x-1)^{n}}{\log \cos ^{m}(x-1)} ; 0<x<2, \quad m$ and $n$ are integers, $m \neq 0, n>0$ and let $p$ be the left hand derivative of $|x-1|$ at $x=1$. If $\lim _{x \rightarrow 1^{+}} g(x)=p$, then\\
solution:
Given, $\quad g(x)=\frac{(x-1)^{n}}{\log \cos ^{m}(x-1)} ; 0<x<2, m \neq 0, \quad n \quad$ are integers and $|x-1|=\begin{array}{ll}x-1, & x \geq 1 \\ 1-x, & x<1\end{array}$

The left hand derivative of $|x-1|$ at $x=1$ is $p=-1$.

Also, $\lim _{x \rightarrow 1^{+}} g(x)=p=-1$

$\Rightarrow \quad \lim _{h \rightarrow 0} \frac{(1+h-1)^{n}}{\log \cos ^{m}(1+h-1)}=-1$

\section*{208 Limit, Continuity and Differentiability}
$$
\begin{array}{lc}
\Rightarrow & \lim _{h \rightarrow 0} \frac{h^{n}}{\log \cos ^{m} h}=-1 \\
\Rightarrow & \lim _{h \rightarrow 0} \frac{h^{n}}{m \log \cos h}=-1 \\
\Rightarrow & \lim _{h \rightarrow 0} \frac{n \cdot h^{n-1}}{m \frac{1}{\cos h}(-\sin h)}=-1 \\
\Rightarrow \quad \lim _{h \rightarrow 0}-\frac{n}{m} \cdot \frac{h^{n-2}}{\frac{\tan h}{h}}=-1 \Rightarrow \frac{n}{m} \lim _{h \rightarrow 0} \frac{h^{n-2}}{\frac{\tan h}{h}}=1 \\
\Rightarrow \quad n=2 \text { and } \frac{n}{m}=1 \Rightarrow m=n=2
\end{array}
$$

question: If $f$ is a differentiable function satisfying $f \frac{1}{n}=0, \forall n \geq 1, n \in I$, then
solution:
Given, $f(1)=f \frac{1}{2}=f \frac{1}{3}=\ldots=\lim _{n \rightarrow \infty} f \frac{1}{n}=0$

as $f \frac{1}{n}=0 ; n \in$ integers and $n \geq 1$.

$$
\Rightarrow \quad \lim _{n \rightarrow \infty} f \frac{1}{n}=0 \Rightarrow f(0)=0
$$

Since, there are infinitely many points in neighbourhood of $x=0$.

$$
\begin{array}{lrl}
\therefore & f(x) & =0 \\
\Rightarrow & f^{\prime}(x) & =0 \\
\Rightarrow & f^{\prime}(0) & =0 \\
\text { Hence, } & f(0) & =f^{\prime}(0)=0
\end{array}
$$

question: The left hand derivative of $f(x)=[x] \sin (\pi x)$ at $x=k, k$ is an integer, is\\

question: Let $f: R \rightarrow R$ be a function defined by $f(x)=\max \left\{x, x^{3}\right\}$. The set of all points, where $f(x)$ is not differentiable, is\\
Let $f: R \rightarrow R$ be any function. Define $g: R \rightarrow R$ by $g(x)=|f(x)|, \forall \quad x$. Then, $g$ is
solution:
Let $h(x)=|x|$, then $g(x)=|f(x)|=h\{f(x)\}$

Since, composition of two continuous functions is continuous, $g$ is continuous if $f$ is continuous. So, answer is (c).

(a) Let $f(x)=x \Rightarrow g(x)=|x|$

Now, $f(x)$ is an onto function. Since, co-domain of $x$ is $R$ and range of $x$ is $R$. But $\mathrm{g}(x)$ is into function. Since, range of $g(x)$ is $[0, \infty)$ but co-domain is given $R$. Hence, (a) is wrong.\\
(b) Let $f(x)=x \Rightarrow g(x)=|x|$. Now, $f(x)$ is one-one function but $g(x)$ is many-one function. Hence, (b) is wrong.

(d) Let $f(x)=x \Rightarrow g(x)=|x|$. Now, $f(x)$ is differentiable for all $x \in R$ but $g(x)=|x|$ is not differentiable at $x=0$ Hence, (d) is wrong.

question: The function $f(x)=\left(x^{2}-1\right)\left|x^{2}-3 x+2\right|+\cos (|x|)$ is not differentiable at\\
solution:
Function $f(x)=\left(x^{2}-1\right)\left|x^{2}-3 x+2\right|+\cos (|x|)$

NOTE In differentiable of $|f(x)|$ we have to consider critical points for which $f(x)=0$

$|x|$ is not differentiable at $x=0$

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \text { but } \quad \cos |x|=\begin{array}{cc}
\cos (-x), & \text { if } x<0 \\
\cos x, & \text { if } x \geq 0
\end{array} \\
& \Rightarrow \quad \cos |x|=\begin{array}{ll}
\cos x, & \text { if } x<0 \\
\cos x, & \text { if } x \geq 0
\end{array}
\end{aligned}
$$

Therefore, it is differentiable at $x=0$.

Now, $\left|x^{2}-3 x+2\right|=|(x-1)(x-2)|$

$$
\begin{aligned}
& (x-1)(x-2), \quad \text { if } x<1 \\
& =(x-1)(2-x), \quad \text { if } 1 \leq x<2 \\
& (x-1)(x-2), \quad \text { if } 2 \leq x
\end{aligned}
$$

Therefore,

$$
f(x)=\begin{array}{cl}
\left(x^{2}-1\right)(x-1)(x-2)+\cos x, & \text { if }-\infty<x<1 \\
-\left(x^{2}-1\right)(x-1)(x-2)+\cos x, & \text { if } 1 \leq x<2 \\
\left(x^{2}-1\right)(x-1)(x-2)+\cos x, & \text { if } 2 \leq x<\infty
\end{array}
$$

Now, $x=1,2$ are critical point for differentiability. Because $f(x)$ is differentiable on other points in its domain.

Differentiability at $x=1$

$$
\begin{aligned}
L f^{\prime}(1)= & \lim _{x \rightarrow 1^{-}} \frac{f(x)-f(1)}{x-1} \\
& =\lim _{x \rightarrow 1^{-}}\left(x^{2}-1\right)(x-2)+\frac{\cos x-\cos 1}{x-1} \\
= & 0-\sin 1=-\sin 1 \\
& {\left[\because \lim _{x \rightarrow 1^{-}} \frac{\cos x-\cos 1}{x-1}=\frac{d}{d x}(\cos x) \text { at } x=1-0\right.} \\
= & -\sin x \text { at } x=1-0=-\sin x \text { at } x=1=-\sin 1]
\end{aligned}
$$

and $R f^{\prime}(1)=\lim _{x \rightarrow 1^{+}} \frac{f(x)-f(1)}{x-1}$

$$
\begin{aligned}
& =\lim _{x \rightarrow 1^{+}}-\left(x^{2}-1\right)(x-2)+\frac{\cos x-\cos 1}{x-1} \\
& =0-\sin 1=-\sin 1 \quad \text { [same approach] }
\end{aligned}
$$

$\because L f^{\prime}(1)=R f^{\prime}$ (1). Therefore, function is differentiable at $x=1$.

Again, $\quad L f^{\prime}(2)=\lim _{x \rightarrow 2^{-}} \frac{f(x)-f(2)}{x-2}$

$$
\begin{aligned}
& =\lim _{x \rightarrow 2^{-}}-\left(x^{2}-1\right)(x-1)+\frac{\cos x-\cos 2}{x-2} \\
& =-(4-1)(2-1)-\sin 2=-3-\sin 2
\end{aligned}
$$

and $\quad R f^{\prime}(2)=\lim _{x \rightarrow 2^{+}} \frac{f(x)-f(2)}{x-2}$

$$
\begin{aligned}
& =\lim _{x \rightarrow 2^{+}}\left(x^{2}-1\right)(x-1)+\frac{\cos x-\cos 2}{x-2} \\
& =\left(2^{2}-1\right)(2-1)-\sin 2=3-\sin 2
\end{aligned}
$$

So, $L f^{\prime}(2) \neq R f^{\prime}(2), f$ is not differentiable at $x=2$ Therefore, (d) is the answer.

question: The set of all points, where the function $f(x)=\frac{x}{1+|x|}$ is differentiable, is\\
There exists a function $f(x)$ satisfying $f(0)=1$, $f^{\prime}(0)=-1, f(x)>0, \forall x$ and\\
solution:
Since, $f(x)$ is continuous and differentiable where $f(0)=1$ and $f^{\prime}(0)=-1, f(x)>0, \forall x$.

Thus, $f(x)$ is decreasing for $x>0$ and concave down.

$$
\Rightarrow \quad f^{\prime \prime}(x)<0
$$

Therefore, (a) is answer.

question: For a real number $y$, let [ $y$ ] denotes the greatest integer less than or equal to $y$. Then, the function $f(x)=\frac{\tan \pi[(x-\pi)]}{1+[x]^{2}}$ is
options: b) continuous at all $x$, but the derivative $f^{\prime}(x)$ does not exist for some $x$
c) $f^{\prime}(\mathrm{x})$ exists for all $x$, but the derivative $f^{\prime \prime}(x)$ does not exist for some $x$
solution:
Here, $f(x)=\frac{\tan \pi[(x-\pi)]}{1+[x]^{2}}$

Since, we know $\pi[(x-\pi)]=n \pi$ and $\tan n \pi=0$

$$
\begin{array}{rr}
\because & 1+[x]^{2} \neq 0 \\
\therefore & f(x)=0, \forall x
\end{array}
$$

Thus, $f(x)$ is a constant function.

$\therefore f^{\prime}(x), f^{\prime \prime}(x), \ldots$ all exist for every $x$, their value being 0 .

$\Rightarrow f^{\prime}(x)$ exists for all $x$.

question:
Let $f: R \rightarrow R$ be a differentiable function such that $f(0)=0, f \frac{\pi}{2}=3$ and $f^{\prime}(0)=1$.

If $g(x)=\int_{x}^{\frac{\pi}{2}}\left[f^{\prime}(t) \operatorname{cosec} t-\cot t \operatorname{cosec} t f(t)\right] d t$

for $x \in 0, \frac{\pi}{2}$, then $\lim _{x \rightarrow 0} g(x)=$
solution:
$g(x)=\int_{x}^{\frac{\pi}{2}}\left(f^{\prime}(t) \operatorname{cosec} t-\cot t \operatorname{cosec} t f(t)\right) d t$

$\therefore \quad g(x)=f \frac{\pi}{2} \quad \operatorname{cosec} \frac{\pi}{2}-f(x) \operatorname{cosec} x$

$\Rightarrow \quad g(x)=3-\frac{f(x)}{\sin x}$

$$
\begin{aligned}
\lim _{x \rightarrow 0} g(x) & =\lim _{x \rightarrow 0} \frac{3 \sin x-f(x)}{\sin x} \\
& =\lim _{x \rightarrow 0} \frac{3 \cos x-f^{\prime}(x)}{\cos x} \\
& =\frac{3-1}{1}=2
\end{aligned}
$$

question:
Let $f: R \rightarrow R$ and $g: R \rightarrow R$ be respectively given by $f(x)=|x|+1$ and $g(x)=x^{2}+1$. Define $h: R \rightarrow R$ by

$$
h(x)=\begin{aligned}
\max \{f(x), g(x)\}, & \text { if } x \leq 0 \\
\min \{f(x), g(x)\}, & \text { if } x>0
\end{aligned}
$$

The number of points at which $h(x)$ is not differentiable is
Let $p(x)$ be a polynomial of degree 4 having extremum at $x=1,2$ and $\lim _{x \rightarrow 0} 1+\frac{p(x)}{x^{2}}=2$. Then, the value of $p(2)$ is $\qquad$\\
solution:
Let $p(x)=a x^{4}+b x^{3}+c x^{2}+d x+e$

$\Rightarrow \quad p^{\prime}(x)=4 a x^{3}+3 b x^{2}+2 c x+d$

$\therefore \quad p^{\prime}(1)=4 a+3 b+2 c+d=0$

and $p^{\prime}(2)=32 a+12 b+4 c+d=0$

Since, $\quad \lim _{x \rightarrow 0} 1+\frac{p(x)}{x^{2}}=2$

[given]

$$
\begin{array}{cc}
\therefore & \lim _{x \rightarrow 0} \frac{a x^{4}+b x^{3}+(c+1) x^{2}+d x+e}{x^{2}}=2 \\
\Rightarrow & c+1=2, d=0, e=0 \\
\Rightarrow & c=1
\end{array}
$$

From Eqs. (i) and (ii), we get

$$
\begin{array}{ll}
\text { and } & 4 a+3 b=-2 \\
\Rightarrow & 32 a+12 b=-4 \\
\therefore & a=\frac{1}{4} \text { and } b=-1 . \\
\Rightarrow & p(x)=\frac{x^{4}}{4}-x^{3}+x^{2} \\
\Rightarrow & p(2)=\frac{16}{4}-8+4 \\
\Rightarrow & p(2)=0
\end{array}
$$

question: If ${ }^{20} C_{1}+\left(2^{2}\right){ }^{20} C_{2}+\left(3^{2}\right)^{20} C_{3}+\ldots . .+\left(20^{2}\right)^{20} C_{20}=A\left(2^{\beta}\right)$ , then the ordered pair $(A, \beta)$ is equal to\\
solution:
We know,

$$
(1+x)^{n}={ }^{n} C_{0}+{ }^{n} C_{1} x+{ }^{n} C_{2} x^{2}+\ldots+{ }^{n} C_{n} x^{n}
$$

On differentiating both sides w.r.t. $x$, we get $n(1+x)^{n-1}={ }^{n} C_{1}+2{ }^{n} C_{2} x+\ldots+n{ }^{n} C_{n} x^{n-1}$

On multiplying both sides by $x$, we get

$$
n x(1+x)^{n-1}={ }^{n} C_{1} x+2^{n} C_{2} x^{2}+\ldots+n^{n} C_{n} x^{n}
$$

Again on differentiating both sides w.r.t. $x$, we get

$$
n\left[(1+x)^{n-1}+(n-1) x(1+x)^{n-2}\right]
$$

$$
={ }^{n} C_{1}+2^{2}{ }^{n} C_{2} x+\ldots+n^{2}{ }^{n} C_{n} x^{n-1}
$$

Now putting $x=1$ in both sides, we get

$$
\begin{gathered}
{ }^{n} C_{1}+\left(2^{2}\right){ }^{n} C_{2}+\left(3^{2}\right){ }^{n} C_{3}+\ldots+\left(n^{2}\right){ }^{n} C_{n} \\
=n\left(2^{n-1}+(n-1) 2^{n-2}\right)
\end{gathered}
$$

For $n=20$, we get

$$
\begin{aligned}
& { }^{20} C_{1}+\left(2^{2}\right){ }^{20} C_{2}+\left(3^{2}\right){ }^{20} C_{3}+\ldots+(20)^{2}{ }^{20} C_{20} \\
& \quad=20\left(2^{19}+(19) 2^{18}\right) \\
& \quad=20(2+19) 2^{18}=420\left(2^{18}\right) \\
& \quad=A\left(2^{B}\right) \text { (given) }
\end{aligned}
$$

On comparing, we get

$$
(A, B)=(420,18)
$$

question: The derivative of $\tan ^{-1} \frac{\sin x-\cos x}{\sin x+\cos x}$, with respect to $\frac{x}{2}$, where $\quad x \in 0, \frac{\pi}{2} \quad$ is\\
If $e^{y}+x y=e$, the ordered pair $\frac{d y}{d x}, \frac{d^{2} y}{d x^{2}}$ at $x=0$ is equal to\\
If $f(1)=1, \quad f^{\prime}(1)=3$, then the derivative of $f(f(f(x)))+(f(x))^{2}$ at $x=1$ is\\
solution:
Let $y=f(f(f(x)))+(f(x))^{2}$

On differentiating both sides w.r.t. $x$, we get

$$
\frac{d y}{d x}=f^{\prime}(f(f(x))) \cdot f^{\prime}(f(x)) \cdot f^{\prime}(x)+2 f(x) f^{\prime}(x)
$$

[by chain rule]

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \text { So, }\left.\frac{d y}{d x}\right|_{\text {at } x=1}=f^{\prime}(f(f(1))) \cdot f^{\prime}(f(1)) \cdot f^{\prime}(1)+2 f(1) f^{\prime}(1) \\
& \left.\therefore \quad \frac{d y}{d x}\right|_{x=1}=f^{\prime}(f(1)) \cdot f^{\prime}(1) \cdot(3)+2(1)(3)
\end{aligned}
$$

$$
\left[\because f(1)=1 \text { and } f^{\prime}(1)=3\right]
$$

$$
\begin{aligned}
& =f^{\prime}(1) \cdot(3) \cdot(3)+6 \\
& =(3 \times 9)+6=27+6=33
\end{aligned}
$$

Let $f: R \rightarrow R$ be a function such that $f(x)=x^{3}+x^{2} f^{\prime}(1)+x f^{\prime \prime}(2)+f^{\prime \prime \prime}(3), x \in R$. Then, $f(2)$ equals\\
If $x=3 \tan t$ and $y=3 \sec t$, then the value of $\frac{d^{2} y}{d x^{2}}$ at $t=\frac{\pi}{4}$, is\\
solution:
We have, $x=3$ tan $t$ and $y=3 \sec t$

Clearly, $\frac{d y}{d x}=\frac{\frac{d y}{d t}}{\frac{d x}{d t}}=\frac{\frac{d}{d t}(3 \sec t)}{\frac{d}{d t}(3 \tan t)}$

$$
=\frac{3 \sec t \tan t}{3 \sec ^{2} t}=\frac{\tan t}{\sec t}=\sin t
$$

and $\frac{d^{2} y}{d x^{2}}=\frac{d}{d x} \quad \frac{d y}{d x}=\frac{d}{d t} \frac{d y}{d x} \cdot \frac{d t}{d x}$

$$
=\frac{\frac{d}{d t} \frac{d y}{d x}}{\frac{d x}{d t}}=\frac{\frac{d}{d t}(\sin t)}{\frac{d}{d t}(3 \tan t)}=\frac{\cos t}{3 \sec ^{2} t}=\frac{\cos ^{3} t}{3}
$$

Now, $\frac{d^{2} y}{d x^{2}}$ at $t=\frac{\pi}{4}=\frac{\cos ^{3} \frac{\pi}{4}}{3}=\frac{1}{3(2 \sqrt{2})}=\frac{1}{6 \sqrt{2}}$

question: For $x \in 0, \frac{1}{4}$, if the derivative of $\tan ^{-1} \frac{6 x \sqrt{x}}{1-9 x^{3}}$ is $\sqrt{x} \cdot g(x)$, then $g(x)$ equals\\

If $g$ is the inverse of a function $f$ and $f^{\prime}(x)=\frac{1}{1+x^{5}}$, then $g^{\prime}(x)$ is equal to
\\
solution:
Here, $g$ is the inverse of $f(x)$.

$\Rightarrow$

$$
f o g(x)=x
$$

On differentiating w.r.t. $x$, we get

$$
\begin{aligned}
& f^{\prime}\{g(x)\} \times g^{\prime}(x)=1 \Rightarrow \quad g^{\prime}(x)=\frac{1}{f^{\prime}(g(x))} \\
&= \frac{1}{\frac{1}{1+\{g(x)\}^{5}}} \\
& \Rightarrow \quad \because f^{\prime}(x)=\frac{1}{1+x^{5}} \\
& \Rightarrow \quad g^{\prime}(x)=1+\{g(x)\}^{5}
\end{aligned}
$$

If $f^{\prime \prime}(x)=-f(x)$, where $f(x)$ is a continuous double differentiable function and $g(x)=f^{\prime}(x)$.


If $F(x)=f \frac{x}{2}^{2}+g \frac{x}{2}^{2} \quad$ and $F(5)=5$,

then $F(10)$ is\\
solution:
Since,

$$
f^{\prime \prime}(x)=-f(x)
$$

$$
\begin{array}{rlrlrl}
\Rightarrow & & \frac{d}{d x}\left\{f^{\prime}(x)\right\} & =-f(x) \\
\Rightarrow & & g^{\prime}(x) & =-f(x) & {\left[\because g(x)=f^{\prime}(x), \text { given }\right] \ldots \text { (i) }}
\end{array}
$$

Also,

$$
F(x)=f \frac{x}{2}^{2}+g \frac{x}{2}^{2}
$$

$\Rightarrow \quad F^{\prime}(x)=2 \quad f \frac{x}{2} \cdot f^{\prime} \frac{x}{2} \cdot \frac{1}{2}$ $+2 \quad g \quad \frac{x}{2} \cdot g^{\prime} \quad \frac{x}{2} \cdot \frac{1}{2}=0$ [from Eq.(i)]

question: Let $f$ be twice differentiable function satisfying $f(1)=1, f(2)=4, f(3)=9$, then
options: c) there exists atleast one $x \in(1,3)$ such that $f^{\prime \prime}(x)=2$
solution:
Let, $g(x)=f(x)-x^{2}$

$\Rightarrow g(x)$ has atleast 3 real roots which are $x=1,2,3$

[by mean value theorem]

$\Rightarrow \quad g^{\prime}(x)$ has atleast 2 real roots in $x \in(1,3)$

$\Rightarrow g^{\prime \prime}(x)$ has atleast 1 real roots in $x \in(1,3)$

$\Rightarrow f^{\prime \prime}(x)-2 \cdot 1=0$. for atleast 1 real root in $x \in(1,3)$

$\Rightarrow f^{\prime \prime}(x)=2$, for atleast one root in $x \in(1,3)$

question: If $y$ is a function of $x$ and $\log (x+y)=2 x y$, then the value of $y^{\prime}(0)$ is\\
solution:
Given that, $\log (x+y)=2 x y$

$\therefore$ At $x=0, \Rightarrow \log (y)=0 \Rightarrow y=1$

$\therefore$ To find $\frac{d y}{d x}$ at $(0,1)$

On differentiating Eq. (i) w.r.t. $x$, we get

$$
\begin{aligned}
\frac{1}{x+y} 1+\frac{d y}{d y} & =2 x \frac{d y}{d x}+2 y \cdot 1 \\
\Rightarrow \quad \frac{d y}{d x} & =\frac{2 y(x+y)-1}{1-2(x+y) x} \\
\Rightarrow \quad \frac{d y}{d x} & =1
\end{aligned}
$$

question: If $x^{2}+y^{2}=1$, then\\
solution:
Given, $x^{2}+y^{2}=1$

On differentiating w.r.t. $x$, we get

$$
\begin{array}{rlrl} 
& & 2 x+2 y y^{\prime} & =0 \\
\Rightarrow & x+y y^{\prime} & =0 .
\end{array}
$$

Again, differentiating w.r.t. $x$, we get

$$
\begin{array}{ll} 
& 1+y^{\prime} y^{\prime}+y y^{\prime \prime}=0 \\
\Rightarrow \quad & 1+\left(y^{\prime}\right)^{2}+y y^{\prime \prime}=0
\end{array}
$$

question: Let $f(x)=\left|\begin{array}{ccc}6 & -1 & 0 \\ p & p^{2} & p^{3}\end{array}\right|$, where $p$ is constant. Then, $\frac{d^{3}}{d x^{3}} f(x)$ at $x=0$ is\\
If $y^{2}=P(x)$ is a polynomial of degree 3 , then $2 \frac{d}{d x} y^{3} \frac{d^{2} y}{d x^{2}}$ equals\\
solution:
Since, $y^{2}=P(x)$

On differentiating both sides, we get

$$
2 y y_{1}=P^{\prime}(x)
$$

Again, differentiating, we get

$$
\begin{array}{rlrl} 
& 2 y y_{2}+2 y_{1}^{2} & =P^{\prime \prime}(x) \\
\Rightarrow & 2 y^{3} y_{2}+2 y^{2} y_{1}^{2} & =y^{2} P^{\prime \prime}(x) \\
\Rightarrow & 2 y^{3} y_{2} & =y^{2} P^{\prime \prime}(x)-2\left(y y_{1}\right)^{2} \\
\Rightarrow & & 2 y^{3} y_{2} & =P(x) \cdot P^{\prime \prime}(x)-\frac{\left\{P^{\prime}(x)\right\}^{2}}{2}
\end{array}
$$

Again, differentiating, we get


\begin{align*}
2 \frac{d}{d x}\left(y^{3} y_{2}\right) & =P^{\prime}(x) \cdot P^{\prime \prime}(x)+P(x) \cdot P^{\prime \prime \prime}(x) \\
\Rightarrow \quad 2 \frac{d}{d x}\left(y^{3} y_{2}\right) & =P(x) \cdot P^{\prime \prime \prime}(x) \\
\Rightarrow \quad 2 \frac{d}{d x} y^{3} \cdot \frac{d^{2} y}{d x^{2}} & =P(x) \cdot P^{\prime \prime \prime}(x)
\end{align*}

question: Let $f: R \rightarrow R$ be a continuous odd function, which vanishes exactly at one point and $f(1)=\frac{1}{2}$. Suppose that $F(x)=\int_{-1}^{x} f(t) d t$ for all $x \in[-1,2]$ and $G(x)=\int_{-1}^{x} t|f\{f(t)\}| d t \quad$ for all $\quad x \in[-1,2]$. If $\lim _{x \rightarrow 1} \frac{F(x)}{G(x)}=\frac{1}{14}$, then the value of $f \frac{1}{2}$ is
If the tangent to the curve $y=\frac{x}{x^{2}-3}, x \in R,(x \neq \pm \sqrt{3})$, at a point $(\alpha, \beta) \neq(0,0)$ on it is parallel to the line $2 x+6 y-11=0$, then
solution:
Equation of given curve is


\begin{equation*}
y=\frac{x}{x^{2}-3}, x \in R,(x \neq \pm \sqrt{3}) \tag{i}
\end{equation*}


On differentiating Eq. (i) w.r.t. $x$, we get

$$
\frac{d y}{d x}=\frac{\left(x^{2}-3\right)-x(2 x)}{\left(x^{2}-3\right)^{2}}=\frac{\left(-x^{2}-3\right)}{\left(x^{2}-3\right)^{2}}
$$

It is given that tangent at a point $(\alpha, \beta) \neq(0,0)$ on it is parallel to the line

$$
2 x+6 y-11=0
$$

$\therefore$ Slope of this line $=-\frac{2}{6}=\left.\frac{d y}{d x}\right|_{(\alpha, \beta)}$

$$
\begin{array}{rr}
\Rightarrow & -\frac{\alpha^{2}+3}{\left(\alpha^{2}-3\right)^{2}}=-\frac{1}{3} \\
\Rightarrow & 3 \alpha^{2}+9=\alpha^{4}-6 \alpha^{2}+9 \\
\Rightarrow & \alpha^{4}-9 \alpha^{2}=0 \\
\Rightarrow & \alpha=0,-3,3 \\
\Rightarrow & \alpha=3 \text { or }-3,
\end{array}
$$

Now, from Eq. (i),

$$
\beta=\frac{\alpha}{\alpha^{2}-3} \Rightarrow \beta=\frac{3}{9-3} \text { or } \frac{-3}{9-3}=\frac{1}{2} \text { or }-\frac{1}{2}
$$

According to the options, $|6 \alpha+2 \beta|=19$

at $(\alpha, \beta)= \pm 3, \pm \frac{1}{2}$

question: Let $S$ be the set of all values of $x$ for which the tangent to the curve $y=f(x)=x^{3}-x^{2}-2 x$ at $(x, y)$ is parallel to the line segment joining the points $(1, f(1))$ and $(-1, f(-1))$, then $S$ is equal to\\
solution:
Given curve is $y=f(x)=x^{3}-x^{2}-2 x$

So, $f(1)=1-1-2=-2$

and $f(-1)=-1-1+2=0$

Since, slope of a line passing through $\left(x_{1}, y_{1}\right)$ and $\left(x_{2}, y_{2}\right)$ is given by $m=\tan \theta=\frac{y_{2}-y_{1}}{x_{2}-x_{1}}$

$\therefore$ Slope of line joining points $(1, f(1))$ and $(-1, f(-1))$ is $m=\frac{f(1)-f(-1)}{1-(-1)}=\frac{-2-0}{1+1}=-1$

Now, $\frac{d y}{d x}=3 x^{2}-2 x-2$

[differentiating Eq. (i), w.r.t. ' $x$ '] According to the question,

$$
\begin{array}{ll} 
& \frac{d y}{d x}=m \\
\Rightarrow & 3 x^{2}-2 x-2=-1 \Rightarrow 3 x^{2}-2 x-1=0 \\
\Rightarrow & (x-1)(3 x+1)=0 \Rightarrow x=1,-\frac{1}{3}
\end{array}
$$

Therefore, set $S=-\frac{1}{3}, 1$.

A helicopter is flying along the curve given by $y-x^{3 / 2}=7,(x \geq 0)$. A soldier positioned at the point $\frac{1}{2}, 7$ wants to shoot down the helicopter when it is nearest to him. Then, this nearest distance is\\
If $\theta$ denotes the acute angle between the curves, $y=10-x^{2}$ and $y=2+x^{2}$ at a point of their intersection, then $|\tan \theta|$ is equal to\\
solution:
Key Idea Angle between two curves is the angle between the tangents to the curves at the point of intersection.

Given equation of curves are

\[
\text { and } \quad \begin{align*}
& y=10-x^{2}  \tag{i}\\
& y=2+x^{2} \tag{ii}
\end{align*}
\]

For point of intersection, consider

$$
\begin{aligned}
\Rightarrow & & 10-x^{2} & =2+x^{2} \\
\Rightarrow & & 2 x^{2} & =8 \\
\Rightarrow & & x^{2} & =4 \\
& & x & = \pm 2
\end{aligned}
$$

Clearly, when $x=2$, then $y=6$ (using Eq. (i)) and when $x=-2$, then $y=6$

Thus, the point of intersection are $(2,6)$ and $(-2,6)$.

Let $m_{1}$ be the slope of tangent to the curve (i) and $m_{2}$ be the slope of tangent to the curve (ii)

For curve (i) $\frac{d y}{d x}=-2 x$ and for curve (ii) $\frac{d y}{d x}=2 x$

$\therefore$ At $(2,6)$, slopes $m_{1}=-4$ and $m_{2}=4$, and in that case

$$
|\tan \theta|=\left|\frac{m_{2}-m_{1}}{1+m_{1} m_{2}}\right|=\left|\frac{4+4}{1-16}\right|=\frac{8}{15}
$$

At $(-2,6)$, slopes $m_{1}=4$ and $m_{2}=-4$ and in that case

$$
|\tan \theta|=\left|\frac{m_{2}-m_{1}}{1+m_{1} m_{2}}\right|=\left|\frac{-4-4}{1-16}\right|=\frac{8}{15}
$$

question: If the curves $y^{2}=6 x, 9 x^{2}+b y^{2}=16$ intersect each other at right angles, then the value of $b$ is\\
solution:
We have, $y^{2}=6 x$

$$
\Rightarrow \quad 2 y \frac{d y}{d x}=6 \quad \Rightarrow \quad \frac{d y}{d x}=\frac{3}{y}
$$

Slope of tangent at $\left(x_{1}, y_{1}\right)$ is $m_{1}=\frac{3}{y_{1}}$

Also, $\quad 9 x^{2}+b y^{2}=16$

$\Rightarrow \quad 18 x+2 b y \frac{d y}{d x}=0 \quad \Rightarrow \quad \frac{d y}{d x}=\frac{-9 x}{b y}$

Slope of tangent at $\left(x_{1}, y_{1}\right)$ is $m_{2}=\frac{-9 x_{1}}{b y_{1}}$

Since, these are intersection at right angle.

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \therefore \quad m_{1} m_{2}=-1 \Rightarrow \frac{27 x_{1}}{b y_{1}^{2}}=1 \\
& \Rightarrow \quad \frac{27 x_{1}}{6 b x_{1}}=1 \quad\left[\because y_{1}^{2}=6 x_{1}\right] \\
& \Rightarrow \quad b=\frac{9}{2}
\end{aligned}
$$

question: The normal to the curve $y(x-2)(x-3)=x+6$ at the point, where the curve intersects the $Y$-axis passes through the point\\
solution:
Given curve is


\begin{equation*}
y(x-2)(x-3)=x+6 \tag{i}
\end{equation*}


Put $x=0$ in Eq. (i), we get

$$
y(-2)(-3)=6 \Rightarrow y=1
$$

So, point of intersection is $(0,1)$.

Now, $y=\frac{x+6}{(x-2)(x-3)}$

$\Rightarrow \quad \frac{d y}{d x}=\frac{1(x-2)(x-3)-(x+6)(x-3+x-2)}{(x-2)^{2}(x-3)^{2}}$

$\Rightarrow \quad \frac{d y}{d x}_{(0,1)}=\frac{6+30}{4 \times 9}=\frac{36}{36}=1$

$\therefore$ Equation of normal at $(0,1)$ is given by

$$
\begin{aligned}
y-1 & =\frac{-1}{1}(x-0) \\
\Rightarrow \quad x+y-1 & =0
\end{aligned}
$$

which passes through the point $\frac{1}{2}, \frac{1}{2}$.

question: The point(s) on the curve $y^{3}+3 x^{2}=12 y$, where the tangent is vertical, is (are)\\
If the normal to the curve $y=f(x)$ at the point $(3,4)$ makes an angle $\frac{3 \pi}{4}$ with the positive $X$-axis, then $f^{\prime}(3)$ is equal to\\
solution:
Slope of tangent $y=f(x)$ is $\frac{d y}{d x}=f^{\prime}(x)_{(3,4)}$

Therefore, slope of normal

$$
=-\frac{1}{f^{\prime}(x)_{(3,4)}}=-\frac{1}{f^{\prime}(3)}
$$

But $\quad-\frac{1}{f^{\prime}(3)}=\tan \frac{3 \pi}{4}$

[given]

$$
\begin{array}{ll}
\Rightarrow & \frac{-1}{f^{\prime}(3)}=\tan \frac{\pi}{2}+\frac{\pi}{4}=-1 \\
\therefore & f^{\prime}(3)=1
\end{array}
$$

question: The normal to the curve $x=a(\cos \theta+\theta \sin \theta)$, $y=a(\sin \theta-\theta \cos \theta)$ at any point ' $\theta$ ' is such that
options: a) it makes a constant angle with the $X$-axis
b) it passes through the origin
c) it is at a constant distance from the origin
solution:
Given, $x=\alpha(\cos \theta+\theta \sin \theta)$

and $y=a(\sin \theta-\theta \cos \theta)$

$\therefore \quad \frac{d x}{d \theta}=a(-\sin \theta+\sin \theta+\theta \cos \theta)=a \theta \cos \theta$

and $\frac{d y}{d \theta}=a(\cos \theta-\cos \theta+\theta \sin \theta)$

$$
\frac{d y}{d \theta}=a \theta \sin \theta \Rightarrow \frac{d y}{d x}=\tan \theta
$$

Thus, equation of normal is

$$
\begin{gathered}
\frac{y-a(\sin \theta-\theta \cos \theta)}{x-a(\cos \theta+\theta \sin \theta)}=\frac{-\cos \theta}{\sin \theta} \\
\Rightarrow \quad-x \cos \theta+a \theta \sin \theta \cos \theta+a \cos ^{2} \theta \\
\Rightarrow \quad x \cos \theta+y \sin \theta=a
\end{gathered}
$$

whose distance from origin is


\begin{equation*}
\frac{|0+0-a|}{\sqrt{\cos ^{2} \theta+\sin ^{2} \theta}}=a \tag{i}
\end{equation*}

question: The slope of the tangent to the curve $\left(y-x^{5}\right)^{2}=x\left(1+x^{2}\right)^{2}$ at the point $(1,3)$ is
solution:
Slope of tangent at the point $\left(x_{1}, y_{1}\right)$ is $\frac{d y}{d x}$.

Given curve, $\quad\left(y-x^{5}\right)^{2}=x\left(1+x^{2}\right)^{2}$

$\Rightarrow 2\left(y-x^{5}\right) \frac{d y}{d x}-5 x^{4}=\left(1+x^{2}\right)^{2}+2 x\left(1+x^{2}\right) \cdot 2 x$

Put $x=1$ and $y=3, d y / d x=8$

question: A spherical iron ball of radius 10 cm is coated with a layer of ice of uniform thickness that melts at a rate of $50 \mathrm{~cm}^{3} / \mathrm{min}$. When the thickness of the ice is 5 cm , then the rate at which the thickness (in $\mathrm{cm} / \mathrm{min}$ ) of the ice decreases, is\\
solution:
Let the thickness of layer of ice is $x \mathrm{~cm}$, the volume of spherical ball (only ice layer) is


\begin{equation*}
V=\frac{4}{3} \pi\left[(10+x)^{3}-10^{3}\right] \tag{i}
\end{equation*}


On differentiating Eq. (i) w.r.t. ' $t$ ', we get

$$
\frac{d V}{d t}=\frac{4}{3} \pi\left(3(10+x)^{2}\right) \frac{d x}{d t}=-50
$$

[-ve sign indicate that volume is decreasing as time passes].

$$
\Rightarrow \quad 4 \pi(10+x)^{2} \frac{d x}{d t}=-50
$$

At $x=5 \mathrm{~cm}$

$$
\frac{d x}{d t}\left[4 \pi(10+5)^{2}\right]=-50
$$

$\Rightarrow \frac{d x}{d t}=-\frac{50}{225(4 \pi)}=-\frac{1}{9(2 \pi)}=-\frac{1}{18 \pi} \mathrm{cm} / \mathrm{min}$

So, the thickness of the ice decreases at the rate of $\frac{1}{18 \pi} \mathrm{cm} / \mathrm{min}$.

question: Let $f(x)=e^{x}-x$ and $g(x)=x^{2}-x, \forall x \in R$. Then, the set of all $x \in R$, where the function $h(x)=(f o g)(x)$ is increasing, is\\
solution:
The given functions are

$$
f(x)=e^{x}-x
$$

and

$$
g(x)=x^{2}-x, \forall x \in R
$$

Then, $h(x)=(f o g)(x)=f(g(x))$

Now, $h^{\prime}(x)=f^{\prime}(g(x)) \cdot g^{\prime}(x)$

$$
\begin{aligned}
& =\left(e^{g(x)}-1\right) \cdot(2 x-1)=\left(e^{\left(x^{2}-x\right)}-1\right)(2 x-1) \\
& =\left(e^{x(x-1)}-1\right)(2 x-1)
\end{aligned}
$$

$\because$ It is given that $h(x)$ is an increasing function, so $h^{\prime}(x) \geq 0$

$$
\Rightarrow \quad\left(e^{x(x-1)}-1\right)(2 x-1) \geq 0
$$

Case I $(2 x-1) \geq 0$ and $\left(e^{x(x-1)}-1\right) \geq 0$

$\Rightarrow \quad x \geq \frac{1}{2}$ and $x(x-1) \geq 0$

$\Rightarrow x \in[1 / 2, \infty)$ and $x \in(-\infty, 0] \cup[1, \infty)$, so $x \in[1, \infty)$

Case II $(2 x-1) \leq 0$ and $\left[e^{x(x-1)}-1\right] \leq 0$

$\Rightarrow \quad x \leq \frac{1}{2}$ and $x(x-1) \leq 0 \Rightarrow x \in-\infty, \frac{1}{2}$ and $x \in[0,1]$

So, $\quad x \in 0, \frac{1}{2}$

From, the above cases, $x \in 0, \frac{1}{2} \cup[1, \infty)$.

question:
If the function $f$ given by

$$
f(x)=x^{3}-3(a-2) x^{2}+3 a x+7
$$

for some $a \in R$ is increasing in ( 0,1$]$ and decreasing in $[1,5)$, then a root of the equation, $\frac{f(x)-14}{(x-1)^{2}}=0(x \neq 1)$ is\\
solution:
Given that function,

$f(x)=x^{3}-3(a-2) x^{2}+3 a x+7, \quad$ for some $a \in R$ is increasing in $(0,1]$ and decreasing in $[1,5)$.


\begin{align*}
& f^{\prime}(1)=0 \\
& {[\because \text { tangent at } x=1 \text { will be }} \\
& \Rightarrow\left(3 x^{2}-6(a-2) x+3 a\right)_{x=1}=0 \\
& \Rightarrow \quad 3-6(a-2)+3 a=0 \\
& \Rightarrow \quad 3-6 a+12+3 a=0 \\
& \Rightarrow \quad 15-3 a=0 \\
& \Rightarrow \quad a=5 \\
& \text { So, } \quad f(x)=x^{3}-9 x^{2}+15 x+7 \\
& \Rightarrow f(x)-14=x^{3}-9 x^{2}+15 x-7 \\
& \Rightarrow f(x)-14=(x-1)\left(x^{2}-8 x+7\right)=(x-1)(x-1)(x-7) \\
& \Rightarrow \quad \frac{f(x)-14}{(x-1)^{2}}=(x-7) \tag{i}
\end{align*}


$$
\Rightarrow \quad x-7=0 \quad \text { [from Eq. (i)] }
$$

$$
\Rightarrow \quad x=7
$$

question: Let $f(x)=\frac{x}{\sqrt{a^{2}+x^{2}}}-\frac{d-x}{\sqrt{b^{2}+(d-x)^{2}}}, x \in R$, where $a, b$ and $d$ are non-zero real constants. Then,
options: a) $f$ is an increasing function of $x$
b) $f^{\prime}$ is not a continuous function of $x$
c) $f$ is a decreasing function of $x$
d) $f$ is neither increasing nor decreasing function of $x$
solution:
We have,

$f(x)=\frac{x}{\left(a^{2}+x^{2}\right)^{1 / 2}}-\frac{(d-x)}{\left(b^{2}+(d-x)^{2}\right)^{1 / 2}}$

Differentiating above w.r.t. $x$, we get

$$
\begin{aligned}
& f^{\prime}(x)=\frac{\left(a^{2}+x^{2}\right)^{1 / 2}-x \frac{1}{2} \frac{2 x}{\left(a^{2}+x^{2}\right)^{1 / 2}}}{\left(a^{2}+x^{2}\right)} \\
& -\frac{\left(b^{2}+(d-x)^{2}\right)^{1 / 2}(-1)-(d-x) \frac{2(d-x)(-1)}{2\left(b^{2}+(d-x)^{2}\right)^{1 / 2}}}{\left(b^{2}+(d-x)^{2}\right)}

question:
If the function $g:(-\infty, \infty) \rightarrow-\frac{\pi}{2}, \frac{\pi}{2}$ is given by

$$
g(u)=2 \tan ^{-1}\left(e^{u}\right)-\frac{\pi}{2} \text {. Then, } g \text { is }
$$

$(2008,3 M)$
options: a) even and is strictly increasing in $(0, \infty)$
b) odd and is strictly decreasing in $(-\infty, \infty)$
c) odd and is strictly increasing in $(-\infty, \infty)$
d) neither even nor odd but is strictly increasing in $(-\infty, \infty)$
solution:
Given, $g(u)=2 \tan ^{-1}\left(e^{u}\right)-\frac{\pi}{2}$ for $u \in(-\infty, \infty)$

$$
\begin{aligned}
g(-u) & =2 \tan ^{-1}\left(e^{-u}\right)-\frac{\pi}{2}=2\left(\cot ^{-1}\left(e^{u}\right)\right)-\frac{\pi}{2} \\
& =2 \frac{\pi}{2}-\tan ^{-1}\left(e^{u}\right)-\frac{\pi}{2} \\
& =\pi / 2-2 \tan ^{-1}\left(e^{u}\right)=-g(u) \\
\therefore \quad g(-u) & =-g(u)
\end{aligned}
$$

$\Rightarrow g(u)$ is an odd function.

We have, $g(u)=2 \tan ^{-1}\left(e^{u}\right)-\pi / 2$

$$
g^{\prime}(u)=\frac{2 e^{u}}{1+e^{2 u}}
$$

$$
g^{\prime}(u)>0, \forall x \in R
$$

$\left[\because e^{u}>0\right]$

So, $g^{\prime}(u)$ is increasing for all $x \in R$.

question: If $f(x)=x^{3}+b x^{2}+c x+d$ and $0<b^{2}<c$, then in $(-\infty, \infty)$
solution:
Given,

$$
f(x)=x^{3}+b x^{2}+c x+d
$$

$\Rightarrow \quad f^{\prime}(x)=3 x^{2}+2 b x+c$

As we know that, if $a x^{2}+b x+c>0, \forall x$, then $a>0$ and $D<0$.

$$
\begin{array}{ll}
\text { Now, } & D=4 b^{2}-12 c=4\left(b^{2}-c\right)-8 c \\
\therefore & \quad \text { [where, } b^{2}-c<0 \text { and } c>0 \text { ] } \\
\Rightarrow f^{\prime}(x)=3 x^{2}+2 b x+c>0 \forall x \in(-\infty, \infty) \\
& \\
& \text { [as } D<0 \text { and } a>0]
\end{array}
$$

Hence, $f(x)$ is strictly increasing function.

question: The length of a longest interval in which the function $3 \sin x-4 \sin ^{3} x$ is increasing, is\\

question: If $f(x)=x e^{x(1-x)}$, then $f(x)$ is\\
solution:
Given, $f(x)=x e^{x(1-x)}$

$$
\begin{aligned}
\Rightarrow \quad f^{\prime}(x) & =e^{x(1-x)}+x e^{x(1-x)}(1-2 x) \\
& =e^{x(1-x)}[1+x(1-2 x)] \\
& =e^{x(1-x)}\left(1+x-2 x^{2}\right) \\
& =-e^{x(1-x)}\left(2 x^{2}-x-1\right) \\
& =-e^{x(1-x)}(x-1)(2 x+1)
\end{aligned}
$$

which is positive in $-\frac{1}{2}, 1$.

Therefore, $f(x)$ is increasing in $-\frac{1}{2}, 1$.

question: Let $f(x)=\int e^{x}(x-1)(x-2) d x$. Then, $f$ decreases in the interval\\
The function $f(x)=\sin ^{4} x+\cos ^{4} x$ increases, if\\
solution:
Given, $f(x)=\sin ^{4} x+\cos ^{4} x$

On differentiating w.r.t. $x$, we get

$$
\begin{aligned}
f^{\prime}(x) & =4 \sin ^{3} x \cos x-4 \cos ^{3} x \sin x \\
& =4 \sin x \cos x\left(\sin ^{2} x-\cos ^{2} x\right) \\
& =2 \sin 2 x(-\cos 2 x) \\
& =-\sin 4 x
\end{aligned}
$$

Now, $\quad \quad^{\prime}(x)>0$, if $\sin 4 x<0$

\[
\begin{array}{ll}
\Rightarrow & \pi<4 x<2 \pi \\
\Rightarrow & \frac{\pi}{4}<x<\frac{\pi}{2} \tag{i}

\]

Now,

$$
\frac{\pi}{4}<x<\frac{3 \pi}{8}
$$

Since, option (b) is the proper subset of Eq. (i), so it is correct.

question: If $f(x)=\frac{x}{\sin x}$ and $g(x)=\frac{x}{\tan x}$, where $0<x \leq 1$, then in this interval
options: a) both $f(x)$ and $g(x)$ are increasing functions
b) both $f(x)$ and $g(x)$ are decreasing functions
solution:
Given, $g(x)=\frac{x}{\tan x}$, where $0<x \leq 1$

Now, $g(x)$ is continuous in $[0,1]$ and differentiable in ] $0,1[$.

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \text { For } 0<x<1 \\
& g^{\prime}(x)=\frac{\tan x-x \sec ^{2} x}{\tan ^{2} x}
\end{aligned}
$$

Again, $\quad H(x)=\tan x-x \sec ^{2} x, 0 \leq x \leq 1$

Now, $H(x)$ is continuous in $[0,1]$ and differentiable in ] $0,1[$.

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \text { For } \quad 0<x<1, H(x)=\tan x-x \sec ^{2} x, 0 \leq x \leq 1 \\
& \Rightarrow \quad H^{\prime}(x)=\sec ^{2} x-\sec ^{2} x-2 x \sec ^{2} x \tan x \\
& =-2 x \sec ^{2} x \tan x<0
\end{aligned}
$$

Hence, $H(x)$ is decreasing function in $[0,1]$.

Thus, $H(x)<H(0)$ for $0<x<1$

$\Rightarrow \quad H(x)<0 \quad$ for $\quad 0<x<1$

$\Rightarrow \quad g^{\prime}(x)<0 \quad$ for $\quad 0<x<1$

$\Rightarrow \quad g(x)$ is decreasing function in $(0,1]$.

Therefore, $g(x)=\frac{x}{\tan x}$ is a decreasing function in $0<x \leq 1$.

Also,

$$
g(x)<g(0) \text { for } 0<x \leq 1
$$

$\Rightarrow \quad \frac{x}{\tan x}<1$ for $0<x \leq 1$

$\Rightarrow \quad x<\tan x$ for $0<x \leq 1$

Now, let $\quad f(x)=\begin{array}{ccc}x / \sin x & \text { for } & 0<x \leq 1 \\ 1 & \text { for } & x=0\end{array}$

Now, $f$ is continuous in $[0,1]$ and differentiable in $] 0,1[$.

For $0<x<1$,

$f^{\prime}(x)=\frac{\sin x-x \cos x}{\sin ^{2} x}=\frac{(\tan x-x) \cos x}{\sin ^{2} x}>0$ for $0<x<1$

$\Rightarrow f(x)$ increases in $[0,1]$.

Thus, $f(x)=\frac{x}{\sin x}$ increases in $0<x \leq 1$.

Therefore, option (c) is the answer.

question: Let $f$ and $g$ be increasing and decreasing functions respectively from $[0, \infty)$ to $[0, \infty)$ and $h(x)=f\{g(x)\}$. If $h(0)=0$, then $h(x)-h(1)$ is
solution:
Let $F(x)=h(x)-h(1)=f\{g(x)\}-f\{g(1)\}$

$$
\begin{aligned}
\therefore \quad F^{\prime}(x) & =f^{\prime}\{g(x)\} \cdot g^{\prime}(x) \\
& =(+)(\rightarrow)=-\mathrm{ve}
\end{aligned}
$$

[since, $f(x)$ is an increasing function $f^{\prime}(g(x))$ is + ve and $g(x)$ is decreasing function $g^{\prime}(f(x))$ is $\rightarrow$ ve ]

Since, $\quad f^{\prime}(x)$ is -ve.

$\therefore f(x)$ is decreasing function.

When

$$
0 \leq x<1
$$

$\Rightarrow$

$$
h(x)-h(1)=+\mathrm{ve}
$$

When

$$
x \geq 1
$$

$\Rightarrow$

$$
h(x)-h(1)=-\mathrm{ve}
$$

Hence, for

$$
x>0
$$

$h(x)-h(1)$ is neither always positive nor always negative, so it is not strictly increasing throughout. Therefore, option (d) is the answer.

question: Let $f(x)=5-|x-2|$ and $g(x)=|x+1|, x \in R$. If $f(x)$ attains maximum value at $\alpha$ and $g(x)$ attains minimum value of $\beta$, then $\lim _{x \rightarrow-\alpha \beta} \frac{(x-1)\left(x^{2}-5 x+6\right)}{x^{2}-6 x+8}$ is equal to\\

If the volume of parallelopiped formed by the vectors $\hat{\mathbf{i}}+\lambda \hat{\mathbf{j}}+\hat{\mathbf{k}}, \hat{\mathbf{j}}+\lambda \hat{\mathbf{k}}$ and $\lambda \hat{\mathbf{i}}+\hat{\mathbf{k}}$ is minimum, then $\lambda$ is equal to\\
solution:
$$
\begin{aligned}
& \text { Key Idea Volume of parallelopiped formed by the vectors } \mathbf{a} \text {, } \\
& \mathbf{b} \text { and } \mathbf{c} \text { is } V=[\mathbf{a} \mathbf{b} \mathbf{c}] \text {. }
\end{aligned}
$$

Given vectors are $\hat{\mathbf{i}}+\lambda \hat{\mathbf{j}}+\hat{\mathbf{k}}, \hat{\mathbf{j}}+\lambda \hat{\mathbf{k}}$ and $\lambda \hat{\mathbf{i}}+\hat{\mathbf{k}}$, which forms a parallelopiped.

$\therefore$ Volume of the parallelopiped is

$$
\begin{aligned}
V & =\left|\begin{array}{lll}
1 & \lambda & 1 \\
0 & 1 & \lambda \\
\lambda & 0 & 1
\end{array}\right| \\
\Rightarrow \quad V & =\lambda^{3}-\lambda+1+\lambda^{3}-\lambda
\end{aligned}
$$

On differentiating w.r.t. $\lambda$, we get

$$
\frac{d V}{d \lambda}=3 \lambda^{2}-1
$$

For maxima or minima, $\frac{d V}{d \lambda}=0$

$\Rightarrow \quad \lambda= \pm \frac{1}{\sqrt{3}}$

and $\quad \frac{d^{2} V}{d \lambda^{2}}=6 \lambda=\begin{aligned} & 2 \sqrt{3}>0, \text { for } \lambda=\frac{1}{\sqrt{3}} \\ & 2 \sqrt{3}<0,\end{aligned}$

$\because \frac{d^{2} V}{d \lambda^{2}}$ is positive for $\lambda=\frac{1}{\sqrt{3}}$, so volume ' $V$ ' is minimum for $\lambda=\frac{1}{\sqrt{3}}$

question: If $m$ is the minimum value of $k$ for which the function $f(x)=x \sqrt{k x-x^{2}}$ is increasing in the interval $[0,3]$ and $M$ is the maximum value of $f$ in the interval $[0,3]$ when $k=m$, then the ordered pair $(m, M)$ is equal to\\
solution:
Given function $f(x)=x \sqrt{k x-x^{2}}$

the function $f(x)$ is defined if $k x-x^{2} \geq 0$

\[
\begin{array}{lr}
\Rightarrow & x^{2}-k x \leq 0 \\
\Rightarrow & x \in[0, k] \tag{ii}
\end{array}
\]

because it is given that $f(x)$ is increasing in interval $x \in[0,3]$, so $k$ should be positive.

Now, on differentiating the function $f(x)$ w.r.t. $x$, we get

$$
\begin{aligned}
f^{\prime}(x) & =\sqrt{k x-x^{2}}+\frac{x}{2 \sqrt{k x-x^{2}}} \times(k-2 x) \\
& =\frac{2\left(k x-x^{2}\right)+k x-2 x^{2}}{2 \sqrt{k x-x^{2}}}=\frac{3 k x-4 x^{2}}{2 \sqrt{k x-x^{2}}}
\end{aligned}
$$

as $f(x)$ is increasing in interval $x \in[0,3]$, so

$$
\begin{array}{rlrl} 
& & f^{\prime}(x) \geq 0 \forall x \in(0,3) \\
\Rightarrow & & 3 k x-4 x^{2} \geq 0 \\
\Rightarrow & & 4 x^{2}-3 k x \leq 0 \\
\Rightarrow & 4 x & x-\frac{3 k}{4} \leq 0 \Rightarrow x \in 0, \frac{3 k}{4} \text { (as } k \text { is positive) }
\end{array}
$$

So, $\quad 3 \leq \frac{3 k}{4} \Rightarrow k \geq 4$

$\Rightarrow$ Minimum value of $k=m=4$

and the maximum value of $f$ in $[0,3]$ is $f(3)$.

$\because f$ is increasing function in interval $x \in[0,3]$

$\because M=f(3)=3 \sqrt{4 \times 3-3^{2}}=3 \sqrt{3}$

Therefore, ordered pair $(m, M)=(4,3 \sqrt{3})$

question: If $f(x)$ is a non-zero polynomial of degree four, having local extreme points at $x=-1,0,1$, then the set $S=\{x \in R: f(x)=f(0)\}$ contains exactly
options: b) two irrational and two rational numbers
d) two irrational and one rational number
solution:
The non-zero four degree polynomial $f(x)$ has extremum points at $x=-1,0,1$, so we can assume $f^{\prime}(x)=a(x+1)(x-0)(x-1)=a x\left(x^{2}-1\right)$

where, $a$ is non-zero constant.

$$
\begin{aligned}
& f^{\prime}(x)=a x^{3}-a x \\
\Rightarrow \quad & f(x)=\frac{a}{4} x^{4}-\frac{a}{2} x^{2}+C
\end{aligned}
$$

[integrating both sides]

where, $C$ is constant of integration.

Now, since $f(x)=f(0)$

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \Rightarrow \quad \frac{a}{4} x^{4}-\frac{a}{2} x^{2}+C=C \Rightarrow \frac{x^{4}}{4}=\frac{x^{2}}{2} \\
& \Rightarrow \quad x^{2}\left(x^{2}-2\right)=0 \Rightarrow x=-\sqrt{2}, 0, \sqrt{2}
\end{aligned}
$$

Thus, $f(x)=f(0)$ has one rational and two irrational roots.

question: The height of a right circular cylinder of maximum volume inscribed in a sphere of radius 3 is\\
If $S_{1}$ and $S_{2}$ are respectively the sets of local minimum and local maximum points of the function, $f(x)=9 x^{4}+12 x^{3}-36 x^{2}+25, x \in R$, then
solution:
Given function is

$$
f(x)=9 x^{4}+12 x^{3}-36 x^{2}+25=y \text { (let) }
$$

For maxima or minima put $\frac{d y}{d x}=0$

$\Rightarrow \quad \frac{d y}{d x}=36 x^{3}+36 x^{2}-72 x=0$

$\Rightarrow \quad x^{3}+x^{2}-2 x=0$

$\Rightarrow \quad x\left[x^{2}+x-2\right]=0$

$\Rightarrow \quad x\left[x^{2}+2 x-x-2\right]=0$

$\Rightarrow \quad x[x(x+2)-1(x+2)]=0$

$\Rightarrow \quad x(x-1)(x+2)=0$

$\Rightarrow \quad x=-2,0,1$

By sign method, we have following

\begin{center}
\includegraphics[max width=\textwidth]{2024_07_10_6bd1f8d6416891e4b4d7g-21}
\end{center}

Since, $\frac{d y}{d x}$ changes it's sign from negative to positive at $x=-2$ ' and ' 1 ', so $x=-2,1$ are points of local minima. Also, $\frac{d y}{d x}$ changes it's sign from positive to negative at $x=0$, so $x=0$ is point of local maxima.

$\therefore S_{1}=\{-2,1\}$ and $S_{2}=\{0\}$.

question: The shortest distance between the line $y=x$ and the curve $y^{2}=x-2$ is\\
The maximum area (in sq. units) of a rectangle having its base on the $X$-axis and its other two vertices on the parabola, $y=12-x^{2}$ such that the rectangle lies inside the parabola, is\\
solution:
Equation of parabola is given, $y=12-x^{2}$

$$
\text { or } \quad x^{2}=-(y-12) \text {. }
$$

Note that vertex of parabola is $(0,12)$ and its open downward.

Let $Q$ be one of the vertices of rectangle which lies on parabola. Then, the coordinates of $Q$ be $\left(a, 12-a^{2}\right)$

\begin{center}
\includegraphics[max width=\textwidth]{2024_07_10_6bd1f8d6416891e4b4d7g-22(1)}
\end{center}

Then, area of rectangle $P Q R S$

$=2 \times($ Area of rectangle $P Q M O)$

[due to symmetry about $Y$-axis]

$$
\left.=2 \times\left[a\left(12-a^{2}\right)\right]=24 a-2 a^{3}=\Delta \text { let }\right) \text {. }
$$

The area function $\Delta_{a}$ will be maximum, when

$$
\begin{array}{cc} 
& \frac{d \Delta}{d a}=0 \\
\Rightarrow & 24-6 a^{2}=0 \\
\Rightarrow & a^{2}=4 \Rightarrow a=2
\end{array}
$$

$[\because a>0]$

So, maximum area of rectangle

$$
P Q R S=(24 \times 2)-2(2)^{3}
$$

$$
=48-16=32 \text { sq units }
$$

question:
The maximum value of the function

$$
f(x)=3 x^{3}-18 x^{2}+27 x-40
$$

on the set $S=\left\{x \in R: x^{2}+30 \leq 11 x\right\}$ is (2019 Main, 11 Jan I)\\
solution:
We have,


\begin{align*}
f(x) & =3 x^{3}-18 x^{2}+27 x-40 \\
\Rightarrow \quad f^{\prime}(x) & =9 x^{2}-36 x+27 \\
= & =9\left(x^{2}-4 x+3\right)=9(x-1)(x-3) \tag{i}
\end{align*}


Also, we have $S=\left\{x \in R: x^{2}+30 \leq 11 x\right\}$

Clearly, $\quad x^{2}+30 \leq 11 x$

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \Rightarrow \quad x^{2}-11 x+30 \leq 0 \\
& \Rightarrow \quad(x-5)(x-6) \leq 0 \Rightarrow x \in[5,6] \\
& \text { So, } \quad S=[5,6]
\end{aligned}
$$

Note that $f(x)$ is increasing in $[5,6]$

$\left[\because f^{\prime}(x)>0\right.$ for $x \in[5,6]$

$\therefore f(6)$ is maximum, where

$$
f(6)=3(6)^{3}-18(6)^{2}+27(6)-40=122
$$

question: Let $A(4,-4)$ and $B(9,6)$ be points on the parabola, $y^{2}=4 x$. Let $C$ be chosen on the arc $A O B$ of the parabola, where $O$ is the origin, such that the area of $\triangle A C B$ is maximum. Then, the area (in sq. units) of $\triangle A C B$, is\\
solution:
According to given information, we have the following figure.

\begin{center}
\includegraphics[max width=\textwidth]{2024_07_10_6bd1f8d6416891e4b4d7g-22}
\end{center}

For $y^{2}=4 a x$, parametric coordinates of a point is $\left(a t^{2}\right.$, $2 a t)$.

$\therefore$ For $y^{2}=4 x$, let coordinates of $C$ be $\left(t^{2}, 2 t\right)$.

Then, area of $\triangle A B C=\frac{1}{2}|| \begin{array}{ccc}t^{2} & 2 t & 1 \\ 9 & 6 & 1 \\ 4 & -4 & 1\end{array}||$

$=\frac{1}{2}\left|t^{2}(6-(-4))-2 t(9-4)+1(-36-24)\right|$

$=\frac{1}{2}\left|10 t^{2}-10 t-60\right|=\frac{10}{2}\left|t^{2}-t-6\right|=5\left|t^{2}-t-6\right|$

Let, $\quad A(t)=5\left|t^{2}-t-6\right|$

Clearly, $A(4,-4) \equiv A\left(t_{1}^{2}, 2 t_{1}\right) \Rightarrow 2 t_{1}=-4$

$$
\Rightarrow \quad t_{1}=-2
$$

and $B(9,6) \equiv B\left(t_{2}^{2}, 2 t_{2}\right) \Rightarrow 2 t_{2}=6 \Rightarrow t_{2}=3$

Since, $C$ is on the arc $A O B$, the parameter ' $t$ ' for point $C \in(-2,3)$.

Let $f(t)=t^{2}-t-6 \Rightarrow f^{\prime \prime}(t)=2 t-1$

Now, $\quad f^{\prime}(t)=0 \Rightarrow t=\frac{1}{2}$

Thus, for $A(t)$, critical point is at $t=\frac{1}{2}$

Now, $A \frac{1}{2}=5\left|\frac{1}{2}^{2}-\frac{1}{2}-6\right|=\frac{125}{4}=31 \frac{1}{4}$ [Using Eq. (i)]

question: The maximum volume (in cu.m) of the right circular cone having slant height 3 m is\\

Let $f(x)=x^{2}+\frac{1}{x^{2}}$ and $g(x)=x-\frac{1}{x}, x \in \mathbf{R}-\{-1,0,1\}$. If

$h(x)=\frac{f(x)}{g(x)}$, then the local minimum value of $h(x)$ is\\
solution:
We have,

$$
\begin{aligned}
& f(x)=x^{2}+\frac{1}{x^{2}} \text { and } g(x)=x-\frac{1}{x} \Rightarrow h(x)=\frac{f(x)}{g(x)} \\
& \therefore \quad h(x)= \frac{x^{2}+\frac{1}{x^{2}}}{x-\frac{1}{x}}=\frac{x-\frac{1}{x}+2}{x-\frac{1}{x}} \\
& \Rightarrow \quad h(x)=x-\frac{1}{x}+\frac{2}{x-\frac{1}{x}} \\
& x-\frac{1}{x}>0, x-\frac{1}{x}+\frac{2}{x-\frac{1}{x}} \in[2 \sqrt{2}, \infty) \\
& x-\frac{1}{x}<0, x-\frac{1}{x}+\frac{2}{x-\frac{1}{x}} \in(-\infty, 2 \sqrt{2}]
\end{aligned}
$$

$\therefore$ Local minimum value is $2 \sqrt{2}$.

The least value of $\alpha \in R$ for which $4 \alpha x^{2}+\frac{1}{x} \geq 1$, for all $x>0$, is
solution:
Here, to find the least value of $\alpha \in R$, for which $4 \alpha x^{2}+\frac{1}{x} \geq 1$, for all $x>0$.

i.e. to find the minimum value of $\alpha$ when $y=4 \alpha x^{2}+\frac{1}{x} ; x>0$ attains minimum value of $\alpha$.

$\therefore \quad \frac{d y}{d x}=8 \alpha x-\frac{1}{x^{2}}$

Now, $\quad \frac{d^{2} y}{d x^{2}}=8 \alpha+\frac{2}{x^{3}}$

When $\quad \frac{d y}{d x}=0$ then $8 x^{3} \alpha=1$

At $x=\frac{1}{8 \alpha}^{1 / 3}, \frac{d^{2} y}{d x^{2}}=8 \alpha+16 \alpha=24 \alpha$, Thus, $y$ attains minimum when $x=\frac{1}{8 \alpha}^{1 / 3} ; \alpha>0$.

$\therefore y$ attains minimum when $x=\frac{1}{8 \alpha}^{1 / 3}$.

$$
\begin{array}{lr}
\text { i.e. } & 4 \alpha \frac{1}{8 \alpha}^{2 / 3}+(8 \alpha)^{1 / 3} \geq 1 \\
\Rightarrow & \alpha^{1 / 3}+2 \alpha^{1 / 3} \geq 1 \\
\Rightarrow & 3 \alpha^{1 / 3} \geq 1 \Rightarrow \alpha \geq \frac{1}{27}
\end{array}
$$

Hence, the least value of $\alpha$ is $\frac{1}{27}$.

question: Let $f(x)$ be a polynomial of degree four having extreme values at $x=1$ and $x=2$. If $\lim _{x \rightarrow 0} 1+\frac{f(x)}{x^{2}}=3$, then $f(2)$ is equal to\\
solution:
PLAN Any function have extreme values (maximum or minimum) at its critical points, where $f^{\prime}(x)=2$.

Since, the function have extreme values at $x=1$ and $x=2$.

\section*{248 Application of Derivatives}
$$
\begin{array}{ll}
\therefore & f^{\prime}(x)=0 \text { at } x=1 \text { and } x=2 \\
\Rightarrow & f^{\prime}(1)=0 \text { and } f^{\prime}(2)=0
\end{array}
$$

Also, it is given that,

$$
\begin{aligned}
\Rightarrow & \lim _{x \rightarrow 0} 1+\frac{f(x)}{x^{2}}=3 \\
\Rightarrow & 1+\lim _{x \rightarrow 0} \frac{f(x)}{x^{2}}=3 \\
\Rightarrow & \lim _{x \rightarrow 0} \frac{f(x)}{x^{2}}=2
\end{aligned}
$$

$\Rightarrow f(x)$ will be of the form $a x^{4}+b x^{3}+2 x^{2}$.

$[\because f(x)$ is of four degree polynomial]

\[
\begin{array}{lrl}
\text { Let } & f(x) & =a x^{4}+b x^{3}+2 x^{2} \\
\Rightarrow & f^{\prime}(x) & =4 a x^{3}+3 b x^{2}+4 x \\
\Rightarrow & f^{\prime}(1) & =4 a+3 b+4=0 \\
\text { and } & f^{\prime}(2) & =32 a+12 b+8=0 \\
\Rightarrow & 8 a+3 b+2 & =0 \tag{ii}
\end{array}
\]

On solving Eqs. (i) and (ii),

$$
\begin{array}{ll}
\text { we get } & a=\frac{1}{2}, b=-2 \\
\therefore & f(x)=\frac{x^{4}}{2}-2 x^{3}+2 x^{2} \\
\Rightarrow & f(2)=8-16+8=0
\end{array}
$$

question:
On the interval $[0,1]$, the function $x^{25}(1-x)^{75}$ takes its maximum value at the point
\\
solution:
Let $f(x)=x^{25}(1-x)^{75}, x \in[0,1]$


$$
\begin{aligned}
\Rightarrow \quad f^{\prime}(x) & =25 x^{24}(1-x)^{75}-75 x^{25}(1-x)^{74} \\
& =25 x^{24}(1-x)^{74}[(1-x)-3 x] \\
& =25 x^{24}(1-x)^{74}(1-4 x)
\end{aligned}
$$

For maximum value of $f(x)$, put $f^{\prime}(x)=0$

$$
\begin{array}{ll}
\Rightarrow & 25 x^{24}(1-x)^{74}(1-4 x)=0 \\
\Rightarrow & x=0,1, \frac{1}{4} \\
\text { Also, at } & x=0, y=0 \\
\text { At } & x=1, y=0 \\
\text { and at } & x=1 / 4, y>0
\end{array}
$$

$\therefore f(x)$ attains maximum at $x=1 / 4$.\\

question: Find the coordinates of all the points $P$ on the ellipse $\frac{x^{2}}{a^{2}}+\frac{y^{2}}{b^{2}}=1$, for which the area of the $\triangle P O N$ is maximum, where $O$ denotes the origin and $N$ is the foot of the perpendicular from $O$ to the tangent at $P$.\\
solution:
Let the coordinates of $P$ be $(a \cos \theta, b \sin \theta)$

Equations of tangents at $P$ is

\begin{center}
\includegraphics[max width=\textwidth]{2024_07_10_6bd1f8d6416891e4b4d7g-25}
\end{center}

$$
\frac{x}{a} \cos \theta+\frac{y}{b} \sin \theta=1
$$

Again, equation of normal at point $P$ is

$$
a x \sec \theta-b y \operatorname{cosec} \theta=a^{2}-b^{2}
$$

Let $M$ be foot of perpendicular from $O$ to $P K$, the normal at $P$.

Area of $\triangle O P N=\frac{1}{2}$ (Area of rectangle $O M P N$ )

$$
=\frac{1}{2} O N \cdot O M
$$

Now, $\quad O N=\frac{1}{\sqrt{\frac{\cos ^{2} \theta}{a^{2}}+\frac{\sin ^{2} \theta}{b^{2}}}}=\frac{a b}{\sqrt{b^{2} \cos ^{2} \theta+a^{2} \sin ^{2} \theta}}$

[perpendicular from $O$, to line $N P$ ]

$$
\text { and } O M=\frac{a^{2}-b^{2}}{\sqrt{a^{2} \sec ^{2} \theta+b^{2} \operatorname{cosec}^{2} \theta}}=\frac{\left(a^{2}-b^{2}\right) \cdot \cos \theta \cdot \sin \theta}{\sqrt{a^{2} \sin ^{2} \theta+b^{2} \cos ^{2} \theta}}
$$

Thus, area of $\triangle O P N=\frac{a b\left(a^{2}-b^{2}\right) \cos \theta \cdot \sin \theta}{2\left(a^{2} \sin ^{2} \theta+b^{2} \cos ^{2} \theta\right)}$

$$
=\frac{a b\left(a^{2}-b^{2}\right) \tan \theta}{2\left(a^{2} \tan ^{2} \theta+b^{2}\right)}
$$

$$
\begin{aligned}
\text { Let } f(\theta) & =\frac{\tan \theta}{\alpha^{2} \tan ^{2} \theta+b^{2}} \quad[0<\theta<\pi / 2] \\
f^{\prime}(\theta) & =\frac{\sec ^{2} \theta\left(a^{2} \tan ^{2} \theta+b^{2}\right)-\tan \theta\left(2 a^{2} \tan \theta \sec ^{2} \theta\right)}{\left(a^{2} \tan ^{2} \theta+b^{2}\right)^{2}} \\
& =\frac{\sec ^{2} \theta\left(a^{2} \tan ^{2} \theta+b^{2}-2 a^{2} \tan ^{2} \theta\right)}{\left(a^{2} \tan ^{2} \theta+b^{2}\right)^{2}} \\
& =\frac{\sec ^{2} \theta(a \tan \theta+b)(b-a \tan \theta)}{\left(a^{2} \tan ^{2} \theta+b^{2}\right)^{2}}
\end{aligned}
$$

For maximum or minimum, we put

$$
\begin{aligned}
& f^{\prime}(\theta)=0 \Rightarrow b-a \tan \theta=0 \\
& {\left[\sec ^{2} \theta \neq 0, a \tan \theta+b \neq 0,0<\theta<\pi / 2\right]} \\
& \Rightarrow \quad \tan \theta=b / a
\end{aligned}
$$

Also, $f^{\prime}(\theta)$

$$
\begin{aligned}
& >0 \text {, if } 0<\theta<\tan ^{-1}(b / a) \\
& <0 \text {, if } \tan ^{-1}(b / a)<\theta<\pi / 2
\end{aligned}
$$

\section*{250 Application of Derivatives}
Therefore, $f(\theta)$ has maximum, when

$$
\begin{aligned}
\theta & =\tan ^{-1} \frac{b}{a} \Rightarrow \tan \theta=\frac{b}{a} \\
\text { Again, } \quad \sin \theta & =\frac{b}{\sqrt{a^{2}+b^{2}}}, \cos \theta=\frac{a}{\sqrt{a^{2}+b^{2}}}
\end{aligned}
$$

By using symmetry, we get the required points

$$
\frac{ \pm a^{2}}{\sqrt{a^{2}+b^{2}}}, \frac{ \pm b^{2}}{\sqrt{a^{2}+b^{2}}}
$$

solution:
$y=a \log x+b x^{2}+x$ has extremum at $x=-1$ and $x=2$.

$$

$$

and $\quad x=2 \Rightarrow \frac{a}{x}+2 b x+1=0$, at $x=-1$

and $\quad x=2$

$\therefore \quad-a-2 b+1=0$

and $\quad \frac{a}{2}+4 b+1=0$

$$
\Rightarrow \quad a=2 \text { and } b=-\frac{1}{2}
$$

question:
If $p, q$ and $r$ are any real numbers, then

A cylindrical container is to be made from certain solid material with the following constraints : It has a fixed inner volume of $V \mathrm{~mm}^{3}$, has a 2 mm thick solid wall and is open at the top. The bottom of the container is a solid circular disc of thickness 2 mm and is of radius equal to the outer radius of the container.

If the volume of the material used to make the container is minimum, when the inner radius of the container is 10 mm , then the value of $\frac{V}{250 \pi}$ is
solution:
Here, volume of cylindrical container, $V=\pi r^{2} h \quad \ldots$ (i) and let volume of the material used be $T$.

$$
\begin{array}{rr}
\therefore & T=\pi\left[(r+2)^{2}-r^{2}\right] h+\pi(r+2)^{2} \times 2 \\
\Rightarrow & T=\pi\left[(r+2)^{2}-r^{2}\right] \cdot \frac{V}{\pi r^{2}}+2 \pi(r+2)^{2} \\
& {\left[\because V=\pi r^{2} h \Rightarrow h=\frac{V}{\pi r^{2}}\right]}

$$
\Rightarrow \quad T=V \frac{r+2}{r}^{2}+2 \pi(r+2)^{2}-V

On differentiating w.r.t. $r$, we get

At $r=10, \frac{d T}{d r}=0$

Now,

$$

where

r=10
