question:
A vertical line passing through the point $(h, 0)$ intersects the ellipse $\frac{x^{2}}{4}+\frac{y^{2}}{3}=1$ at the points $P$ and $Q$. If the tangents to the ellipse at $P$ and $Q$ meet at the point R.

If $\Delta(h)=$ area of the $\triangle P Q R, \Delta_{1}=\max _{1 / 2 \leq h \leq 1} \Delta(h)$ and $\Delta_{2}=\min _{1 / 2 \leq h \leq 1} \Delta(h)$, then $\frac{8}{\sqrt{5}} \Delta_{1}-8 \Delta_{2}$ is equal to
solution:
PLAN As to maximise or minimise area of triangle, we should find area in terms of parametric coordinates and use second derivative test.

Here, tangent at $P(2 \cos \theta, \sqrt{3} \sin \theta)$ is


\begin{align*}
& \text { < } \\
& \frac{x}{2} \cos \theta+\frac{y}{\sqrt{3}} \sin \theta=1 \\
& \therefore \quad R(2 \sec \theta, 0) \\
& \Rightarrow \quad \Delta=\text { Area of } \triangle P Q R \\
& =\frac{1}{2}(2 \sqrt{3} \sin \theta)(2 \sec \theta-2 \cos \theta) \\
& =2 \sqrt{3} \cdot \sin ^{3} \theta / \cos \theta  \tag{i}\\
& \frac{1}{2} \leq h \leq 1 \\
& \therefore \quad \frac{1}{2} \leq 2 \cos \theta \leq 1 \\
& \Rightarrow \quad \frac{1}{4} \leq \cos \theta \leq \frac{1}{2}  \tag{ii}\\
& \therefore \quad \frac{d \Delta}{d \theta}=\frac{2 \sqrt{3}\left\{\cos \theta \cdot 3 \sin ^{2} \theta \cos \theta-\sin ^{3} \theta(-\sin \theta)\right\}}{\cos ^{2} \theta} \\
& =\frac{2 \sqrt{3} \cdot \sin ^{2} \theta}{\cos ^{2} \theta}\left[3 \cos ^{2} \theta+\sin ^{2} \theta\right] \\
& =\frac{2 \sqrt{3} \sin ^{2} \theta}{\cos ^{2} \theta} \cdot\left[2 \cos ^{2} \theta+1\right] \\
& =2 \sqrt{3} \tan ^{2} \theta\left(2 \cos ^{2} \theta+1\right)>0
\end{align*}


$\therefore \quad \Delta_{1}=\Delta_{\text {max }}$ occurs at $\cos \theta=\frac{1}{4}=\frac{2 \sqrt{3} \cdot \sin ^{3} \theta}{\cos \theta}$

When $\cos \theta=\frac{1}{4}=\frac{45 \sqrt{5}}{8}$

$\Delta_{2}=\Delta_{\text {min }}$ occurs at $\cos \theta=\frac{1}{2}$

$$
=\frac{2 \sqrt{3} \sin ^{3} \theta}{\cos \theta}
$$

When $\quad \cos \theta=\frac{1}{2}=\frac{9}{2}$

$\therefore \quad \frac{8}{\sqrt{5}} \Delta_{1}-8 \Delta_{2}=45-36=9$

question: Let $f: R \rightarrow R$ be defined as $f(x)=|x|+\left|x^{2}-1\right|$. The total number of points at which $f$ attains either a local maximum or a local minimum is
solution:
PLAN

(i) Local maximum and local minimum are those points at which $f^{\prime}(x)=0$, when defined for all real numbers.

(ii) Local maximum and local minimum for piecewise functions are also been checked at sharp edges.

Description of Situation $\quad y=|x|=\begin{aligned} & x \text {, if } x \geq 0 \\ & -x \text {, if } x<0\end{aligned}$

Also,

$$
\begin{aligned}
& y=\left|x^{2}-1\right|=\begin{array}{ll}
\left(x^{2}-1\right), & \text { if } x \leq-1 \text { or } x \geq 1 \\
\left(1-x^{2}\right), & \text { if }-1 \leq x \leq 1
\end{array} \\
& -x+1-x^{2}, \text { if } x \leq-1 \\
& y=|x|+\left|x^{2}-1\right|=\begin{array}{ll}
-x+1-x^{2}, & \text { if }-1 \leq x \leq 0 \\
x+1-x^{2}, & \text { if } 0 \leq x \leq 1
\end{array} \\
& x+x^{2}-1, \quad \text { if } x \geq 1 \\
& -x^{2}-x+1, \quad \text { if } \quad x \leq-1 \\
& =-x^{2}-x+1, \quad \text { if }-1 \leq x \leq 0 \\
& -x^{2}+x+1, \quad \text { if } \quad 0 \leq x \leq \\
& x^{2}+x-1 \text {, if } \quad x \geq 1
\end{aligned}
$$

which could be graphically shown as

\begin{center}
\includegraphics[max width=\textwidth]{2024_07_10_6bd1f8d6416891e4b4d7g-37}
\end{center}

Thus, $f(x)$ attains maximum at $x=\frac{1}{2}, \frac{-1}{2}$ and $f(x)$ attains minimum at $x=-1,0,1$.

$\Rightarrow$ Total number of points $=5$

question: Let $p(x)$ be a real polynomial of least degree which has a local maximum at $x=1$ and a local minimum at $x=3$. If $p(1)=6$ and $p(3)=2$, then $p^{\prime}(0)$ is equal to
solution:
PLAN If $f(x)$ is least degree polynomial having local maximum and local minimum at $\alpha$ and $\beta$.

Then, $\quad f^{\prime}(x)=\lambda(x-\alpha)(x-\beta)$

Here, $\quad p^{\prime}(x)=\lambda(x-1)(x-3)=\lambda\left(x^{2}-4 x+3\right)$

On integrating both sides between 1 to 3 , we get

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \int_{1}^{3} p^{\prime}(x) d x=\int_{1}^{3} \lambda\left(x^{2}-4 x+3\right) d x \\
& \Rightarrow \quad(p(x))_{1}^{3}=\lambda \quad \frac{x^{3}}{3}-2 x^{2}+3 x
\end{aligned}
$$

\section*{262 Application of Derivatives}
$$
\begin{array}{rlrl}
\Rightarrow & p(3)-p(1) & =\lambda(9-18+9)-\frac{1}{3}-2+3 \\
\Rightarrow & 2-6 & =\lambda \frac{-4}{3} \\
\Rightarrow & \lambda & =3 \\
\Rightarrow & & p^{\prime}(x) & =3(x-1)(x-3) \\
\therefore & & p^{\prime}(0) & =9
\end{array}
$$

question: The number of distinct real roots of $x^{4}-4 x^{3}+12 x^{2}+x-1=0$ is.....
solution:
$f(x)=x^{4}-4 x^{3}+12 x^{2}+x-1$

$f^{\prime}(x)=4 x^{3}-12 x^{2}+24 x+1$

$f^{\prime \prime}(x)=12 x^{2}-24 x+24=12\left(x^{2}-2 x+2\right)$

$$
=12\left\{(x-1)^{2}+1\right\}>0 \forall x
$$

$\Rightarrow \quad f^{\prime}(x)$ is increasing.

Since, $f^{\prime}(x)$ is cubic and increasing.

$\Rightarrow f^{\prime}(x)$ has only one real root and two imaginary roots.

$\therefore f(x)$ cannot have all distinct roots.

$\Rightarrow$ Atmost 2 real roots.

Now, $f(-1)=15, f(0)=-1, f(1)=9$

$\therefore f(x)$ must have one root in $(-1,0)$ and other in $(0,1)$.

$\Rightarrow 2$ real roots.

question: Let $f$ be a function defined on $R$ (the set of all real numbers) such that $f^{\prime}(x)=2010(x-2009)(x-2010)^{2}$ $(x-2011)^{3}(x-2012)^{4}, \forall x \in R$. If $g$ is a function defined on $R$ with values in the interval $(0, \infty)$ such that $f(x)=\ln (g(x)), \forall x \in R$, then the number of points in $R$ at which $g$ has a local maximum is......
solution:
Let $g(x)=e^{f(x)}, \forall x \in R$

$\Rightarrow \quad g^{\prime}(x)=e^{f(x)} \cdot f^{\prime}(x)$

$\Rightarrow f^{\prime}(x)$ changes its sign from positive to negative in the neighbourhood of $x=2009$

$\Rightarrow f(x)$ has local maxima at $x=2009$.

So, the number of local maximum is one.\\

question: The maximum value of the expression $\frac{1}{\sin ^{2} \theta+3 \sin \theta \cos \theta+5 \cos ^{2} \theta}$ is .....
The maximum value of the function $f(x)=2 x^{3}-15 x^{2}+36 x-48$ on the set $A=\left\{x \mid x^{2}+20 \leq 9 x\right\}$ is $\qquad$ .

Let $\alpha \in(0, \pi / 2)$ be fixed. If the integral

$$
\int \frac{\tan x+\tan \alpha}{\tan x-\tan \alpha} d x=A(x) \cos 2 \alpha+B(x)
$$

$\sin 2 \alpha+C$, where $C$ is a constant of integration, then the functions $A(x)$ and $B(x)$ are respectively
solution:
Let $I=\int \frac{\tan x+\tan \alpha}{\tan x-\tan \alpha} d x, \alpha \in 0, \frac{\pi}{2}$

$$
\begin{aligned}
& =\int \frac{\frac{\sin x}{\cos x}+\frac{\sin \alpha}{\cos \alpha}}{\frac{\sin x}{\cos x}-\frac{\sin \alpha}{\cos \alpha}} d x \\
& =\int \frac{\sin x \cos \alpha+\sin \alpha \cos x}{\sin x \cos \alpha-\sin \alpha \cos x} d x \\
& =\int \frac{\sin (x+\alpha)}{\sin (x-\alpha)} d x
\end{aligned}
$$

Now, put $x-\alpha=t \Rightarrow d x=d t$, so

$$
\begin{aligned}
I & =\int \frac{\sin (t+2 \alpha)}{\sin t} d t \\
& =\int \frac{\sin t \cos 2 \alpha+\sin 2 \alpha \cos t}{\sin t} d t \\
& =\int \cos 2 \alpha+\sin 2 \alpha \frac{\cos t}{\sin t} d t
\end{aligned}
$$

$=t(\cos 2 \alpha)+(\sin 2 \alpha) \log _{e}|\sin t|+C$

$=(x-\alpha) \cos 2 \alpha+(\sin 2 \alpha) \log _{e}|\sin (x-\alpha)|+C$

$=A(x) \cos 2 \alpha+B(x) \sin 2 \alpha+C$ (given)

Now on comparing, we get

$$
A(x)=x-\alpha \text { and } B(x)=\log _{e}|\sin (x-\alpha)|
$$

question: The integral $\int \frac{2 x^{3}-1}{x^{4}+x} d x$ is equal to (2019 Main, 12 April I)\\
reference: here $C$ is a constant of integration
solution:
2. Key Idea
(i) Divide each term of numerator and denominator by $x^{2}$.

(ii) Let $x^{2}+\frac{1}{x}=t$

Let integral is $I=\int \frac{2 x^{3}-1}{x^{4}+x} d x=\int \frac{2 x-1 / x^{2}}{x^{2}+\frac{1}{x}} d x$

[dividing each term of numerator and denominator by $\left.x^{2}\right]$

Put $x^{2}+\frac{1}{x}=t \Rightarrow 2 x+-\frac{1}{x^{2}} \quad d x=d t$

$$
\begin{aligned}
\therefore \quad & =\int \frac{d t}{t}=\log _{e}|(t)|+C \\
& =\log _{e}\left|x^{2}+\frac{1}{x}\right|+C \\
& =\log _{e}\left|\frac{x^{3}+1}{x}\right|+C
\end{aligned}
$$

question: If $\int \frac{d x}{\left(x^{2}-2 x+10\right)^{2}}=A \tan ^{-1} \frac{x-1}{3}+\frac{f(x)}{x^{2}-2 x+10}+C$, where, $C$ is a constant of integration, then
solution:
Let $I=\int \frac{d x}{\left(x^{2}-2 x+10\right)^{2}}=\int \frac{d x}{\left((x-1)^{2}+3^{2}\right)^{2}}$

Now, put $x-1=3 \tan \theta \Rightarrow d x=3 \sec ^{2} \theta d \theta$

$$
\text { So, } I=\int \frac{3 \sec ^{2} \theta d \theta}{\left(3^{2} \tan ^{2} \theta+3^{2}\right)^{2}}=\int \frac{3 \sec ^{2} \theta d \theta}{3^{4} \sec ^{4} \theta}
$$

$$
\begin{aligned}
& =\frac{1}{27} \int \cos ^{2} \theta d \theta=\frac{1}{27} \int \frac{1+\cos 2 \theta}{2} d \theta \\
& \because \cos ^{2} \theta=\frac{1+\cos 2 \theta}{2} \\
& =\frac{1}{54} \int(1+\cos 2 \theta) d \theta=\frac{1}{54} \theta+\frac{\sin 2 \theta}{2}+C \\
& =\frac{1}{54} \tan ^{-1} \frac{x-1}{3}+\frac{1}{108} \frac{2 \tan \theta}{1+\tan ^{2} \theta}+C \\
& \because \sin 2 \theta=\frac{2 \tan \theta}{1+\tan ^{2} \theta} \\
& =\frac{1}{54} \tan ^{-1} \frac{x-1}{3}+\frac{1}{54} \frac{\frac{x-1}{3}}{1+\frac{x-1}{3}}+C \\
& =\frac{1}{54} \tan ^{-1} \frac{x-1}{3}+\frac{1}{18} \frac{x-1}{(x-1)^{2}+3^{2}}+C \\
& =\frac{1}{54} \tan ^{-1} \frac{x-1}{3}+\frac{1}{18} \frac{x-1}{x^{2}-2 x+10}+C \\
& =\frac{1}{54} \tan ^{-1} \frac{x-1}{3}+\frac{3(x-1)}{x^{2}-2 x+10}+C
\end{aligned}
$$

It is given, that

$$
I=A \tan ^{-1} \frac{x-1}{3}+\frac{f(x)}{x^{2}-2 x+10}+C
$$

On comparing, we get $A=\frac{1}{54}$ and $f(x)=3(x-1)$.

question:
If $\int \frac{d x}{x^{3}\left(1+x^{6}\right)^{23}}=x f(x)\left(1+x^{6}\right)^{\frac{1}{3}}+C$

where, $C$ is a constant of integration, then the function $f(x)$ is equal to\\
solution:
Let $I=\int \frac{d x}{x^{3}\left(1+x^{6}\right)^{2 / 3}}$

$$
=\int \frac{d x}{x^{3} \cdot x^{4} \frac{1}{x^{6}}+1}=\int \frac{d x}{x^{7} \frac{1}{x^{6}}+1}
$$

Now, put $\quad \frac{1}{x^{6}}+1=t^{3}$

$$
\begin{array}{llrl}
\Rightarrow & -\frac{6}{x^{7}} d x & =3 t^{2} d t \\
\Rightarrow & \frac{d x}{x^{7}} & =-\frac{t^{2}}{2} d t
\end{array}
$$

So, $I=\int \frac{-\frac{1}{2} t^{2} d t}{t^{2}}=-\frac{1}{2} \int d t$

$$
\begin{aligned}
& =-\frac{1}{2} t+C=-\frac{1}{2} \frac{1}{x^{6}}+1^{1 / 3}+C \quad \because t^{3}=\frac{1}{x^{6}}+1 \\
& =-\frac{1}{2} \frac{1}{x^{2}}\left(1+x^{6}\right)^{1 / 3}+C \\
& =x \cdot f(x) \cdot\left(1+x^{6}\right)^{1 / 3}+C
\end{aligned}
$$

On comparing both sides, we get

$$
f(x)=-\frac{1}{2 x^{3}}
$$

question: $\int \frac{\sin \frac{5 x}{2}}{\sin \frac{x}{2}} d x$ is equal to
solution:
Let $I=\int \frac{\sin \frac{5 x}{2}}{\sin \frac{x}{2}} d x=\int \frac{2 \sin \frac{5 x}{2} \cos \frac{x}{2}}{2 \sin \frac{x}{2} \cos \frac{x}{2}} d x$

[multiplying by $2 \cos \frac{x}{2}$ in numerator and denominator]

$$
=\int \frac{\sin 3 x+\sin 2 x}{\sin x} d x
$$

$[\because 2 \sin A \cos B=\sin (A+B)+\sin (A-B)$ and $\sin 2 A=2 \sin A \cos A]$

$=\int \frac{\left(3 \sin x-4 \sin ^{3} x\right)+2 \sin x \cos x}{\sin x} d x$

$\left[\because \sin 3 x=3 \sin x-4 \sin ^{3} x\right]$

$=\int\left(3-4 \sin ^{2} x+2 \cos x\right) d x$

$=\int[3-2(1-\cos 2 x)+2 \cos x] d x$

$\left[\because 2 \sin ^{2} x=1-\cos 2 x\right]$

$=\int[3-2+2 \cos 2 x+2 \cos x] d x$

$=\int[1+2 \cos 2 x+2 \cos x] d x$

$$
=x+2 \sin x+\sin 2 x+C
$$

question: The integral $\int \frac{3 x^{13}+2 x^{11}}{\left(2 x^{4}+3 x^{2}+1\right)^{4}} d x$ is equal to (where $C$ is a constant of integration)\\
solution:
Let

$I=\int \frac{3 x^{13}+2 x^{11}}{\left(2 x^{4}+3 x^{2}+1\right)^{4}} d x=\int \frac{\frac{3}{x^{3}}+\frac{2}{x^{5}}}{2+\frac{3}{x^{2}}+{\frac{1}{x^{4}}}^{4}} d x$

[on dividing numerator and denominator by $x^{16}$ ]

Now, put $2+\frac{3}{x^{2}}+\frac{1}{x^{4}}=t$

$\Rightarrow \quad \frac{-6}{x^{3}}-\frac{4}{x^{5}} \quad d x=d t \Rightarrow \frac{3}{x^{3}}+\frac{2}{x^{5}} \quad d x=-\frac{d t}{2}$

So, $I=\int \frac{-d t}{2 t^{4}}=-\frac{1}{2} \times \frac{t^{-4+1}}{-4+1}+C=\frac{1}{6 t^{3}}+C$

$$
\begin{array}{ll}
=\frac{1}{62+\frac{3}{x^{2}}+{\frac{1}{x^{4}}}^{3}}+C \quad \because t=2+\frac{3}{x^{2}}+\frac{1}{x^{4}} \\
=\frac{x^{12}}{6\left(2 x^{4}+3 x^{2}+1\right)^{3}}+C
\end{array}
$$

question: If $\int \frac{x+1}{\sqrt{2 x-1}} d x=f(x) \sqrt{2 x-1}+C$, where $C$ is a constant of integration, then $f(x)$ is equal to\\
solution:
We have,


\begin{equation*}
\int \frac{x+1}{\sqrt{2 x-1}} d x=f(x) \sqrt{2 x-1}+C \tag{i}
\end{equation*}


Let $I=\int \frac{x+1}{\sqrt{2 x-1}} d x$

Put $2 x-1=t^{2} \Rightarrow 2 d x=2 t d t \Rightarrow d x=t d t$

$$
I=\int \frac{\frac{t^{2}+1}{2}+1}{t} t d t=\frac{1}{2} \int\left(t^{2}+3\right) d t
$$

$$
\because 2 x-1=t^{2} \Rightarrow x=\frac{t^{2}+1}{2}
$$

$=\frac{1}{2} \frac{t^{3}}{3}+3 t+C=\frac{t}{6}\left(t^{2}+9\right)+C$

$=\frac{\sqrt{2 x-1}}{6}(2 x-1+9)+C \quad[\because t=\sqrt{2 x-1}]$

$=\frac{\sqrt{2 x-1}}{6}(2 x+8)+C$

$=\frac{x+4}{3} \sqrt{2 x-1}+C$

On comparing it with Eq. (i), we get

$$
f(x)=\frac{x+4}{3}
$$

question:
If $\int \frac{\sqrt{1-x^{2}}}{x^{4}} d x=A(x)\left(\sqrt{1-x^{2}}\right)^{m}+C$,


for a suitable chosen integer $m$ and a function $A(x)$, where $C$ is a constant of integration, then $(A(x))^{m}$ equals\\

Let $n \geq 2$ be a natural number and $0<\theta<\frac{\pi}{2}$. Then, $\int \frac{\left(\sin ^{n} \theta-\sin \theta\right)^{\frac{1}{n}} \cos \theta}{\sin ^{n+1} \theta} d \theta$ is equal to (where $C$ is a constant of integration)
solution:
Let $I=\int \frac{\left(\sin ^{n} \theta-\sin \theta\right)^{1 / n} \cos \theta}{\sin ^{n+1} \theta} d \theta$

Put $\sin \theta=t \Rightarrow \cos \theta d \theta=d t$

$$
\therefore \quad I=\int \frac{\left(t^{n}-t\right)^{1 / n}}{t^{n+1}} d t
$$

\begin{center}
\includegraphics[max width=\textwidth]{2024_07_10_e39a72e0271d1f70f814g-07}
\end{center}

$$
=\int \frac{t\left(1-1 / t^{n-1}\right)^{1 / n}}{t^{n+1}} d t=\int \frac{\left(1-1 / t^{n-1}\right)^{1 / n}}{t^{n}} d t
$$

Put $\quad 1-\frac{1}{t^{n-1}}=u$

or $\quad 1-t^{(n-1)}=u \Rightarrow \frac{(n-1)}{t^{n}} d t=d u$

$\Rightarrow \quad \frac{d t}{t^{n}}=\frac{d u}{n-1}$

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \Rightarrow \quad I=\int \frac{u^{1 / n} d u}{n-1}=\frac{u^{\frac{1}{n}+1}}{(n-1) \frac{1}{n}+1}+C \\
&= \frac{n 1-\frac{1}{t^{n-1}}}{(n-1)(n+1)}+C \\
&= \frac{n 1-\frac{1}{\sin ^{n-1} \theta}}{n^{2}-1}+C \\
& \because u=1-\frac{1}{t^{n-1}} \text { and } t=\sin \theta
\end{aligned}
$$

question: If $f(x)=\int \frac{5 x^{8}+7 x^{6}}{\left(x^{2}+1+2 x^{7}\right)^{2}} d x,(x \geq 0)$, and $f(0)=0$, then the value of $f(1)$ is\\
solution:
We have, $f(x)=\int \frac{5 x^{8}+7 x^{6}}{\left(x^{2}+1+2 x^{7}\right)^{2}} d x$

$$
=\int \frac{5 \frac{x^{8}}{x^{14}}+7 \frac{x^{6}}{x^{14}}}{\frac{x^{2}}{x^{7}}+\frac{1}{x^{7}}+\frac{2 x^{7}}{x^{7}}} d x
$$

(dividing both numerator and denominator by $x^{14}$ )

$$
=\int \frac{5 x^{-6}+7 x^{-8}}{\left(x^{-5}+x^{-7}+2\right)^{2}} d x
$$

Let $\quad x^{-5}+x^{-7}+2=t$

$\Rightarrow \quad\left(-5 x^{-6}-7 x^{-8}\right) d x=d t$

$\Rightarrow \quad\left(5 x^{-6}+7 x^{-8}\right) d x=-d t$

$\therefore f(x)=\int-\frac{d t}{t^{2}}=-\int t^{-2} d t$

$$
\begin{aligned}
& =-\frac{t^{-2+1}}{-2+1}+C=-\frac{t^{-1}}{-1}+C=\frac{1}{t}+C \\
& =\frac{1}{x^{-5}+x^{-7}+2}+C=\frac{x^{7}}{2 x^{7}+x^{2}+1}+C
\end{aligned}
$$

$\because f(0)=0$

$\therefore \quad 0=\frac{0}{0+0+1}+C \Rightarrow C=0$

$\therefore f(x)=\frac{x^{7}}{2 x^{7}+x^{2}+1}$

$\Rightarrow \quad f(1)=\frac{1}{2(1)^{7}+1^{2}+1}=\frac{1}{4}$

question:
For $x^{2} \neq n \pi+1, n \in N$ (the set of natural numbers), the integral

$\int x \sqrt{\frac{2 \sin \left(x^{2}-1\right)-\sin 2\left(x^{2}-1\right)}{2 \sin \left(x^{2}-1\right)+\sin 2\left(x^{2}-1\right)}} d x$ is equal to (2019 Main, 9Jan I)
reference: where $C$ is a constant of integration
solution:
Let $I=\int x \sqrt{\frac{2 \sin \left(x^{2}-1\right)-\sin 2\left(x^{2}-1\right)}{2 \sin \left(x^{2}-1\right)+\sin 2\left(x^{2}-1\right)}} d x$ Put $\frac{x^{2}-1}{2}=\theta \Rightarrow x^{2}-1=2 \theta \Rightarrow 2 x d x=2 d \theta$ $\Rightarrow \quad x d x=d \theta$

Now, $I=\int \sqrt{\frac{2 \sin 2 \theta-\sin 4 \theta}{2 \sin 2 \theta+\sin 4 \theta}} d \theta$

$$
=\int \sqrt{\frac{2 \sin 2 \theta-2 \sin 2 \theta \cos 2 \theta}{2 \sin 2 \theta+2 \sin 2 \theta \cos 2 \theta}} d \theta
$$

$(\because \sin 2 A=2 \sin A \cos A)$

\section*{270 Indefinite Integration}
$$
\begin{aligned}
& =\int \sqrt{\frac{2 \sin 2 \theta(1-\cos 2 \theta)}{2 \sin 2 \theta(1+\cos 2 \theta)}} d \theta \\
& =\int \sqrt{\frac{1-\cos 2 \theta}{1+\cos 2 \theta}} d \theta=\int \sqrt{\frac{2 \sin ^{2} \theta}{2 \cos ^{2} \theta}} d \theta \\
& =\int \sqrt{\tan ^{2} \theta} d \theta=\int \tan \theta d \theta \\
& =\log _{e}|\sec \theta|+C=\log _{e}\left|\sec \frac{x^{2}-1}{2}\right|+C \because \theta=\frac{x^{2}-1}{2}
\end{aligned}
$$

question:
The integral
$$
\begin{aligned}
& \int \frac{\sin ^2 x \cos ^2 x}{\left(\sin ^5 x+\cos ^3 x \sin ^2 x+\sin ^3 x \cos ^2 x\right.} d x \\
& \left.+\cos ^5 x\right)^2 \\
&
\end{aligned}
$$
is equal to\\
solution:
We have,

$$
\begin{aligned}
I & =\int \frac{\sin ^{2} x \cdot \cos ^{2} x}{\left(\sin ^{5} x+\cos ^{3} x \cdot \sin ^{2} x+\sin ^{3} x \cdot \cos ^{2} x+\cos ^{5} x\right)^{2}} d x \\
& =\int \frac{\sin ^{2} x \cos ^{2} x}{\left\{\sin ^{3} x\left(\sin ^{2} x+\cos ^{2} x\right)+\cos ^{3} x\left(\sin ^{2} x+\cos ^{2} x\right)\right\}^{2}} d x \\
& =\int \frac{\sin ^{2} x \cos ^{2} x}{\left(\sin ^{3} x+\cos ^{3} x\right)^{2}} d x=\int \frac{\sin ^{2} x \cos ^{2} x}{\cos ^{6} x\left(1+\tan ^{3} x\right)^{2}} d x \\
& =\int \frac{\tan ^{2} x \sec ^{2} x}{\left(1+\tan ^{3} x\right)^{2}} d x
\end{aligned}
$$

Put $\tan ^{3} x=t \quad \Rightarrow 3 \tan ^{2} x \sec ^{2} x d x=d t$

$$
\begin{array}{ll}
\therefore & I=\frac{1}{3} \int \frac{d t}{(1+t)^{2}} \\
\Rightarrow & I=\frac{-1}{3(1+t)}+C \Rightarrow I=\frac{-1}{3\left(1+\tan ^{3} x\right)}+C
\end{array}
$$

question: The value of $\int \frac{d x}{x^{2}\left(x^{4}+1\right)^{3 / 4}}$ is\\
solution:
$\int \frac{d x}{x^{2}\left(x^{4}+1\right)^{3 / 4}}=\int \frac{d x}{x^{5} 1+{\frac{1}{x^{4}}}^{3 / 4}}$

Put $\quad 1+\frac{1}{x^{4}}=t^{4}$

$\Rightarrow \quad \frac{-4}{x^{5}} d x=4 t^{3} d t$

$\Rightarrow \quad \frac{d x}{x^{5}}=-t^{3} d t$

Hence, the integral becomes

$$
\int \frac{-t^{3} d t}{t^{3}}=-\int d t=-t+c=-1+{\frac{1}{x^{4}}}^{1 / 4}+c
$$

question: $\int \frac{\sec ^{2} x}{(\sec x+\tan x)^{9 / 2}} d x$ equals to (for some arbitrary constant $K$)
solution:
PLAN Integration by Substitution

$$
\begin{array}{lrlrl} 
& \text { i.e. } & I & =\int f\{g(x)\} \cdot g^{\prime}(x) d x \\
\text { Put } & g(x) & =t \Rightarrow g^{\prime}(x) d x=d t \\
& \therefore & I & =\int f(t) d t
\end{array}
$$

Description of Situation Generally, students gets confused after substitution, i.e. $\sec x+\tan x=t$.

Now, for $\sec x$, we should use

$$
\begin{array}{rlrl} 
& \sec ^{2} x-\tan ^{2} x & =1 \\
\Rightarrow & & (\sec x-\tan x)(\sec x+\tan x) & =1 \\
\Rightarrow & \sec x-\tan x & =\frac{1}{t}
\end{array}
$$

Here,

$$
I=\int \frac{\sec ^{2} d x}{(\sec x+\tan x)^{9 / 2}}
$$

Put $\sec x+\tan x=t$

$\Rightarrow \quad\left(\sec x \tan x+\sec ^{2} x\right) d x=d t$

$$
\begin{array}{lll}
\Rightarrow & \sec x \cdot t d x=d t \Rightarrow \sec x d x=\frac{d t}{t} \\
\therefore & \sec x-\tan x=\frac{1}{t} \Rightarrow \sec x=\frac{1}{2} \quad t+\frac{1}{t}
\end{array}
$$

$$
\therefore \quad I=\int \frac{\sec x \cdot \sec x d x}{(\sec x+\tan x)^{9 / 2}}
$$

$\Rightarrow I=\int \frac{\frac{1}{2} t+\frac{1}{t} \cdot \frac{d t}{t}}{t^{9 / 2}}=\frac{1}{2} \int \frac{1}{t^{9 / 2}}+\frac{1}{t^{13 / 2}} d t$

$$
=-\frac{1}{2} \frac{2}{7 t^{7 / 2}}+\frac{2}{11 t^{11 / 2}}+K
$$

$$
\begin{aligned}
& =-\frac{1}{7(\sec x+\tan x)^{7 / 2}}+\frac{1}{11(\sec x+\tan x)^{11 / 2}}+K \\
& =\frac{-1}{(\sec x+\tan x)^{1 / 2}} \frac{1}{11}+\frac{1}{7}(\sec x+\tan x)^{2}+K
\end{aligned}
$$

question:
If $I=\int \frac{e^{x}}{e^{4 x}+e^{2 x}+1} d x, J=\int \frac{e^{-x}}{e^{-4 x}+e^{-2 x}+1} d x$.

Then, for an arbitrary constant $c$, the value of $J-I$ equals\\
solution:
Since, $\quad I=\int \frac{e^{x}}{e^{4 x}+e^{2 x}+1} d x$ and $J=\int \frac{e^{3 x}}{1+e^{2 x}+e^{4 x}} d x$

$\therefore \quad J-I=\int \frac{\left(e^{3 x}-e^{x}\right)}{1+e^{2 x}+e^{4 x}} d x$

Put $e^{x}=u \Rightarrow e^{x} d x=d u$

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \therefore \quad J-I=\int \frac{\left(u^{2}-1\right)}{1+u^{2}+u^{4}} d u=\int \frac{1-\frac{1}{u^{2}}}{1+\frac{1}{u^{2}}+u^{2}} d u \\
& =\int \frac{1-\frac{1}{u^{2}}}{u+\frac{1}{u}^{2}-1} d u \\
& \text { Put } \quad u+\frac{1}{u}=t \\
& \Rightarrow \quad 1-\frac{1}{u^{2}} d u=d t \\
& =\int \frac{d t}{t^{2}-1}=\frac{1}{2} \log \left|\frac{t-1}{t+1}\right|+c \\
& =\frac{1}{2} \log \left|\frac{u^{2}-u+1}{u^{2}+u+1}\right|+c \\
& =\frac{1}{2} \log \left|\frac{e^{2 x}-e^{x}+1}{e^{2 x}+e^{x}+1}\right|+c
\end{aligned}
$$

question: If $f(x)=\frac{x}{\left(1+x^{n}\right)^{1 / n}}$ for $n \geq 2$ and $g(x)=\underbrace{(f \circ f o \ldots o f)}_{f \text { occurs } n \text { times }}(x)$. Then, $\int x^{n-2} g(x) d x$ equals
solution:
Given, $f(x)=\frac{x}{\left(1+x^{n}\right)^{1 / n}}$ for $n \geq 2$

$$
\therefore \quad f f(x)=\frac{f(x)}{\left[1+f(x)^{n}\right]^{1 / n}}=\frac{x}{\left(1+2 x^{n}\right)^{1 / n}}
$$

and $\quad f f f(x)=\frac{x}{\left(1+3 x^{n}\right)^{1 / n}}$

$$
\therefore \quad g(x)=\underbrace{(f o f o \ldots o f)}_{n \text { times }}(x)=\frac{x}{\left(1+n x^{n}\right)^{1 / n}}
$$

Let

$$
\begin{aligned}
I & =\int x^{n-2} g(x) d x=\int \frac{x^{n-1} d x}{\left(1+n x^{n}\right)^{1 / n}} \\
& =\frac{1}{n^{2}} \int \frac{n^{2} x^{n-1} d x}{\left(1+n x^{n}\right)^{1 / n}}=\frac{1}{n^{2}} \int \frac{\frac{d}{d x}\left(1+n x^{n}\right)}{\left(1+n x^{n}\right)^{1 / n}} d x \\
I & =\frac{1}{n(n-1)}\left(1+n x^{n}\right)^{1-\frac{1}{n}}+c
\end{aligned}
$$

question: The value of $\int \frac{\left(x^{2}-1\right) d x}{x^{3} \sqrt{2 x^{4}-2 x^{2}+1}}$ is\\
solution:
Let $I=\int \frac{\left(x^{2}-1\right) d x}{x^{3} \sqrt{2 x^{4}-2 x^{2}+1}}$

[dividing numerator and enominator by $x^{5}$ ]

$$
=\int \frac{\frac{1}{x^{3}}-\frac{1}{x^{5}} d x}{\sqrt{2-\frac{2}{x^{2}}+\frac{1}{x^{4}}}}
$$

Put $\quad 2-\frac{2}{x^{2}}+\frac{1}{x^{4}}=t$

$\Rightarrow \quad \frac{4}{x^{3}}-\frac{4}{x^{5}} \quad d x=d t$

$\therefore \quad I=\frac{1}{4} \int \frac{d t}{\sqrt{t}}=\frac{1}{4} \cdot \frac{t^{1 / 2}}{1 / 2}+c$

$$
=\frac{1}{2} \sqrt{2-\frac{2}{x^{2}}+\frac{1}{x^{4}}}+c
$$

question: The integral $\int \sec ^{2 / 3} x \operatorname{cosec}^{4 / 3} x \, dx$ is equal to (here $C$ is a constant of integration)
solution:
Let $I=\int \sec ^{\frac{2}{3}} x \operatorname{cosec}^{\frac{4}{3}} x d x=\int \frac{d x}{\cos ^{\frac{2}{3}} x \sin ^{\frac{4}{3}} x}$

$$
\int \frac{d x}{\frac{\sin x}{\cos x}{ }^{\frac{4}{3}} \cos ^{\frac{4}{3}} x \cos ^{\frac{2}{3}} x}
$$

[dividing and multiplying by $\cos ^{4 / 3} x$ in denominator]

$$
=\int \frac{d x}{\tan ^{\frac{4}{3}} x \cos ^{2} x}=\int \frac{\sec ^{2} x d x}{(\tan x)^{\frac{4}{3}}}
$$

Now, put $\tan x=t \Rightarrow \sec ^{2} x d x=d t$

$$
\begin{aligned}
\therefore I & =\int \frac{d t}{t^{43}}=\frac{t^{\frac{-4}{3}}+1}{\frac{-4}{3}+1}+C \\
& =-3 \frac{1}{t^{\frac{1}{3}}}+C=\frac{-3}{(\tan x)^{\frac{1}{3}}}+C=-3 \tan ^{-\frac{1}{3}} x+C
\end{aligned}
$$

question: Let $I_{n}=\int \tan ^{n} x \, dx\,(n>1)$. If $I_{4}+I_{6}=a \tan ^{5} x+b x+C$, where $C$ is a constant of integration, then the ordered pair $(a, b)$ is equal to
solution:
We have, $I_{n}=\int \tan ^{n} x d x$

$$
\begin{aligned}
\therefore \quad I_{n}+I_{n+2} & =\int \tan ^{n} x d x+\int \tan ^{n+2} x d x \\
& =\int \tan ^{n} x\left(1+\tan ^{2} x\right) d x \\
& =\int \tan ^{n} x \sec ^{2} x d x=\frac{\tan ^{n+1} x}{n+1}+C
\end{aligned}
$$

Put $n=4$, we get $I_{4}+I_{6}=\frac{\tan ^{5} x}{5}+C$

$$
\therefore \quad a=\frac{1}{5} \text { and } b=0
$$

question: If $\int x^{5} e^{-x^{2}} \, dx=g(x) e^{-x^{2}}+C$, where $C$ is a constant of integration, then $g(-1)$ is equal to
solution:
Let given integral, $I=\int x^{5} e^{-x^{2}} d x$

Put $x^{2}=t \Rightarrow 2 x d x=d t$

So, $\quad I=\frac{1}{2} \int t^{2} e^{-t} d t$


\begin{align*}
& =\frac{1}{2}\left[\left(-t^{2} e^{-t}\right)+\int e^{-t}(2 t) d t\right] \\
& =\frac{1}{2}\left[-t^{2} e^{-t}+2 t\left(-e^{-t}\right)+\int 2 e^{-t} d t\right] \\
& =\frac{1}{2}\left[-t^{2} e^{-t}-2 t e^{-t}-2 e^{-t}\right]+C \\
& =-\frac{e^{-t}}{2}\left(t^{2}+2 t+2\right)+C \\
& =-\frac{e^{-x^{2}}}{2}\left(x^{4}+2 x^{2}+2\right)+C\left[\because t=x^{2}\right] \tag{i}
\end{align*}


$\because$ It is given that,

$$
I=\int x^{5} e^{-x^{2}} d x=g(x) \cdot e^{-x^{2}}+C
$$

By Eq. (i), comparing both sides, we get

$$
\begin{aligned}
g(x) & =-\frac{1}{2}\left(x^{4}+2 x^{2}+2\right) \\
\text { So, } \quad g(-1) & =-\frac{1}{2}(1+2+2)=-\frac{5}{2}
\end{aligned}
$$

question: If $\int e^{\sec x}\n\left(\sec x \tan x f(x)+\left(\sec x \tan x+\sec ^{2} x\right)\right) \, dx=e^{\sec x} f(x)+C$, then a possible choice of $f(x)$ is
solution:
Given, $\int e^{\sec x}\left[(\sec x \tan x) f(x)+\left(\sec x \tan x+\sec ^{2} x\right)\right] d x$

$$
=e^{\sec x} \cdot f(x)+C
$$

On differentiating both sides w.r.t. $x$, we get

$e^{\sec x}\left[(\sec x \tan x) f(x)+\left(\sec x \tan x+\sec ^{2} x\right)\right]$

$$
=e^{\sec x} f^{\prime}(x)+e^{\sec x}(\sec x \tan x) f(x)
$$

$\Rightarrow e^{\sec x}\left(\sec x \tan x+\sec ^{2} x\right)=e^{\sec x} f^{\prime}(x)$

$\Rightarrow \quad f^{\prime}(x)=\sec x \tan x+\sec ^{2} x$

So, $\quad f(x)=\int f^{\prime}(x) d x=\int\left(\sec x \tan x+\sec ^{2} x\right) d x$

$$
=\sec x+\tan x+C
$$

So, possible value of $f(x)$ from options, is

$$
f(x)=\sec x+\tan x+\frac{1}{2}
$$

question: The integral $\int \cos \left(\log _{e} x\right) d x$ is equal to (where $C$ is a constant of integration)
solution:
Let $I=\int \cos \left(\log _{e} x\right) d x$

$$
\begin{aligned}
&=x \cos \left(\log _{e} x\right)-\int x\left(-\sin \left(\log _{e} x\right)\right) \frac{1}{x} \cdot d x \\
& \text { [using integration by parts] }
\end{aligned}
$$

$$
\begin{aligned}
& =x \cos \left(\log _{e} x\right)+\int \sin \left(\log _{e} x\right) d x \\
& =x \cos \left(\log _{e} x\right)+x \sin \left(\log _{e} x\right)-\int x\left(\cos \left(\log _{e} x\right)\right) \frac{1}{x} d x
\end{aligned}
$$

[again, using integration by parts]

$$
\Rightarrow \quad I=x \cos \left(\log _{e} x\right)+x \sin \left(\left(\log _{e} x\right)-I\right.
$$

$$
\Rightarrow \quad I=\frac{x}{2}\left[\cos \left(\log _{e} x\right)+\sin \left(\log _{e} x\right)\right]+C
$$

question: If $\int x^{5} e^{-4 x^{3}} d x=\frac{1}{48} e^{-4 x^{3}} f(x)+C$, where $C$ is a constant of integration, then $f(x)$ is equal to\\
solution:
Given, $\int x^{5} e^{-4 x^{3}} d x=\frac{1}{48} e^{-4 x^{3}} f(x)+C$

In LHS, put $x^{3}=t$

$\Rightarrow \quad 3 x^{2} d x=d t$

So, $\int x^{5} e^{-4 x^{3}} d x=\frac{1}{3} \int t e^{-4 t} d t$

$$
=\frac{1}{3} t \frac{e^{-4 t}}{-4}-\int \frac{e^{-4 t}}{-4} d t
$$

[using integration by parts]


\begin{align*}
& =\frac{1}{3} \frac{t e^{-4 t}}{-4}+\frac{e^{-4 t}}{-16}+C \\
& =-\frac{1}{48} e^{-4 t}[4 t+1]+C \\
& =-\frac{e^{-4 x^{3}}}{48}\left[4 x^{3}+1\right]+C \tag{3}
\end{align*}


$\therefore \quad f(x)=-1-4 x^{3}$ (comparing with given equation)

question: $\int 1+x-\frac{1}{x} e^{x+\frac{1}{x}} d x$ is equal to\\
solution:
$\int 1+x-\frac{1}{x} e^{x+\frac{1}{x}} d x$

$$
\begin{aligned}
& =\int e^{x+\frac{1}{x}} d x+\int x 1-\frac{1}{x^{2}} e^{x+\frac{1}{x}} d x \\
& =\int e^{x+\frac{1}{x}} d x+x e^{x+\frac{1}{x}}-\int \frac{d}{d x}(x) e^{x+\frac{1}{x}} d x
\end{aligned}
$$

$$
\begin{gathered}
=\int e^{x+\frac{1}{x}} d x+x e^{x+\frac{1}{x}}-\int e^{x+\frac{1}{x}} d x \\
\because \int 1-\frac{1}{x^{2}} e^{x+\frac{1}{x}} d x=e^{x+\frac{1}{x}} \\
=\int e^{x+\frac{1}{x}} d x+x e^{x+\frac{1}{x}}-\int e e^{x+\frac{1}{x}} d x=x e^{x+\frac{1}{x}}+c
\end{gathered}
$$

question: If $\int f(x) d x=\psi(x)$, then $\int x^{5} f\left(x^{3}\right) d x$ is equal to
solution:
Given, $\int f(x) d x=\psi(x)$

\[
\begin{array}{lc}
\text { Let } & I=\int x^{5} f\left(x^{3}\right) d x \\
\text { Put } & x^{3}=t \\
\Rightarrow & x^{2} d x=\frac{d t}{3} \\
\therefore \quad I=\frac{1}{3} \int t f(t) d t  \tag{i}\\
& =\frac{1}{3} t \cdot \int f(t) d t-\int \frac{d}{d t}(t) \int f(t) d t \quad d t \\
& =\frac{1}{3}\left[t \Psi(t)-\int \Psi(t) d t\right] \\
& =\frac{1}{3}\left[x^{3} \Psi\left(x^{3}\right)-3 \int x^{2} \Psi\left(x^{3}\right) d x\right]+c \quad \text { [from Eq. (i) ] } \\
& =\frac{1}{3} x^{3} \Psi\left(x^{3}\right)-\int x^{2} \Psi\left(x^{3}\right) d x+c
\end{array}
\]

question: The integral $\int \frac{2 x^{12}+5 x^{9}}{\left(x^{5}+x^{3}+1\right)^{3}} d x$ is equal to
solution:
Let $I=\int \frac{2 x^{12}+5 x^{9}}{\left(x^{5}+x^{3}+1\right)^{3}} d x=\int \frac{2 x^{12}+5 x^{9}}{x^{15}\left(1+x^{-2}+x^{-5}\right)^{3}} d x$

$$
=\int \frac{2 x^{-3}+5 x^{-6}}{\left(1+x^{-2}+x^{-5}\right)^{3}} d x
$$

$$
\text { Now, put } 1+x^{-2}+x^{-5}=t
$$

$$
\begin{aligned}
\Rightarrow & \left(-2 x^{-3}-5 x^{-6}\right) d x=d t \\
\Rightarrow & \left(2 x^{-3}+5 x^{-6}\right) d x=-d t \\
\therefore & I=-\int \frac{d t}{t^{3}}=-\int t^{-3} d t \\
& =-\frac{t^{-3+1}}{-3+1}+C=\frac{1}{2 t^{2}}+C \\
& =\frac{x^{10}}{2\left(x^{5}+x^{3}+1\right)^{2}}+C
\end{aligned}
$$

question:
The value of $\int \frac{\cos ^{3} x+\cos ^{5} x}{\sin ^{2} x+\sin ^{4} x} d x$ is

$(1995,2 M)$

A value of $\alpha$ such that

$$
\int_{\alpha}^{\alpha+1} \frac{d x}{(x+\alpha)(x+\alpha+1)}=\log _{e} \frac{9}{8} \text { is }
$$\\
solution:
Let $I=\int_{\alpha}^{\alpha+1} \frac{d x}{(x+\alpha)(x+\alpha+1)}$

$$
\begin{aligned}
& =\int_{\alpha}^{\alpha+1} \frac{(x+\alpha+1)-(x+\alpha)}{(x+\alpha)(x+\alpha+1)} d x \\
& =\int_{\alpha}^{\alpha+1} \frac{1}{x+\alpha}-\frac{1}{x+\alpha+1} d x \\
& =\left[\log _{e}(x+\alpha)-\log _{e}(x+\alpha+1)\right]_{\alpha}^{\alpha+1} \\
& =\log _{e} \frac{x+\alpha}{x+\alpha+1}_{\alpha}^{\alpha+1} \\
& =\log _{e} \frac{2 \alpha+1}{2 \alpha+2}-\log _{e} \frac{2 \alpha}{2 \alpha+1} \\
& =\log _{e} \frac{2 \alpha+1}{2 \alpha+2} \times \frac{2 \alpha+1}{2 \alpha}=\log _{e} \frac{9}{8} \\
& \Rightarrow \frac{(2 \alpha+1)^{2}}{4 \alpha(\alpha+1)}=\frac{9}{8} \Rightarrow 8\left[4 \alpha^{2}+4 \alpha+1\right]=36\left(\alpha^{2}+\alpha\right) \\
& \Rightarrow \quad 8 \alpha^{2}+8 \alpha+2=9 \alpha^{2}+9 \alpha \\
& \Rightarrow \quad \alpha^{2}+\alpha-2=0 \\
& \Rightarrow \quad(\alpha+2)(\alpha-1)=0 \\
& \Rightarrow \quad \alpha=1,-2
\end{aligned}
$$

(given)

From the options we get $\alpha=-2$

question: If $\int_{0}^{\pi / 2} \frac{\cot x}{\cot x+\operatorname{cosec} x} d x=m(\pi+n)$, then $m \cdot n$ is equal to\\
solution:
Let $I=\int_{0}^{\pi / 2} \frac{\cot x}{\cot x+\operatorname{cosec} x} d x$

$$
\begin{aligned}
& =\int_{0}^{\pi / 2} \frac{\frac{\cos x}{\sin x}}{\frac{\cos x}{\sin x}+\frac{1}{\sin x}} d x=\int_{0}^{\pi / 2} \frac{\cos x}{1+\cos x} d x \\
& =\int_{0}^{\pi / 2} \frac{\cos x(1-\cos x)}{1-\cos ^{2} x} d x \\
& =\int_{0}^{\pi / 2} \frac{\cos x-\cos ^{2} x}{\sin ^{2} x} d x \\
& =\int_{0}^{\pi / 2}\left(\operatorname{cosec} x \cot x-\cot ^{2} x\right) d x \\
& =\int_{0}^{\pi / 2}\left(\operatorname{cosec} x \cot x-\operatorname{cosec}^{2} x+1\right) d x \\
& =[-\operatorname{cosec} x+\cot x+x]_{0}^{\pi / 2} \\
& =x+\frac{\cos x-1}{\sin x} \quad=x+\frac{-2 \sin ^{2} \frac{x}{2}}{2 \sin \frac{x}{2} \cos \frac{x}{2}} \\
& =x-\tan \frac{x}{2}
\end{aligned}
$$

[given]

On comparing, we get $m=\frac{1}{2}$ and $n=-2$

$$
\therefore \quad m \cdot n=-1
$$

\section*{Alternate Solution}
Let $I=\int_{0}^{\pi / 2} \frac{\cot x}{\cot x+\operatorname{cosec} x} d x$

$$
=\int_{0}^{\pi / 2} \frac{\frac{\cos x}{\sin x}}{\frac{\cos x}{\sin x}+\frac{1}{\sin x}} d x
$$

$$
\begin{aligned}
& =\int_{0}^{\pi / 2} \frac{\cos x}{\cos x+1} d x \\
& =\int_{0}^{\pi / 2} \frac{2 \cos ^{2} \frac{x}{2}-1}{2 \cos ^{2} \frac{x}{2}} d x \\
& \because \cos \theta=2 \cos ^{2} \frac{\theta}{2}-1 \text { and } \cos \theta+1=2 \cos ^{2} \frac{\theta}{2} \\
& =\int_{0}^{\pi / 2} 1-\frac{1}{2} \sec ^{2} \frac{x}{2} d x \\
& =x-\tan \frac{x}{2}{ }_{0}^{\pi / 2}=\frac{\pi}{2}-1=\frac{1}{2}(\pi-2)
\end{aligned}
$$

Since, $\quad I=m(\pi-n)$

$\therefore m(\pi-n)=\frac{1}{2}(\pi-2)$

On comparing both sides, we get

$$
m=\frac{1}{2} \text { and } n=-2
$$

Now, $m n=\frac{1}{2} \times-2=-1$

question: The integral $\int_{\pi / 6}^{\pi / 3} \sec ^{2 / 3} x \operatorname{cosec}^{4 / 3} x d x$ is equal to\\
solution:
Let

$$
\begin{aligned}
I & =\int_{\pi / 6}^{\pi / 3} \sec ^{2 / 3} x \operatorname{cosec}^{4 / 3} x d x \\
& =\int_{\pi / 6}^{\pi / 3} \frac{1}{\cos ^{2 / 3} x \sin ^{4 / 3} x} d x \\
& =\int_{\pi / 6}^{\pi / 3} \frac{\sec ^{2} x}{(\tan x)^{4 / 3}} d x
\end{aligned}
$$

[multiplying and dividing the denominator by $\cos ^{4 / 3} x$ ] Put, $\tan x=t$, upper limit, at $x=\pi / 3 \Rightarrow t=\sqrt{3}$ and lower limit, at $x=\pi / 6 \Rightarrow t=1 / \sqrt{3}$

and $\sec ^{2} x d x=d t$

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \text { So, } \quad I=\int_{1 / \sqrt{3}}^{\sqrt{3}} \frac{d t}{t^{4 / 3}}={\frac{t^{-1 / 3}}{-1 / 3}}_{1 / \sqrt{3}}^{\sqrt{3}} \\
& =-3 \frac{1}{3^{1 / 6}}-3^{1 / 6} \\
& =3 \cdot 3^{1 / 6}-3 \cdot 3^{-1 / 6} \\
& =3^{7 / 6}-3^{5 / 6}
\end{aligned}
$$

question: The value of $\int_{0}[\sin 2 x(1+\cos 3 x)] d x$, where $[t]$ denotes the greatest integer function, is\\
solution:
Given integral


\begin{align*}
I & =\int_{0}^{2 \pi}[\sin 2 x \cdot(1+\cos 3 x)] d x \\
& =\int_{0}^{\pi}[\sin 2 x \cdot(1+\cos 3 x)] d x \\
& \quad \quad \quad \int_{\pi}^{2 \pi}[\sin 2 x \cdot(1+\cos 3 x)] d x \\
& =I_{1}+I_{2} \text { (let) } \tag{i}
\end{align*}


Now, $\quad I_{2}=\int_{\pi}^{2 \pi}[\sin 2 x \cdot(1+\cos 3 x)] d x$

let $2 \pi-x=t$, upper limit $t=0$ and lower limit $t=\pi$ and $\quad d x=-d t$

So, $\quad I_{2}=-\int_{\pi}^{0}[-\sin 2 x \cdot(1+\cos 3 x)] d x$

$=\int_{0}^{\pi}[-\sin 2 x \cdot(1+\cos 3 x)] d x$

$\therefore \quad I=\int_{0}^{\pi}[\sin 2 x \cdot(1+\cos 3 x)] d x$

$+\int_{0}^{\pi}[-\sin 2 x \cdot(1+\cos 3 x)] d x$

[from Eqs. (i) and (ii)]

$$
\left.=\int_{0}^{\pi}(-1) d x\right][\because[x]+[-x]=-1, x \notin \text { Integer }]
$$

$$
=\pi \pi
$$

question: The value of the integral $\int_{0}^{1} x \cot ^{-1}\left(1-x^{2}+x^{4}\right) d x$ is\\
solution:
Let $I=\int_{0}^{1} x \cot ^{-1}\left(1-x^{2}+x^{4}\right) d x$

Now, put $x^{2}=t \Rightarrow 2 x d x=d t$

Lower limit at $x=0, t=0$

Upper limit at $x=1, t=1$

$\therefore I=\frac{1}{2} \int_{0}^{1} \cot ^{-1}\left(1-t+t^{2}\right) d t$

$$
\begin{gathered}
=\frac{1}{2} \int_{0}^{1} \tan ^{-1} \frac{1}{1-t+t^{2}} d t \quad \because \cot ^{-1} x=\tan ^{-1} \frac{1}{x} \\
=\frac{1}{2} \int_{0}^{1} \tan ^{-1} \frac{t-(t-1)}{1+t(t-1)} d t \\
=\frac{1}{2} \int_{0}^{1}\left(\tan ^{-1} t-\tan ^{-1}(t-1) d t\right. \\
\because \tan ^{-1} \frac{x-y}{1+x y}=\tan ^{-1} x-\tan ^{-1} y \\
\because \int_{0}^{1} \tan ^{-1}(t-1) d t=\int_{0}^{1} \tan ^{-1}(1-t-1) d t=-\int_{0}^{1} \tan ^{-1}(t) d t
\end{gathered}
$$

$$
\text { because } \int_{0}^{a} f(x) d x=\int_{0}^{a} f(a-x) d x
$$

$$
\text { So, } \begin{aligned}
I & =\frac{1}{2} \int_{0}^{1}\left(\tan ^{-1} t+\tan ^{-1} t\right) d t \\
& =\int_{0}^{1} \tan ^{-1} t d t=\left[t \tan ^{-1} t\right]_{0}^{1}-\int_{0}^{1} \frac{t}{1+t^{2}} d t
\end{aligned}
$$

[by integration by parts method]

$$
=\frac{\pi}{4}-\frac{1}{2}\left[\log _{e}\left(1+t^{2}\right)\right]_{0}^{1}=\frac{\pi}{4}-\frac{1}{2} \log _{e} 2
$$

question:
The value of $\int_{0}^{\pi / 2} \frac{\sin ^{3} x}{\sin x+\cos x} d x$ is
\\
Let $f(x)=\int_{0}^{x} g(t) d t$, where $g$ is a non-zero even function. If $f(x+5)=g(x)$, then $\int_{0}^{x} f(t) d t$ equals\\
solution:
Given, $f(x)=\int_{0}^{x} g(t) d t$

On replacing $x$ by $(-x)$, we get

$$
f(-x)=\int_{0}^{-x} g(t) d t
$$

Now, put $t=-u$, so

$$
f(-x)=-\int_{0}^{x} g(-u) d u=-\int_{0}^{x} g(u) d u=-f(x)
$$

$[\because g$ is an even function]

$\Rightarrow \quad f(-x)=-f(x) \Rightarrow f$ is an odd function

Now, it is given that $f(x+5)=g(x)$

$$
\therefore \quad f(5-x)=g(-x)=g(x)=f(x+5)
$$

$[\because g$ is an even function]


\begin{equation*}
\Rightarrow \quad f(5-x)=f(x+5) \tag{i}
\end{equation*}


Let $I=\int_{0}^{x} f(t) d t$

Put $t=u+5 \Rightarrow t-5=u \Rightarrow d t=d u$

$\therefore \quad I=\int_{-5}^{x-5} f(u+5) d u=\int_{-5}^{x-5} g(u) d u$

Put

$$
u=-t \Rightarrow \underset{5-x}{d u}=-d t \text {, we get }
$$

$$
I=-\int_{5}^{5-x} g(-t) d t=\int_{-x}^{5} g(t) d t
$$

\section*{288 Definite Integration}
[ $\because-\int_{a}^{b} f(x) d x=\int_{b}^{a} f(x) d x$ and $g$ is an even function]

$$
\begin{aligned}
I & \left.=\int_{5}^{0} f^{\prime}(t) d t \quad \text { [by Leibnitz rule } f^{\prime}(x)=g(x)\right] \\
& =f(5)-f(5-x)=f(5)-f(5+x) \quad \text { [from Eq. (i)] } \\
& =\int_{5}^{5} f^{\prime \prime}(t) d t=\int_{5+x}^{5} g(t) d t
\end{aligned}
$$

question: If $f(x)=\frac{2-x \cos x}{2+x \cos x}$ and $g(x)=\log _{e} x,(x>0)$ then the value of the integral $\int_{-\pi / 4}^{\pi / 4} g(f(x)) d x$ is\\
Let $f$ and $g$ be continuous functions on $[0, a]$ such that $f(x)=f(a-x)$ and $g(x)+g(a-x)=4$, then $\int_{0}^{a} f(x) g(x) d x$ is equal to\\
solution:
Let $I=\int_{0}^{a} f(x) g(x) d x$

$$
\begin{aligned}
=\int_{0}^{a} f(a-x) g(a-x) d & \\
\because & \because \int_{0}^{a} f(x) d x=\int_{0}^{a} f(a-x) d x
\end{aligned}
$$

$\Rightarrow \quad I=\int_{0}^{a} f(x)[4-g(x)] d x$

$$
[\because f(x)=f(a-x) \text { and } g(x)+g(a-x)=4]
$$

$$
=\int_{0}^{a} 4 f(x) d x-\int_{0}^{a} f(x) g(x) d x
$$

$\Rightarrow \quad I=4 \int_{0}^{a} f(x) d x-I$

[from Eq. (i)]

$\Rightarrow \quad 2 I=4 \int_{0}^{a} f(x) d x \Rightarrow \quad I=2 \int_{0}^{a} f(x) d x$.

question:
The integral $\int_{1}^{e} \frac{x^{2 x}}{e}-\frac{e}{x} \log _{e} x d x$ is\\
equal to\\
solution:
Let $I=\int_{1}^{e} \frac{x}{e}^{2 x}-\frac{e}{x}^{x} \log _{e} x d x$

Now, put $\frac{x^{x}}{e}=t \Rightarrow \quad x \log _{e} \frac{x}{e}=\log t$

$\Rightarrow \quad x\left(\log _{e} x-\log _{e} e\right)=\log t$

$\Rightarrow \quad x \frac{1}{x}+\left(\log _{e} x-\log _{e} e\right) d x=\frac{1}{t} d t$

$\Rightarrow\left(1+\log _{e} x-1\right) d x=\frac{1}{t} d t \Rightarrow\left(\log _{e} x\right) d x=\frac{1}{t} d t$\\
Also, upper limit $x=e \Rightarrow t=1$ and lower limit $x=1 \Rightarrow$ $t=\frac{1}{e}$

$$
\begin{aligned}
\therefore I & =\int_{1 / e}^{1} t^{2}-\frac{1}{t} \cdot \frac{1}{t} d t \Rightarrow I=\int_{1 / e}^{1}\left(t-t^{-2}\right) d t \\
I & =\frac{t^{2}}{2}+\frac{1}{t} \underset{\frac{1}{e}}{1}=\frac{1}{2}+1-\frac{1}{2 e^{2}}+e \quad=\frac{3}{2}-e-\frac{1}{2 e^{2}}
\end{aligned}
$$

question: The integral $\int_{\pi / 6}^{\pi / 4} \frac{d x}{\sin 2 x\left(\tan ^{5} x+\cot ^{5} x\right)}$ equals\\
The value of the integral $\int_{-2}^{2} \frac{\sin ^{2} x}{\frac{x}{\pi}+\frac{1}{2}} d x$ (where, $[x]$ denotes the greatest integer less than or equal to $x$ ) is\\
solution:
Let $I=\int_{-2}^{2} \frac{\sin ^{2} x}{\frac{1}{2}+\frac{x}{\pi}} d x$

Also, let $f(x)=\frac{\sin ^{2} x}{\frac{1}{2}+\frac{x}{\pi}}$

Then, $f(-x)=\frac{\sin ^{2}(-x)}{\frac{1}{2}+-\frac{x}{\pi}}($ replacing $x$ by $-x)$

$$
\begin{aligned}
& =\frac{\sin ^{2} x}{\frac{1}{2}+-1-\frac{x}{\pi}} \because[-x]=\begin{array}{ccc}
-[x], & \text { if } & x \in I \\
-1-[x], & \text { if } & x \notin I
\end{array} \\
\Rightarrow \quad f(-x) & =-\frac{\sin ^{2} x}{\frac{1}{2}+\frac{x}{\pi}}=-f(x)
\end{aligned}
$$

i.e. $f(x)$ is odd function

$\therefore I=0 \quad \because \int_{-a}^{a} f(x) d x=\begin{gathered}0 \text {, if } f(x) \text { is odd function } \\ 2 \int_{0}^{a} f(x) d x \text {, if } f(x) \text { is even function }\end{gathered}$

question: Let $I=\int_{a}\left(x^{4}-2 x^{2}\right) d x$. If $I$ is minimum, then the ordered pair $(a, b)$ is\\
If $\int_{0}^{\pi / 3} \frac{\tan \theta}{\sqrt{2 k \sec \theta}} d \theta=1-\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}},(k>0)$, then the value of $k$ is\\
solution:
We have, $\int_{0}^{\pi / 3} \frac{\tan \theta}{\sqrt{2 k \sec \theta}} d \theta=1-\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}},(k>0)$

Let $I=\int_{0}^{\pi / 3} \frac{\tan \theta}{\sqrt{2 k \sec \theta}} d \theta=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2 k}} \int_{0}^{\pi / 3} \frac{\tan \theta}{\sqrt{\sec \theta}} d \theta$

$$
=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2 k}} \int_{0}^{\pi / 3} \frac{(\sin \theta)}{(\cos \theta) \sqrt{\frac{1}{\cos \theta}}} d \theta=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2 k}} \int_{0}^{\pi / 3} \frac{\sin \theta}{\sqrt{\cos \theta}} d \theta
$$

Let $\cos \theta=t \Rightarrow-\sin \theta d \theta=d t \Rightarrow \sin \theta d \theta=-d t$ for lower limit, $\theta=0 \Rightarrow t=\cos 0=1$ for upper limit, $\theta=\frac{\pi}{3} \Rightarrow t=\cos \frac{\pi}{3}=\frac{1}{2}$


\begin{align*}
& \Rightarrow \quad I=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2 k}} \int_{1}^{1 / 2} \frac{-d t}{\sqrt{t}}=\frac{-1}{\sqrt{2 k}} \int_{1}^{1 / 2} t^{-\frac{1}{2}} d t \\
& =-\frac{1}{\sqrt{2 k}}{\frac{t^{-\frac{1}{2}+1}}{-\frac{1}{2}+1}}_{1}^{\overline{2}}=-\frac{1}{\sqrt{2 k}}[2 \sqrt{t}]_{1}^{\frac{1}{2}} \\
& =-\frac{2}{\sqrt{2 k}} \sqrt{\frac{1}{2}}-\sqrt{1}=\frac{2}{\sqrt{2 k}} 1-\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}} \\
& \because \quad I=1-\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}} \tag{given}
\end{align*}

question: The value of $\int_{0}^{\pi}|\cos x|^{3} d x$ is\\
The value of $\int_{-\pi / 2}^{\pi / 2} \frac{\sin ^{2} x}{1+2^{x}} d x$ is\\
solution:
Key idea Use property $=\int_{a}^{b} f(x) d x=\int_{a}^{b} f(a+b-x) d x$

$$
\begin{aligned}
\text { Let } & I=\int_{-\pi / 2}^{\pi / 2} \frac{\sin ^{2} x}{1+2^{x}} d x \\
\Rightarrow & I=\int_{-\pi / 2}^{\pi / 2} \frac{\sin ^{2}-\frac{\pi}{2}+\frac{\pi}{2}-x}{1+2^{-\frac{\pi}{2}+\frac{\pi}{2}-x}} d x
\end{aligned}
$$

$$
\because \int_{a}^{b} f(x) d x=\int_{a}^{b} f(a+b-x) d x
$$

$$
\begin{array}{ll}
\Rightarrow & I=\int_{-\pi / 2}^{\pi / 2} \frac{\sin ^{2} x}{1+2^{-x}} d x \\
\Rightarrow & I=\int_{-\pi / 2}^{\pi / 2} \frac{2^{x} \sin ^{2} x}{2^{x}+1} d x \\
\Rightarrow & 2 I=\int_{-\pi / 2}^{\pi / 2} \sin ^{2} x \frac{2^{x}+1}{2^{x}+1} d x \\
\Rightarrow & 2 I=\int_{-\pi / 2}^{\pi / 2} \sin ^{2} x d x
\end{array}
$$

$$
\begin{array}{ll}
\Rightarrow & 2 I=2 \int_{0}^{\pi / 2} \sin ^{2} x d x\left[\because \sin ^{2} x \text { is an even function }\right] \\
\Rightarrow & I=\int_{0}^{\pi / 2} \sin ^{2} x d x \\
\Rightarrow & I=\int_{0}^{\pi / 2} \cos ^{2} x d x \quad \because \int_{0}^{a} f(x) d x=\int_{0}^{a} f(a-x) d x \\
\Rightarrow & 2 I=\int_{0}^{\pi / 2} d x \\
\Rightarrow & 2 I=[x]_{0}^{\pi / 2} \Rightarrow \quad I=\frac{\pi}{4}
\end{array}
$$

question: $\int_{\pi / 4}^{3 \pi / 4} \frac{d x}{1+\cos x}$ is equal to\\
The value of $\int_{-\pi / 2}^{\pi / 2} \frac{x^{2} \cos x}{1+e^{x}} d x$ is equal to\\
The integral $\int_2^4 \frac{\log x^2}{\log x^2+\log \left(36-12 x+x^2\right)} \, dx$ is equal to
solution:
PLAN Apply the property

$$
\int_{a}^{b} f(x) d x=\int_{a}^{b} f(a+b-x) d x \text { and then add. }
$$

Let

$$
\begin{aligned}
I & =\int_{2}^{4} \frac{\log x^{2}}{\log x^{2}+\log \left(36-12 x+x^{2}\right)} d x \\
& =\int_{2}^{4} \frac{2 \log x}{2 \log x+\log (6-x)^{2}} d x \\
& =\int_{2}^{4} \frac{2 \log x d x}{2[\log x+\log (6-x)]}
\end{aligned}
$$

\[
\begin{array}{r}
\Rightarrow \quad I=\int_{2}^{4} \frac{\log x d x}{[\log x+\log (6-x)]} \\
\Rightarrow \quad I=\int_{2}^{4} \frac{\log (6-x)}{\log (6-x)+\log x} d x  \tag{ii}\\
\because \int_{a}^{b} f(x) d x=\int_{a}^{b} f(a+b-x) d x
\end{array}
\]

On adding Eqs. (i) and (ii), we get

$$
\begin{aligned}
& 2 I=\int_{2}^{4} \frac{\log x+\log (6-x)}{\log x+\log (6-x)} d x \\
\Rightarrow \quad & 2 I=\int_{2}^{4} d x=[x]_{2}^{4} \Rightarrow 2 I=2 \\
\Rightarrow \quad & 2 I=2 \Rightarrow I=1
\end{aligned}
$$

question: The integral $\int_{\pi / 4}^{\pi / 2}(2 \operatorname{cosec} x)^{17} d x$ is equal to
solution:
PLAN This type of question can be done using appropriate substitution.

Given, $I=\int_{\pi / 4}^{\pi / 2}(2 \operatorname{cosec} x)^{17} d x$

$$
=\int_{\pi / 4}^{\pi / 2} \frac{2^{17}(\operatorname{cosec} x)^{16} \operatorname{cosec} x(\operatorname{cosec} x+\cot x)}{(\operatorname{cosec} x+\cot x)} d x
$$

Let

$$
\operatorname{cosec} x+\cot x=t
$$

$\Rightarrow \quad\left(-\operatorname{cosec} x \cdot \cot x-\operatorname{cosec}^{2} x\right) d x=d t$

and $\operatorname{cosec} x-\cot x=1 / t$

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \Rightarrow \quad 2 \operatorname{cosec} x=t+\frac{1}{t} \\
& \therefore \quad I=-\int_{\sqrt{2}+1}^{1} 2^{17} \frac{t+\frac{1}{t}^{16}}{2} \frac{d t}{t}
\end{aligned}
$$

Let $t=e^{u} \Rightarrow d t=e^{u} d u$.

When $t=1, e^{u}=1 \Rightarrow u=0$

and when $t=\sqrt{2}+1, e^{u}=\sqrt{2}+1$

$$
\begin{array}{rlrl}
\Rightarrow & & u & =\ln (\sqrt{2}+1) \\
\Rightarrow & & I & =-\int_{\ln (\sqrt{2}+1)}^{0} 2\left(e^{u}+e^{-u}\right)^{16} \frac{e^{u} d u}{e^{u}} \\
& & =2 \int_{0}^{\ln (\sqrt{2}+1)}\left(e^{u}+e^{-u}\right)^{16} d u
\end{array}
$$

question: The integral $\int_{0}^{\pi} \sqrt{1+4 \sin ^{2} \frac{x}{2}-4 \sin \frac{x}{2}} d x$ is equal to\\
The value of the integral $\int_{-\pi / 2}^{\pi / 2} x^{2}+\log \frac{\pi-x}{\pi+x} \cos x d x$ is\\
solution:
$I=\int_{-\pi / 2}^{\pi / 2} x^{2}+\log \frac{\pi-x}{\pi+x} \quad \cos x d x$

As, $\quad \int_{-a}^{a} f(x) d x=0$, when $f(-x)=-f(x)$

$$
\begin{aligned}
\therefore \quad I & =\int_{-\pi / 2}^{\pi / 2} x^{2} \cos x d x+0=2 \int_{0}^{\pi / 2}\left(x^{2} \cos x\right) d x \\
& =2\left\{\left(x^{2} \sin x\right)_{0}^{\pi / 2}-\int_{0}^{\pi / 2} 2 x \cdot \sin x d x\right\} \\
& =2 \frac{\pi^{2}}{4}-2\left\{(-x \cdot \cos x)_{0}^{\pi / 2}-\int_{0}^{\pi / 2} 1 \cdot(-\cos x) d x\right\} \\
& =2 \frac{\pi^{2}}{4}-2(\sin x)_{0}^{\pi / 2}=2 \frac{\pi^{2}}{4}-2=\frac{\pi^{2}}{2}-4
\end{aligned}
$$

question: The value of $\int_{\sqrt{\log 2}}^{\sqrt{\log 3}} \frac{x \sin x^{2}}{\sin x^{2}+\sin \left(\log 6-x^{2}\right)} d x$ is\\
The value of $\int_{-2}^{0}\left[x^{3}+3 x^{2}+3 x+3+(x+1) \cos (x+1)\right] d x$ is $(2005,1 \mathrm{M})$\\
solution:
Let $I=\int_{-2}^{0}\left[x^{3}+3 x^{2}+3 x+3+(x+1) \cos (x+1)\right] d x$

$$
=\int_{-2}^{0}\left[(x+1)^{3}+2+(x+1) \cos (x+1)\right] d x
$$

Put $x+1=t$

$$
\begin{aligned}
\Rightarrow \quad d x & =d t \\
\therefore \quad & =\int_{-1}^{1}\left(t^{3}+2+t \cos t\right) d t \\
& =\int_{-1}^{1} t^{3} d t+2 \int_{-1}^{1} d t+\int_{-1}^{1} t \cos t d t \\
& =0+2 \cdot 2[x]_{0}^{1}+0 \\
& =4
\end{aligned}
$$

[since, $t^{3}$ and $t \cos t$ are odd functions]

question:

$$

question: The value of the integral $\int_{e^{e^{2}}}^{e^{-1}} \frac{\log _{e} x}{x} d x$ is $\quad$ (2000, 2M)\\
solution:
$\int_{e^{-1}}^{e^{2}} \frac{\log _{e} x}{x} d x=\int_{e^{-1}}^{1} \frac{\log _{e} x}{x} d x-\int_{1}^{e^{2}} \frac{\log _{e} x}{x} d x$ since, 1 is turning point for $\frac{\log _{e} x}{x}$ for + ve and - ve values

$=-\int_{e^{-1}}^{1} \frac{\log _{e} x}{x} d x+\int_{1}^{e^{2}} \frac{\log _{e} x}{x} d x$

$=-\frac{1}{2}\left[\left(\log _{e} x\right)^{2}\right]_{e^{-1}}^{1}+\frac{1}{2}\left[\left(\log _{e} x\right)^{2}\right]_{1}^{e^{2}}$

$=-\frac{1}{2}\left\{0-(-1)^{2}\right\}+\frac{1}{2}\left(2^{2}-0\right)=\frac{5}{2}$

question:
If for a real number $y,[y]$ is the greatest integer less than or equal to $y$, then the value of the integral $\int_{\pi / 2}^{3 \pi / 2}[2 \sin x] d x$ is

Let $f(x)=x-[x]$, for every real number $x$, where $[x]$ is the integral part of $x$. Then, $\int_{-1}^{1} f(x) d x$ is

$(1998,2 M)$\\
solution:
Let $\int_{-1}^{1} f(x) d x=\int_{-1}^{1}(x-[x]) d x=\int_{-1}^{1} x d x-\int_{-1}^{1}[x] d x$

$$
=0-\int_{-1}^{1}[x] d x \quad[\because x \text { is an odd function }]
$$

$$
-1 \text {, if }-1 \leq x<0
$$

But $\quad[x]=0$, if $0 \leq x<1$

$$
1, \quad \text { if } \quad x=1
$$

$$
\begin{aligned}
\therefore \quad \int_{-1}^{1}[x] d x & =\int_{-1}^{0}[x] d x+\int_{0}^{1}[x] d x \\
& =\int_{-1}^{0}(-1) d x+\int_{0}^{1} 0 d x \\
& =-[x]_{-1}^{0}+0=-1 ; \therefore \int_{-1}^{1} f(x) d x=1
\end{aligned}
$$

question:
If $g(x)=\int_{0}^{x} \cos ^{4} t d t$, then $g(x+\pi)$ equals

$(1997,2 \mathrm{M})$\\
solution:
Given, $\quad g(x)=\int_{0}^{x} \cos ^{4} t d t$

$$
\begin{aligned}
\Rightarrow \quad g(x+\pi) & =\int_{0}^{\pi+x} \cos ^{4} t d t \\
& =\int_{0}^{\pi} \cos ^{4} t d t+\int_{\pi}^{\pi+x} \cos ^{4} t d t=I_{1}+I_{2}
\end{aligned}
$$

where, $\quad I_{1}=\int_{0}^{\pi} \cos ^{4} t d t=g(\pi)$

and $\quad I_{2}=\int_{\pi}^{\pi+x} \cos ^{4} t d t$

Put $\quad t=\pi+y$

$\Rightarrow \quad d t=d y$

$$
I_{2}=\int_{0}^{x} \cos ^{4}(y+\pi) d y
$$

$$
=\int_{0}^{x}(-\cos y)^{4} d y=\int_{0}^{x} \cos ^{4} y d y=g(x)
$$

$\therefore \quad g(x+\pi)=g(\pi)+g(x)$

question:
Let $f$ be a positive function.

If $I_{1}=\int_{1-k}^{k} x f[x(1-x)] d x$ and

$$
I_{2}=\int_{1-k}^{k} f[x(1-x)] d x \text {, where } 2 k-1>0
$$

Then, $\frac{I_{1}}{I_{2}}$ is\\
solution:
Given,

$$
I_{1}=\int_{1-k}^{k} x f[x(1-x)] d x
$$

$$
\begin{aligned}
\Rightarrow \quad I_{1} & =\int_{1-k}^{k}(1-x) f[(1-x) x] d x \\
& \left.\left.=\int_{1-k}^{k} f[(1-x)] d x\right]-\int_{1-k}^{k} x f(1-x)\right] d x
\end{aligned}
$$

$$
\Rightarrow \quad I_{1}=I_{2}-I_{1} \Rightarrow \frac{I_{1}}{I_{2}}=\frac{1}{2}
$$

question: The value of $\int_{0}^{2 \pi}[2 \sin x] d x$, where [.] represents the greatest integral functions, is\\

If $f(x)=A \sin \frac{\pi x}{2}+B$,

$f^{\prime} \frac{1}{2}=\sqrt{2}$ and $\int_{0}^{1} f(x) d x=\frac{2 A}{\pi}$, then constants

$A$ and $B$ are\\
solution:
Given, $f(x)=A \sin \frac{\pi x}{2}+B, f^{\prime} \quad \frac{1}{2}=\sqrt{2}$

and $\quad \int_{0}^{1} f(x) d x=\frac{2 A}{\pi}$

$$
f^{\prime}(x)=\frac{A \pi}{2} \cos \frac{\pi x}{2} \Rightarrow f^{\prime} \frac{1}{2}=\frac{A \pi}{2} \cos \frac{\pi}{4}=\frac{A \pi}{2 \sqrt{2}}
$$

But $\quad f^{\prime} \frac{1}{2}=\sqrt{2} \therefore \quad \frac{A \pi}{2 \sqrt{2}}=\sqrt{2} \quad \Rightarrow \quad A=\frac{4}{\pi}$

Now, $\int_{0}^{1} f(x) d x=\frac{2 A}{\pi} \Rightarrow \int_{0}^{1} A \sin \frac{\pi x}{2}+B \quad d x=\frac{2 A}{\pi}$

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \Rightarrow \quad-\frac{2 A}{\pi} \cos \frac{\pi x}{2}+B x \underset{0}{1}=\frac{2 A}{\pi} \quad \Rightarrow \quad B+\frac{2 A}{\pi}=\frac{2 A}{\pi} \\
& \Rightarrow \quad B=0
\end{aligned}
$$

question: The value of $\int_{0}^{\pi / 2} \frac{d x}{1+\tan ^{3} x}$ is\\
Let $f: R \rightarrow R$ and $g: R \rightarrow R$ be continuous functions. Then, the value of the integral $\int_{-\pi / 2}^{\pi / 2}[f(x)+f(-x)][g(x)-g(-x)] d x$ is\\
solution:
Let $I=\int_{-\pi / 2}^{\pi / 2}[f(x)+f(-x)][g(x)-g(-x)] d x$

Let $\quad \varphi(x)=[f(x)+f(-x)][g(x)-g(-x)]$

$\Rightarrow \quad \varphi(-x)=[f(-x)+f(x)][g(-x)-g(x)]$

$\Rightarrow \quad \varphi(-x)=-\varphi(x)$

$\Rightarrow \varphi(x)$ is an odd function.

$$
\therefore \quad \int_{-\pi / 2}^{\pi / 2} \varphi(x) d x=0
$$

question: Let $f: R \rightarrow R$ be a function defined by $f(x)=\begin{array}{cc}{[x],} & x \leq 2 \\ 0, & x>2\end{array}$, where $[x]$ denotes the greatest integer less than or equal to $x$. If $I=\int_{-1}^{2} \frac{x f\left(x^{2}\right)}{2+f(x+1)} d x$, then the value of $(4 I-1)$ is
solution:
Here, $f(x)=\begin{array}{cc}{[x],} & x \leq 2 \\ 0, & x>2\end{array}$

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \therefore \quad I=\int_{-1}^{2} \frac{x f\left(x^{2}\right)}{2+f(x+1)} d x \\
& =\int_{-1}^{0} \frac{x f\left(x^{2}\right)}{2+f(x+1)} d x+\int_{0}^{1} \frac{x f\left(x^{2}\right)}{2+f(x+1)} d x \\
& +\int_{1}^{\sqrt{2}} \frac{x f\left(x^{2}\right)}{2+f(x+1)} d x+\int_{\sqrt{2}}^{\sqrt{3}} \frac{x f\left(x^{2}\right)}{2+f(x+1)} d x \\
& +\int_{\sqrt{3}}^{2} \frac{x f\left(x^{2}\right)}{2+f(x+1)} d x \\
& =\int_{-1}^{0} 0 d x+\int_{0}^{1} 0 d x+\int_{1}^{\sqrt{2}} \frac{x \cdot 1}{2+0} d x \\
& +\int_{\sqrt{2}}^{\sqrt{3}} 0 d x+\int_{\sqrt{3}}^{2} 0 d x \\
& \begin{array}{r}
\because-1<x<0 \Rightarrow 0<x^{2}<1 \Rightarrow\left[x^{2}\right]=0 \\
0<x<1 \Rightarrow 0<x^{2}<1 \Rightarrow\left[x^{2}\right]=0
\end{array} \\
& 1<x<\sqrt{2} \Rightarrow \quad 1<x^{2}<2 \quad \Rightarrow\left[x^{2}\right]=1 \\
& \sqrt{2}<x<\sqrt{3} \Rightarrow 2<x^{2}<3 \Rightarrow f\left(x^{2}\right)=0 \\
& \text { and } \sqrt{3}<x<2 \Rightarrow 3<x^{2}<4 \Rightarrow f\left(x^{2}\right)=0 \\
& \Rightarrow \quad I=\int_{1}^{\sqrt{2}} \frac{x}{2} d x={\frac{x^{2}}{4}}_{1}^{\sqrt{2}}=\frac{1}{4}(2-1)=\frac{1}{4} \\
& \therefore \quad 4 I=1 \Rightarrow 4 I-1=0
\end{aligned}
$$

question: If $\boldsymbol{\alpha}=\int_{0}^{1}\left(e^{9 x+3 \tan ^{-1} x}\right) \frac{12+9 x^{2}}{1+x^{2}} d x$, where $\tan ^{-1} x$ takes only principal values, then the value of $\log _{e}|1+\alpha|-\frac{3 \pi}{4}$ is
solution:
Here, $\boldsymbol{\alpha}=\int_{0}^{1} e^{\left(9 x+3 \tan ^{-1} x\right)} \frac{12+9 x^{2}}{1+x^{2}} d x$

Put $9 x+3 \tan ^{-1} x=t$

$\Rightarrow \quad 9+\frac{3}{1+x^{2}} d x=d t$

$\therefore \quad \alpha=\int_{0}^{9+3 \pi / 4} e^{t} d t=\left[e^{t}\right]_{0}^{9+3 \pi / 4}=e^{9+3 \pi / 4}-1$

$\Rightarrow \quad \log _{e}|1+\alpha|=9+\frac{3 \pi}{4}$

$\Rightarrow \quad \log _{e}|\alpha+1|-\frac{3 \pi}{4}=9$

question: The value of $\int_{0}^{1} 4 x^{3} \frac{d^{2}}{d x^{2}}\left(1-x^{2}\right)^{5} d x$ is
solution:
PLAN Integration by parts

$\int f(x) g(x) d x=f(x) \int g(x) d x-\int \frac{d}{d x}[f(x)] \int g(x) d x d x$ Given, $I=\int_{0}^{1} \underset{I}{4 x^{3}} \frac{d^{2}}{d x^{2}}\left(1-x_{\text {II }}^{2}\right)^{5} d x$

$$
=4 x^{3} \frac{d}{d x}\left(1-x^{2}\right)^{5}{ }_{0}^{1}-\int_{0}^{1} 12 x^{2} \frac{d}{d x}\left(1-x^{2}\right)^{5} d x
$$

$$
\begin{aligned}
& =4 x^{3} \times 5\left(1-x^{2}\right)^{4}(-2 x) \\
& \quad-12\left[x^{2}\left(1-x^{2}\right)^{5}\right]_{0}^{1}-\int_{0}^{1} 2 x\left(1-x^{2}\right)^{5} d x \\
& =0-0-12(0-0)+12 \int_{0}^{1} 2 x\left(1-x^{2}\right)^{5} d x \\
& =12 \times-{\frac{\left(1-x^{2}\right)^{6}}{6}}_{0}^{1}=120+\frac{1}{6}=2
\end{aligned}
$$

question: The value of $\int_{-\pi / 2}^{\pi / 2} \frac{d x}{[x]+[\sin x]+4}$, where $[t]$ denotes the greatest integer less than or equal to $t$, is\\
solution:
Let $I=\int_{\frac{-\pi}{2}}^{\frac{\pi}{2}} \frac{d x}{[x]+[\sin x]+4}$

$$
\begin{aligned}
& =\int_{\frac{\pi}{2}}^{-1} \frac{d x}{[x]+[\sin x]+4}+\int_{-1}^{0} \frac{d x}{[x]+[\sin x]+4} \\
& +\int_{0}^{1} \frac{d x}{[x]+[\sin x]+4}+\int_{1}^{\frac{\pi}{2}} \frac{d x}{[x]+[\sin x]+4} \\
& \because \quad[x]=\begin{array}{ll}
-2, & -\pi / 2<x<-1 \\
0, & -1 \leq x<0 \\
1, & 1 \leq x<1 \\
1, & 1 \leq x<\pi / 2
\end{array} \\
& \text { and }[\sin x]=\begin{array}{cc}
-1, & -\pi / 2<x<-1 \\
0, & -1<x<0 \\
0, & 0<x<1 \\
0, & 1<x<\pi / 2
\end{array} \\
& {[\because \text { For } \mathrm{x}<0,-1 \leq \sin \mathrm{x}<0 \text { and for } \mathrm{x}>0,0<\sin \mathrm{x} \leq 1]}
\end{aligned}
$$

So, $\quad I=\int_{\frac{-\pi}{2}}^{-1} \frac{d x}{-2-1+4}+\int_{-1}^{0} \frac{d x}{-1-1+4}+\int_{0}^{1} \frac{d x}{0+0+4}$ $+\int_{1}^{\frac{\pi}{2}} \frac{d x}{1+0+4}$

$=\int_{\frac{-\pi}{2}}^{-1} \frac{d x}{1}+\int_{-1}^{0} \frac{d x}{2}+\int_{0}^{1} \frac{d x}{4}+\int_{1}^{\frac{\pi}{2}} \frac{d x}{5}$

$=-1+\frac{\pi}{2}+\frac{1}{2}(0+1)+\frac{1}{4}(1-0)+\frac{1}{5} \frac{\pi}{2}-1$

$=-1+\frac{1}{2}+\frac{1}{4}-\frac{1}{5}+\frac{\pi}{2}+\frac{\pi}{10}$

$=\frac{-20+10+5-4}{20}+\frac{5 \pi+\pi}{10}$

$=-\frac{9}{20}+\frac{3 \pi}{5}=\frac{3}{20}(4 \pi-3)$\\

question: Let $T>0$ be a fixed real number. Suppose, $f$ is a continuous function such that for all $x \in R . f(x+T)=f(x)$. If $I=\int_{0}^{T} f(x) d x$, then the value of $\int_{3}^{3+3 T} f(2 x) d x$ is\\
solution:
$\int_{3}^{3+3 T} f(2 x) d x$ Put $2 x=y \Rightarrow d x=\frac{1}{2} d y$

$$
\therefore \quad \frac{1}{2} \int_{6}^{6+6 T} f(y) d y=\frac{6 I}{2}=3 I
$$

question: Let $g(x)=\int_{0}^{x} f(t) d t$, where $f$ is such that $\frac{1}{2} \leq f(t) \leq 1$ for $t \in[0,1]$ and $0 \leq f(t) \leq \frac{1}{2}$ for $t \in[1,2]$. Then, $g(2)$ satisfies the inequality

solution:
Given, $f(x)=\begin{array}{cc}x-[x], & \text { if }[x] \text { is odd. } \\ 1+[x]-x, & \text { if }[x] \text { is even. }\end{array}$

$f(x)$ and $\cos \pi x$ both are periodic with period 2 and both are even.

$$
\therefore \quad \int_{-10}^{10} f(x) \cos \pi x d x=2 \int_{0}^{10} f(x) \cos \pi x d x
$$

\begin{center}
\includegraphics[max width=\textwidth]{2024_07_10_095bc572856da6d17d04g-29}
\end{center}

Now, $\int_{0}^{1} f(x) \cos \pi x d x$

$$
=\int_{0}^{1}(1-x) \cos \pi x d x=-\int_{0}^{1} u \cos \pi u d u
$$

and $\int_{1}^{2} f(x) \cos \pi x d x=\int_{1}^{2}(x-1) \cos \pi x d x$

$$
=-\int_{0}^{1} u \cos \pi u d u
$$

$\therefore \quad \int_{-10}^{10} f(x) \cos \pi x d x=-20 \int_{0}^{1} u \cos \pi u d u=\frac{40}{\pi^{2}}$

$\Rightarrow \quad \frac{\pi^{2}}{10} \int_{-10}^{10} f(x) \cos \pi x d x=4$

\section*{Topic 3 Estimation, Gamma Function and Derivative of Definite Integration}

question: If $\int_{0}^{x} f(t) d t=x^{2}+\int_{x}^{1} t^{2} f(t) d t$, then $f^{\prime} \frac{1}{2}$ is\\

Let $f:[0,2] \rightarrow R$ be a function which is continuous on $[0,2]$ and is differentiable on $(0,2)$ with $f(0)=1$.

Let $F(x)=\int_{0}^{x^{2}} f(\sqrt{t}) d t$, for $x \in[0,2]$. If $F^{\prime}(x)=f^{\prime}(x), \forall$ $x \in(0,2)$, then $F(2)$ equals\\
solution:
PLAN Newton-Leibnitz's formula

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \frac{d}{d x} \int_{\varphi(x)}^{\psi(x)} f(t) d t=f\{\psi(x)\} \quad \frac{d}{d x} \Psi(x)-f\{\varphi(x)\} \quad \frac{d}{d x} \varphi(x) \\
& F(x)=\int_{0}^{x^{2}} f(\sqrt{t}) d t \\
& \therefore \quad F^{\prime \prime}(x)=2 x f(x) \\
& \text { Also, } \quad F^{\prime}(x)=f^{\prime}(x) \\
& \Rightarrow \quad 2 x f(x)=f^{\prime}(x) \\
& \Rightarrow \quad \frac{f^{\prime}(x)}{f(x)}=2 x \\
& \Rightarrow \quad \int \frac{f^{\prime}(x)}{f(x)} d x=\int 2 x d x \Rightarrow \quad \text { In } f(x)=x^{2}+c \\
& \Rightarrow \quad f(x)=e^{x^{2}+c} \Rightarrow f(x)=K e^{x^{2}} \quad\left[K=e^{c}\right] \\
& \text { Now, } \quad f(0)=1 \\
& \therefore \quad 1=K \\
& f(x)=e^{x^{2}} \\
& F(2)=\int_{0}^{4} e^{t} d t=\left[e^{t}\right]_{0}^{4}=e^{4}-1
\end{aligned}
$$

question: The intercepts on $X$-axis made by tangents to the curve, $y=\int_{0}^{x}|t| d t, x \in R$, which are parallel to the line $y=2 x$, are equal to\\
solution:
Given, $y=\int_{0}^{x}|t| d t$

$\therefore \frac{d y}{d x}=|x| \cdot 1-0=|x| \quad$ [by Leibnitz's rule]

$\because$ Tangent to the curve $y=\int_{0}^{x}|t| d t, x \in R$ are parallel to the line $y=2 x$

$\therefore$ Slope of both are equal $\Rightarrow x= \pm 2$

Points, $\quad y=\int_{0}^{ \pm 2}|t| d t= \pm 2$

Equation of tangent is

$$
y-2=2(x-2) \text { and } y+2=2(x+2)
$$

For $x$ intercept put $y=0$, we get

$$
0-2=2(x-2) \text { and } 0+2=2(x+2)
$$

$$
\Rightarrow \quad x= \pm 1
$$

question: Let $f$ be a non-negative function defined on the interval $[0,1]$. If $\int_{0}^{x} \sqrt{1-\left(f^{\prime}(t)\right)^{2}} d t=\int_{0}^{x} f(t) d t, 0 \leq x \leq 1 \quad$ and $f(0)=0$, then
solution:
Given $\int_{0}^{x} \sqrt{1-\left\{f^{\prime}(t)\right\}^{2}} d t=\int_{0}^{x} f(t) d t, 0 \leq x \leq 1$

Differentiating both sides w.r.t. $x$ by using Leibnitz's rule, we get

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \sqrt{1-\left\{f^{\prime}(x)\right\}^{2}}=f(x) \Rightarrow f^{\prime}(x)= \pm \sqrt{1-\{f(x)\}^{2}} \\
& \Rightarrow \int \frac{f^{\prime}(x)}{\sqrt{1-\{f(x)\}^{2}}} d x= \pm \int d x \Rightarrow \sin ^{-1}\{f(x)\}= \pm x+c
\end{aligned}
$$

Put $\quad x=0 \Rightarrow \sin ^{-1}\{f(0)\}=c$

$\Rightarrow \quad c=\sin ^{-1}(0)=0 \quad[\because f(0)=0]$

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \therefore \quad f(x)= \pm \sin x \\
& \text { but } \quad f(x) \geq 0, \forall x \in[0,1] \\
& \therefore \quad f(x)=\sin x
\end{aligned}
$$

As we know that,

$$
\begin{array}{ll} 
& \sin x<x, \forall x>0 \\
\therefore \quad & \sin \frac{1}{2}<\frac{1}{2} \text { and } \sin \frac{1}{3}<\frac{1}{3} \\
\Rightarrow \quad & f \frac{1}{2}<\frac{1}{2} \text { and } f \frac{1}{3}<\frac{1}{3}
\end{array}
$$

question: If $\int_{\sin x}^{1} t^{2} f(t) d t=1-\sin x, \forall x \in(0, \pi / 2)$, then $f \frac{1}{\sqrt{3}}$ is\\
solution:
Since $\int_{\sin x}^{1} t^{2} f(t) d t=1-\sin x$, thus to find $f(x)$.

On differentiating both sides using Newton Leibnitz formula

i.e.

$$
\frac{d}{d x} \int_{\sin x}^{1} t^{2} f(t) d t=\frac{d}{d x}(1-\sin x)
$$

$\Rightarrow\left\{1^{2} f(1)\right\} \cdot(0)-\left(\sin ^{2} x\right) \cdot f(\sin x) \cdot \cos x=-\cos x$

$$
\Rightarrow \quad f(\sin x)=\frac{1}{\sin ^{2} x}
$$

For $f \frac{1}{\sqrt{3}}$ is obtained when $\sin x=1 / \sqrt{3}$

$$
\text { i.e. } \quad f \frac{1}{\sqrt{3}}=(\sqrt{3})^{2}=3
$$

question:
If $f(x)$ is differentiable and $\int_{0}^{t^{2}} x f(x) d x=\frac{2}{5} t^{5}$, then $f \frac{4}{25}$ equals


$(2004,1 \mathrm{M})$\\

If $f(x)=\int_{x^{2}}^{x^{2}+1} e^{-t^{2}} d t$, then $f(x)$ increases in

$(2003,1 \mathrm{M})$\\
solution:
Given, $f(x)=\int_{x^{2}}^{x^{2}+1} e^{-t^{2}} d t$

On differentiating both sides using Newton's Leibnitz's formula, we get

$$
\begin{aligned}
& f^{\prime}(x)=e^{-\left(x^{2}+1\right)^{2}} \frac{d}{d x}\left(x^{2}+1\right)-e^{-\left(x^{2}\right)^{2}} \frac{d}{d x}\left(x^{2}\right) \\
& =e^{-\left(x^{2}+1\right)^{2}} \cdot 2 x-e^{-\left(x^{2}\right)^{2}} \cdot 2 x \\
& =2 x e^{-\left(x^{4}+2 x^{2}+1\right)}\left(1-e^{2 x^{2}+1}\right) \\
& \therefore \quad f^{\prime}(x)>0
\end{aligned}
$$

question: If $I(m, n)=\int_{0}^{1} t^{m}(1+t)^{n} d t$, then the expression for $I(m, n)$ in terms of $I(m+1, n-1)$ is
solution:
Here, $I(m, n)=\int_{0}^{1} t^{m}(1+t)^{n} d t$ reduce into $I(m+1, n-1)$ [we apply integration by parts taking $(1+t)^{n}$ as first and $t^{m}$ as second function] $\therefore \quad I(m, n)=(1+t)^{n} \cdot \frac{t^{m+1}}{m+1}{ }_{0}^{1}-\int_{0}^{1} n(1+t)^{(n-1)} \cdot \frac{t^{m+1}}{m+1} d t$ $=\frac{2^{n}}{m+1}-\frac{n}{m+1} \int_{0}^{1}(1+t)^{(n-1)} \cdot t^{m+1} d t$

$\therefore \quad I(m, n)=\frac{2^{n}}{m+1}-\frac{n}{m+1} \cdot I(m+1, n-1)$

question: Let $f(x)=\int_{1}^{x} \sqrt{2-t^{2}} d t$. Then, the real roots of the equation $x^{2}-f^{\prime}(x)=0$ are\\
solution:
Given, $f(x)=\int_{1}^{x} \sqrt{2-t^{2}} d t \Rightarrow f^{\prime}(x)=\sqrt{2-x^{2}}$

Also, $x^{2}-f^{\prime}(x)=0$

$$
\begin{aligned}
\therefore & & x^{2}=\sqrt{2-x^{2}} \Rightarrow x^{4}=2-x^{2} \\
\Rightarrow & x^{4}+x^{2}-2 & =0 \Rightarrow x= \pm 1
\end{aligned}
$$

question: Let $f:(0, \infty) \rightarrow R$ and $F(x)=\int_{0}^{x} f(t) d t$. If $F\left(x^{2}\right)=x^{2}(1+x)$, then $f(4)$ equals\\
$\int_{0}^{x} f(t) d t=x+\int_{x}^{1} t f(t) d t$, then the value of $f(1)$ is\\
solution:
Given, $\int_{0}^{x} f(t) d t=x+\int_{x}^{1} t f(t) d t$

On differentiating both sides w.r.t. $x$, we get

$$
f(x) 1=1-x f(x) \cdot 1 \quad \Rightarrow \quad(1+x) f(x)=1
$$

$$
\Rightarrow \quad f(x)=\frac{1}{1+x} \Rightarrow f(1)=\frac{1}{1+1}=\frac{1}{2}
$$

question:
Let $f: R \rightarrow R$ be a differentiable function and $f(1)=4$. Then, the value of $\lim _{x \rightarrow 1} \int_{4}^{f(x)} \frac{2 t}{x-1} d t$ is

$(1990,2 \mathrm{M})$\\
The value of the definite integral $\int_{0}^{1}\left(1+e^{-x^{2}}\right) d x$ is
solution:
If $f(x)$ is a continuous function defined on $[a, b]$, then

$$
m(b-a) \leq \int_{a}^{b} f(x) d x \leq M(b-a)
$$

where, $M$ and $m$ are maximum and minimum values respectively of $f(x)$ in $[a, b]$.

Here, $f(x)=1+e^{-x^{2}}$ is continuous in $[0,1]$.

$$
\begin{array}{ll}
\text { Now, } \quad 0<x<1 \Rightarrow x^{2}<x \Rightarrow e^{x^{2}}<e^{x} \Rightarrow e^{-x^{2}}>e^{-x} \\
\text { Again, } 0<x<1 \Rightarrow x^{2}>0 \Rightarrow e^{x^{2}}>e^{0} \Rightarrow e^{-x^{2}}<1 \\
\therefore & e^{-x}<e^{-x^{2}}<1, \forall \quad x \in[0,1] \\
\Rightarrow & 1+e^{-x}<1+e^{-x^{2}}<2, \forall x \in[0,1] \\
\Rightarrow & \int_{0}^{1}\left(1+e^{-x}\right) d x<\int_{0}^{1}\left(1+e^{-x^{2}}\right) d x<\int_{0}^{1} 2 d x \\
\Rightarrow & 2-\frac{1}{e}<\int_{0}^{1}\left(1+e^{-x^{2}}\right) d x<2
\end{array}
$$

question: $\lim _{n \rightarrow \infty} \frac{(n+1)^{1 / 3}}{n^{4 / 3}}+\frac{(n+2)^{1 / 3}}{n^{4 / 3}}+\ldots .+\frac{(2 n)^{1 / 3}}{n^{4 / 3}}$ is equal to \\
$\lim _{n \rightarrow \infty} \frac{n}{n^{2}+1^{2}}+\frac{n}{n^{2}+2^{2}}+\frac{n}{n^{2}+3^{2}}+\ldots+\frac{1}{5 n}$ is equal to\\
$\lim _{n \rightarrow \infty} \frac{(n+1)(n+2) \ldots 3 n}{n^{2 n}}{ }^{1 / n}$ is equal to\\
solution:
Let $l=\lim _{n \rightarrow \infty} \frac{(n+1) \cdot(n+2) \ldots(3 n)}{n^{2 n}}{ }^{\frac{1}{n}}$

$$
\begin{aligned}
& =\lim _{n \rightarrow \infty} \frac{(n+1) \cdot(n+2) \ldots(n+2 n)^{\frac{1}{n}}}{n^{2 n}} \\
& =\lim _{n \rightarrow \infty} \frac{n+1}{n} \quad \frac{n+2}{n} \ldots \frac{n+2 n}{n}^{\frac{1}{n}}
\end{aligned}
$$

Taking log on both sides, we get

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \log l=\lim _{n \rightarrow \infty} \frac{1}{n} \log \quad 1+\frac{1}{n} \quad 1+\frac{2}{n} \cdots 1+\frac{2 n}{n} \\
\Rightarrow & \log l=\lim _{n \rightarrow \infty} \frac{1}{n} \\
& \log 1+\frac{1}{n}+\log 1+\frac{2}{n}+\ldots+\log 1+\frac{2 n}{n} \\
\Rightarrow & \log l=\lim _{n \rightarrow \infty} \frac{1}{n} \sum_{r=1}^{2 n} \log 1+\frac{r}{n} \\
\Rightarrow & \log l=\int_{0}^{2} \log (1+x) d x \\
\Rightarrow & \log l=\log (1+x) \cdot x-\int \frac{1}{1+x} \cdot x d x \\
\Rightarrow & \log l=[\log (1+x) \cdot x]_{0}^{2}-\int_{0}^{2} \frac{x+1}{1+x} d x \\
\Rightarrow & \log l=2 \cdot \log 3-\int_{0}^{2} 1-\frac{1}{1+x} d x \\
\Rightarrow & \log l=2 \cdot \log 3-[x-\log |1+x|]_{0}^{2} \\
\Rightarrow & \log l=2 \cdot \log 3-[2-\log 3] \\
\Rightarrow & \log l=3 \cdot \log 3-2 \\
\Rightarrow & \log l=\log 27-2 \\
\therefore \quad & l=e^{\log 27-2}=27 \cdot e^{-2}=\frac{27}{e^{2}}
\end{aligned}
$$

question: If the area enclosed between the curves $y=k x^{2}$ and $x=k y^{2},(k>0)$, is 1 square unit. Then, $k$ is\\
solution:
We know that, area of region bounded by the parabolas $x^{2}=4 a y$ and $y^{2}=4 b x$ is $\frac{16}{3}(a b)$ sq units.

On comparing $y=k x^{2}$ and $x=k y^{2}$ with above equations, we get $4 a=\frac{1}{k}$ and $4 b=\frac{1}{k}$

$$
\Rightarrow \quad a=\frac{1}{4 k} \text { and } b=\frac{1}{4 k}
$$

$\therefore$ Area enclosed between $y=k x^{2}$ and $x=k y^{2}$ is

$$
\begin{aligned}
\Rightarrow & \frac{16}{3} \frac{1}{4 k} \quad \frac{1}{4 k} & =\frac{1}{3 k^{2}} \\
\Rightarrow & \frac{1}{3 k^{2}} & =1 \quad \text { [given, area }=1 \quad \text { sq.unit] } \\
\Rightarrow & k^{2} & =\frac{1}{3} \quad \Rightarrow k= \pm \frac{1}{\sqrt{3}} \\
\Rightarrow & k & =\frac{1}{\sqrt{3}} \quad[\because k>0]
\end{aligned}
$$

solution:
PLAN (i) $y=m x+a / m$ is an equation of tangent to the parabola $y^{2}=4 a x$

(ii) A line is a tangent to circle, if distance of line from centre is equal to the radius of circle.

(iii) Equation of chord drawn from exterior point $\left(x_{1}, y_{1}\right)$ to a circle/parabola is given by $T=0$.

(iv) Area of trapezium $=\frac{1}{2}$ (Sum of parallel sides)

\section*{316 Area}
Let equation of tangent to parabola be $y=m x+\frac{2}{m}$

It also touches the circle $x^{2}+y^{2}=2$.

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \therefore \quad \frac{2}{m \sqrt{1+m^{2}}}=\sqrt{2} \\
& \Rightarrow m^{4}+m^{2}=2 \Rightarrow m^{4}+m^{2}-2=0 \\
& \Rightarrow \quad\left(m^{2}-1\right)\left(m^{2}+2\right)=0 \\
& \Rightarrow \quad m= \pm 1, m^{2}=-2 \quad\left[\text { rejected } m^{2}=-2\right]
\end{aligned}
$$

So, tangents are $y=x+2, y=-x-2$.

They, intersect at $(-2,0)$.

\begin{center}
\includegraphics[max width=\textwidth]{2024_07_10_5cf63a802979f4b91aebg-06}
\end{center}

Equation of chord $P Q$ is $-2 x=2 \Rightarrow x=-1$

Equation of chord $R S$ is $O=4(x-2) \Rightarrow \quad x=2$

$\therefore$ Coordinates of $P, Q, R, S$ are

$P(-1,1), Q(-1,-1), R(2,4), S(2,-4)$

$\therefore$ Area of quadrilateral $=\frac{(2+8) \times 3}{2}=15$ sq units

Its meet the coordinate axes at

question: If the area (in sq units) bounded by the parabola $y^{2}=4 \lambda x$ and the line $y=\lambda x, \lambda>0$, is $\frac{1}{9}$, then $\lambda$ is equal to\\

solution:
Given region is $\left\{(x, y): y^{2} \leq 4 x, x+y \leq 1, x \geq 0, y \geq 0\right\}$

\begin{center}
\includegraphics[max width=\textwidth]{2024_07_10_5cf63a802979f4b91aebg-08}
\end{center}

Now, for point $P$, put value of $y=1-x$ to $y^{2}=4 x$, we get

$$
\begin{aligned}
(1-x)^{2}=4 x \Rightarrow x^{2}+1-2 x & =4 x \\
\Rightarrow & x^{2}-6 x+1=0 \\
\Rightarrow \quad x & =\frac{6 \pm \sqrt{36-4}}{2} \\
& =3 \pm 2 \sqrt{2} .
\end{aligned}
$$

Since, $x$-coordinate of $P$ less than $x$-coordinate of point $A(1,0)$.

$\therefore x=3-2 \sqrt{2}$

Now, required area


\begin{align*}
& =\int_{0}^{3-2 \sqrt{2}} 2 \sqrt{x} d x+\int_{3-2 \sqrt{2}}^{1}(1-x) d x \\
& =2\left|\frac{x^{3 / 2}}{3 / 2}\right|_{0}^{3-2 \sqrt{2}}+x-{\frac{x^{2}}{2}}_{3-2 \sqrt{2}}^{1} \\
& =\frac{4}{3}(3-2 \sqrt{2})^{3 / 2}+1-\frac{1}{2}-(3-2 \sqrt{2})+\frac{(3-2 \sqrt{2})^{2}}{2} \\
& =\frac{4}{3}\left[(\sqrt{2}-1)^{2}\right]^{3 / 2}+\frac{1}{2}-3+2 \sqrt{2}+\frac{1}{2}(9+8-12 \sqrt{2}) \\
& =\frac{4}{3}(\sqrt{2}-1)^{3}-\frac{5}{2}+2 \sqrt{2}+\frac{17}{2}-6 \sqrt{2} \\
& =\frac{4}{3}(2 \sqrt{2}-3(2)+3(\sqrt{2})-1)-4 \sqrt{2}+6 \\
& =\frac{4}{3}(5 \sqrt{2}-7)-4 \sqrt{2}+6=\frac{8 \sqrt{2}}{3}-\frac{10}{3} \\
& =a \sqrt{2}+b \tag{given}
\end{align*}


So, on comparing $a=\frac{8}{3}$ and $b=-\frac{10}{3}$

$$
\therefore \quad a-b=\frac{8}{3}+\frac{10}{3}=6
$$
