Then, $\frac{\Delta_{1}}{\Delta_{2}}$ is
If the parabolas $y^{2}=4 b(x-c)$ and $y^{2}=8 a x$ have a common normal, then which one of the following is a valid choice for the ordered triad $(a, b, c)$ ?\\
solution:
Normal to parabola $y^{2}=4 a x$ is given by

$$
y=m x-2 a m-a m^{3}
$$

$\therefore$ Normal to parabola


\begin{align*}
& y^{2}=4 b(x-c) \text { is } \\
& y=m(x-c)-2 b m-b m^{3} \\
& \quad[\text { replacing } a \text { by } b \text { and } x \text { by } x-c] \\
&=m x-(2 b+c) m-b m^{3} \tag{i}
\end{align*}


and normal to parabola $y^{2}=8 a x$ is


\begin{equation*}
y=m x-4 a m-2 a m^{3} \tag{ii}
\end{equation*}


[replacing a by $2 a$ ]

For common normal, we should have

$$
m x-4 a m-2 a m^{3}=m x-(2 b+c) m-b m^{3}
$$

[using Eqs. (i) and (ii)]

$$
\begin{array}{cc} 
& 4 a m+2 a m^{3}=(2 b+c) m+b m^{3} \\
\Rightarrow & (2 a-b) m^{3}+(4 a-2 b-c) m=0 \\
\Rightarrow & m\left((2 a-b) m^{2}+(4 a-2 b-c)\right)=0 \\
\Rightarrow & m=0 \\
\text { or } & m^{2}=\frac{2 b+c-4 a}{2 a-b}=\frac{c}{2 a-b}-2
\end{array}
$$

As, $m^{2}>0$, therefore $\frac{c}{2 a-b}>2$

Note that if $m=0$, then all options satisfy ( $\because y=0$ is a common normal) and if common normal is other than the axis, then only option (c) satisfies

$$
\left[\because \text { for option (c), } 2 a-b=\frac{3}{2-1}=3>2\right]
$$

question: If $x+y=k$ is normal to $y^{2}=12 x$, then $k$ is\\
solution:
If $y=m x+c$ is normal to the parabola $y^{2}=4 a x$, then $c=-2 a m-a m^{3}$.

From given condition, $y^{2}=12 x$

$$
\begin{array}{lrl}
\Rightarrow & y^{2} & =4 \cdot 3 \cdot x \\
\Rightarrow & a & =3 \\
\text { And } & x+y & =k \\
\Rightarrow & y & =(-1) x+k \\
\Rightarrow & m & =-1 \\
\text { and } & c & =k \\
\therefore & c & =k=-2(3)(-1)-3(-1)^{3}=9
\end{array}
$$

question: If the normals of the parabola $y^{2}=4 x$ drawn at the end points of its latusrectum are tangents to the circle $(x-3)^{2}+(y+2)^{2}=r^{2}$, then the value of $r^{2}$ is

If $\Delta S^{\prime} B S$ is a right angled triangle with right angle at $B$ and area $\left(\Delta S^{\prime} B S\right)=8 \mathrm{sq}$ units, then the length of a latus rectum of the ellipse is\\

Let the length of the latus rectum of an ellipse with its major axis along $X$-axis and centre at the origin, be 8 . If the distance between the foci of this ellipse is equal to the length of its minor axis, then which one of the following points lies on it?\\
solution:
Let the equation of ellipse be $\frac{x^{2}}{a^{2}}+\frac{y^{2}}{b^{2}}=1$

Then, according the problem, we have

$$
\frac{2 b^{2}}{a}=8 \text { and } 2 a e=2 b
$$

$$
\text { LLength of latusrectum }=\frac{2 b^{2}}{a} \text { and }
$$

length of minor axis $=2 b$


\begin{align*}
\Rightarrow & b \frac{b}{a} & =4 \text { and } \frac{b}{a}=e \\
\Rightarrow & b(e) & =4 \\
\Rightarrow & b & =4 . \frac{1}{e} \tag{i}
\end{align*}


Also, we know that $b^{2}=a^{2}\left(1-e^{2}\right)$

\[
\begin{array}{ccc}
\Rightarrow & \frac{b^{2}}{a^{2}}=1-e^{2} \Rightarrow e^{2}=1-e^{2} & \because \frac{b}{a}=e \\
\Rightarrow & 2 e^{2}=1 & \\
\Rightarrow & e=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}} & \ldots \text { (ii) } \tag{ii}
\end{array}
\]

From Eqs. (i) and (ii), we get

$$
b=4 \sqrt{2}
$$

Now,

$$
a^{2}=\frac{b^{2}}{1-e^{2}}=\frac{32}{1-\frac{1}{2}}=64
$$

$\therefore$ Equation of ellipse be $\frac{x^{2}}{64}+\frac{y^{2}}{32}=1$

Now, check all the options.

Only $(4 \sqrt{3}, 2 \sqrt{2})$, satisfy the above equation.

=\sqrt{7+9}=\sqrt{16}=4

If $P=(x, y), F_{1}=(3,0), F_{2}=(-3,0)$ and $16 x^{2}+25 y^{2}=400$, then $P F_{1}+P F_{2}$ equals \\

question: If the normal to the ellipse $3 x^{2}+4 y^{2}=12$ at a point $P$ on it is parallel to the line, $2 x+y=4$ and the tangent to the ellipse at $P$ passes through $Q(4,4)$ then $P Q$ is equal to\\
The tangent and normal to the ellipse $3 x^{2}+5 y^{2}=32$ at the point $P(2,2)$ meets the $X$-axis at $Q$ and $R$, respectively. Then, the area (in sq units) of the $\triangle P Q R$ is\\
solution:
Equation of given ellipse is


\begin{equation*}
3 x^{2}+5 y^{2}=32 \tag{i}
\end{equation*}


Now, the slope of tangent and normal at point $P(2,2)$ to the ellipse (i) are respectively

$$
m_{T}=\left.\frac{d y}{d x}\right|_{(2,2)} \text { and } m_{N}=-\left.\frac{d x}{d y}\right|_{(2,2)}
$$

On differentiating ellipse (i), w.r.t. $x$, we get

$$
6 x+10 y \frac{d y}{d x}=0 \Rightarrow \frac{d y}{d x}=-\frac{3 x}{5 y}
$$

So, $m_{T}=-\left.\frac{3 x}{5 y}\right|_{(2,2)}=-\frac{3}{5}$ and $m_{N}=\left.\frac{5 y}{3 y}\right|_{(2,2)}=\frac{5}{3}$

Now, equation of tangent and normal to the given ellipse (i) at point $P(2,2)$ are

$$
(y-2)=-\frac{3}{5}(x-2)
$$

and $(y-2)=\frac{5}{3}(x-2)$ respectively.

It is given that point of intersection of tangent and normal are $Q$ and $R$ at $X$-axis respectively

So, $\quad Q \frac{16}{3}, 0$ and $R \frac{4}{5}, 0$

$\therefore$ Area of $\triangle P Q R=\frac{1}{2}(Q R) \times$ height

$$
\begin{gathered}
=\frac{1}{2} \times \frac{68}{15} \times 2=\frac{68}{15} \text { sq units } \\
{\left[\because Q R=\sqrt{\frac{16}{3}-\frac{4}{5}^{2}}=\sqrt{\frac{68}{15}^{2}}=\frac{68}{15} \text { and height }=2\right]}
\end{gathered}
$$

question: If the line $x-2 y=12$ is tangent to the ellipse $\frac{x^{2}}{a^{2}}+\frac{y^{2}}{b^{2}}=1$ at the point $3, \frac{-9}{2}$, then the length of the latusrectum of the ellipse is\\
If the tangent to the parabola $y^{2}=x$ at a point $(\alpha, \beta),(\beta>0)$ is also a tangent to the ellipse, $x^{2}+2 y^{2}=1$, then $\alpha$ is equal to\\
solution:
Since the point $(\alpha, \beta)$ is on the parabola $y^{2}=x$, so


\begin{equation*}
\alpha=\beta^{2} \tag{i}
\end{equation*}


Now, equation of tangent at point $(\alpha, \beta)$ to the parabola $y^{2}=x$, is $T=0$

$$
\Rightarrow \quad y \beta=\frac{1}{2}(x+\alpha)
$$

$\left[\because\right.$ equation of the tangent to the parabola $y^{2}=4 a x$ at a point $\left(x_{1}, y_{1}\right)$ is given by $\left.y y_{1}=2 a\left(x+x_{1}\right)\right]$

\[
\begin{array}{ll}
\Rightarrow & 2 y \beta=x+\beta^{2} \\
\Rightarrow & y=\frac{x}{2 \beta}+\frac{\beta}{2} \tag{ii}
\end{array}
\]

Since, line (ii) is also a tangent of the ellipse

$$
\begin{aligned}
& x^{2}+2 y^{2}=1 \\
& \therefore \quad \frac{\beta}{2}^{2}=(1)^{2} \frac{1}{2 \beta}^{2}+\frac{1}{2}
\end{aligned}
$$

$[\because$ condition of tangency of line $y=m x+c$ to ellipse $\frac{x^{2}}{a^{2}}+\frac{y^{2}}{b^{2}}=1$ is $c^{2}=a^{2} m^{2}+b^{2}$,

here $\quad m=\frac{1}{2 \beta}, a=1, b=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}$ and $c=\frac{\beta}{2}$

$\Rightarrow \quad \frac{\beta^{2}}{4}=\frac{1}{4 \beta^{2}}+\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}$

$\Rightarrow \quad \beta^{4}=1+2 \beta^{2}$

$\Rightarrow \quad \beta^{4}-2 \beta^{2}-1=0$

$\Rightarrow \quad \beta^{2}=\frac{2 \pm \sqrt{4+4}}{2}=\frac{2 \pm 2 \sqrt{2}}{2}=1 \pm \sqrt{2}$

$\Rightarrow \quad \beta^{2}=1+\sqrt{2}$

$\left[\because \beta^{2}>0\right]$

$\because \quad \alpha=\beta^{2}=1+\sqrt{2}$

question: If the tangents on the ellipse $4 x^{2}+y^{2}=8$ at the points $(1,2)$ and $(a, b)$ are perpendicular to each other, then $a^{2}$ is equal to\\

If tangents are drawn to the ellipse $x^{2}+2 y^{2}=2$ at all points on the ellipse other than its four vertices, then the mid-points of the tangents intercepted between the coordinate axes lie on the curve\\
solution:
Given equation of ellipse is $x^{2}+2 y^{2}=2$, which can be written as $\frac{x^{2}}{2}+\frac{y^{2}}{1}=1$

Let $P$ be a point on the ellipse, other than its four vertices. Then, the parametric coordinates of $P$ be $(\sqrt{2} \cos \theta, \sin \theta)$

\begin{center}
\includegraphics[max width=\textwidth]{2024_07_10_b84c45764effd0648ef4g-10(1)}
\end{center}

Now, the equation of tangent at $P$ is $\frac{x \sqrt{2} \cos \theta}{2}+\frac{y \sin \theta}{1}=1$

$\left[\because\right.$ equation of tangent at $\left(x_{1}, y_{1}\right)$ is given by $T=0$

$$
\Rightarrow \frac{x x_{1}}{a^{2}}+\frac{y y_{1}}{b^{2}}=1
$$

$$
\Rightarrow \quad \frac{x}{\sqrt{2} \sec \theta}+\frac{y}{\operatorname{cosec} \theta}=1
$$

$\therefore A(\sqrt{2} \sec \theta, 0)$ and $B(0, \operatorname{cosec} \theta)$

Let mid-point of $A B$ be $R(h, k)$, then

$$
\begin{aligned}
h & =\frac{\sqrt{2} \sec \theta}{2} \text { and } k=\frac{\operatorname{cosec} \theta}{2} \\
2 h & =\sqrt{2} \sec \theta \text { and } 2 k=\operatorname{cosec} \theta \\
\Rightarrow \quad \cos \theta & =\frac{1}{\sqrt{2} h} \text { and } \sin \theta=\frac{1}{2 k}
\end{aligned}
$$

We know that, $\cos ^{2} \theta+\sin ^{2} \theta=1$

$\therefore \quad \frac{1}{2 h^{2}}+\frac{1}{4 k^{2}}=1$

So, locus of $(h, k)$ is $\frac{1}{2 x^{2}}+\frac{1}{4 y^{2}}=1$

question: Equation of a common tangent to the parabola $y^{2}=4 x$ and the hyperbola $x y=2$ is\\
solution:
We know that, $y=m x+\frac{a}{m}$ is the equation of tangent to the parabola $y^{2}=4 a x$.

$\therefore y=m x+\frac{1}{m}$ is a tangent to the parabola $y^{2}=4 x$.

$[\because a=1]$

Let, this tangent is also a tangent to the hyperbola $x y=2$

Now, on substituting $y=m x+\frac{1}{m}$ in $x y=2$, we get

$$
\begin{aligned}
x m x+\frac{1}{m} & =2 \\
\Rightarrow \quad m^{2} x^{2}+x-2 m & =0
\end{aligned}
$$

Note that tangent touch the curve exactly at one point, therefore both roots of above equations are equal.

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \Rightarrow \quad D=0 \Rightarrow 1-4\left(m^{2}\right)(-2 m) \Rightarrow m^{3}=-\frac{1}{2} \\
& \Rightarrow \quad m=-\frac{1}{2}
\end{aligned}
$$

$\therefore$ Required equation of tangent is

$$
\begin{aligned}
& y=-\frac{x}{2}-2 \\
& \Rightarrow \quad 2 y=-x-4 \\
& \Rightarrow \quad x+2 y+4=0
\end{aligned}
$$

question: The eccentricity of an ellipse whose centre is at the origin is $1 / 2$. If one of its directrices is $x=-4$, then the equation of the normal to it at $1, \frac{3}{2}$ is\\
solution:
We have, $e=\frac{1}{2}$ and $\frac{a}{e}=4$

$\therefore \quad a=2$

Now, $b^{2}=a^{2}\left(1-e^{2}\right)=(2)^{2} 1-\frac{1}{2}^{2}=41-\frac{1}{4}=3$

$\Rightarrow \quad b=\sqrt{3}$

$\therefore$ Equation of the ellipse is $\frac{x^{2}}{(2)^{2}}+\frac{y^{2}}{(\sqrt{3})^{2}}=1$

$$
\Rightarrow \quad \frac{x^{2}}{4}+\frac{y^{2}}{3}=1
$$

Now, the equation of normal at $1, \frac{3}{2}$ is

$$
\begin{aligned}
\Rightarrow & \frac{a^{2} x}{x_{1}}-\frac{b^{2} y}{y_{1}} & =a^{2}-b^{2} \\
\Rightarrow & \frac{4 x}{1}-\frac{3 y}{(3 / 2)} & =4-3 \\
\Rightarrow & 4 x-2 y & =1
\end{aligned}
$$

question: The area (in sq units) of the quadrilateral formed by the tangents at the end points of the latusrectum to the ellipse $\frac{x^{2}}{9}+\frac{y^{2}}{5}=1$ is\\
The locus of the foot of perpendicular drawn from the centre of the ellipse $x^{2}+3 y^{2}=6$ on any tangent to it is
solution:
Equation of ellipse is $x^{2}+3 y^{2}=6$ or $\frac{x^{2}}{6}+\frac{y^{2}}{2}=1$.

Equation of the tangent is $\frac{x \cos \theta}{a}+\frac{y \sin \theta}{b}=1$

Let $(h, k)$ be any point on the locus.


\begin{equation*}
\therefore \quad \frac{h}{a} \cos \theta+\frac{k}{b} \sin \theta=1 \tag{i}
\end{equation*}


Slope of the tangent line is $\frac{-b}{a} \cot \theta$.

Slope of perpendicular drawn from centre $(0,0)$ to $(h, k)$ is $k / h$.

Since, both the lines are perpendicular.

$$
\begin{array}{rlrl}
\therefore & \frac{k}{h} \times-\frac{b}{a} \cot \theta & =-1 \\
\Rightarrow & \frac{\cos \theta}{h a} & =\frac{\sin \theta}{k b}=\alpha \\
\Rightarrow & & \cos \theta & =\alpha h a \\
& & \sin \theta & =\alpha k b
\end{array}
$$

From Eq. (i), $\frac{h}{a}(\alpha h a)+\frac{k}{b}(\alpha k b)=1$

$$
\begin{aligned}
\Rightarrow & h^{2} \alpha+k^{2} \alpha & =1 \\
\Rightarrow & \alpha & =\frac{1}{h^{2}+k^{2}}
\end{aligned}
$$

Also, $\quad \sin ^{2} \theta+\cos ^{2} \theta=1$

$\Rightarrow \quad(\alpha k b)^{2}+(\alpha h a)^{2}=1$

$\Rightarrow \quad \alpha^{2} k^{2} b^{2}+\alpha^{2} h^{2} a^{2}=1$

$\Rightarrow \frac{k^{2} b^{2}}{\left(h^{2}+k^{2}\right)^{2}}+\frac{h^{2} a^{2}}{\left(h^{2}+k^{2}\right)^{2}}=1$

$\Rightarrow \frac{2 k^{2}}{\left(h^{2}+k^{2}\right)^{2}}+\frac{6 h^{2}}{\left(h^{2}+k^{2}\right)^{2}}=1 \quad\left[\because a^{2}=6, b^{2}=2\right]$

$\Rightarrow \quad 6 x^{2}+2 y^{2}=\left(x^{2}+y^{2}\right)^{2}$

question: The normal at a point $P$ on the ellipse $x^{2}+4 y^{2}=16$ meets the $X$-axis at $Q$. If $M$ is the mid-point of the line segment $P Q$, then the locus of $M$ intersects the latusrectum of the given ellipse at the points \\

The line passing through the extremity $A$ of the major axis and extremity $B$ of the minor axis of the ellipse $x^{2}+9 y^{2}=9$ meets its auxiliary circle at the point $M$. Then, the area (insqunits) of the triangle with vertices at $A, M$ and the origin $O$ is
\\
Tangents are drawn to the ellipse $x^{2}+2 y^{2}=2$, then the locus of the mid-point of the intercept made by the tangents between the coordinate axes is\\

Tangent is drawn to ellipse $\frac{x^{2}}{27}+y^{2}=1$ at ( $3 \sqrt{3} \cos \theta, \sin \theta$ ) (where, $\theta \in(0, \pi / 2$ ).

Then, the value of $\theta$ such that the sum of intercepts on axes made by this tangent is minimum, is\\
solution:
Given, tangent is drawn at $(3 \sqrt{3} \cos \theta, \sin \theta)$ to $\frac{x^{2}}{27}+\frac{y^{2}}{1}=1$.

$\therefore$ Equation of tangent is $\frac{x \cos \theta}{3 \sqrt{3}}+\frac{y \sin \theta}{1}=1$.

Thus, sum of intercepts $=\frac{3 \sqrt{3}}{\cos \theta}+\frac{1}{\sin \theta}=f(\theta) \quad$ [say]

$$
\begin{array}{lr}
\Rightarrow & f^{\prime}(\theta)=\frac{3 \sqrt{3} \sin ^{3} \theta-\cos ^{3} \theta}{\sin ^{2} \theta \cos ^{2} \theta}, \text { put } f^{\prime}(\theta)=0 \\
\Rightarrow & \sin ^{3} \theta=\frac{1}{3^{3 / 2}} \cos ^{3} \theta \\
\Rightarrow & \tan \theta=\frac{1}{\sqrt{3}}, \text { i.e. } \theta=\frac{\pi}{6} \text { and at } \theta=\frac{\pi}{6}, f^{\prime \prime}(0)>0
\end{array}
$$

Hence, tangent is minimum at $\theta=\frac{\pi}{6}$.

question: If $a>2 b>0$, then positive value of $m$ for which $y=m x-b \sqrt{1+m^{2}}$ is a common tangent to $x^{2}+y^{2}=b^{2}$ and $(x-a)^{2}+y^{2}=b^{2}$ is\\
solution:
Given, $y=m x-b \sqrt{1+m^{2}}$ touches both the circles, so distance from centre $=$ radius of both the circles.

$$
\begin{array}{rlrl} 
& \frac{\left|m a-0-b \sqrt{1+m^{2}}\right|}{\sqrt{m^{2}+1}}=b \text { and } \frac{\left|-b \sqrt{1+m^{2}}\right|}{\sqrt{m^{2}+1}}=b \\
\Rightarrow & \left|m a-b \sqrt{1+m^{2}}\right|=\left|-b \sqrt{1+m^{2}}\right| \\
\Rightarrow & m^{2} a^{2}-2 a b m \sqrt{1+m^{2}}+b^{2}\left(1+m^{2}\right)=b^{2}\left(1+m^{2}\right) \\
\Rightarrow & m a-2 b \sqrt{1+m^{2}}=0 \\
\Rightarrow & m^{2} a^{2}=4 b^{2}\left(1+m^{2}\right) \\
\therefore & m & =\frac{2 b}{\sqrt{a^{2}-4 b^{2}}}
\end{array}
$$

question: The number of values of $c$ such that the straight line $y=4 x+c$ touches the curve $\frac{x^{2}}{4}+y^{2}=1$ is\\

Suppose that the foci of the ellipse $\frac{x^{2}}{9}+\frac{y^{2}}{5}=1$ are $\left(f_{1}, 0\right)$ and ( $f_{2}, 0$ ), where $f_{1}>0$ and $f_{2}<0$. Let $P_{1}$ and $P_{2}$ be two parabolas with a common vertex at $(0,0)$ with foci at $\left(f_{1}, 0\right)$ and $\left(2 f_{2}, 0\right)$, respectively. Let $T_{1}$ be a tangent to $P_{1}$ which passes through $\left(2 f_{2}, 0\right)$ and $T_{2}$ be a tangent to $P_{2}$ which passes through ( $f_{1}, 0$ ). If $m_{1}$ is the slope of $T_{1}$ and $m_{2}$ is the slope of $T_{2}$, then the value of $\frac{1}{m_{1}^{2}}+m_{2}^{2}$ is

Let $P$ be the point of intersection of the common tangents to the parabola $y^{2}=12 x$ and the hyperbola $8 x^{2}-y^{2}=8$. If $S$ and $S^{\prime}$ denotes the foci of the hyperbola where $S$ lies on the positive $X$-axis then $P$ divides $S S^{\prime}$ in a ratio\\
solution:
Equation of given parabola $y^{2}=12 x$

and hyperbola $8 x^{2}-y^{2}=8$

Now, equation of tangent to parabola $y^{2}=12 x$ having slope ' $m$ ' is $y=m x+\frac{3}{m}$

and equation of tangent to hyperbola

$\frac{x^{2}}{1}-\frac{y^{2}}{8}=1$ having slope ' $m$ ' is


\begin{equation*}
y=m x \pm \sqrt{1^{2} m^{2}-8} \tag{iv}
\end{equation*}


Since, tangents (iii) and (iv) represent the same line

$$
\begin{array}{ll}
\therefore & m^{2}-8=\frac{3}{m} \\
\Rightarrow & m^{4}-8 m^{2}-9=0 \\
\Rightarrow & \left(m^{2}-9\right)\left(m^{2}+1\right)=0 \\
\Rightarrow & m= \pm 3 .
\end{array}
$$

Now, equation of common tangents to the parabola (i) and hyperbola (ii) are $y=3 x+1$ and $y=-3 x-1$

$\because$ Point ' $P$ ' is point of intersection of above common tangents,

$\therefore P(-1 / 3,0)$

and focus of hyperbola $S(3,0)$ and $S^{\prime}(-3,0)$.

Thus, the required ratio $=\frac{P S}{P S^{\prime}}=\frac{3+1 / 3}{3-1 / 3}=\frac{10}{8}=\frac{5}{4}$

question: If $5 x+9=0$ is the directrix of the hyperbola $16 x^{2}-9 y^{2}=144$, then its corresponding focus is\\
solution:
Equation of given hyperbola is


\begin{align*}
\Rightarrow & 16 x^{2}-9 y^{2} & =144 \\
& \frac{x^{2}}{9}-\frac{y^{2}}{16} & =1 \tag{i}
\end{align*}


So, the eccentricity of Eq. (i)

$$
e=\sqrt{1+\frac{16}{9}}=\frac{5}{3}
$$

$\left[\because\right.$ the eccentricity (e) of the hyperbola $\frac{x^{2}}{a^{2}}-\frac{y^{2}}{b^{2}}=1$ is

$$
\left.\sqrt{1+(b / a)^{2}}\right]
$$

and given directrix is $5 x+9=0 \Rightarrow x=-9 / 5$

So, corresponding focus is $-3 \frac{5}{3}, 0=(-5,0)$

question: If a directrix of a hyperbola centred at the origin and passing through the point $(4,-2 \sqrt{3})$ is $5 x=4 \sqrt{5}$ and its eccentricity is $e$, then\\
If the vertices of a hyperbola be at $(-2,0)$ and $(2,0)$ and one of its foci be at $(-3,0)$, then which one of the following points does not lie on this hyperbola?\\
solution:
The vertices of hyperbola are given as $( \pm 2,0)$ and one of its foci is at $(-3,0)$.

$\therefore(a, 0)=(2,0)$ and $(-a e, 0),=(-3,0)$

On comparing $x$-coordinates both sides, we get

$\Rightarrow a=2$ and $-a e=-3$

$\Rightarrow 2 e=3 \Rightarrow e=\frac{3}{2}$

Also, $\quad \frac{9}{4}=1+\frac{b^{2}}{4} \Rightarrow b^{2}=5$

$$
\because e^{2}=1+\frac{b^{2}}{a^{2}}
$$

So, equation of the hyperbola is


\begin{equation*}
\frac{x^{2}}{4}-\frac{y^{2}}{5}=1 \tag{i}
\end{equation*}


The point $(6,5 \sqrt{2})$ from the given options does not satisfy the above equation of hyperbola.

question: If a hyperbola has length of its conjugate axis equal to 5 and the distance between its foci is 13, then the eccentricity of the hyperbola is\\
solution:
We know that in $\frac{x^{2}}{a^{2}}-\frac{y^{2}}{b^{2}}=1$, where $b^{2}=a^{2}\left(e^{2}-1\right)$, the length of conjugate axis is $2 b$ and distance between the foci is $2 a e$.

$\therefore$ According the problem, $2 b=5$ and $2 a e=13$

Now, $\quad b^{2}=a^{2}\left(e^{2}-1\right)$

$\Rightarrow \quad \frac{5}{2}=a^{2} e^{2}-a^{2}$

$\Rightarrow \quad \frac{25}{4}=\frac{(2 a e)^{2}}{4}-a^{2}$

$\Rightarrow \quad \frac{25}{4}=\frac{169}{4}-a^{2}$

$[\because 2 a e=13]$

$$
\Rightarrow \quad a^{2}=\frac{169-25}{4}=\frac{144}{4}=36
$$

$\Rightarrow \quad a=6$

Now, $\quad 2 a e=13$

$\Rightarrow \quad 2 \times 6 \times e=13$

$$
\Rightarrow \quad e=\frac{13}{12}
$$

question:
Let $S=(x, y) \in R^{2}: \frac{y^{2}}{1+r}-\frac{x^{2}}{1-r}=1$,

where $r \neq \pm 1$. Then, $S$ represents (2019 Main, 10 Jan II)
options: a) a hyperbola whose eccentricity is $\frac{2}{\sqrt{1-r}}$, when $0<r<1$.
b) a hyperbola whose eccentricity is $\frac{2}{\sqrt{r+1}}$, when $0<r<1$.
c) an ellipse whose eccentricity is $\sqrt{\frac{2}{r+1}}$, when $r>1$.
d) an ellipse whose eccentricity is $\frac{1}{\sqrt{r+1}}$, when $r>1$.
solution:
Given, $S=(x, y) \in R^{2}: \frac{y^{2}}{1+r}-\frac{x^{2}}{1-r}=1$

$$
=(x, y) \in R^{2}: \frac{y^{2}}{1+r}+\frac{x^{2}}{r-1}=1
$$

For $r>1, \frac{y^{2}}{1+r}+\frac{x^{2}}{r-1}=1$, represents a vertical ellipse.

$[\because$ for $r>1, r-1<r+1$ and $r-1>0$ ]

Now, eccentricity $(e)=\sqrt{1-\frac{r-1}{r+1}}$

$$
\begin{aligned}
\because & \text { For } \frac{x^{2}}{a^{2}}+\frac{y^{2}}{b^{2}}=1, a<b, e=\sqrt{1-\frac{a^{2}}{b^{2}}} \\
& =\sqrt{\frac{(r+1)-(r-1)}{r+1}} \\
& =\sqrt{\frac{2}{r+1}}
\end{aligned}
$$

question: A hyperbola has its centre at the origin, passes through the point $(4,2)$ and has transverse axis of length 4 along the $X$-axis. Then the eccentricity of the hyperbola is\\
solution:
Equation of hyperbola is given by

$$
\frac{x^{2}}{a^{2}}-\frac{y^{2}}{b^{2}}=1
$$

$\because$ Length of transverse axis $=2 a=4$

$\therefore \quad a=2$

Thus, $\frac{x^{2}}{4}-\frac{y^{2}}{b^{2}}=1$ is the equation of hyperbola

$\because$ It passes through $(4,2)$.

$\therefore \quad \frac{16}{4}-\frac{4}{b^{2}}=1 \Rightarrow 4-\frac{4}{b^{2}}=1 \Rightarrow b^{2}=\frac{4}{3} \Rightarrow b=\frac{2}{\sqrt{3}}$

Now, eccentricity,

$$
e=\sqrt{1+\frac{b^{2}}{a^{2}}}=\sqrt{1+\frac{4}{3}}=\sqrt{1+\frac{1}{3}}=\frac{2}{\sqrt{3}}
$$

question: Let $0<\theta<\frac{\pi}{2}$. If the eccentricity of the hyperbola $\frac{x^{2}}{\cos ^{2} \theta}-\frac{y^{2}}{\sin ^{2} \theta}=1$ is greater than 2 , then the length of its latus rectum lies in the interval\\
solution:
For the hyperbola $\frac{x^{2}}{a^{2}}-\frac{y^{2}}{b^{2}}=1$,

$$
e=\sqrt{1+\frac{b^{2}}{a^{2}}}
$$

$\therefore$ For the given hyperbola,

$$
e=\sqrt{1+\frac{\sin ^{2} \theta}{\cos ^{2} \theta}}>2
$$

$\left(\because a^{2}=\cos ^{2} \theta\right.$ and $\left.b^{2}=\sin ^{2} \theta\right)$

$$
\Rightarrow 1+\tan ^{2} \theta>4
$$

$\Rightarrow \tan ^{2} \theta>3$

$\Rightarrow \tan \theta \in(-\infty,-\sqrt{3}) \cup(\sqrt{3}, \infty)$

$$
\left[x^{2}>3 \Rightarrow|x|>\sqrt{3} \Rightarrow x \in(-\infty,-\sqrt{3}) \cup(\sqrt{3}, \infty)\right]
$$

But $\theta \in 0, \frac{\pi}{2} \Rightarrow \tan \theta \in(\sqrt{3}, \infty)$

$\Rightarrow \theta \in \frac{\pi}{3}, \frac{\pi}{2}$

Now, length of latusrectum

$$
=\frac{2 b^{2}}{a}=2 \frac{\sin ^{2} \theta}{\cos \theta}=2 \sin \theta \tan \theta
$$

Since, both $\sin \theta$ and $\tan \theta$ are increasing functions in $\frac{\pi}{3}, \frac{\pi}{2}$.

$\therefore$ Least value of latusrectum is

$$
=2 \sin \frac{\pi}{3} \cdot \tan \frac{\pi}{3}=2 \cdot \frac{\sqrt{3}}{2} \cdot \sqrt{3}=3 \quad \text { at } \theta=\frac{\pi}{3}
$$

and greatest value of latusrectum is $<\infty$

$$
\text { Hence, latusrectum length } \in(3, \infty)
$$

question: The eccentricity of the hyperbola whose length of the latusrectum is equal to 8 and the length of its conjugate axis is equal to half of the distance between its foci, is\\
solution:
We have, $\frac{2 b^{2}}{a}=8$ and $2 b=a e$

$\Rightarrow b^{2}=4 a$ and $2 b=a e$

Consider, $\quad 2 b=a e$

$$
\begin{array}{lrrr}
\Rightarrow & 4 b^{2}=a^{2} e^{2} & \\
\Rightarrow & 4 a^{2}\left(e^{2}-1\right)=a^{2} e^{2} & \\
\Rightarrow & 4 e^{2}-4=e^{2} & {[\because a \neq 0]} \\
\Rightarrow & 3 e^{2}=4 & \\
\Rightarrow & e=\frac{2}{\sqrt{3}} & & {[\because e>0]}
\end{array}
$$

question:
Consider a branch of the hyperbola

$$
x^{2}-2 y^{2}-2 \sqrt{2} x-4 \sqrt{2} y-6=0
$$

with vertex at the point $A$. Let $B$ be one of the end points of its latusrectum. If $C$ is the focus of the hyperbola nearest to the point $A$, then the area of the $\triangle A B C$ is
A hyperbola, having the transverse axis of length $2 \sin \theta$, is confocal with the ellipse $3 x^{2}+4 y^{2}=12$. Then, its equation is
solution:
The given ellipse is

$$
\begin{array}{rlrl} 
& \frac{x^{2}}{4}+\frac{y^{2}}{3} & =1 \Rightarrow \quad a=2, b=\sqrt{3} \\
\therefore & 3 & =4\left(1-e^{2}\right) \Rightarrow \quad e=\frac{1}{2} \\
& \text { So, } & a e & =2 \times \frac{1}{2}=1
\end{array}
$$

Hence, the eccentricity $e_{1}$ of the hyperbola is given by

$$
\begin{array}{rlrl} 
& & e_{1}=\operatorname{cosec} \theta & {[\because a e=e \sin \theta]} \\
\Rightarrow \quad & b^{2}=\sin ^{2} \theta\left(\operatorname{cosec}^{2} \theta-1\right)=\cos ^{2} \theta
\end{array}
$$

Hence, equation of hyperbola is $\frac{x^{2}}{\sin ^{2} \theta}-\frac{y^{2}}{\cos ^{2} \theta}=1$ or $x^{2} \operatorname{cosec}^{2} \theta-y^{2} \sec ^{2} \theta=1$.

question: If $e_{1}$ is the eccentricity of the ellipse $\frac{x^{2}}{16}+\frac{y^{2}}{25}=1$ and $e_{2}$ is the eccentricity of the hyperbola passing through the foci of the ellipse and $e_{1} e_{2}=1$, then equation of the hyperbola is\\
solution:
The eccentricity of $\frac{x^{2}}{16}+\frac{y^{2}}{25}=1$ is

$$
\begin{aligned}
e_{1} & =\sqrt{1-\frac{16}{25}}=\frac{3}{5} \\
\therefore \quad e_{2} & =\frac{5}{3} \quad\left[\because e_{1} e_{2}=1\right]
\end{aligned}
$$

$\Rightarrow$ Foci of ellipse $(0, \pm 3)$

$\Rightarrow$ Equation of hyperbola is $\frac{x^{2}}{16}-\frac{y^{2}}{9}=-1$.

question: For hyperbola $\frac{x^{2}}{\cos ^{2} \alpha}-\frac{y^{2}}{\sin ^{2} \alpha}=1$, which of the following remains constant with change in ' $\alpha$ '?\\
solution:
Given equation of hyperbola is $\frac{x^{2}}{\cos ^{2} \alpha}-\frac{y^{2}}{\sin ^{2} \alpha}=1$

Here,

$$
a^{2}=\cos ^{2} \alpha \text { and } b^{2}=\sin ^{2} \alpha
$$

[i.e. comparing with standard equation $\frac{x^{2}}{a^{2}}-\frac{y^{2}}{b^{2}}=1$ ]

We know that, foci $=( \pm \alpha e, 0)$

where, $a e=\sqrt{a^{2}+b^{2}}=\sqrt{\cos ^{2} \alpha+\sin ^{2} \alpha}=1$ $\Rightarrow \quad$ Foci $=( \pm 1,0)$

where, vertices are $( \pm \cos \alpha, 0)$.

Eccentricity, $\quad a e=1$ or $e=\frac{1}{\cos \alpha}$

Hence, foci remains constant with change in $\alpha$.

question: The equation $\frac{x^{2}}{1-r}-\frac{y^{2}}{1+r}=1,|r|<1$ represents\\
solution:
Given equation is $\frac{x^{2}}{1-r}-\frac{y^{2}}{1+r}=1$, where $|r|<1$ $\Rightarrow 1-r$ is (+ve) and $1+r$ is (+ve)

$\therefore$ Given equation is of the form $\frac{x^{2}}{a^{2}}-\frac{y^{2}}{b^{2}}=1$.

Hence, it represents a hyperbola when $|r|<1$.

question: The equation of a common tangent to the curves, $y^{2}=16 x$ and $x y=-4$, is\\
solution:
Key Idea An equation of tangent having slope ' $m$ ' to parabola $y^{2}=4 a x$ is $y=m x+\frac{a}{m}$.

Given equation of curves are


\begin{equation*}
y^{2}=16 x \text { (parabola) } \tag{i}
\end{equation*}


and $\quad x y=-4$ (rectangular hyperbola)

Clearly, equation of tangent having slope ' $m$ ' to parabola

(i) is $y=m x+\frac{4}{m}$

Now, eliminating $y$ from Eqs. (ii) and (iii), we get

$$
x m x+\frac{4}{m}=-4 \Rightarrow m x^{2}+\frac{4}{m} x+4=0
$$

which will give the points of intersection of tangent and rectangular hyperbola.

Since, line $y=m x+\frac{4}{m}$ is also a tangent to the rectangular hyperbola.

$\therefore$ Discriminant of quadratic equation $m x^{2}+\frac{4}{m} x+4=0$, should be zero.

[ $\because$ there will be only one point of intersection]

$$
\begin{array}{ll}
\Rightarrow & D=\frac{4}{m}^{2}-4(m)(4)=0 \\
\Rightarrow & m^{3}=1 \Rightarrow m=1
\end{array}
$$

So, equation of required tangent is $y=x+4$.

question: If the line $y=m x+7 \sqrt{3}$ is normal to the hyperbola $\frac{x^{2}}{24}-\frac{y^{2}}{18}=1$, then a value of $m$ is\\
If the eccentricity of the standard hyperbola passing through the point $(4,6)$ is 2 , then the equation of the tangent to the hyperbola at $(4,6)$ is \\

The equation of a tangent to the hyperbola $4 x^{2}-5 y^{2}=20$ parallel to the line $x-y=2$ is
\\
solution:
Given equation of hyperbola is

$$
4 x^{2}-5 y^{2}=20
$$

which can be rewritten as

$$
\Rightarrow \quad \frac{x^{2}}{5}-\frac{y^{2}}{4}=1
$$

The line $x-y=2$ has slope, $m=1$

$\therefore$ Slope of tangent parallel to this line $=1$

We know equation of tangent to hyperbola $\frac{x^{2}}{a^{2}}-\frac{y^{2}}{b^{2}}=1$ having slope $m$ is given by

$$
y=m x \pm \sqrt{a^{2} m^{2}-b^{2}}
$$

Here, $a^{2}=5, b^{2}=4$ and $m=1$

$\therefore$ Required equation of tangent is

$\Rightarrow \quad y=x \pm \sqrt{5-4}$

$\Rightarrow \quad y=x \pm 1 \Rightarrow x-y \pm 1 \Rightarrow 0$

question: Tangents are drawn to the hyperbola $4 x^{2}-y^{2}=36$ at the points $P$ and $Q$. If these tangents intersect at the point $T(0,3)$, then the area (in sq units) of $\triangle P T Q$ is\\
solution:
Tangents are drawn to the hyperbola $4 x^{2}-y^{2}=36$ at the point $P$ and $Q$.

Tangent intersects at point $T(0,3)$

\begin{center}
\includegraphics[max width=\textwidth]{2024_07_10_7aeb41d6126cade54f5ag-08}
\end{center}

Clearly, $P Q$ is chord of contact.

$\therefore$ Equation of $P Q$ is $-3 y=36$

$\Rightarrow \quad y=-12$

Solving the curve $4 x^{2}-y^{2}=36$ and $y=-12$,

we get $\quad x= \pm 3 \sqrt{5}$

Area of $\triangle P Q T=\frac{1}{2} \times P Q \times S T=\frac{1}{2}(6 \sqrt{5} \times 15)=45 \sqrt{5}$

question: If a hyperbola passes through the point $P(\sqrt{2}, \sqrt{3})$ and has foci at $( \pm 2,0)$, then the tangent to this hyperbola at $P$ also passes through the point\\
solution:
Let the equation of hyperbola be $\frac{x^{2}}{a^{2}}-\frac{y^{2}}{b^{2}}=1$.

$$
\begin{array}{lc}
\therefore & a e=2 \Rightarrow a^{2} e^{2}=4 \\
\Rightarrow & a^{2}+b^{2}=4 \Rightarrow b^{2}=4-a^{2} \\
\therefore & \frac{x^{2}}{a^{2}}-\frac{y^{2}}{4-a^{2}}=1
\end{array}
$$

Since, $(\sqrt{2}, \sqrt{3})$ lie on hyperbola.

$$
\begin{array}{rlrl}
\therefore & \frac{2}{a^{2}}-\frac{3}{4-a^{2}} & =1 \\
\Rightarrow & 8-2 a^{2}-3 a^{2} & =a^{2}\left(4-a^{2}\right) \\
\Rightarrow & 8-5 a^{2} & =4 a^{2}-a^{4} \\
\Rightarrow & a^{4}-9 a^{2}+8 & =0 \\
\Rightarrow & & \left(a^{4}-8\right)\left(a^{4}-1\right) & =0 \\
\therefore & a & =1
\end{array}
$$

Now, equation of hyperbola is $\frac{x^{2}}{1}-\frac{y^{2}}{3}=1$.

$\therefore$ Equation of tangent at $(\sqrt{2}, \sqrt{3})$ is given by

$$
\sqrt{2} x-\frac{\sqrt{3} y}{3}=1 \Rightarrow \sqrt{2} x-\frac{y}{\sqrt{3}}=1
$$

which passes through the point $(2 \sqrt{2}, 3 \sqrt{3})$.

question: Let $P(6,3)$ be a point on the hyperbola $\frac{x^{2}}{a^{2}}-\frac{y^{2}}{b^{2}}=1$. If the normal at the point $P$ intersects the $X$-axis at $(9,0)$, then the eccentricity of the hyperbola is\\
If the line $2 x+\sqrt{6} y=2$ touches the hyperbola $x^{2}-2 y^{2}=4$, then the point of contact is\\

Let $P(a \sec \theta, b \tan \theta)$ and $Q(a \sec \varphi, b \tan \varphi)$, where $\theta+\varphi=\frac{\pi}{2}$, be two points on the hyperbola $\frac{x^{2}}{a^{2}}-\frac{y^{2}}{b^{2}}=1$.

If $(h, k)$ is the point of the intersection of the normals at

$P$ and $Q$, then $k$ is equal to\\
solution:
Firstly, we obtain the slope of normal to $\frac{x^{2}}{a^{2}}-\frac{y^{2}}{b^{2}}=1$ at $(a \sec \theta, b \tan \theta)$. On differentiating w.r.t. $x$, we get

$$
\frac{2 x}{a^{2}}-\frac{2 y}{b^{2}} \times \frac{d y}{d x}=0 \Rightarrow \frac{d y}{d x}=\frac{b^{2}}{a^{2}} \frac{x}{y}
$$

Slope for normal at the point ( $a \sec \theta, b \tan \theta$ ) will be

$$
-\frac{a^{2} b \tan \theta}{b^{2} a \sec \theta}=-\frac{a}{b} \sin \theta
$$

$\therefore$ Equation of normal at $(a \sec \theta, b \tan \theta)$ is


\begin{align*}
& y-b \tan \theta=-\frac{a}{b} \sin \theta(x-a \sec \theta) \\
& \Rightarrow \quad(a \sin \theta) x+b y=\left(a^{2}+b^{2}\right) \tan \theta \\
& \Rightarrow \quad a x+b \operatorname{cosec} \theta=\left(a^{2}+b^{2}\right) \sec \theta \tag{i}
\end{align*}


Similarly, equation of normal to $\frac{x^{2}}{a^{2}}-\frac{y^{2}}{b^{2}}=1$ at

$\left(a \sec \varphi, b \tan \varphi\right.$ ) is $a x+b y \operatorname{cosec} \varphi=\left(a^{2}+b^{2}\right) \sec \varphi$

On subtracting Eq. (ii) from Eq. (i), we get

$$
\begin{aligned}
& b(\operatorname{cosec} \theta-\operatorname{cosec} \varphi) y=\left(a^{2}+b^{2}\right)(\sec \theta-\sec \varphi) \\
& \Rightarrow \quad y=\frac{a^{2}+b^{2}}{b} \cdot \frac{\sec \theta-\sec \varphi}{\operatorname{cosec} \theta-\operatorname{cosec} \varphi} \\
& \text { But } \frac{\sec \theta-\sec \varphi}{\operatorname{cosec} \theta-\operatorname{cosec} \varphi}=\frac{\sec \theta-\sec (\pi / 2-\theta)}{\operatorname{cosec} \theta-\operatorname{cosec}(\pi / 2-\theta)} \\
& {[\because \varphi+\theta=\pi / 2]} \\
& =\frac{\sec \theta-\operatorname{cosec} \theta}{\sec \theta-\sec \theta}=-1 \\
& y=-\frac{a^{2}+b^{2}}{b} \text {, i.e. } k=-\frac{a^{2}+b^{2}}{b}
\end{aligned}
$$

question: The line $2 x+y=1$ is tangent to the hyperbola $\frac{x^{2}}{a^{2}}-\frac{y^{2}}{b^{2}}=1$. If this line passes through the point of intersection of the nearest directrix and the $X$-axis, then the eccentricity of the hyperbola is
If $x=9$ is the chord of contact of the hyperbola $x^{2}-y^{2}=9$, then the equation of the corresponding pair of tangents is\\
solution:
Let $(h, k)$ be a point whose chord of contact with respect to hyperbola $x^{2}-y^{2}=9$ is $x=9$.

We know that, chord of contact of $(h, k)$ with respect to hyperbola $x^{2}-y^{2}=9$ is $T=0$.

$$
\begin{array}{rlrl}
\Rightarrow & h \cdot x+k(-y)-9 & =0 \\
\therefore & & h x-k y-9 & =0
\end{array}
$$

But it is the equation of the line $x=9$.

This is possible when $h=1, k=0$ (by comparing both equations).

Again equation of pair of tangents is

$$
\begin{array}{lc} 
& T^{2}=S S_{1} \\
\Rightarrow & (x-9)^{2}=\left(x^{2}-y^{2}-9\right)\left(1^{2}-0^{2}-9\right) \\
\Rightarrow & x^{2}-18 x+81=\left(x^{2}-y^{2}-9\right)(-8) \\
\Rightarrow & x^{2}-18 x+81=-8 x^{2}+8 y^{2}+72 \\
\Rightarrow & 9 x^{2}-8 y^{2}-18 x+9=0
\end{array}
$$

question: If the circle $x^{2}+y^{2}=a^{2}$ intersects the hyperbola $x y=c^{2}$ in four points $P\left(x_{1}, y_{1}\right), Q\left(x_{2}, y_{2}\right), R\left(x_{3}, y_{3}\right), S\left(x_{4}, y_{4}\right)$, then
solution:
It is given that,


\begin{align*}
x^{2}+y^{2} & =a^{2}  \tag{array}\\
x y & =c^{2}  \tag{ii}\\
\text { and } \quad x^{2}+c^{4} / x^{2} & =a^{2} \\
\text { We obtain } \quad x^{4}-a^{2} x^{2}+c^{4} & =0 \tag{iii}
\end{align*}


Now, $x_{1}, x_{2}, x_{3}, x_{4}$ will be roots of Eq. (iii).

Therefore, $\quad \sum x_{1}=x_{1}+x_{2}+x_{3}+x_{4}=0$ and product of the roots $x_{1} x_{2} x_{3} x_{4}=c^{4}$

Similarly, $\quad y_{1}+y_{2}+y_{3}+y_{4}=0$

and $\quad y_{1} y_{2} y_{3} y_{4}=c^{4}$

Hence, all options are correct.

question: The value of $\sin 10^{\circ} \sin 30^{\circ} \sin 50^{\circ} \sin 70^{\circ}$ is\\
solution:
We have, $\sin 10^{\circ} \sin 30^{\circ} \sin 50^{\circ} \sin 70^{\circ}$ $=\sin \left(30^{\circ}\right)\left[\sin \left(10^{\circ}\right) \sin \left(50^{\circ}\right) \sin \left(70^{\circ}\right)\right]$ $=\frac{1}{2}\left[\sin \left(10^{\circ}\right) \sin \left(60^{\circ}-10^{\circ}\right) \sin \left(60^{\circ}+10^{\circ}\right)\right]$

$$
=\frac{1}{2} \frac{1}{4} \sin \left(3\left(10^{\circ}\right)\right)
$$

$$
\left[\because \sin \theta \sin \left(60^{\circ}-\theta\right) \sin \left(60^{\circ}+\theta\right)=\frac{1}{4} \sin 3 \theta\right]
$$

$$
=\frac{1}{8} \sin 30^{\circ}=\frac{1}{8} \times \frac{1}{2}=\frac{1}{16}
$$

question: The value of $\cos ^{2} 10^{\circ}-\cos 10^{\circ} \cos 50^{\circ}+\cos ^{2} 50^{\circ}$ is\\
solution:
We have, $\cos ^{2} 10^{\circ}-\cos 10^{\circ} \cos 50^{\circ}+\cos ^{2} 50^{\circ}$

$$
\begin{aligned}
& =\frac{1}{2}\left[2 \cos ^{2} 10^{\circ}-2 \cos 10^{\circ} \cos 50^{\circ}+2 \cos ^{2} 50^{\circ}\right] \\
& =\frac{1}{2}\left[1+\cos 20^{\circ}-\left(\cos 60^{\circ}+\cos 40^{\circ}\right)+1+\cos 100^{\circ}\right] \\
& {\left[\because 2 \cos ^{2} A=1+\cos 2 A\right. \text { and }} \\
& 2 \cos A \cos B=\cos (A+B)+\cos (A-B)]
\end{aligned}
$$

$$
\begin{aligned}
& =\frac{1}{2} 2+\cos 20^{\circ}+\cos 100^{\circ}-\frac{1}{2}-\cos 40^{\circ} \quad \because \cos 60^{\circ}=\frac{1}{2} \\
& =\frac{1}{2} \frac{3}{2}+\left(\cos 20^{\circ}-\cos 40^{\circ}\right)+\cos 100^{\circ} \\
& =\frac{1}{2} \frac{3}{2}-2 \sin \frac{20^{\circ}+40^{\circ}}{2} \sin \frac{20^{\circ}-40^{\circ}}{2}+\cos 100^{\circ} \\
& \because \cos C-\cos D=-2 \sin \frac{C+D}{2} \sin \frac{C-D}{2} \\
& =\frac{1}{2} \frac{3}{2}-2 \sin 30^{\circ} \sin \left(-10^{\circ}\right)+\cos \left(90^{\circ}+10^{\circ}\right) \\
& =\frac{1}{2} \frac{3}{2}+\sin 10^{\circ}-\sin 10^{\circ} \quad\left[\because \cos \left(90^{\circ}+\theta\right)=-\sin \theta\right] \\
& =\frac{1}{2} \times \frac{3}{2}=\frac{3}{4}
\end{aligned}
$$

question: If the lengths of the sides of a triangle are in AP and the greatest angle is double the smallest, then a ratio of lengths of the sides of this triangle is \\
solution:
Let $a, b$ and $c$ be the lengths of sides of a $\triangle A B C$ such that $a<b<c$.

Since, sides are in AP.


\begin{align*}
& \therefore \quad 2 b=a+c \\
& \text { Let } \quad \angle A=\theta \\
& \text { Then, } \quad \angle C=2 \theta \\
& \text { [according to the question] } \\
& \text { So, } \quad \angle B=\pi-3 \theta \tag{ii}
\end{align*}


On applying sine rule in Eq. (i), we get


\begin{align*}
& \quad 2 \sin B=\sin A+\sin C \\
& \Rightarrow \quad 2 \sin (\pi-3 \theta)=\sin \theta+\sin 2 \theta  \tag{ii}\\
& \Rightarrow 2 \sin 3 \theta=\sin \theta+\sin 2 \theta \\
& \Rightarrow 2\left[3 \sin \theta-4 \sin ^{3} \theta\right]=\sin \theta+2 \sin \theta \cos \theta \\
& \Rightarrow 6-8 \sin ^{2} \theta=1+2 \cos \theta \quad[\because \sin \theta \operatorname{con} n \\
& \Rightarrow 6-8\left(1-\cos ^{2} \theta\right)=1+2 \cos \theta \\
& \Rightarrow \quad 8 \cos ^{2} \theta-2 \cos \theta-3=0 \\
& \Rightarrow(2 \cos \theta+1)(4 \cos \theta-3)=0 \\
& \Rightarrow \cos \theta=\frac{3}{4} \\
& \begin{align*}
& \text { orcos } \theta=-\frac{1}{2} \text { (rejected). } \\
& \text { Clearly, } \operatorname{the} \text { ratio of } \operatorname{sides} \text { is } \alpha: b: c \\
& \quad=\sin \theta: \sin 3 \theta: \sin 2 \theta \\
& \quad=\sin \theta:(3 \sin \theta-4 \sin \theta): 2 \sin \theta \cos \theta \\
& \quad=1:(3-4 \sin 2): 2 \cos \theta \\
& \quad=1:\left(4 \cos ^{2} \theta-1\right): 2 \cos \theta \\
& \quad=1: \frac{5}{4}: \frac{6}{4}=4: 5: 6
\end{align*}
\end{align*}


$[\because \sin \theta$ can not be zero]

question:
If $\cos (\alpha+\beta)=\frac{3}{5}, \sin (\alpha-\beta)=\frac{5}{13}$ and $0<\alpha, \beta<\frac{\pi}{4}$, then $\tan (2 \alpha)$ is equal to
\\
solution:
Given, $\sin (\alpha-\beta)=\frac{5}{13}$

and $\cos (\alpha+\beta)=\frac{3}{5}$, where $\alpha, \beta \in 0, \frac{\pi}{4}$

Since, $0<\alpha<\frac{\pi}{4}$ and $0<\beta<\frac{\pi}{4}$

$$
\begin{array}{ll}
\therefore & 0<\alpha+\beta<\frac{\pi}{4}+\frac{\pi}{4}=\frac{\pi}{2} \\
\Rightarrow & 0<\alpha+\beta<\frac{\pi}{2}
\end{array}
$$

Also, $\quad-\frac{\pi}{4}<-\beta<0$

$\therefore \quad 0-\frac{\pi}{4}<\alpha-\beta<\frac{\pi}{4}+0$

$\Rightarrow \quad-\frac{\pi}{4}<\alpha-\beta<\frac{\pi}{4}$

$\therefore \alpha+\beta \in 0, \frac{\pi}{2}$ and $\alpha-\beta \in-\frac{\pi}{4}, \frac{\pi}{4}$

But $\sin (\alpha-\beta)>0$, therefore $\alpha-\beta \in 0, \frac{\pi}{4}$.

Now, $\quad \sin (\alpha-\beta)=\frac{5}{13}$

$\Rightarrow \quad \tan (\alpha-\beta)=\frac{5}{12}$

and $\quad \cos (\alpha+\beta)=\frac{3}{5}$

$\Rightarrow \quad \tan (\alpha+\beta)=\frac{4}{3}$

Now, $\quad \tan (2 \alpha)=\tan [(\alpha+\beta)+(\alpha-\beta)]$

$$
=\frac{\tan (\alpha+\beta)+\tan (\alpha-\beta)}{1-\tan (\alpha+\beta) \tan (\alpha-\beta)}=\frac{\frac{4}{3}+\frac{5}{12}}{1-\frac{4}{3} \times \frac{5}{12}}
$$

[from Eqs. (i) and (ii)]

$=\frac{48+15}{36-20}=\frac{63}{16}$

question: Let $f_{k}(x)=\frac{1}{k}\left(\sin ^{k} x+\cos ^{k} x\right)$ for $k=1,2,3 \ldots$. Then, for all $x \in R$, the value of $f_{4}(x)-f_{6}(x)$ is equal to\\
solution:
We have,

$$
\begin{aligned}
f_{k}(x) & =\frac{1}{k}\left(\sin ^{k} x+\cos ^{k} x\right), k=1,2,3, \ldots \\
\therefore f_{4}(x) & =\frac{1}{4}\left(\sin ^{4} x+\cos ^{4} x\right) \\
& =\frac{1}{4}\left(\left(\sin ^{2} x+\cos ^{2} x\right)^{2}-2 \sin ^{2} x \cos ^{2} x\right) \\
& =\frac{1}{4} 1-\frac{1}{2}(\sin 2 x)^{2}=\frac{1}{4}-\frac{1}{8} \sin ^{2} 2 x
\end{aligned}
$$

and $f_{6}(x)=\frac{1}{6}\left(\sin ^{6} x+\cos ^{6} x\right)$

$$
=\frac{1}{6}\left\{\left(\sin ^{2} x+\cos ^{2} x\right)^{3}-3 \sin ^{2} x \cos ^{2} x\right.
$$

$$
\left.\left(\sin ^{2} x+\cos ^{2} x\right)\right\}
$$

$=\frac{1}{6} \quad 1-\frac{3}{4}(2 \sin x \cos x)^{2}=\frac{1}{6}-\frac{1}{8} \sin ^{2} 2 x$

Now, $f_{4}(x)-f_{6}(x)=\frac{1}{4}-\frac{1}{6}=\frac{3-2}{12}=\frac{1}{12}$

question: The value of $\cos \frac{\pi}{2^{2}} \cdot \cos \frac{\pi}{2^{3}} \ldots \ldots \cos \frac{\pi}{2^{10}} \cdot \sin \frac{\pi}{2^{10}}$ is\\
solution:
We know that,

$\cos \alpha \cdot \cos (2 \alpha) \cos \left(2^{2} \alpha\right) \ldots \cos \left(2^{n-1} \alpha\right)=\frac{\sin \left(2^{n} \alpha\right)}{2^{n} \sin \alpha}$

$\therefore \cos \frac{\pi}{2^{2}} \cdot \cos \frac{\pi}{2^{3}} \ldots \cos \frac{\pi}{2^{10}} \cdot \sin \frac{\pi}{2^{10}}$

$=\frac{\sin \frac{\pi}{2^{10}} 2^{9}}{2^{9} \sin \frac{\pi}{2^{10}}} \sin \frac{\pi}{2^{10}} \quad\left[\because\right.$ here, $\alpha=\frac{\pi}{2^{10}}$ and $\left.n=9\right]$

$=\frac{1}{2^{9}} \sin \frac{\pi}{2}=\frac{1}{2^{9}}=\frac{1}{512}$

question:
For any $\theta \in \frac{\pi}{4}, \frac{\pi}{2}$, the expression

$3(\sin \theta-\cos \theta)^{4}+6(\sin \theta+\cos \theta)^{2}+4 \sin ^{6} \theta$ equals
solution:
Given expression

$=3(\sin \theta-\cos \theta)^{4}+6(\sin \theta+\cos \theta)^{2}+4 \sin ^{6} \theta$ $=3\left((\sin \theta-\cos \theta)^{2}\right)^{2}+6(\sin \theta+\cos \theta)^{2}+4\left(\sin ^{2} \theta\right)^{3}$ $=3(1-\sin 2 \theta)^{2}+6(1+\sin 2 \theta)+4\left(1-\cos ^{2} \theta\right)^{3}$ $\left[\because 1+\sin 2 \theta=(\cos \theta+\sin \theta)^{2}\right.$ and $\left.1-\sin 2 \theta=(\cos \theta-\sin \theta)^{2}\right]$ $=3\left(1^{2}+\sin ^{2} 2 \theta-2 \sin 2 \theta\right)+6(1+\sin 2 \theta)$

$+4\left(1-\cos ^{6} \theta-3 \cos ^{2} \theta+3 \cos ^{4} \theta\right)$ $\left[\because(a-b)^{2}=a^{2}+b^{2}-2 a b\right.$ and $\left.(a-b)^{3}=a^{3}-b^{3}-3 a^{2} b+3 a b^{2}\right]$

$=3+3 \sin ^{2} 2 \theta-6 \sin 2 \theta+6+6 \sin 2 \theta+4$ $-4 \cos ^{6} \theta-12 \cos ^{2} \theta+12 \cos ^{4} \theta$

$=13+3 \sin ^{2} 2 \theta-4 \cos ^{6} \theta-12 \cos ^{2} \theta+12 \cos ^{4} \theta$

$=13+3(2 \sin \theta \cos \theta)^{2}-4 \cos ^{6} \theta-12 \cos ^{2} \theta\left(1-\cos ^{2} \theta\right)$

$=13+12 \sin ^{2} \theta \cos ^{2} \theta-4 \cos ^{6} \theta-12 \cos ^{2} \theta \sin ^{2} \theta$

$=13-4 \cos ^{6} \theta$

question: The expression $\frac{\tan A}{1-\cot A}+\frac{\cot A}{1-\tan A}$ can be written as\\
solution:
Given expression is

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \frac{\tan A}{1-\cot A}+\frac{\cot A}{1-\tan A} \\
& \quad=\frac{\sin A}{\cos A} \times \frac{\sin A}{\sin A-\cos A}+\frac{\cos A}{\sin A} \times \frac{\cos A}{\cos A-\sin A} \\
& \quad=\frac{1}{\sin A-\cos A} \frac{\sin ^{3} A-\cos ^{3} A}{\cos A \sin A} \\
& \quad=\frac{\sin ^{2} A+\sin A \cos A+\cos ^{2} A}{\sin A \cos A} \\
& \quad=\frac{1+\sin A \cos A}{\sin A \cos A}=1+\sec A \operatorname{cosec} A
\end{aligned}
$$

question: Given both $\theta$ and $\varphi$ are acute angles and $\sin \theta=\frac{1}{2}, \cos \varphi=\frac{1}{3}$, then the value of $\theta+\varphi$ belongs to\\
solution:
Since, $\sin \theta=\frac{1}{2}$

and $\cos \varphi=\frac{1}{3} \Rightarrow \quad \theta=\frac{\pi}{6}$ and $0<\cos \varphi=\frac{1}{3}<\frac{1}{2} \quad$ as $0<\frac{1}{3}<\frac{1}{2}$

$\Rightarrow \theta=\frac{\pi}{6} \quad$ and $\quad \cos ^{-1}(0)>\varphi>\cos ^{-1} \frac{1}{2}$

the sign changed as $\cos x$ is decreasing between $0, \frac{\pi}{2}$

$\Rightarrow \quad \theta=\frac{\pi}{6} \quad$ and $\quad \frac{\pi}{3}<\varphi<\frac{\pi}{2} \quad \Rightarrow \frac{\pi}{2}<\theta+\varphi<\frac{2 \pi}{3}$

$\therefore \quad \theta \in \frac{\pi}{2}, \frac{2 \pi}{3}$

question: Which of the following numbers is rational? $(1998,2 \mathrm{M})$\\
solution:
Since, $\sin 15^{\circ}=\frac{1}{2} \sqrt{2-\sqrt{3}}$ and $\cos 15^{\circ}=\frac{1}{2} \sqrt{2+\sqrt{3}}$ and $\quad \sin 15^{\circ} \cos 75^{\circ}=\sin 15^{\circ} \cdot \sin 15^{\circ}=\frac{1}{4}(2-\sqrt{3})$

Therefore, all these values are irrational and $\sin 15^{\circ} \cos 15^{\circ}=\frac{1}{2} \cdot 2 \sin 15^{\circ} \cos 15^{\circ}$

$$
=\frac{1}{2} \cdot \sin 30^{\circ}=\frac{1}{4} \text {, which is rational. }
$$

question:
$3(\sin x-\cos x)^{4}+6(\sin x+\cos x)^{2}+4\left(\sin ^{6} x+\cos ^{6} x\right)$ equals
\\
solution:
Given expression $=$

$3(\sin x-\cos x)^{4}+6(\sin x+\cos x)^{2}+4\left(\sin ^{6} x+\cos ^{6} x\right)$

$=3(1-\sin 2 x)^{2}+6(1+\sin 2 x)+4\left\{\left(\sin ^{2} x+\cos ^{2} x\right)^{3}\right.$ $\left.-3 \sin ^{2} x \cos ^{2} x\left(\sin ^{2} x+\cos ^{2} x\right)\right\}$

$=3\left(1-2 \sin 2 x+\sin ^{2} 2 x\right)+6+6 \sin 2 x$

$+4\left(1-3 \sin ^{2} x \cos ^{2} x\right)$

$=3\left(1-2 \sin 2 x+\sin ^{2} 2 x+2+2 \sin 2 x\right)+4 \quad 1-\frac{3}{4} \cdot \sin ^{2} 2 x$

$=13+3 \sin ^{2} 2 x-3 \sin ^{2} 2 x=13$

question: The value of the expression $\sqrt{3} \operatorname{cosec} 20^{\circ}-\sec 20^{\circ}$ is equal to
solution:
Given expression $=$

$\sqrt{3} \operatorname{cosec} 20^{\circ}-\sec 20^{\circ}=\tan 60^{\circ} \operatorname{cosec} 20^{\circ}-\sec 20^{\circ}$

$$
\begin{aligned}
& =\frac{\sin 60^{\circ} \cos 20^{\circ}-\cos 60^{\circ} \cdot \sin 20^{\circ}}{\cos 60^{\circ} \cdot \sin 20^{\circ} \cdot \cos 20^{\circ}} \\
& =\frac{\sin \left(60^{\circ}-20^{\circ}\right)}{\cos 60^{\circ} \cdot \sin 20^{\circ} \cdot \cos 20^{\circ}}=\frac{\sin 40^{\circ}}{\frac{1}{2} \cdot \sin 20^{\circ} \cos 20^{\circ}} \\
& =\frac{2 \sin 20^{\circ} \cos 20^{\circ}}{\frac{1}{2} \sin 20^{\circ} \cos 20^{\circ}}=4
\end{aligned}
$$

& \left.+\sin ^{6}(5 \pi-\alpha)\right] \\
& =3\left(\cos ^{4} \alpha+\sin ^{4} \alpha\right)-2\left(\cos ^{6} \alpha+\sin ^{6} \alpha\right) \\

question: If $\alpha+\beta=\frac{\pi}{2}$ and $\beta+\gamma=\alpha$, then $\tan \alpha$ equals \\
solution:
Given, & \alpha+\beta=\pi / 2 \\
\Rightarrow & \alpha=(\pi / 2)-\beta \\
\Rightarrow & \tan \alpha=\tan (\pi / 2-\beta) \\
\Rightarrow & \tan \alpha=\cot \beta \\
\Rightarrow & \tan \alpha \tan \beta=1 \\
\text { Again, } & \beta+\gamma=\alpha \\
\Rightarrow & \gamma=(\alpha-\beta) \\
\Rightarrow & \tan \gamma=\tan (\alpha-\beta) \\
\Rightarrow & \tan \gamma=\frac{\tan \alpha-\tan \beta}{1+\tan \alpha \tan \beta} \\
\Rightarrow & \\
\therefore & \tan \gamma=\frac{\tan \alpha-\tan \beta}{1+1} \\
\Rightarrow & 2 \tan \gamma=\tan \alpha-\tan \beta \\
\Rightarrow & \tan \alpha=\tan \beta+2 \tan \gamma
\end{array}
$$

question:
The maximum value of

$$
 3 \cos \theta+5 \sin \theta-\frac{\pi}{6}
$$

for any real value of $\theta$ is\\
solution:
Given expression $3 \cos \theta+5 \sin \theta-\frac{\pi}{6}$

$$
\begin{aligned}
& =3 \cos \theta+5 \sin \theta \cos \frac{\pi}{6}-\sin \frac{\pi}{6} \cos \theta \\
& =3 \cos \theta+5 \frac{\sqrt{3}}{2} \sin \theta-\frac{1}{2} \cos \theta \\
& =3 \cos \theta-\frac{5}{2} \cos \theta+\frac{5 \sqrt{3}}{2} \sin \theta \\
& =\frac{1}{2} \cos \theta+\frac{5 \sqrt{3}}{2} \sin \theta
\end{aligned}
$$

$\because$ The maximum value of $a \cos \theta+b \sin \theta$ is $\sqrt{a^{2}+b^{2}}$

So, maximum value of $\frac{1}{2} \cos \theta+\frac{5 \sqrt{3}}{2} \sin \theta$ is

$$
=\sqrt{\frac{1}{2}^{2}+\frac{5 \sqrt{3}^{2}}{2}}=\sqrt{\frac{1}{4}+\frac{75}{4}}=\sqrt{\frac{76}{4}}=\sqrt{19}
$$

solution:

question: Let $S=\left\{\theta \in[-2 \pi, 2 \pi]: 2 \cos ^{2} \theta+3 \sin \theta=0\right\}$, then the sum of the elements of $S$ is\\
solution:
We have, $\theta \in[-2 \pi, 2 \pi]$

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \text { and } \quad 2 \cos ^{2} \theta+3 \sin \theta=0 \\
& \Rightarrow \quad 2\left(1-\sin ^{2} \theta\right)+3 \sin \theta=0 \\
& \Rightarrow \quad 2-2 \sin ^{2} \theta+3 \sin \theta=0 \\
& \Rightarrow \quad 2 \sin ^{2} \theta-3 \sin \theta-2=0 \\
& \Rightarrow \quad 2 \sin ^{2} \theta-4 \sin \theta+\sin \theta-2=0 \\
& \Rightarrow 2 \sin \theta(\sin \theta-2)+1(\sin \theta-2)=0 \\
& \Rightarrow \quad(\sin \theta-2)(2 \sin \theta+1)=0 \\
& \therefore \sin \theta=\frac{-1}{2} \quad[\because(\sin \theta-2) \neq 0] \\
& \therefore \theta=2 \pi-\frac{\pi}{6},-\pi+\frac{\pi}{6},-\frac{\pi}{6}, \pi+\frac{\pi}{6}
\end{aligned}
$$

Now, sum of all solutions

$$
=2 \pi-\frac{\pi}{6}-\pi+\frac{\pi}{6}-\frac{\pi}{6}+\pi+\frac{\pi}{6}=2 \pi
$$

question: If $\sin ^{4} \alpha+4 \cos ^{4} \beta+2=4 \sqrt{2} \sin \alpha \cos \beta$; $\alpha, \beta \in[0, \pi]$, then $\cos (\alpha+\beta)-\cos (\alpha-\beta)$ is equal to\\

$$
\frac{\sin ^{4} \alpha+4 \cos ^{4} \beta+2}{4} \geq\left(\left(\sin ^{4} \alpha\right)\left(4 \cos ^{4} \beta\right) \cdot 1 \cdot 1\right)^{1 / 4}
$$

$\Rightarrow \sin ^{4} \alpha+4 \cos ^{4} \beta+2 \geq 4 \sqrt{2} \sin \alpha \cos \beta$

But, it is given that

$$
\sin ^{4} \alpha+4 \cos ^{4} \beta+2=4 \sqrt{2} \sin \alpha \cos \beta
$$

So, $\quad \sin ^{4} \alpha=4 \cos ^{4} \beta=1$

$[\because$ In $\mathrm{AM} \geq \mathrm{GM}$, equality holds when all given

$\Rightarrow \sin \alpha=1$ and $\sin \beta=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}$ positive quantities are equal.]

question: Let $\alpha$ and $\beta$ be the roots of the quadratic equation $x^{2} \sin \theta-x(\sin \theta \cos \theta+1)+\cos \theta=0\left(0<\theta<45^{\circ}\right)$ and $\alpha<\beta$. Then, $\sum_{n=0}^{\infty} \alpha^{n}+\frac{(-1)^{n}}{\beta^{n}}$ is equal to\\
solution:
Given,

$x^{2} \sin \theta-x \sin \theta \cos \theta-x+\cos \theta=0$, where $0<\theta<45^{\circ}$

$\Rightarrow x \sin \theta(x-\cos \theta)-1(x-\cos \theta)=0$

$$
\Rightarrow \quad(x-\cos \theta)(x \sin \theta-1)=0
$$

$$
\Rightarrow \quad x=\cos \theta, x=\operatorname{cosec} \theta
$$

$\Rightarrow \quad \alpha=\cos \theta$ and $\beta=\operatorname{cosec} \theta$

$\left(\because\right.$ For $0<\theta<45^{\circ}, \frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}<\cos \theta<1$ and $\sqrt{2}<\operatorname{cosec} \theta<\infty$ $\Rightarrow \cos \theta<\cos e c \theta$ )

Now, consider, $\sum_{n=0}^{\infty} \alpha^{n}+\frac{(-1)^{n}}{\beta^{n}}=\sum_{n=0}^{\infty} \alpha^{n}+\sum_{n=0}^{\infty} \frac{(-1)^{n}}{\beta^{n}}$ $=\left(1+\alpha+\alpha^{2}+\alpha^{3}+\ldots \infty\right)$ $+1-\frac{1}{\beta}+\frac{1}{\beta^{2}}-\frac{1}{\beta^{3}}+\ldots \infty$

$$
=\frac{1}{1-\alpha}+\frac{1}{1--\frac{1}{\beta}}=\frac{1}{1-\alpha}+\frac{1}{1+\frac{1}{\beta}}
$$


\begin{equation*}
=\frac{1}{1-\cos \theta}+\frac{1}{1+\sin \theta} \tag{1}
\end{equation*}

question: The sum of all values of $\theta \in 0, \frac{\pi}{2}$ satisfying $\sin ^{2} 2 \theta+\cos ^{4} 2 \theta=\frac{3}{4}$ is\\
solution:
Given, $\sin ^{2} 2 \theta+\cos ^{4} 2 \theta=\frac{3}{4}$

$\Rightarrow \quad\left(1-\cos ^{2} 2 \theta\right)+\cos ^{4} 2 \theta=\frac{3}{4} \quad\left(\because \sin ^{2} x=1-\cos ^{2} x\right)$

$\Rightarrow 4 \cos ^{4} 2 \theta-4 \cos ^{2} 2 \theta+1=0$

$\Rightarrow \quad\left(2 \cos ^{2} 2 \theta-1\right)^{2}=0$

$\Rightarrow \quad 2 \cos ^{2} 2 \theta-1=0 \Rightarrow \cos ^{2} 2 \theta=\frac{1}{2}$

$\Rightarrow \quad \cos 2 \theta= \pm \frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}$

If $\theta \in 0, \frac{\pi}{2}$, then $2 \theta \in(0, \pi)$

$\therefore \cos 2 \theta= \pm \frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}$

$\Rightarrow \quad 2 \theta=\frac{\pi}{4}, \frac{3 \pi}{4}$,

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \because \cos \frac{3 \pi}{4}=\cos \pi-\frac{\pi}{4}=-\cos \frac{\pi}{4}=-\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}} \\
& \Rightarrow \quad=\frac{\pi}{8}, \frac{3 \pi}{8}
\end{aligned}
$$

Sum of values of $\theta=\frac{\pi}{8}+\frac{3 \pi}{8}=\frac{\pi}{2}$

question: If $0 \leq x<\frac{\pi}{2}$, then the number of values of $x$ for which $\sin x-\sin 2 x+\sin 3 x=0$, is\\
solution:
We have, $\sin x-\sin 2 x+\sin 3 x=0$

$\Rightarrow(\sin x+\sin 3 x)-\sin 2 x=0$

$$
\begin{aligned}
\Rightarrow 2 \sin & \frac{x+3 x}{2} \cos \frac{x-3 x}{2}-\sin 2 x=0 \\
& {\left[\because \sin C+\sin D=2 \sin \frac{C+D}{2} \cos \frac{C-D}{2}\right] }
\end{aligned}
$$

$\Rightarrow \quad 2 \sin 2 x \cos x-\sin 2 x=0 \quad[\because \cos (-\theta)=\cos \theta]$

$$
\Rightarrow \quad \sin 2 x(2 \cos x-1)=0
$$

$\Rightarrow \sin 2 x=0$ or $2 \cos x-1=0$

$\Rightarrow \quad 2 x=0, \pi, \ldots$ or $\cos x=\frac{1}{2}$

$\Rightarrow \quad x=0, \frac{\pi}{2} \ldots$ or $x=\frac{\pi}{3}$

In the interval $0, \frac{\pi}{2}$ only two values satisfy, namely $x=0$ and $x=\frac{\pi}{3}$.

question:
If sum of all the solutions of the equation

$$
 8 \cos x \cdot \cos \frac{\pi}{6}+x \cdot \cos \frac{\pi}{6}-x-\frac{1}{2}=1
$$

in $[0, \pi]$ is $k \pi$, then $k$ is equal to\\
solution:
Key idea Apply the identity

$\cos (x+y) \cos (x-y)=\cos ^{2} x-\sin ^{2} y$

and $\cos 3 x=4 \cos ^{3} x-3 \cos x$

We have, $8 \cos x \cos \frac{\pi}{6}+x \cos \frac{\pi}{6}-x-\frac{1}{2}=1$

$\Rightarrow 8 \cos x \cos ^{2} \frac{\pi}{6}-\sin ^{2} x-\frac{1}{2}=1$

$\Rightarrow \quad 8 \cos x \frac{3}{4}-\sin ^{2} x-\frac{1}{2}=1$

$\Rightarrow 8 \cos x \frac{3}{4}-\frac{1}{2}-1+\cos ^{2} x=1$

$\Rightarrow \quad 8 \cos x \frac{-3+4 \cos ^{2} x}{4}=1$

$\Rightarrow \quad 2\left(4 \cos ^{3} x-3 \cos x\right)=1$

$\Rightarrow \quad 2 \cos 3 x=1 \Rightarrow \cos 3 x=\frac{1}{2}$

$\Rightarrow \quad 3 x=\frac{\pi}{3}, \frac{5 \pi}{3}, \frac{7 \pi}{3} \quad[0 \leq 3 x \leq 3 \pi]$

$\Rightarrow \quad x=\frac{\pi}{9}, \frac{5 \pi}{9}, \frac{7 \pi}{9}$

Sum $=\frac{\pi}{9}+\frac{5 \pi}{9}+\frac{7 \pi}{9}=\frac{13 \pi}{9} \Rightarrow k \pi=\frac{13 \pi}{9}$

Hence,

$$
k=\frac{13}{9}
$$

question: If $5\left(\tan ^{2} x-\cos ^{2} x\right)=2 \cos 2 x+9$, then the value of $\cos 4 x$ is\\
solution:
Given, $5\left(\tan ^{2} x-\cos ^{2} x\right)=2 \cos 2 x+9$

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \Rightarrow \quad 5 \frac{2 \sin ^{2} x}{2 \cos ^{2} x}-\cos ^{2} x=2 \cos 2 x+9 \\
& \Rightarrow \quad 5 \frac{1-\cos 2 x}{1+\cos 2 x}-\frac{1+\cos 2 x}{2}=2 \cos 2 x+9
\end{aligned}
$$

Put $\cos 2 x=y$, we have

$$
\begin{array}{rlrl} 
& 5 \frac{1-y}{1+y}-\frac{1+y}{2} & =2 y+9 \\
\Rightarrow & 5\left(2-2 y-1-y^{2}-2 y\right) & =2(1+y)(2 y+9) \\
\Rightarrow & 5\left(1-4 y-y^{2}\right) & =2\left(2 y+9+2 y^{2}+9 y\right) \\
\Rightarrow & 5-20 y-5 y^{2} & =22 y+18+4 y^{2} \\
\Rightarrow & 9 y^{2}+42 y+13 & =0 \\
\Rightarrow & 9 y^{2}+3 y+39 y+13 & =0 \\
\Rightarrow & 3 y(3 y+1)+13(3 y+1) & =0 \\
\Rightarrow & & (3 y+1)(3 y+13) & =0 \\
\Rightarrow & & y=-\frac{1}{3},-\frac{13}{3} \\
\therefore & & \cos 2 x=-\frac{1}{3},-\frac{13}{3} \\
\therefore & & \cos 2 x=-\frac{1}{3}
\end{array}
$$

Now,

$$
\cos 4 x=2 \cos ^{2} 2 x-1
$$

$$
=2 \quad-\frac{1}{3}^{2}-1=\frac{2}{9}-1=-\frac{7}{9}
$$

question:
If $0 \leq x<2 \pi$, then the number of real values of $x$, which satisfy the equation

$\cos x+\cos 2 x+\cos 3 x+\cos 4 x=0$, is\\
solution:
Given equation is $\cos x+\cos 2 x+\cos 3 x+\cos 4 x=0$ $\Rightarrow \quad(\cos x+\cos 3 x)+(\cos 2 x+\cos 4 x)=0$

$$
\begin{array}{lc}
\Rightarrow & 2 \cos 2 x \cos x+2 \cos 3 x \cos x=0 \\
\Rightarrow & 2 \cos x(\cos 2 x+\cos 3 x)=0 \\
\Rightarrow & 2 \cos x 2 \cos \frac{5 x}{2} \cos \frac{x}{2}=0 \\
\Rightarrow & \cos x \cdot \cos \frac{5 x}{2} \cdot \cos \frac{x}{2}=0 \\
\Rightarrow & \cos x=0 \\
\text { or } & \cos \frac{5 x}{2}=0 \\
\text { or } & \cos \frac{x}{2}=0 \\
\text { Now, } & \cos x=0 \\
\Rightarrow & x=\frac{\pi}{2}, \frac{3 \pi}{2} \\
\Rightarrow & \frac{\cos }{2} \frac{5 x}{2}=0 \\
\Rightarrow & x=\frac{\pi}{2}, \frac{3 \pi}{2}, \frac{5 \pi}{2}, \frac{7 \pi}{2}, \frac{9 \pi}{2}, \frac{11 \pi}{2} \cdots, \\
\Rightarrow & x=\frac{\pi}{5}, \pi, \frac{7 \pi}{5}, \frac{9 \pi}{5} \quad[\because 0 \leq x<2 \pi] \\
\Rightarrow & {[\because 0 \leq x<2 \pi]}
\end{array}
$$

and

$$
\cos \frac{x}{2}=0
$$

$$
\Rightarrow \quad \frac{x}{2}=\frac{\pi}{2}, \frac{3 \pi}{2}, \frac{5 \pi}{2}, \ldots
$$

$\Rightarrow \quad x=\pi \quad[\because 0 \leq x<2 \pi]$

Hence,

$$
x=\frac{\pi}{2}, \frac{3 \pi}{2}, \pi, \frac{\pi}{5}, \frac{3 \pi}{5}, \frac{7 \pi}{5}, \frac{9 \pi}{5}
$$

question: Let $S=x \in(-\pi, \pi): x \neq 0, \pm \frac{\pi}{2}$. The sum of all distinct solutions of the equation $\sqrt{3} \sec x+\operatorname{cosec} x$ $+2(\tan x-\cot x)=0$ in the set $S$ is equal to\\
solution:
Given, $\sqrt{3} \sec x+\operatorname{cosec} x+2(\tan x-\cot x)=0$,

$(-\pi<x<\pi)-\{0, \pm \pi / 2\}$

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \Rightarrow \quad \sqrt{3} \sin x+\cos x+2\left(\sin ^{2} x-\cos ^{2} x\right)=0 \\
& \Rightarrow \quad \sqrt{3} \sin x+\cos x-2 \cos 2 x=0
\end{aligned}
$$

Multiplying and dividing by $\sqrt{a^{2}+b^{2}}$, i.e. $\sqrt{3+1}=2$, we get

$$
\begin{aligned}
& 2 \frac{\sqrt{3}}{2} \sin x+\frac{1}{2} \cos x-2 \cos 2 x=0 \\
& \Rightarrow \quad \cos x \cdot \cos \frac{\pi}{3}+\sin x \cdot \sin \frac{\pi}{3} \quad-\cos 2 x=0 \\
& \Rightarrow \quad \cos x-\frac{\pi}{3}=\cos 2 x \\
& \therefore \quad 2 x=2 n \pi \pm x-\frac{\pi}{3} \quad \begin{array}{l}
\text { since, } \cos \theta=\cos \alpha \\
\Rightarrow \theta=2 n \pi \pm \alpha
\end{array} \\
& \Rightarrow \quad 2 x=2 n \pi+x-\frac{\pi}{3} \\
& \text { or } \quad 2 x=2 n \pi-x+\frac{\pi}{3} \\
& \Rightarrow \quad x=2 n \pi-\frac{\pi}{3} \text { or } 3 x=2 n \pi+\frac{\pi}{3} \\
& \Rightarrow \quad x=2 n \pi-\frac{\pi}{3} \\
& \text { or } \\
& x=\frac{2 n \pi}{3}+\frac{\pi}{9}
\end{aligned}
$$

\section*{480 Trigonometrical Equations}
$$
\therefore \quad x=\frac{-\pi}{3} \text { or } x=\frac{\pi}{9}, \frac{-5 \pi}{9}, \frac{7 \pi}{9}
$$

Now, sum of all distinct solutions

$$
=\frac{-\pi}{3}+\frac{\pi}{9}-\frac{5 \pi}{9}+\frac{7 \pi}{9}=0
$$

question:
If $P=\{\theta: \sin \theta-\cos \theta=\sqrt{2} \cos \theta\}$ and


$Q=\{\theta: \sin \theta+\cos \theta=\sqrt{2} \sin \theta\}$ be two sets. Then, \\
solution:
$P=\{\theta: \sin \theta-\cos \theta=\sqrt{2} \cos \theta\}$

$\Rightarrow \cos \theta(\sqrt{2}+1)=\sin \theta$

$\Rightarrow \tan \theta=\sqrt{2}+1$

$\Rightarrow Q=\{\theta: \sin \theta+\cos \theta\}=\sqrt{2} \sin \theta$

$\Rightarrow \sin \theta(\sqrt{2}-1)=\cos \theta$

$\Rightarrow \quad \tan \theta=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}-1} \times \frac{\sqrt{2}+1}{\sqrt{2}+1}=(\sqrt{2}+1)$

$\therefore \quad P=Q$

question: Let $n$ be an odd integer. If $\sin n \theta=\sum_{r=0}^{n} b_{r} \sin ^{r} \theta$, for every value of $\theta$, then\\
The general value of $\theta$ satisfying the equation $2 \sin ^{2} \theta-3 \sin \theta-2=0$, is\\
solution:
Given, $2 \sin ^{2} \theta-3 \sin \theta-2=0$

$$
\begin{array}{cc}
\Rightarrow & (2 \sin \theta+1)(\sin \theta-2)=0 \\
\Rightarrow & \sin \theta=-1 / 2 \\
& {[\text { neglecting } \sin \theta=2, \text { as }|\sin \theta| \leq 1]} \\
\therefore & \theta=n \pi+(-1)^{n}(7 \pi / 6)
\end{array}
$$

question: In a $\triangle A B C$, angle $A$ is greater than angle $B$. If the measures of angles $A$ and $B$ satisfy the equation $3 \sin x-4 \sin ^{3} x-k=0,0<k<1$, then the measure of $\angle C$ is\\
solution:
Given, $3 \sin x-4 \sin ^{3} x=k, 0<k<1$ which can also be written as $\sin 3 x=k$.

It is given that $A$ and $B$ are solutions of this equation. Therefore,

$$
\begin{array}{lrl} 
& \sin 3 A=k \text { and } \sin 3 B=k, \text { where } 0<k<1 \\
\Rightarrow & 0<3 A<\pi \text { and } 0<3 B<\pi \\
\text { Now, } & \sin 3 A=k \text { and } \sin 3 B=k \\
\Rightarrow & & \sin 3 A-\sin 3 B=0 \\
\Rightarrow & 2 \cos \frac{3}{2}(A+B) \sin \frac{3}{2}(A-B)=0
\end{array}
$$

$\Rightarrow \quad \cos 3 \frac{A+B}{2}=0, \sin 3 \frac{A-B}{2}=0$

But it is given that, $A>B$ and $0<3 A<\pi, 0<3 B<\pi$.

Therefore, $\sin 3 \frac{A-B}{2} \neq 0$

Hence, $\cos 3 \frac{A+B}{2}=0$

$$
\begin{aligned}
\Rightarrow & 3 \frac{A+B}{2} & =\frac{\pi}{2} \\
\Rightarrow & A+B & =\frac{\pi}{3} \\
\Rightarrow & C & =\pi-(A+B)=\frac{2 \pi}{3}
\end{aligned}
$$

question: The general solution of $\sin x-3 \sin 2 x+\sin 3 x=\cos x-3 \cos 2 x+\cos 3 x$ is\\
The general solution of the trigonometric equation $\sin x+\cos x=1$ is given by
solution:
Given, $\sin x+\cos x=1$

On dividing and multiplying each terms by $\sqrt{2}$, we get

$$
\begin{array}{ll} 
& \frac{1}{\sqrt{2}} \sin x+\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}} \cos x=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}} \\
\Rightarrow & \sin x \cos \frac{\pi}{4}=\cos x \sin \frac{\pi}{4}=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}} \\
\Rightarrow & \sin x+\frac{\pi}{4}=\sin \frac{\pi}{4} \\
\Rightarrow & x+\frac{\pi}{4}=n \pi+(-1)^{n} \frac{\pi}{4} \\
\Rightarrow & x=n \pi+(-1)^{n} \frac{\pi}{4}-\frac{\pi}{4}, n \in I
\end{array}
$$

question: The equation $2 \cos ^{2} \frac{x}{2} \sin ^{2} x=x^{2}+x^{-2}, x \leq \frac{\pi}{9}$ has
options: c) more than one real solution
solution:
Given equation is $2 \cos ^{2} \frac{x}{2} \sin ^{2} x=x^{2}+x^{-2}, x \leq \frac{\pi}{9}$

LHS $=2 \cos ^{2} \frac{x}{2} \sin ^{2} x<2$ and RHS $=x^{2}+\frac{1}{x^{2}} \geq 2$

$\therefore$ The equation has no real solution.

question: The number of distinct solutions of the equation $\frac{5}{4} \cos ^{2} 2 x+\cos ^{4} x+\sin ^{4} x+\cos ^{6} x+\sin ^{6} x=2 \quad$ in the interval $[0,2 \pi]$ is
solution:
Here, $\frac{5}{4} \cos ^{2} 2 x+\left(\cos ^{4} x+\sin ^{4} x\right)+\left(\cos ^{6} x+\sin ^{6} x\right)=2$ $\Rightarrow \quad \frac{5}{4} \cot 2 x+\left[\left(\cos ^{2} x+\sin ^{2} x\right)^{2}-2 \sin ^{2} x \cos ^{2} x\right]$ $+\left(\cos ^{2} x+\sin ^{2} x\right)\left[\left(\cos ^{2} x+\sin ^{2} x\right)^{2}-3 \sin ^{2} x \cos ^{2} x\right]=2$ $\Rightarrow \frac{5}{4} \cos ^{2} 2 x+\left(1-2 \sin ^{2} x \cos ^{2} x\right)+\left(1-3 \cos ^{2} x \sin ^{2} x\right)=2$

$$
\Rightarrow \quad \frac{5}{4} \cos ^{2} 2 x-5 \sin ^{2} x \cos ^{2} x=0
$$

$$
\begin{array}{lc}
\Rightarrow & \frac{5}{4} \cos ^{2} 2 x-\frac{5}{4} \sin ^{2} 2 x=0 \\
\Rightarrow & \frac{5}{4} \cos ^{2} 2 x-\frac{5}{4}+\frac{5}{4} \cos ^{2} 2 x=0 \\
\Rightarrow & \frac{5}{2} \cos ^{2} 2 x=\frac{5}{4} \Rightarrow \cos ^{2} 2 x=\frac{1}{2} \\
\Rightarrow & 2 \cos ^{2} 2 x=1 \\
\Rightarrow & 1+\cos 4 x=1 \\
\Rightarrow & \cos 4 x=0 \text { as } 0 \leq x \leq 2 \pi \\
\therefore & 4 x=\frac{\pi}{2}, \frac{3 \pi}{2}, \frac{5 \pi}{2}, \frac{7 \pi}{2}, \frac{9 \pi}{2}, \frac{11 \pi}{2}, \frac{13 \pi}{2}, \frac{15 \pi}{2} \\
\text { as } & 0 \leq 4 x \leq 8 \pi \\
\Rightarrow & x=\frac{\pi}{8}, \frac{3 \pi}{8}, \frac{5 \pi}{8}, \frac{7 \pi}{8}, \frac{9 \pi}{8}, \frac{11 \pi}{8}, \frac{13 \pi}{8}, \frac{15 \pi}{8}
\end{array}
$$

Hence, the total number of solutions is 8 .

question: All $x$ satisfying the inequality $\left(\cot ^{-1} x\right)^{2}-7\left(\cot ^{-1} x\right)+10>0$, lie in the interval

$\cot ^{-1} x \in(0,2)$

question: The set of values of $\theta$ satisfying the inequation $2 \sin ^{2} \theta-5 \sin \theta+2>0$, where $0<\theta<2 \pi$, is
solution:
Since, $2 \sin ^{2} \theta-5 \sin \theta+2>0$

$$
\Rightarrow \quad(2 \sin \theta-1)(\sin \theta-2)>0
$$

[where, $(\sin \theta-2)<0, \forall \theta \in R$ ]

$$
\therefore \quad(2 \sin \theta-1)<0
$$

$\Rightarrow \quad \sin \theta<\frac{1}{2}$

question: For $x \in(0, \pi)$, the equation $\sin x+2 \sin 2 x-\sin 3 x=3$ has
solution:
PLAN For solving this type of questions, obtain the LHS and RHS in equation and examine, the two are equal or not for a given interval.

Given, trigonometrical equation

$$
(\sin x-\sin 3 x)+2 \sin 2 x=3
$$

$\Rightarrow-2 \cos 2 x \sin x+4 \sin x \cos x=3$

$$
\begin{gathered}
{\left[\because \sin C-\sin D=2 \cos \frac{C+D}{2} \sin \frac{C-D}{2}\right. \text { and }} \\
\Rightarrow \quad 2 \sin 2 \theta=2 \sin \theta \cos \theta] \\
\Rightarrow \quad 2 \sin x\left(2 \cos x-2 \cos ^{2} x+1\right)=3 \\
\Rightarrow \quad 2 \sin x \frac{3}{2}-2 \cos x-\frac{1}{2}^{2}=3 \\
\Rightarrow \quad 3 \sin x-3=4 \cos x-\frac{1}{2} \sin x
\end{gathered}
$$

As $x \in(0, \pi) \quad$ LHS $\leq 0$ and RHS $\geq 0$

For solution to exist, $\mathrm{LHS}=\mathrm{RHS}=0$

Now, LHS $=0$

$$
\begin{aligned}
\Rightarrow & 3 \sin x-3 & =0 \\
\Rightarrow & \sin x & =1 \\
\Rightarrow & x & =\frac{\pi}{2}
\end{aligned}
$$

For

$$
x=\frac{\pi}{2}
$$

$\mathrm{RHS}=4 \quad \cos \frac{\pi}{2}-\frac{1}{2}^{2} \quad \sin \frac{\pi}{2}=4 \frac{1}{4} \quad$ (1) $=1 \neq 0$

$\therefore$ No solution of the equation exists.

question: The number of solutions of the pair of equations $2 \sin ^{2} \theta-\cos 2 \theta=0$ and $2 \cos ^{2} \theta-3 \sin \theta=0 \quad$ in the interval $[0,2 \pi]$ is\\
solution:
$2 \sin ^{2} \theta-\cos 2 \theta=0$

$\Rightarrow \quad \sin ^{2} \theta=\frac{1}{4}$

Also, $2 \cos ^{2} \theta=3 \sin \theta$

$\therefore \quad \sin \theta=\frac{1}{2}$

$[\because \sin \theta+2 \neq 0]$

$\Rightarrow$ Two solutions exist in the interval $[0,2 \pi]$.

question: The number of integral values of $k$ for which the equation $7 \cos x+5 \sin x=2 k+1$ has a solution, is\\
solution:
We know that,

$$
\begin{array}{llrl} 
& -\sqrt{a^{2}+b^{2}} & \leq a \sin x+b \cos x \leq \sqrt{a^{2}+b^{2}} \\
\therefore & & -\sqrt{74} & \leq 7 \cos x+5 \sin x \leq \sqrt{74} \\
\text { i.e. } & & -\sqrt{74} \leq 2 k+1 \leq \sqrt{74}
\end{array}
$$

Since, $k$ is integer, $-9<2 k+1<9$

$\Rightarrow-10<2 k<8 \quad \Rightarrow \quad-5<k<4$

$\Rightarrow$ Number of possible integer values of $k=8$.

question: The number of values of $x$ in the interval $[0,5 \pi]$ satisfying the equation $3 \sin ^{2} x-7 \sin x+2=0$ is\\
solution:
Given, $3 \sin ^{2} x-7 \sin x+2=0$

$\Rightarrow \quad 3 \sin ^{2} x-6 \sin x-\sin x+2=0$

$\Rightarrow \quad 3 \sin x(\sin x-2)-1(\sin x-2)=0$

$\Rightarrow \quad(3 \sin x-1)(\sin x-2)=0$

$\Rightarrow \quad \sin x=\frac{1}{3} \quad[\because \sin x=2$ is rejected $]$

$$
\Rightarrow \quad x=n \pi+(-1)^{n} \sin ^{-1} \frac{1}{3}, n \in I
$$

For $0 \leq n \leq 5, x \in[0,5 \pi]$

There are six values of $x \in[0,5 \pi]$ which satisfy the equation $3 \sin ^{2} x-7 \sin x+2=0$.

question: Number of solutions of the equation $\tan x+\sec x=2 \cos x$ lying in the interval $[0,2 \pi]$ is\\
solution:
$\tan x+\sec x=2 \cos x, x \notin(2 n+1) \frac{\pi}{2}$

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \Rightarrow \quad \sin x+1=2 \cos ^{2} x \\
& \Rightarrow \quad \sin x+1=2\left(1-\sin ^{2} x\right) \\
& \Rightarrow \quad 2 \sin ^{2} x+\sin x-1=0 \\
& \Rightarrow \quad(2 \sin x-1)(\sin x+1)=0 \\
& \Rightarrow \quad \sin x=\frac{1}{2}, \sin x=-1 \\
& \Rightarrow \quad x=\frac{\pi}{6}, \frac{5 \pi}{6} \\
& \text { or } \quad x=\frac{3 \pi}{2} \\
& \text { but } \quad x \notin(2 n+1) \frac{\pi}{2} \\
& \therefore \quad x=\frac{\pi}{6}, \frac{5 \pi}{6}
\end{aligned}
$$

Hence, number of solutions are two.

question: The number of solutions of the equation $\sin \left(e^{x}\right)=5^{x}+5^{-x}$ is\\
The equation $(\cos p-1) x^{2}+(\cos p) x+\sin p=0$ in the variable $x$, has real roots. Then, $p$ can take any value in the interval\\
solution:
Since, the given quadratic equation

$$
(\cos p-1) x^{2}+(\cos p) x+\sin p=0
$$

has real roots.

$\therefore$ Discriminant, $\cos ^{2} p-4 \sin p(\cos p-1) \geq 0$

$$
\Rightarrow \quad(\cos p-2 \sin p)^{2}-4 \sin ^{2} p+4 \sin p \geq 0
$$

$$
\begin{array}{lr}
\Rightarrow & (\cos p-2 \sin p)^{2}+4 \sin p(1-\sin p) \geq 0 \\
\because & 4 \sin p(1-\sin p)>0 \text { for } 0<p<\pi \\
\text { and } & (\cos p-2 \sin p)^{2} \geq 0
\end{array}
$$

Thus, $(\cos p-2 \sin p)^{2}+4 \sin p(1-\sin p) \geq 0$

for $0<p<\pi$.

Hence, the equation has real roots for $0<p<\pi$.

question: The smallest positive root of the equation $\tan x-x=0$ lies in\\
solution:
Let $f(x)=\tan x-x$

We know, for $0<x<\frac{\pi}{2}$

$$
\Rightarrow \quad \tan x>x
$$

$$
\therefore \quad f(x)=\tan x-x \text { has no root in }(0, \pi / 2)
$$

For $\pi / 2<x<\pi, \tan x$ is negative.

$$
\begin{array}{ll}
\therefore & f(x)=\tan x-x<0 \\
\text { So, } & f(x)=0 \text { has no root in } \frac{\pi}{2}, \pi \\
\text { For } & \frac{3 \pi}{2}<x<2 \pi, \tan x \text { is negative. } \\
\therefore & f(x)=\tan x-x<0
\end{array}
$$

So, $\quad f(x)=0$ has no root in $\frac{3 \pi}{2}, 2 \pi$.

We have, $f(\pi)=0-\pi<0$

and $\quad f \frac{3 \pi}{2}=\tan \frac{3 \pi}{2}-\frac{3 \pi}{2}>0$

$\therefore f(x)=0$ has at least one root between $\pi$ and $\frac{3 \pi}{2}$.

question: The number of all possible triplets $\left(a_{1}, a_{2}, a_{3}\right)$ such that $a_{1}+a_{2} \cos (2 x)+a_{3} \sin ^{2}(x)=0, \forall x$ is\\
solution:
Given,

$a_{1}+a_{2} \cos 2 x+a_{3} \sin ^{2} x=0, \forall x$

$\Rightarrow a_{1}+a_{2} \cos 2 x+a_{3} \frac{1-\cos 2 x}{2}=0, \forall x$

$\Rightarrow \quad a_{1}+\frac{a_{3}}{2}+a_{2}-\frac{a_{3}}{2} \cos 2 x=0, \forall x$

$\Rightarrow \quad a_{1}+\frac{a_{3}}{2}=0 \quad$ and $\quad a_{2}-\frac{a_{3}}{2}=0$

$\Rightarrow \quad a_{1}=-\frac{k}{2}, a_{2}=\frac{k}{2}, a_{3}=k$, where $k \in R$

Hence, the solutions, are $-\frac{k}{2}, \frac{k}{2}, k$, where $k$ is any real number.

Thus, the number of triplets is infinite.\\

question: The positive integer value of $n>3$ satisfying the equation $\frac{1}{\sin \frac{\pi}{n}}=\frac{1}{\sin \frac{2 \pi}{n}}+\frac{1}{\sin \frac{3 \pi}{n}}$ is .....
solution:
Given, $n>3 \in$ Integer

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \text { and } \frac{1}{\sin \frac{\pi}{n}}=\frac{1}{\sin \frac{2 \pi}{n}}+\frac{1}{\sin \frac{3 \pi}{n}} \\
& \Rightarrow \quad \frac{1}{\sin \frac{\pi}{n}}-\frac{1}{\sin \frac{3 \pi}{n}}=\frac{1}{\sin \frac{2 \pi}{n}}
\end{aligned}
$$

$$
\begin{array}{rlrl}
\Rightarrow & \frac{\sin \frac{3 \pi}{n}-\sin \frac{\pi}{n}}{\sin \frac{\pi}{n} \cdot \sin \frac{3 \pi}{n}}=\frac{1}{\sin \frac{2 \pi}{n}} \\
\Rightarrow & 2 \cos \frac{2 \pi}{n} \cdot \sin \frac{\pi}{n} & =\frac{\sin \frac{\pi}{n} \cdot \sin \frac{3 \pi}{n}}{\sin \frac{2 \pi}{n}} \\
\Rightarrow & & 2 \sin \frac{2 \pi}{n} \cdot \cos \frac{2 \pi}{n} & =\sin \frac{3 \pi}{n} \\
\Rightarrow & & \sin \frac{4 \pi}{n} & =\sin \frac{3 \pi}{n} \\
\Rightarrow & \frac{4 \pi}{n} & =\pi-\frac{3 \pi}{n} \\
\Rightarrow & & =\pi \Rightarrow n=7
\end{array}
$$

question: The number of values of $\theta$ in the interval $-\frac{\pi}{2}, \frac{\pi}{2}$ such that $\theta \neq \frac{n \pi}{5}$ for $n=0, \pm 1, \pm 2$ and $\tan \theta=\cot 5 \theta$ as well as $\sin 2 \theta=\cos 4 \theta$ is.
solution:
Given, $\tan \theta=\cot 5 \theta$

$$
\begin{aligned}
\Rightarrow & \tan \theta & =\tan \frac{\pi}{2}-5 \theta \\
\Rightarrow & \frac{\pi}{2}-5 \theta & =n \pi+\theta \\
\Rightarrow & 6 \theta & =\frac{\pi}{2}-n \pi \\
\Rightarrow & \theta & =\frac{\pi}{12}-\frac{n \pi}{6}
\end{aligned}
$$

Also, $\cos 4 \theta=\sin 2 \theta=\cos \frac{\pi}{2}-2 \theta$

$$
\Rightarrow \quad 4 \theta=2 n \pi \pm \frac{\pi}{2}-2 \theta
$$

Taking positive sign,

$$
\begin{aligned}
& 6 \theta=2 n \pi+\frac{\pi}{2} \\
& \Rightarrow \quad \theta=\frac{n \pi}{3}+\frac{\pi}{12}
\end{aligned}
$$

Taking negative sign,

$$
2 \theta=2 n \pi-\frac{\pi}{2} \Rightarrow \theta=n \pi-\frac{\pi}{4}
$$

Above values of $\theta$ suggest that there are only 3 common solutions.

Given function is

$$
\tan ^{-1} \sqrt{x(x+1)}+\sin ^{-1} \sqrt{x^{2}+x+1}=\frac{\pi}{2}
$$

Function is defined, if

(i) $x(x+1) \geq 0$, since domain of square root function.

(ii) $x^{2}+x+1 \geq 0$, since domain of square root function.

(iii) $\sqrt{x^{2}+x+1} \leq 1$, since domain of $\sin ^{-1}$ function

From (ii) and (iii), $0 \leq x^{2}+x+1 \leq 1 \cap x^{2}+x \geq 0$

$$
\begin{array}{lc}
\Rightarrow & 0 \leq x^{2}+x+1 \leq 1 \cap x^{2}+x+1 \geq 1 \\
\Rightarrow & x^{2}+x+1=1 \\
\Rightarrow & x^{2}+x=0 \\
\Rightarrow & x(x+1)=0 \\
\Rightarrow & x=0, x=-1
\end{array}
$$

The value of $\sin ^{-1} \frac{12}{13}-\sin ^{-1} \frac{3}{5}$ is equal to
solution:

We have,

$$

if $x^{2}+y^{2} \leq 1$ or if $x y>0$ and $\left.x^{2}+y^{2}>1 \forall x, y \in[-1,1]\right]$

question: If $\cos ^{-1} x-\cos ^{-1} \frac{y}{2}=\alpha$, where $-1 \leq x \leq 1, \quad-2 \leq y \leq 2$, $x \leq \frac{y}{2}$, then for all $x, y, 4 x^{2}-4 x y \cos \alpha+y^{2}$ is equal to
solution:
Given equation is

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \cos ^{-1} x-\cos ^{-1} \frac{y}{2}=\alpha, \text { where }-1 \leq x \leq 1 \\
& -2 \leq y \leq 2 \text { and } x \leq \frac{y}{2}
\end{aligned} \begin{gathered}
{\left[\because \cos ^{-1} x-\cos ^{-1} y=\cos ^{-1}\left(x y+\sqrt{1-x^{2}} \sqrt{\left.1-y^{2}\right)}\right.\right.} \\
\quad x \frac{y}{2}+\sqrt{1-x^{2}} \sqrt{1-(y / 2)^{2}}=\alpha \\
\Rightarrow \frac{x y}{2}+\sqrt{1-x^{2}} \sqrt{1-(y / 2)^{2}}=\cos \alpha \\
\Rightarrow \quad \sqrt{1-x^{2}} \sqrt{1-(y / 2)^{2}}=\cos \alpha-\frac{x y}{2}
\end{gathered}
$$

On squaring both sides, we get

$$
\left(1-x^{2}\right) 1-\frac{y^{2}}{4}=\cos ^{2} \alpha+\frac{x^{2} y^{2}}{4}-2 \frac{x y}{2} \cos \alpha
$$

$\Rightarrow 1-x^{2}-\frac{y^{2}}{4}+\frac{x^{2} y^{2}}{4}=\cos ^{2} \alpha+\frac{x^{2} y^{2}}{4}-x y \cos \alpha$

$\Rightarrow x^{2}+\frac{y^{2}}{4}-x y \cos \alpha=1-\cos ^{2} \alpha$

$\Rightarrow 4 x^{2}-4 x y \cos \alpha+y^{2}=4 \sin ^{2} \alpha$

question: If $\alpha=\cos ^{-1} \frac{3}{5}, \beta=\tan ^{-1} \frac{1}{3}$, where $0<\alpha, \beta<\frac{\pi}{2}$, then $\alpha-\beta$ is equal to\\
Considering only the principal values of inverse functions, the set $A=x \geq 0: \tan ^{-1}(2 x)+\tan ^{-1}(3 x)=\frac{\pi}{4}$
options: c) contains more than two elements
solution:
Given equation is

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \tan ^{-1}(2 x)+\tan ^{-1}(3 x)=\frac{\pi}{4}, x \geq 0 \\
& \Rightarrow \quad \tan ^{-1} \frac{5 x}{1-6 x^{2}}=\frac{\pi}{4}, 6 x^{2}<1 \\
& {\left[\because \tan ^{-1} x+\tan ^{-1} y=\tan ^{-1} \frac{x+y}{1-x y}, x y<1\right]} \\
& \Rightarrow \quad \frac{5 x}{1-6 x^{2}}=1, x^{2}<\frac{1}{6} \\
& \Rightarrow \quad 6 x^{2}+5 x-1=0,0 \leq x<\frac{1}{\sqrt{6}} \quad[\because x \geq 0] \\
& \Rightarrow 6 x^{2}+6 x-x-1=0, \quad 0 \leq x<\frac{1}{\sqrt{6}} \\
& \Rightarrow 6 x(x+1)-1(x+1)=0 \\
& 0 \leq x<\frac{1}{\sqrt{6}}
\end{aligned}
$$

$$
\begin{array}{lll}
\Rightarrow & (6 x-1)(x+1)=0, & 0 \leq x<\frac{1}{\sqrt{6}} \\
\Rightarrow & x=\frac{1}{6},-1, & 0 \leq x<\frac{1}{\sqrt{6}} \\
\Rightarrow & x=\frac{1}{6}, & {\left[\because 0 \leq x<\frac{1}{\sqrt{6}}\right]}
\end{array}
$$

So ' $A$ ' is a singleton set.

$\therefore$ The solution of given differential equation represents a circle with centre on the $X$-axis.

The value of $\cot \sum_{n=1}^{23} \cot ^{-1} 1+\sum_{k=1}^{n} 2 k$ is\\
solution:
We have, cot $\sum_{n=1}^{23} \cot ^{-1} 1+\sum_{k=1}^{n} 2 k$

$\Rightarrow \cot \sum_{n=1}^{23} \cot ^{-1}(1+2+4+6+8+\ldots+2 n)$

$\Rightarrow \cot \sum_{n=1}^{23} \cot ^{-1}\{1+n(n+1)\}$

$\Rightarrow \cot \sum_{n=1}^{23} \tan ^{-1} \frac{1}{1+n(n+1)}$

$\Rightarrow \cot \sum_{n=1}^{23} \tan ^{-1} \frac{(n+1)-n}{1+n(n+1)}$

$\Rightarrow \cot \sum_{n=1}^{23}\left(\tan ^{-1}(n+1)-\tan ^{-1} \ln n\right)$

$\Rightarrow \cot \left[\left(\tan ^{-1} 2-\tan ^{-1} 1\right)+\left(\tan ^{-1} 3-\tan ^{-1} 2\right)\right.$

$$
\left.\left.+\left(\tan ^{-1} 4-\tan ^{-1} 3\right)\right]+\ldots+\left(\tan ^{-1} 24-\tan ^{-1} 23\right)\right]
$$

$\Rightarrow \cot \left(\tan ^{-1} 24-\tan ^{-1} 1\right)$

$\Rightarrow \cot \tan ^{-1} \frac{24-1}{1+24 \cdot(1)}=\cot \tan ^{-1} \frac{23}{25}$

$$
=\text { cot } \cot ^{-1} \frac{25}{23}=\frac{25}{23}
$$

question: If $x, y$ and $z$ are in AP and $\tan ^{-1} x, \tan ^{-1} y$ and $\tan ^{-1} z$ are also in AP, then
solution:
Since, $x, y$ and $z$ are in an AP.

$$
\therefore \quad 2 y=x+z
$$

Also, $\tan ^{-1} x, \tan ^{-1} y$ and $\tan ^{-1} z$ are in an AP.

$$
\begin{aligned}
\therefore & 2 \tan ^{-1} y & =\tan ^{-1} x+\tan ^{-1}(z) \\
& \Rightarrow & \tan ^{-1} \frac{2 y}{1-y^{2}}=\tan ^{-1} \frac{x+z}{1-x z} \\
\Rightarrow & \frac{x+z}{1-y^{2}}=\frac{x+z}{1-x z} & \Rightarrow y^{2}=x z
\end{aligned}
$$

Since $x, y$ and $z$ are in an AP as well as in a GP.

$$
\therefore \quad x=y=z
$$

solution:
We know that, $\frac{a}{\sin A}=\frac{b}{\sin B}=\frac{c}{\sin C}=2 R$ and given that, $a+b=x, a b=y$ and $x^{2}-c^{2}=y$

\begin{center}
\includegraphics[max width=\textwidth]{2024_07_10_ca048dd8a56296afce23g-06(2)}
\end{center}

$\therefore \quad(a+b)^{2}-c^{2}=a b$

$\Rightarrow \quad a^{2}+b^{2}-c^{2}=-2 a b+a b$

$\Rightarrow \quad a^{2}+b^{2}-c^{2}=-a b$

$\Rightarrow \quad \frac{a^{2}+b^{2}-c^{2}}{2 a b}=\frac{-a b}{2 a b}=-\frac{1}{2}$

$\therefore \cos C=-\frac{1}{2} \Rightarrow C=120^{\circ}$

[using cosine rule, $\cos C=\frac{a^{2}+b^{2}-c^{2}}{2 a b}$ ]

Now, $\frac{c}{\sin C}=2 R$

$$

$$

$\therefore \quad R=\frac{c}{\sqrt{3}}$

question: $A B C D$ is a trapezium such that $A B$ and $C D$ are parallel and $B C \perp C D$, if $\angle A D B=\theta, B C=p$ and $C D=q$, then $A B$ is equal to\\

If the angles $A, B$ and $C$ of a triangle are in an arithmetic progression and if $a, b$ and $c$ denote the lengths of the sides opposite to $A, B$ and $C$ respectively, then the value of the expression $\frac{a}{c} \sin 2 C+\frac{c}{a} \sin 2 A$ is\\
In a $\triangle A B C$, among the following which one is true?
solution:
Let $a, b, c$ are the sides of $\triangle A B C$.

Now, $\frac{b+c}{a}=\frac{k(\sin B+\sin C)}{k \sin A} \quad$ [by sine rule]

$$
=\frac{2 \sin \frac{B+C}{2} \cos \frac{B-C}{2}}{2 \sin \frac{A}{2} \cos \frac{A}{2}} \Rightarrow \frac{b+c}{a}=\frac{\cos \frac{B-C}{2}}{\sin \frac{A}{2}}
$$

Also,

$$
\frac{b-c}{a}=\frac{\sin \frac{B-C}{2}}{\cos \frac{A}{2}}
$$

question: If the angles of a triangle are in the ratio $4: 1: 1$, then the ratio of the longest side to the perimeter is\\
In a $\triangle A B C, 2 a c \sin \frac{1}{2}(A-B+C)$ is equal to\\
solution:
We know that, $A+B+C=180^{\circ}$

$\Rightarrow$

$$
A+C-B=180-2 B
$$

Now, $2 a c \sin \frac{1}{2}(A-B+C)=2 a c \sin \left(90^{\circ}-B\right)$

$$
=2 a c \cos B=\frac{2 a c \cdot\left(a^{2}+c^{2}-b^{2}\right)}{2 a c} \quad[\text { by cosine rule }]
$$

$$
=a^{2}+c^{2}-b^{2}
$$

question: In a $\triangle P Q R, \angle R=\frac{\pi}{2}$, if $\tan \frac{P}{2}$ and $\tan \frac{Q}{2}$ are the roots of the equation $a x^{2}+b x+c=0(a \neq 0)$, then\\
solution:
It is given that, $\tan (P / 2)$ and $\tan (Q / 2)$ are the roots of the quadratic equation $a x^{2}+b x+c=0$

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \text { and } \\
& \angle R=\pi / 2 \\
& \therefore \quad \tan (P / 2)+\tan (Q / 2)=-b / a \\
& \text { and } \quad \tan (P / 2) \tan (Q / 2)=c / a \\
& \text { Since, } \quad P+Q+R=180^{\circ} \\
& \Rightarrow \quad P+Q=90^{\circ} \\
& \Rightarrow \quad \frac{P+Q}{2}=45^{\circ} \\
& \Rightarrow \quad \tan \frac{P+Q}{2}=\tan 45^{\circ}
\end{aligned}
$$

$$
\begin{array}{ll}
\Rightarrow & \frac{\tan (P / 2)+\tan (Q / 2)}{1-\tan (P / 2) \tan (Q / 2)}=1 \\
\Rightarrow & \frac{-b / a}{1-c / a}=1 \\
\Rightarrow & \frac{-b / a}{\frac{a-c}{a}}=1 \\
\Rightarrow & \frac{-b}{a-c}=1 \\
\Rightarrow & -b=a-c \\
\Rightarrow & a+b=c
\end{array}
$$

question: In a $\triangle A B C, \angle B=\frac{\pi}{3}$ and $\angle C=\frac{\pi}{4}$. Let $D$ divides $B C$ internally in the ratio $1: 3$, then $\frac{\sin \angle B A D}{\sin \angle C A D}$ is equal to\\
With the usual notation, in $\triangle A B C$, if $\angle A+\angle B=120^{\circ}, a=\sqrt{3}+1$ and $b=\sqrt{3}-1$, then the ratio $\angle A: \angle B$, is\\
solution:
For a $\triangle A B C$, it is given that $a=\sqrt{3}+1$, $b=\sqrt{3}-1$ and $\angle A+\angle B=120^{\circ}$

\begin{center}
\includegraphics[max width=\textwidth]{2024_07_10_ca048dd8a56296afce23g-11}
\end{center}

$$
\text { Clearly, } \quad \angle C=60^{\circ} \quad\left[\because \angle A+\angle B+\angle C=180^{\circ}\right]
$$

Now, by tangent law, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
\tan \frac{A-B}{2} & =\frac{a-b}{a+b} \cot \frac{C}{2} \\
& =\frac{(\sqrt{3}+1)-(\sqrt{3}-1)}{(\sqrt{3}+1)+(\sqrt{3}-1)} \cot \frac{60^{\circ}}{2} \\
& =\frac{2}{2 \sqrt{3}} \cot \left(30^{\circ}\right) \\
& =\frac{1}{\sqrt{3}} \times \sqrt{3}=1 \\
\Rightarrow \quad \tan \frac{A-B}{2} & =1=\tan 45^{\circ} \\
\Rightarrow \quad \frac{A-B}{2} & =45^{\circ} \\
\Rightarrow \quad \angle A-\angle B & =90^{\circ}
\end{aligned}
$$

On solving $\angle A-\angle B=90^{\circ}$ and $\angle A+\angle B=120^{\circ}$, we get $\angle A=105^{\circ}$ and $\angle B=15^{\circ}$

So, $\angle A: \angle B=7: 1$
