solution:
Equation of plane, which contains the line of intersection of the planes


\begin{gather*}
x+y+z-6=0 \text { and } 2 x+3 y+z+5=0, \text { is } \\
(x+y+z-6)+\lambda(2 x+3 y+z+5)=0 \tag{i}
\end{gather*}


$\Rightarrow(1+2 \lambda) x+(1+3 \lambda) y+(1+\lambda) z+(5 \lambda-6)=0$

$\because$ The plane (i) is perpendicular to $X Y$-plane (as DR's of normal to $X Y$-plane is $(0,0,1)$ ).

$\therefore 0(1+2 \lambda)+0(1+3 \lambda)+1(1+\lambda)=0$

$\Rightarrow \quad \lambda=-1$

On substituting $\lambda=-1$ in Eq. (i),

we get


\begin{align*}
& -x-2 y-11=0 \\
& \Rightarrow \quad x+2 y+11=0 \tag{ii}
\end{align*}


which is the required equation of the plane.

Now, the distance of the point $(0,0,256)$ from plane $P$ is

$$
\frac{0+0+11}{\sqrt{1+4}}=\frac{11}{\sqrt{5}}
$$

$\left[\because\right.$ distance of $\left(x_{1}, y_{1}, z_{1}\right)$ from the plane

$$
a x+b y+c z-d=0, \text { is }\left|\frac{a x_{1}+b y_{1}+c z_{1}-d}{\sqrt{a^{2}+b^{2}+c^{2}}}\right|
$$

question: A plane passing through the points $(0,-1,0)$ and $(0,0,1)$ and making an angle $\frac{\pi}{4}$ with the plane $y-z+5=0$, also passes through the point\\
solution:
Let the equation of plane is


\begin{equation*}
a x+b y+c z=d \tag{i}
\end{equation*}


Since plane (i) passes through the points $(0,-1,0)$ and $(0,0,1)$, then $-b=d$ and $c=d$

$\therefore$ Equation of plane becomes $a x-d y+d z=d$\\
$\because$ The plane (ii) makes an angle of $\frac{\pi}{4}$ with the plane $y-z+5=0$.

$\cos \frac{\pi}{4}=\left|\frac{-d-d}{\sqrt{a^{2}+d^{2}+d^{2}} \sqrt{1+1}}\right|$

$[\because$ The angle between the two planes $a_{1} x+b_{1} y+c_{1} z+d=0$ and $a_{2} x+b_{2} y+c_{2} z+d=0$ is

$$
\cos \theta=\left|\frac{a_{1} a_{2}+b_{1} b_{2}+c_{1} c_{2}}{\sqrt{a_{1}^{2}+b_{1}^{2}+c_{1}^{2}} \sqrt{a_{2}^{2}+b_{2}^{2}+c_{2}^{2}}}\right|
$$

$\Rightarrow \frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}=\frac{|-2 d|}{\sqrt{a^{2}+2 d^{2}} \sqrt{2}} \Rightarrow \sqrt{a^{2}+2 d^{2}}=|-d|$

$\Rightarrow a^{2}+2 d^{2}=4 d^{2}$

[squaring both sides]

$\Rightarrow a^{2}=2 d^{2} \Rightarrow a= \pm \sqrt{2} d$

So, the Eq. (ii) becomes


\begin{equation*}
\pm \sqrt{2} x-y+z=1 \tag{i}
\end{equation*}


Now, from options $(\sqrt{2}, 1,4)$ satisfy the plane

$$
-\sqrt{2} x-y+z=1
$$

question: If the line $\frac{x-1}{2}=\frac{y+1}{3}=\frac{z-2}{4}$ meets the plane, $x+2 y+3 z=15$ at a point $P$, then the distance of $P$ from the origin is\\
solution:
Equation of given plane is


\begin{gather*}
x+2 y+3 z=15  \tag{i}\\
\text { and line is, } \frac{x-1}{2}=\frac{y+1}{3}=\frac{z-2}{4}=r \text { (let) } \tag{ii}
\end{gather*}


So, the coordinates of any point on line (ii) is

$P(1+2 r,-1+3 r, 2+4 r)$.

$\because$ Point $P$ is intersecting point of plane (i) and line (ii)

$\therefore(1+2 r)+2(-1+3 r)+3(2+4 r)=15$

$\Rightarrow 1+2 r-2+6 r+6+12 r=15 \Rightarrow 20 r=10$

$\Rightarrow r=\frac{1}{2}$

$\therefore$ Coordinates of $P=1+1,-1+\frac{3}{2}, 2+2=2, \frac{1}{2}, 4$

Now, distance of the point $P$ from the origin

$=\sqrt{4+\frac{1}{4}+16}=\sqrt{20+\frac{1}{4}}=\sqrt{\frac{81}{4}}=\frac{9}{2}$ units

question: The vector equation of the plane through the line of intersection of the planes $x+y+z=1$ and $2 x+3 y+4 z=5$, which is perpendicular to the plane $x-y+z=0$ is\\
solution:
Since, equation of planes passes through the line of intersection of the planes

$$
x+y+z=1
$$

and $2 x+3 y+4 z=5$, is


\begin{equation*}
(x+y+z-1)+\lambda(2 x+3 y+4 z-5)=0 \tag{i}
\end{equation*}


$\Rightarrow(1+2 \lambda) x+(1+3 \lambda) y+(1+4 \lambda) z-(1+5 \lambda)=0$

$\because$ The plane (i) is perpendicular to the plane

$$
x-y+z=0
$$

$\therefore \quad(1+2 \lambda)-(1+3 \lambda)+(1+4 \lambda)=0$

$\left[\because\right.$ if plane $a_{1} x+b_{1} y+c_{1} z+d_{1}=0$ is perpendicular to plane $a_{2} x+b_{2} y+c_{2} z+d_{2}=0$, then $a_{1} a_{2}+b_{1} b_{2}+c_{1} c_{2}=0$ ]


\begin{align*}
\Rightarrow & 3 \lambda+1 & =0 \\
\Rightarrow & \lambda & =-\frac{1}{3} \tag{ii}
\end{align*}


So, the equation of required plane, is

$1-\frac{2}{3} x+1-\frac{3}{3} y+1-\frac{4}{3} z-1-\frac{5}{3}=0$

$\Rightarrow \frac{1}{3} x-\frac{1}{3} z+\frac{2}{3}=0 \Rightarrow x-z+2=0$

Now, vector form, is $\mathbf{r} \cdot(\hat{\mathbf{i}}-\hat{\mathbf{k}})+2=0$

question: The length of the perpendicular from the point $(2,-1,4)$ on the straight line, $\frac{x+3}{10}=\frac{y-2}{-7}=\frac{z}{1}$ is
options: a) greater than 3 but less than 4
c) greater than 2 but less than 3
solution:
Equation of given line is


\begin{equation*}
\frac{x+3}{10}=\frac{y-2}{-7}=\frac{z}{1}=r \text { (let) } \tag{i}
\end{equation*}


Coordinates of a point on line (i) is

$$
A(10 r-3,-7 r+2, r)
$$

Now, let the line joining the points $P(2,-1,4)$ and $A(10 r-3,-7 r+2, r)$ is perpendicular to line (i). Then,

$$
\mathbf{P A} \cdot(10 \hat{\mathbf{i}}-7 \hat{\mathbf{j}}+\hat{\mathbf{k}})=0
$$

$[\because$ vector along line (i) is $(10 \hat{\mathbf{i}}-7 \hat{\mathbf{j}}+\hat{\mathbf{k}})]$

$\Rightarrow[(10 r-5) \hat{\mathbf{i}}+(-7 r+3) \hat{\mathbf{j}}+(r-4) \hat{\mathbf{k}}] \cdot[10 \hat{\mathbf{i}}-7 \hat{\mathbf{j}}+\hat{\mathbf{k}}]=0$

$\Rightarrow 10(10 r-5)-7(3-7 r)+(r-4)=0$

$\Rightarrow 100 r-50-21+49 r+r-4=0$

$\Rightarrow 150 r=75 \Rightarrow r=\frac{1}{2}$

So, the foot of perpendicular is $A 2,-\frac{3}{2}, \frac{1}{2}$

$$
\text { [put } r=\frac{1}{2} \text { in the coordinates of point } A \text { ] }
$$

Now, perpendicular distance of point $P(2,-1,4)$ from the line (i) is

$$
\begin{aligned}
P A & =\sqrt{(2-2)^{2}+-\frac{3}{2}^{2}+\frac{1}{2}^{2}-4^{2}} \\
& =\sqrt{\frac{1}{4}+\frac{49}{4}}=\sqrt{\frac{50}{4}}=\frac{5}{\sqrt{2}}
\end{aligned}
$$

which lies in $(3,4)$.

question: The magnitude of the projection of the vector $2 \hat{\mathbf{i}}+3 \hat{\mathbf{j}}+\hat{\mathbf{k}}$ on the vector perpendicular to the plane containing the vectors $\hat{\mathbf{i}}+\hat{\mathbf{j}}+\hat{\mathbf{k}}$ and $\hat{\mathbf{i}}+2 \hat{\mathbf{j}}+3 \hat{\mathbf{k}}$, is\\
The equation of a plane containing the line of intersection of the planes $2 x-y-4=0$ and $y+2 z-4=0$ and passing through the point $(1,1,0)$ is\\
If an angle between the line, $\frac{x+1}{2}=\frac{y-2}{1}=\frac{z-3}{-2}$ and the plane, $x-2 y-k z=3$ is $\cos ^{-1} \frac{2 \sqrt{2}}{3}$, then value of $k$ is\\

Let $S$ be the set of all real values of $\lambda$ such that a plane passing through the points $\left(-\lambda^{2}, 1,1\right),\left(1,-\lambda^{2}, 1\right)$ and $\left(1,1,-\lambda^{2}\right)$ also passes through the point $(-1,-1,1)$. Then, $S$ is equal to\\
solution:
According to the question points $\left(-\lambda^{2}, 1,1\right),\left(1,-\lambda^{2}, 1\right)$ and $\left(1,1,-\lambda^{2}\right)$ are coplanar with the point $(-1,-1,1)$, so

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \left|\begin{array}{ccc}
1-\lambda^{2} & 2 & 0 \\
2 & 1-\lambda^{2} & 0 \\
2 & 2 & -\lambda^{2}-1
\end{array}\right|=0 \\
& \left.\because \begin{array}{lll}
\because \text { condition of coplanarity is } \\
x_{2}-x_{1} & y_{2}-y_{1} & z_{2}-z_{1} \\
x_{3}-x_{1} & y_{3}-y_{1} & z_{3}-z_{1} \\
x_{4}-x_{1} & y_{4}-y_{1} & z_{4}-z_{1}
\end{array} \right\rvert\,=0 \\
& \Rightarrow \quad\left(-1-\lambda^{2}\right)\left[\left(1-\lambda^{2}\right)^{2}-4\right]=0 \\
& \Rightarrow\left(1+\lambda^{2}\right)\left[\left(1-\lambda^{2}-2\right)\left(1-\lambda^{2}+2\right)\right]=0 \\
& \Rightarrow \quad\left(1+\lambda^{2}\right)^{2}\left(3-\lambda^{2}\right)=0 \\
& \Rightarrow \quad \lambda^{2}=3 \quad\left[\because 1+\lambda^{2} \neq 0 \quad \forall \lambda \in R\right] \\
& \Rightarrow \quad \lambda= \pm \sqrt{3}
\end{aligned}
$$

question:
The perpendicular distance from the origin to the plane containing the two lines, $\frac{x+2}{3}=\frac{y-2}{5}=\frac{z+5}{7}$

and $\frac{x-1}{1}=\frac{y-4}{4}=\frac{z+4}{7}$, is\\
Two lines $\frac{x-3}{1}=\frac{y+1}{3}=\frac{z-6}{-1}$ and $\frac{x+5}{7}=\frac{y-2}{-6}=\frac{z-3}{4}$ intersect at the point $R$. The reflection of $R$ in the $x y$-plane has coordinates\\
solution:
Let $\frac{x-3}{1}=\frac{y+1}{3}=\frac{z-6}{-1}=a$ (say). Then, any point on this line is of the form $P(a+3,3 a-1,-a+6)$

Similarly, any point on the line. $\frac{x+5}{7}=\frac{y-2}{-6}=\frac{z-3}{4}=$ $b$ (say), is of the form $Q(7 b-5,-6 b+2,4 b+3)$

Now, if the lines are intersect, then $P=Q$ for some $a$ and $b$.

$$
\begin{array}{ll}
\Rightarrow & a+3=7 b-5 \\
& 3 a-1=-6 b+2 \\
\text { and } & -a+6=4 b+3 \\
\Rightarrow a-7 b=-8, a+2 b=1 \text { and } a+4 b=3
\end{array}
$$

On solving $a-7 b=-8$ and $a+2 b=1$, we get $b=1$ and $a=-1$,

which also satisfy $a+4 b=3$

$$
\therefore \quad P=Q \equiv(2,-4,7) \quad \text { for } a=-1 \text { and } b=1
$$

Thus, coordinates of point $R$ are $(2,-4,7)$ and reflection of $R$ in $x y$-plane is $(2,-4,-7)$

question: If the point $(2, \alpha, \beta)$ lies on the plane which passes through the points $(3,4,2)$ and (7, 0, 6) and is perpendicular to the plane $2 x-5 y=15$, then $2 \alpha-3 \beta$ is equal to\\
The plane containing the line $\frac{x-3}{2}=\frac{y+2}{-1}=\frac{z-1}{3}$ and also containing its projection on the plane $2 x+3 y-z=5$, contains which one of the following points?\\
solution:
Let the direction vector of the line

$$
\frac{x-3}{2}=\frac{y+2}{-1}=\frac{z-1}{3} \text { is } \mathbf{b}=2 \hat{\mathbf{i}}-\hat{\mathbf{j}}+3 \hat{\mathbf{k}}
$$

Since, the required plane contains this line and its projection along the plane $2 x+3 y-z=5$, it will also contain the normal of the plane $2 x+3 y-z=5$.

\begin{center}
\includegraphics[max width=\textwidth]{2024_07_10_29ca17f5325e4f30e274g-14}
\end{center}

Normal vector of the plane $2 x+3 y-z=5$ is $\mathbf{n}=2 \hat{\mathbf{i}}+3 \hat{\mathbf{j}}-\hat{\mathbf{k}}$.

Now, the required plane contains $\mathbf{b}=2 \hat{\mathbf{i}}-\hat{\mathbf{j}}+3 \hat{\mathbf{k}}$ and $\mathbf{n}=2 \hat{\mathbf{i}}+3 \hat{\mathbf{j}}-\hat{\mathbf{k}}$.

$\therefore$ Normal of the required plane is $\mathbf{b} \times \mathbf{n}$.

Since, the plane contains the line

$\frac{x-3}{2}=\frac{y+2}{-1}=\frac{z-1}{3}$, therefore it also contains the point $\mathbf{a}=3 \hat{\mathbf{i}}-2 \hat{\mathbf{j}}+\hat{\mathbf{k}}$.

Now, the equation of required plane is $(\mathbf{r}-\mathbf{a}) \cdot(\mathbf{b} \times \mathbf{n})=0$

$$
\left|\begin{array}{ccc}
x-3 & y+2 & z-1 \\
2 & -1 & 3 \\
2 & 3 & -1
\end{array}\right|=0
$$

$\Rightarrow(x-3)[1-9]-(y+2)[-2-6]+(z-1)[6+2]=0$

$\Rightarrow-8 x+8 y+8 z+32=0$

$\Rightarrow x-y-z=4$

Note that $(2,0,-2)$ is the only point which satisfy above equation.\\

question: The direction ratios of normal to the plane through the points $(0,-1,0)$ and $(0,0,1)$ and making an angle $\pi / 4$ with the plane $y-z+5=0$ are\\
solution:
Let the equation of plane be

$$
a(x-0)+b(y+1)+c(z-0)=0
$$

$[\because$ Equation of plane passing through a point $\left(x_{1}, y_{1}, z_{1}\right)$ is given by $a\left(x-x_{1}\right)+b\left(y-y_{1}\right)+c\left(z-z_{1}\right)=0$ ] $\Rightarrow a x+b y+c z+b=0$

Since, it also passes through $(0,0,1)$, therefore, we get


\begin{equation*}
c+b=0 \tag{ii}
\end{equation*}


Now, as angle between the planes

$a x+b y+c z+b=0$

and

$$
y-z+5=0 \text { is } \frac{\pi}{4}
$$

$\therefore \cos \frac{\pi}{4}=\frac{\left|\mathbf{n}_{1} \cdot \mathbf{n}_{2}\right|}{\left|\mathbf{n}_{1}\right|\left|\mathbf{n}_{2}\right|} ;$ where $\mathbf{n}_{1}=a \hat{\mathbf{i}}+b \hat{\mathbf{j}}+c \hat{\mathbf{k}}$

$$
\text { and } \quad \mathbf{n}_{2}=0 \hat{\mathbf{i}}+\hat{\mathbf{j}}-\hat{\mathbf{k}}
$$

$$
\begin{aligned}
\Rightarrow \quad \frac{1}{\sqrt{2}} & =\frac{|(a \hat{\mathbf{i}}+b \hat{\mathbf{j}}+c \hat{\mathbf{k}}) \cdot(0 \hat{\mathbf{i}}+\hat{\mathbf{j}}-\hat{\mathbf{k}})|}{\sqrt{a^{2}+b^{2}+c^{2}} \sqrt{0+1+1}} \\
& =\frac{|b-c|}{\sqrt{a^{2}+b^{2}+c^{2}} \sqrt{2}}
\end{aligned}
$$

$\Rightarrow \quad a^{2}+b^{2}+c^{2}=\mid b-c^{2}=(b-c)^{2}=b^{2}+c^{2}-2 b c$

$\Rightarrow \quad a^{2}=-2 b c$

$\Rightarrow \quad a^{2}=2 b^{2}$

[Using Eq. (ii)]

$$
\Rightarrow \quad a= \pm \sqrt{2} b
$$

$\Rightarrow$ Direction ratios $(a, b, c)=( \pm \sqrt{2}, 1,-1)$

So, options (b) and (c) are correct because

$2, \sqrt{2},-\sqrt{2}$ and $\sqrt{2}, 1,-1$. are multiple of each other.

question: The plane which bisects the line segment joining the points $(-3,-3,4)$ and $(3,7,6)$ at right angles, passes through which one of the following points?\\
solution:
Let the given points be $A(-3,-3,4)$ and $B(3,76)$.

Then, mid-point of line joining $A, B$ is

$$
P \frac{-3+3}{2}, \frac{-3+7}{2}, \frac{4+6}{2}=P(0,2,5)
$$

$\because$ The required plane is perpendicular

bisector of line joining $A, B$, so direction ratios of normal to the plane is proportional to the direction ratios of line joining $A, B$.

So, direction ratios of normal to the plane are $6,10,2$.

$[\because$ DR's of $A B$ are $3+3,7+3,6-4$, i.e. 6, 10, 2]

Now, equation of plane is given by

$$
\begin{array}{r}
a\left(x-x_{1}\right)+b\left(y-y_{1}\right)+c\left(z-z_{1}\right)=0 \\
6(x-0)+10(y-2)+2(z-5)=0
\end{array}
$$

$[\because P(0,2,5)$ line on the plane $]$

$$
\Rightarrow \quad 3 x+5 y-10+z-5=0
$$


\begin{equation*}
\Rightarrow \quad 3 x+5 y+z=15 \tag{i}
\end{equation*}


On checking all the options, the option $(4,1,-2)$ satisfy the equation of plane (i).

question: On which of the following lines lies the point of intersection of the line, $\frac{x-4}{2}=\frac{y-5}{2}=\frac{z-3}{1}$ and the plane, $x+y+z=2$ ?\\
solution:
Given equation of line is

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \frac{x-4}{2}=\frac{y-5}{2}=\frac{z-3}{1}=r \text { (let) } \\
& \Rightarrow \quad x=2 r+4 ; y=2 r+5 \text { and } z=r+3
\end{aligned}
$$

$\therefore$ General point on the line (i) is

$$
P(2 r+4,2 r+5, r+3)
$$

So, the point of intersection of line (i) and plane $x+y+z=2$ will be of the form $P(2 r+4,2 r+5, r+3)$ for some $r \in R$.

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \Rightarrow(2 r+4)+(2 r+5)+(r+3)=2 \\
& {[\because \text { the point will lie on the plane }] } \\
& \Rightarrow 5 r=-10 \quad \Rightarrow \quad r=-2
\end{aligned}
$$

So, the point of intersection is $P(0,1,1)$ [putting $r=-2$ in $(2 r+4,2 r+5, r+3)$ ]

Now, on checking the options, we get $\frac{x-1}{1}=\frac{y-3}{2}=\frac{z+4}{-5}$ contain the point $(0,1,1)$

question: The plane passing through the point $(4,-1,2)$ and parallel to the lines $\frac{x+2}{3}=\frac{y-2}{-1}=\frac{z+1}{2}$ and $\frac{x-2}{1}=\frac{y-3}{2}=\frac{z-4}{3}$ also passes through the point\\
solution:
Let a be the position vector of the given point $(4,-1,2)$.

Then, $\mathbf{a}=4 \hat{\mathbf{i}}-\hat{\mathbf{j}}+2 \hat{\mathbf{k}}$

The direction vector of the lines

$$
\frac{x+2}{3}=\frac{y-2}{-1}=\frac{z+1}{2} \text { and } \quad \frac{x-2}{1}=\frac{y-3}{2}=\frac{z-4}{3}
$$

are respectively

$$
\begin{array}{ll} 
& \mathbf{b}_{1}=3 \hat{\mathbf{i}}-\hat{\mathbf{j}}+2 \hat{\mathbf{k}} \\
\text { and } \quad & \mathbf{b}_{2}=\hat{\mathbf{i}}+2 \hat{\mathbf{j}}+3 \hat{\mathbf{k}}
\end{array}
$$

Now, as the plane is parallel to both $\mathbf{b}_{1}$ and $\mathbf{b}_{2}$ $[\because$ plane is parallel to the given lines]

So, normal vector ( $\mathbf{n}$ ) of the plane is perpendicular to both $\mathbf{b}_{1}$ and $\mathbf{b}_{2}$.

$$
\Rightarrow \quad \mathbf{n}=\mathbf{b}_{1} \times \mathbf{b}_{2} \text { and }
$$

Required equation of plane is

$$
\begin{aligned}
& (\mathbf{r}-\mathbf{a}) \cdot \mathbf{n}=0 \\
& \Rightarrow \quad(\mathbf{r}-\mathbf{a}) \cdot\left(\mathbf{b}_{1} \times \mathbf{b}_{2}\right)=0 \\
& \Rightarrow \quad\left|\begin{array}{ccc}
x-4 & y+1 & z-2 \\
3 & -1 & 2 \\
1 & 2 & 3
\end{array}\right|=0 \\
& \because \mathbf{r}-\mathbf{a}=(x \hat{\mathbf{i}}+y \hat{\mathbf{j}}+z \hat{\mathbf{k}})-(4 \hat{\mathbf{i}}-\hat{\mathbf{j}}+2 \hat{\mathbf{k}}) \\
& =(x-4) \hat{\mathbf{i}}+(y+1) \hat{\mathbf{j}}+(z-2) \hat{\mathbf{k}} \\
& =\left|\begin{array}{lll}
a_{1} & a_{2} & a_{3} \\
b_{1} & b_{2} & b_{3} \\
c_{1} & c_{2} & c_{3}
\end{array}\right|
\end{aligned}
$$

$(1,1,1)$ is the only point that satisfies.

question: Let $A$ be a point on the line $\mathbf{r}=(1-3 \mu) \hat{\mathbf{i}}+(\mu-1) \hat{\mathbf{j}}+(2+5 \mu) \hat{\mathbf{k}}$ and $B(3,2,6)$ be a point in the space. Then, the value of $\mu$ for which the vector $\mathbf{A B}$ is parallel to the plane $x-4 y+3 z=1$ is\\

The equation of the plane containing the straight line $\frac{x}{2}=\frac{y}{3}=\frac{z}{4}$ and perpendicular to the plane containing the straight lines $\frac{x}{3}=\frac{y}{4}=\frac{z}{2}$ and $\frac{x}{4}=\frac{y}{2}=\frac{z}{3}$ is\\
solution:
Let $P_{1}$ be the plane containing the lines

$$
\frac{x}{3}=\frac{y}{4}=\frac{z}{2} \text { and } \quad \frac{x}{4}=\frac{y}{2}=\frac{z}{3}
$$

For these two lines, direction vectors are

$$
\mathbf{b}_{1}=3 \hat{\mathbf{i}}+4 \hat{\mathbf{j}}+2 \hat{\mathbf{k}} \text { and } \mathbf{b}_{2}=4 \hat{\mathbf{i}}+2 \hat{\mathbf{j}}+3 \hat{\mathbf{k}}
$$

A vector along the normal to the plane $P_{1}$ is given by

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathbf{n}_{1}=\mathbf{b}_{1} \times \mathbf{b}_{2} & =\left|\begin{array}{ccc}
\hat{\mathbf{i}} & \hat{\mathbf{j}} & \hat{\mathbf{k}} \\
3 & 4 & 2 \\
4 & 2 & 3
\end{array}\right| \\
& =\hat{\mathbf{i}}(12-4)-\hat{\mathbf{j}}(9-8)+\hat{\mathbf{k}}(6-16)=8 \hat{\mathbf{i}}-\hat{\mathbf{j}}-10 \hat{\mathbf{k}}
\end{aligned}
$$

Let $P_{2}$ be the plane containing the line $\frac{x}{2}=\frac{y}{3}=\frac{z}{4}$ and perpendicular to plane $P_{1}$.

For the line $\frac{x}{2}=\frac{y}{3}=\frac{z}{4}$, the direction vector is $\mathbf{b}=2 \hat{\mathbf{i}}+3 \hat{\mathbf{j}}+4 \hat{\mathbf{k}}$ and it passes through the point with position vector $\mathbf{a}=0 \hat{\mathbf{i}}+0 \hat{\mathbf{j}}+0 \hat{\mathbf{k}}$.

$\because P_{2}$ is perpendicular to $P_{1}$, therefore $\mathbf{n}_{1}$ and $\mathbf{b}$ lies along the plane.

Also, $P_{2}$ also passes through the point with position vector a.

$\therefore$ Equation of plane $P_{2}$ is given by

$$
\begin{aligned}
& (\mathbf{r}-\mathbf{a}) \cdot\left(\mathbf{n}_{1} \times \mathbf{b}\right)=0 \Rightarrow\left|\begin{array}{ccc}
x-0 & y-0 & z-0 \\
8 & -1 & -10 \\
2 & 3 & 4
\end{array}\right|=0 \\
& \Rightarrow x(-4+30)-y(32+20)+z(24+2)=0 \\
& \Rightarrow 26 x-52 y+26 z=0 \\
& \Rightarrow \quad x-2 y+z=0
\end{aligned}
$$

question: The plane through the intersection of the planes $x+y+z=1$ and $2 x+3 y-z+4=0$ and parallel to $Y$-axis also passes through the point \\
solution:
Key Idea Equation of plane through the intersection of two planes $P_{1}$ and $P_{2}$ is given by $P_{1}+\lambda P_{2}=0$

The plane through the intersection of the planes $x+y+z-1=0$ and $2 x+3 y-z+4=0$ is given by $(x+y+z-1)+\lambda(2 x+3 y-z+4)=0$, where $\lambda \in R$

$$
\Rightarrow(1+2 \lambda) x+(1+3 \lambda) y+(1-\lambda) z+(4 \lambda-1)=0
$$

where

$\lambda \in R$

Since, this plane is parallel to $Y$-axis, therefore its normal is perpendicular to $Y$-axis.

$$
\begin{array}{lc}
\Rightarrow & \{(1+2 \lambda) \hat{\mathbf{i}}+(1+3 \lambda) \hat{\mathbf{j}}+(1-\lambda) \hat{\mathbf{k}}\} \cdot \hat{\mathbf{j}}=0 \\
\Rightarrow & 1+3 \lambda=0 \Rightarrow \quad \lambda=-\frac{1}{3}
\end{array}
$$

Now, required equation of plane is

$$
1-\frac{2}{3} x+1-\frac{3}{3} y+1+\frac{1}{3} z+-\frac{4}{3}-1=0
$$

$$
\text { [substituting } \lambda=\frac{-1}{3} \text { in Eq. (i)] }
$$

$\Rightarrow x+4 z-7=0$

Here, only $(3,2,1)$ satisfy the above equation.

question:
The equation of the line passing through $(-4,3,1)$, parallel to the plane $x+2 y-z-5=0$ and intersecting the line
 $\frac{x+1}{-3}=\frac{y-3}{2}=\frac{z-2}{-1}$ is\\
solution:
Any point on the line $\frac{x+1}{-3}=\frac{y-3}{2}=\frac{z-2}{-1}$ is of the form $(-3 \lambda-1,2 \lambda+3,-\lambda+2)$

$$
\begin{array}{r}
{\left[\operatorname{take} \frac{x+1}{-3}=\frac{y-3}{2}=\frac{z-2}{-1}=\lambda \Rightarrow x=-3 \lambda-1\right.} \\
y=2 \lambda+3 \text { and } z=-\lambda+2]
\end{array}
$$

So, the coordinates of point of intersection of two lines will be $(-3 \lambda-1,2 \lambda+3,-\lambda+2$ ) for some $\lambda \in R$.

Let the point $A \equiv(-3 \lambda-1,2 \lambda+3,-\lambda+2) \quad$ and $B \equiv(-4,3,1)$

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \text { Then, } \quad \mathbf{A B}=\mathbf{O B}-\mathbf{O A} \\
& =(-4 \hat{\mathbf{i}}+3 \hat{\mathbf{j}}+\hat{\mathbf{k}})-\{(-3 \lambda-1) \hat{\mathbf{i}}+(2 \lambda+3) \hat{\mathbf{j}}+(-\lambda+2) \hat{\mathbf{k}}\} \\
& =(3 \lambda-3) \hat{\mathbf{i}}-2 \lambda \hat{\mathbf{j}}+(\lambda-1) \hat{\mathbf{k}}
\end{aligned}
$$

Now, as the line is parallel to the given plane, therefore AB will be parallel to the given plane and so $\mathbf{A B}$ will be perpendicular to the normal of plane.

$\Rightarrow \mathbf{A B} \cdot \lambda=0$, where $\mathbf{n}=\hat{\mathbf{i}}+2 \hat{\mathbf{j}}-\hat{\mathbf{k}}$ is normal to the plane.

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \Rightarrow((3 \lambda-3) \hat{\mathbf{i}}-2 \lambda \hat{\mathbf{j}}+(\lambda-1) \hat{\mathbf{k}}) \cdot(\hat{\mathbf{i}}+2 \hat{\mathbf{j}}-\hat{\mathbf{k}})=0 \\
& \Rightarrow 3(\lambda-1)-4 \lambda+(-1)(\lambda-1)=0 \\
& \quad\left[\because \text { If } \mathbf{a}=a_{1} \hat{\mathbf{i}}+a_{2} \hat{\mathbf{j}}+a_{3} \hat{\mathbf{k}} \text { and } \mathbf{b}=b_{1} \hat{\mathbf{i}}+b_{2} \hat{\mathbf{j}}+b_{3} \hat{\mathbf{k}}\right.
\end{aligned}
$$

$$
\text { then } \left.\mathbf{a} \cdot \mathbf{b}=a_{1} b_{1}+a_{2} b_{2}+a_{3} b_{3}\right]
$$

$\Rightarrow \quad 3 \lambda-3-4 \lambda-\lambda+1=0$

$$
\Rightarrow \quad-2 \lambda=2 \Rightarrow \lambda=-1
$$

Now, the required equation is the equation of line joining $A(2,1,3)$ and $B(-4,3,1)$, which is

$$
\frac{x-(-4)}{2-(-4)}=\frac{y-3}{1-3}=\frac{z-1}{3-1}
$$

$\left[\because\right.$ Equation of line joining $\left(x_{1}, y_{1}, z_{1}\right)$ and $\left(x_{2}, y_{2}, z_{2}\right)$ is

$$
\begin{array}{ll}
\Rightarrow \quad \frac{x+4}{6}=\frac{y-3}{-2}=\frac{z-1}{2} & \frac{x-x_{1}}{x_{2}-x_{1}}=\frac{y-y_{1}}{y_{2}-y_{1}}=\frac{z-z_{1}}{z_{2}-z_{1}} \\
\text { or } & \frac{x+4}{3}=\frac{y-3}{-1}=\frac{z-1}{1} \quad \text { [multiplying by 2] }
\end{array}
$$

question: If $L_{1}$ is the line of intersection of the planes $2 x-2 y+3 z-2=0, x-y+z+1=0$ and $L_{2}$ is the line of intersection of the planes $x+2 y-z-3=0$, $3 x-y+2 z-1=0$, then the distance of the origin from the plane, containing the lines $L_{1}$ and $L_{2}$ is\\
The length of the projection of the line segment joining the points $(5,-1,4)$ and $(4,-1,3)$ on the plane, $x+y+z=7$ is\\

Let $\mathbf{u}$ be a vector coplanar with the vectors $\mathbf{a}=2 \hat{\mathbf{i}}+3 \hat{\mathbf{j}}-\hat{\mathbf{k}}$ and $\mathbf{b}=\hat{\mathbf{j}}+\hat{\mathbf{k}}$. If $\mathbf{u}$ is perpendicular to $\mathbf{a}$ and $\mathbf{u} \cdot \mathbf{b}=24$, then $|\mathbf{u}|^{2}$ is equal to\\
solution:
Key Idea If any vector x is coplanar with the vector y and z , then $x=\lambda y+\mu z$

Here, $\mathbf{u}$ is coplanar with $\mathbf{a}$ and $\mathbf{b}$.

$$
\therefore \quad \mathbf{u}=\lambda a+\mu \mathbf{b}
$$

Dot product with a, we get


\begin{equation*}
\mathbf{u} \cdot \mathbf{a}=\lambda(\mathbf{a} \cdot \mathbf{a})+\mu(\mathbf{b} \cdot \mathbf{a}) \Rightarrow 0=14 \lambda+2 \mu \tag{i}
\end{equation*}


$$
[\because \mathbf{a}=2 \hat{\mathbf{i}}+3 \hat{\mathbf{j}}-\hat{\mathbf{k}}, \mathbf{b}=\hat{\mathbf{j}}+\hat{\mathbf{k}}, \mathbf{u} \cdot \mathbf{a}=0]
$$

Dot product with $\mathbf{b}$, we get

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \mathbf{u} \cdot \mathbf{b}=\lambda(\mathbf{a} \cdot \mathbf{b})+\mu(\mathbf{b} \cdot \mathbf{b}) \\
& 24=2 \lambda+2 \mu
\end{aligned}
$$

Solving Eqs. (i) and (ii), we get

$$
\lambda=-2, \mu=14
$$

Dot product with $\mathbf{u}$, we get

$$
\begin{aligned}
& |\mathbf{u}|^{2}=\lambda(\mathbf{u} \cdot \mathbf{a})+\mu(\mathbf{u} \cdot \mathbf{b}) \\
& |\mathbf{u}|^{2}=-2(0)+14(24) \Rightarrow|\mathbf{u}|^{2}=336
\end{aligned}
$$

question: If the image of the point $P(1,-2,3)$ in the plane $2 x+3 y-4 z+22=0$ measured parallel to the line $\frac{x}{1}=\frac{y}{4}=\frac{z}{5}$ is $Q$, then $P Q$ is equal to\\

The distance of the point $(1,3,-7)$ from the plane passing through the point $(1,-1,-1)$ having normal perpendicular to both the lines $\frac{x-1}{1}=\frac{y+2}{-2}=\frac{z-4}{3}$ and $\frac{x-2}{2}=\frac{y+1}{-1}=\frac{z+7}{-1}$, is\\
solution:
Given, equations of lines are

$$
\frac{x-1}{1}=\frac{y+2}{-2}=\frac{z-4}{3}
$$

and

$$
\frac{x-2}{2}=\frac{y+1}{-1}=\frac{z+7}{-1}
$$

Let $\mathbf{n}_{1}=\hat{\mathbf{i}}-2 \hat{\mathbf{j}}+3 \hat{\mathbf{k}}$ and $\mathbf{n}_{2}=2 \hat{\mathbf{i}}-\hat{\mathbf{j}}-\hat{\mathbf{k}}$ $\therefore$ Any vector $\mathbf{n}$ perpendicular to both $\mathbf{n}_{1}, \mathbf{n}_{2}$ is given by

$$
\Rightarrow \quad \mathbf{n}=\left|\begin{array}{ccc}
\hat{\mathbf{i}} & \hat{\mathbf{j}} & \hat{\mathbf{k}} \\
1 & -2 & 3 \\
2 & -1 & -1
\end{array}\right|=5 \hat{\mathbf{i}}+7 \hat{\mathbf{j}}+3 \hat{\mathbf{k}}
$$

$\therefore$ Equation of a plane passing through $(1,-1,-1)$ and perpendicular to $\mathbf{n}$ is given by

$$
\begin{array}{rlrl} 
& & 5(x-1)+7(y+1)+3(z+1) & =0 \\
\Rightarrow & 5 x+7 y+3 z+5 & =0
\end{array}
$$

$\therefore$ Required distance $=\left|\frac{5+21-21+5}{\sqrt{5^{2}+7^{2}+3^{2}}}\right|=\frac{10}{\sqrt{83}}$ units

question: The equation of the plane passing through the point $(1,1,1)$ and perpendicular to the planes $2 x+y-2 z=5$ and $3 x-6 y-2 z=7$ is\\
solution:
Let the equation of plane be $a x+b y+c z=1$. Then

$$
\begin{gathered}
a+b+c=1 \\
2 a+b-2 c=0 \\
3 a-6 b-2 c=0 \Rightarrow a=7 b, c=\frac{15 b}{2} \\
b=\frac{2}{31}, a=\frac{14}{31}, c=\frac{15}{31} \\
\therefore 14 x+2 y+15 z=31
\end{gathered}
$$

question: Let $P$ be the image of the point $(3,1,7)$ with respect to the plane $x-y+z=3$. Then, the equation of the plane passing through $P$ and containing the straight line $\frac{x}{1}=\frac{y}{2}=\frac{z}{1}$ is\\
The equation of the plane containing the lines $2 x-5 y+z=3, x+y+4 z=5$ and parallel to the plane $x+3 y+6 z=1$ is\\
The distance of the point $(1,0,2)$ from the point of intersection of the line $\frac{x-2}{3}=\frac{y+1}{4}=\frac{z-2}{12}$ and the plane $x-y+z=16$ is\\
The image of the line $\frac{x-1}{3}=\frac{y-3}{1}=\frac{z-4}{-5}$ in the plane $2 x-y+z+3=0$ is the line\\
solution:
Here, plane, line and its image are parallel to each other. So, find any point on the normal to the plane from which the image line will be passed and then find equation of image line.

Here, plane and line are parallel to each other.

Equation of normal to the plane through the point $(1,3,4)$ is

$$
\frac{x-1}{2}=\frac{y-3}{-1}=\frac{z-4}{1}=k \quad \text { [say] }
$$

Any point in this normal is $(2 k+1,-k+3,4+k)$.

Then, $\quad \frac{2 k+1+1}{2}, \frac{3-k+3}{2}, \frac{4+k+4}{2}$ lies on plane. $\Rightarrow \quad 2(k+1)-\frac{6-k}{2}+\frac{8+k}{2}+3=0 \Rightarrow k=-2$

Hence, point through which this image pass is

$$
(2 k+1,3-k, 4+k)
$$

i.e. $[2(-2)+1,3+2,4-2]=(-3,5,2)$

Hence, equation of image line is $\frac{x+3}{3}=\frac{y-5}{1}=\frac{z-2}{-5}$.

question: Perpendicular are drawn from points on the line $\frac{x+2}{2}=\frac{y+1}{-1}=\frac{z}{3}$ to the plane $x+y+z=3$. The feet of perpendiculars lie on the line\\
solution:
Key Idea To find the foot of perpendiculars and find its locus. Formula used

Footof perpendicular from $\left(x_{1}, y_{1}, z_{1}\right)$ to $a x+b y+c z+d=0$ be $\left(x_{2}, y_{2}, z_{2}\right)$, then

$$
\frac{x_{2}-x_{1}}{a}=\frac{y_{2}-y_{1}}{b}=\frac{z_{2}-z_{1}}{c}=\frac{-\left(a x_{1}+b y_{1}+c z_{1}+d\right)}{a^{2}+b^{2}+c^{2}}
$$

Any point on $\frac{x+2}{2}=\frac{y+1}{-1}=\frac{z}{3}=\lambda$

$$
\Rightarrow \quad x=2 \lambda-2, y=-\lambda-1, z=3 \lambda
$$

Let foot of perpendicular from ( $2 \lambda-2,-\lambda-1,3 \lambda$ )

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \text { to } x+y+z=3 \text { be }\left(x_{2}, y_{2}, z_{2}\right) \text {. } \\
& \therefore \quad \frac{x_{2}-(2 \lambda-2)}{1}=\frac{y_{2}-(-\lambda-1)}{1}=\frac{z_{2}-(3 \lambda)}{1} \\
& =-\frac{(2 \lambda-2-\lambda-1+3 \lambda-3)}{1+1+1} \\
& \Rightarrow \quad x_{2}-2 \lambda+2=y_{2}+\lambda+1=z_{2}-3 \lambda=2-\frac{4 \lambda}{3} \\
& \therefore \quad x_{2}=\frac{2 \lambda}{3}, y_{2}=1-\frac{7 \lambda}{3}, z_{2}=2+\frac{5 \lambda}{3} \\
& \Rightarrow \quad \lambda=\frac{x_{2}-0}{2 / 3}=\frac{y_{2}-1}{-7 / 3}=\frac{z_{2}-2}{5 / 3}
\end{aligned}
$$

Hence, foot of perpendicular lie on

$$
\frac{x}{2 / 3}=\frac{y-1}{-7 / 3}=\frac{z-2}{5 / 3} \Rightarrow \frac{x}{2}=\frac{y-1}{-7}=\frac{z-2}{5}
$$

question: Distance between two parallel planes $2 x+y+2 z=8$ and $4 x+2 y+4 z+5=0$ is\\
solution:
Given planes are

$2 x+y+2 z-8=0$ and $2 x+y+2 z+\frac{5}{2}=0$

$\therefore$ Distance between two planes

$$
=\frac{\left|c_{1}-c_{2}\right|}{\sqrt{a^{2}+b^{2}+c^{2}}}=\left|\frac{-8-\frac{5}{2}}{\sqrt{2^{2}+1^{2}+2^{2}}}\right|=\frac{21 / 2}{3}=\frac{7}{2}
$$

question: The equation of a plane passing through the line of intersection of the planes $x+2 y+3 z=2$ and $x-y+z=3$ and at a distance $2 / \sqrt{3}$ from the point $(3,1,-1)$ is (2012)\\
solution:
Key Idea

(i) Equation of plane through intersection of two planes,

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \text { i.e. }\left(a_{1} x+b_{1} y+c_{1} z+d_{1}\right)+\lambda \\
& \qquad\left(a_{2} x+b_{2} y+c_{2} z+d_{2}\right)=0
\end{aligned}
$$

(ii) Distance of a point $\left(x_{1}, y_{1}, z_{1}\right)$ from

$$
\begin{aligned}
a x+b y+c z+d & =0 \\
& =\frac{\left|a x_{1}+b y_{1}+c z_{1}+d\right|}{\sqrt{a^{2}+b^{2}+c^{2}}}
\end{aligned}
$$

Equation of plane passing through intersection of two planes $x+2 y+3 z=2$ and $x-y+z=3$ is

$$
\begin{gathered}
(x+2 y+3 z-2)+\lambda(x-y+z-3)=0 \\
\Rightarrow(1+\lambda) x+(2-\lambda) y+(3+\lambda) z-(2+3 \lambda)=0
\end{gathered}
$$

whose distance from $(3,1,-1)$ is $\frac{2}{\sqrt{3}}$.

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \Rightarrow \frac{|3(1+\lambda)+1 \cdot(2-\lambda)-1(3+\lambda)-(2+3 \lambda)|}{\sqrt{(1+\lambda)^{2}+(2-\lambda)^{2}+(3+\lambda)^{2}}}=\frac{2}{\sqrt{3}} \\
& \Rightarrow \quad \frac{|-2 \lambda|}{\sqrt{3 \lambda^{2}+4 \lambda+14}}=\frac{2}{\sqrt{3}} \\
& \Rightarrow \quad 3 \lambda^{2}=3 \lambda^{2}+4 \lambda+14 \\
& \Rightarrow \quad \lambda=-\frac{7}{2} \\
& \therefore \quad 1-\frac{7}{2} x+2+\frac{7}{2} y+3-\frac{7}{2} z-2-\frac{21}{2}=0 \\
& \Rightarrow \quad-\frac{5 x}{2}+\frac{11}{2} y-\frac{1}{2} z+\frac{17}{2}=0 \\
& \text { or } \quad 5 x-11 y+z-17=0
\end{aligned}
$$

question:
The point $P$ is the intersection of the straight line joining the points $Q(2,3,5)$ and $R(1,-1,4)$ with the plane $5 x-4 y-z=1$. If $S$ is the foot of the perpendicular drawn from the point $T(2,1,4)$ to $Q R$, then the length of the line segment $P S$ is
\\
solution:
PLAN It is based on two concepts one is intersection of straight line and plane and other is the foot of perpendicular from a point to the straight line

\section*{Description of Situation}
(i) If the straight line

$$
\frac{x-x_{1}}{a}=\frac{y-y_{1}}{b}=\frac{z-z_{1}}{c}=\lambda
$$

\begin{center}
\includegraphics[max width=\textwidth]{2024_07_10_29ca17f5325e4f30e274g-19(2)}
\end{center}

intersects the plane $A x+B y+C z+d=0$.

Then, $\left(a \lambda+x_{1}, b \lambda+y_{1}, c \lambda+z_{1}\right)$ would satisfy

$$
A x+B y+C z+d=0
$$

(ii) If $A$ is the foot of perpendicular from $P$ to $l$. Then, (DR's of $P A$ ) is perpendicular to DR's of $l$.

\begin{center}
\includegraphics[max width=\textwidth]{2024_07_10_29ca17f5325e4f30e274g-19(1)}
\end{center}

$$
\Rightarrow \quad \overline{P A} \cdot \bar{l}=0
$$

Equation of straight line $Q R$, is

$$
\begin{array}{ll} 
& \frac{x-2}{1-2}=\frac{y-3}{-1-3}=\frac{z-5}{4-5} \\
\Rightarrow & \frac{x-2}{-1}=\frac{y-3}{-4}=\frac{z-5}{-1} \\
\Rightarrow & \frac{x-2}{1}=\frac{y-3}{4}=\frac{z-5}{1}=\lambda \ldots(\mathrm{i}) \\
\therefore P(\lambda+2,4 \lambda+3, \lambda+5) \text { must lie on } 5 x-4 y-z=1 . \\
\Rightarrow & 5(\lambda+2)-4(4 \lambda+3)-(\lambda+5)=1 \\
\Rightarrow & 5 \lambda+10-16 \lambda-12-\lambda-5=1 \\
\Rightarrow & -7-12 \lambda=1 \\
\therefore & \lambda=\frac{-2}{3} \\
\text { or } & P \frac{4}{3}, \frac{1}{3}, \frac{13}{3}
\end{array}
$$

Again, we can assume $S$ from Eq.(i),

as $S(\mu+2,4 \mu+3, \mu+5)$

$\therefore$ DR's of $T S=<\mu+2-2,4 \mu+3-1, \mu+5-4>$

$$
=<\mu, 4 \mu+2, \mu+1>
$$

and DR's of $Q R=<1,4,1>$

Since, perpendicular

$\therefore \quad 1(\mu)+4(4 \mu+2)+1(\mu+1)=0$

$\Rightarrow \mu=-\frac{1}{2}$ and $S \frac{3}{2}, 1, \frac{9}{2}$

$\therefore$ Length of $P S=\sqrt{\frac{3}{2}-\frac{4}{3}^{2}+1-\frac{1}{3}^{2}+\frac{9}{2}-\frac{13}{3}^{2}}=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}$

If the truth value of the statement $p \rightarrow(\sim q \vee r)$ is false (F), then the truth values of the statements $p, q$ and $r$ are respectively
\\
solution:
$$

\end{aligned}
$$

Given statement is

$p \rightarrow(\sim q \vee r)=\sim p \vee(\sim q \vee r)$

Now, from the options

(a) When $p=\mathrm{T}, q=\mathrm{T}$ and $r=\mathrm{F}$

then $\sim p \vee(\sim q \vee r)=\mathrm{F} \vee(\mathrm{F} \vee \mathrm{F})=\mathrm{F}$

(b) When $p=\mathrm{T}, q=\mathrm{F}$ and $r=\mathrm{F}$ then $\sim p \vee(\sim q \vee r)=\mathrm{F} \vee(\mathrm{T} \vee \mathrm{F})=\mathrm{T}$

question: The negation of the boolean expression $\sim s \vee(\sim r \wedge s)$ is equivalent to\\
solution:
Key Idea Use De-morgan's law, Distributive law and Identity law as $p \vee F \equiv p$

The given boolean expression is $\sim s \vee((\sim r) \wedge s)$

Now, the negation of given boolean expression is

$\sim(\sim s \vee((\sim r) \wedge s))$

$$
\begin{array}{ll}
=s \wedge(\sim((\sim r) \wedge s)) & {[\because \sim(p \wedge q)=\sim p \vee \sim q]} \\
=s \wedge(r \vee(\sim s)) & {[\because \sim(p \vee q)=\sim p \wedge \sim q]}
\end{array}
$$

$=(s \wedge r) \vee(s \wedge(\sim s))$

$[\because p \wedge(q \vee r) \equiv(p \wedge q) \vee(p \wedge r)]$

$$
=(s \wedge r) \quad[\because p \wedge \sim p \equiv \mathrm{F}]
$$

Which one of the following Boolean expressions is a tautology?\\
solution:
Option (a) $(p \vee q) \vee(p \vee(\sim q))$

$\equiv p \vee(q \vee \sim q)$ is tautology,

$$
[\because q \vee(\sim q) \equiv \mathrm{T} \text { and } p \vee \mathrm{T} \equiv \mathrm{T}]
$$

Option (b)

$$
(p \wedge q) \vee(p \wedge(\sim q)) \equiv p \wedge(q \vee \sim q)
$$

not a tautology,

$$
[\because q \vee \sim q \equiv \mathrm{T} \text { and } p \wedge \mathrm{T} \equiv p]
$$

Option (c)

$$
(p \vee q) \wedge(p \vee(\sim q)) \equiv p \vee(q \wedge \sim q)
$$

not a tautology $\quad[\because q \wedge \sim q \equiv \mathrm{F}$ and $p \vee \mathrm{F} \equiv p]$ Option (d)

$(p \vee q) \wedge((\sim p) \vee(\sim q)) \equiv(p \vee q) \wedge(\sim(p \wedge q))$ not a tautology.

and their median (arranged numbers are in increasing order) $=35$

$$
\begin{aligned}
\Rightarrow & & \frac{34+x}{2} & =35 \\
\Rightarrow & & 34+x & =70 \\
\Rightarrow & & x & =36

On substituting $x=36$ in Eq. (i), we get

$$
36+y=120

$$
\begin{aligned}

$$

question: If $p \Rightarrow(q \vee r)$ is false, then the truth values of $p, q, r$ are respectively\\
solution:
Given statement $p \Rightarrow(q \vee r)$ is false.

\section*{$\because \quad p \rightarrow(q \vee r)=(\sim p) \vee(q \vee r)$}
Now, by trial and error method, if truth value of $p$ is T, $q$ is F and $r$ is F ,

then truth value of ( $q \vee r$ ) is F .

So, truth value of $[(\sim p) \vee(q \vee r)]$ is false.

Thus, if truth value of $p, q, r$ are $\mathrm{T}, \mathrm{F}, \mathrm{F}$, then the statement $p \rightarrow(q \vee r)$ is false.\\

question: For any two statements $p$ and $q$, the negation of the expression $p \vee(\sim p \wedge q)$ is\\
solution:
$\because p \vee((\sim p) \wedge q)$

$$
\begin{aligned}
& =(p \vee(\sim p)) \wedge(p \vee q) \\
& =p \vee q
\end{aligned}
$$

[by Distributive law]

o negation of $p \vee((\sim p) \wedge q)$

$=\sim[p \vee(\sim p) \wedge q]=\sim(p \vee q)$

$=(\sim p) \wedge(\sim q)$

[by Demorgan's law]

question: If the standard deviation of the numbers $-1,0,1, k$ is $\sqrt{5}$ where $k>0$, then $k$ is equal to\\
solution:
Given observations are $-1,0,1$ and $k$.

Also, standard deviation of these four observations $=\sqrt{5}$

$\therefore \sqrt{\frac{(-1)^{2}+(0)^{2}+(1)^{2}+k^{2}}{4}-\frac{-1+0+1+k^{2}}{4}}=\sqrt{5}$

$\left[\because\right.$ if $x_{1}, x_{2} \ldots x_{n}$ are $n$ observation, then standard deviation $=\sqrt{\frac{1}{n} \sum_{i=1}^{n} x_{i}^{2}-\frac{1}{n} \sum_{i=1}^{n} x_{i}}$

$\Rightarrow \quad \frac{2+k^{2}}{4}-\frac{k^{2}}{16}=5 \quad$ [squaring both sides]

$\Rightarrow \frac{8+4 k^{2}-k^{2}}{16}=5 \Rightarrow \frac{8+3 k^{2}}{16}=5$

$\Rightarrow 8+3 k^{2}=80 \Rightarrow 3 k^{2}=72$

$\Rightarrow k^{2}=24 \Rightarrow k=2 \sqrt{6}$ or $-2 \sqrt{6}$

$\Rightarrow \quad k=2 \sqrt{6}$

$[\because k>0]$

Which one of the following statements is not a tautology?\\
solution:
$(p \wedge q) \rightarrow(\sim p) \vee q$

$$
\begin{array}{ll}
\equiv(\sim(p \wedge q)) \vee((\sim p) \vee q) & \\
\equiv((\sim p) \vee(\sim q)) \vee((\sim p) \vee q) \\
\equiv(\sim p) \vee(\sim q) \vee q \quad \quad[\because(\sim p) \vee(\sim p) \equiv \sim p] \\
& \equiv(\sim p) \vee \mathrm{T} \\
& {[\because \sim q \vee q \equiv \mathrm{T}]}
\end{array}
$$

So, it is a tautology\\
(b)

$$
\begin{aligned}
& (p \wedge q) \rightarrow p \equiv(p \wedge q) \vee p \\
& \equiv((\sim p) \vee(\sim q)) \vee p \\
& \quad[\because \sim(p \wedge q) \equiv(\sim p) \vee(\sim q)]
\end{aligned}
$$

$\equiv(\sim p \vee p) \vee(\sim q)$ is tautology

$[\because \sim p \vee p$ is a tautology and $(\sim q) \vee \mathrm{T} \equiv \mathrm{T}]$

(c) $\because p \rightarrow(p \vee q) \equiv(\sim p) \vee(p \vee q)$

$[\because p \rightarrow q$ is equivalent to $(\sim p \vee q)]$ $\equiv(\sim p \vee p) \vee q$ is tautology.

$[\because(\sim p \vee p)$ is tautology and $q \vee \mathrm{T} \equiv \mathrm{T}]$

(d) $(p \vee q) \rightarrow(p \vee(\sim q))$

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \equiv(\sim(p \vee q)) \vee(p \vee(\sim q)) \\
& \equiv((\sim p) \wedge(\sim q)) \vee(p \vee(\sim q)) \\
& \equiv(p \vee(\sim q) \vee((\sim p) \wedge(\sim q)) \\
& \equiv(p \vee(\sim q) \vee(\sim p)) \wedge(p \vee(\sim q) \vee(\sim q)) \\
& \equiv(\mathrm{T} \vee(\sim q)) \wedge(p \wedge(\sim q)) \\
& \equiv \mathrm{T} \wedge(p \wedge(\sim q)) \\
& \equiv p \wedge(\sim q), \text { which is not a tautology. }
\end{aligned}
$$

question: The sum of all natural numbers ' $n$ ' such that $100<n$ $<200$ and $\mathrm{HCF}(91, n)>1$ is\\
solution:
The natural numbers between 100 and 200 are 101, $102,103, \ldots, 199$.

Since, $91=13 \times 7$, so the natural numbers between 100 and 200 whose HCF with 91 is more than 1 are the numbers which are either divisible by 7 or 13 .

So, the required sum of numbers between 100 and $200=$ (sum of numbers divisible by 7) + (sum of numbers divisible by 13) - (sum of numbers divisible by 91 )

$$
\begin{aligned}
& =\sum_{r=1}^{14}(98+7 r)+\sum_{r=1}^{8}(91+13 r)-(182) \\
& =(98 \times 14)+7 \frac{14 \times 15}{2}+(91 \times 8)+13 \frac{8 \times 9}{2}-(182) \\
& =1372+735+728+468-182 \\
& =3303-182=3121
\end{aligned}
$$

question: The mean and variance of seven observations are 8 and 16 , respectively. If 5 of the observations are 2,4 , $10,12,14$, then the product of the remaining two observations is\\
solution:
Let the remaining two observations are $a$ and $b$. According to the question,

\[
\begin{array}{lr}
\text { Mean }=\frac{2+4+10+12+14+a+b}{7} & =8 \\
\Rightarrow & 42+a+b=56 \\
\Rightarrow & a+b=14 \tag{i}
\end{array}
\]

and variance

$$
=\frac{a^{2}+b^{2}+4+16+100+144+196}{7}-8^{2}=16
$$

\[
\begin{array}{lr}
\Rightarrow & \frac{a^{2}+b^{2}+460}{7}-64=16 \\
\Rightarrow & \frac{a^{2}+b^{2}+460}{7}=80 \\
\Rightarrow & a^{2}+b^{2}+460=560 \\
\Rightarrow & a^{2}+b^{2}=100 \tag{ii}
\end{array}
\]

We know that

$$
\begin{array}{cc} 
& (a+b)^{2}=\left(a^{2}+b^{2}\right)+2 a b \\
\Rightarrow & (14)^{2}=100+2 a b \\
\Rightarrow & 196=100+2 a b \\
\Rightarrow & 2 a b=96 \\
\Rightarrow & a b=48
\end{array}
$$

So, product of remaining two observations is 48 .\\

The contrapositive of the statement "If you are born in India, then you are a citizen of India", is
options: a) If you are not a citizen of India, then you are not born in India.
b) If you are a citizen of India, then you are born in India.
c) If you are born in India, then you are not a citizen of India.
d) If you are not born in India, then you are not a citizen of India.
solution:
Given statement is "If you are born in India, then you are a citizen of India".

Now, let statement $p$ : you are born in India and $q:$ you are citizen of India.

Then, given statement, "If you are born in India then you are a citizen of India" is equivalent to $p \Rightarrow q$.

$\because$ The contrapositive of statement $p \Rightarrow q$ is $\sim q \Rightarrow \sim p$.

$\therefore$ The contrapositive of the given statement is "If you are not a citizen of India, then you are not born in India.

question: The mean and the variance of five observations are 4 and 5.20 , respectively. If three of the observations are 3,4 and 4 , then the absolute value of the difference of the other two observations, is\\
solution:
Given mean $\bar{x}=4$

$$
\text { variance } \sigma^{2}=5.20
$$

and numbers of observation $n=5$

Let $x_{1}=3, x_{2}=4, x_{3}=4$ and $x_{4}, x_{5}$ be the five observations


\begin{align*}
& \text { So, } \quad \sum_{i=1}^{5} x_{i}=5 \cdot \bar{x}=5 \times 4=20 \\
& \Rightarrow \quad x_{1}+x_{2}+x_{3}+x_{4}+x_{5}=20 \\
& \Rightarrow \quad 3+4+4+x_{4}+x_{5}=20 \\
& \Rightarrow \quad x_{4}+x_{5}=9 \tag{i}
\end{align*}


Now, variance $\sigma^{2}=\frac{\sum_{i=1}^{5} x_{i}^{2}}{5}-(\bar{x})^{2}$

$\Rightarrow \frac{x_{1}^{2}+x_{2}^{2}+x_{3}^{2}+x_{4}^{2}+x_{5}^{2}}{5}-(4)^{2}=5.20$

$\Rightarrow \quad \frac{9+16+16+x_{4}^{2}+x_{5}^{2}}{5}=16+5.20$

$\Rightarrow \quad 41+x_{4}^{2}+x_{5}^{2}=5 \times 21.20$

$\Rightarrow \quad x_{4}^{2}+x_{5}^{2}=106-41$

$\Rightarrow \quad x_{4}^{2}+x_{5}^{2}=65$

$\because \quad\left(x_{4}+x_{5}\right)^{2}=x_{4}^{2}+x_{5}^{2}+2 x_{4} x_{5}$

$\therefore \quad 81=65+2 x_{4} x_{5} \quad$ [from Eqs. (i) and (ii)]

$\Rightarrow \quad 16=2 x_{4} x_{5}$

$\Rightarrow \quad x_{4} x_{5}=8$

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \text { Now, }\left(\left|x_{4}-x_{5}\right|\right)^{2}=x_{4}^{2}+x_{5}^{2}-2 x_{4} x_{5} \\
& =65-16 \quad \text { [from Eqs. (ii) and (iii)] } \\
& =49 \\
& \Rightarrow \quad\left|x_{4}-x_{5}\right|=7
\end{aligned}
$$

question: In a class of 60 students, 40 opted for NCC, 30 opted for NSS and 20 opted for both NCC and NSS. If one of these students is selected at random, then the probability that the student selected has opted neither for NCC nor for NSS is\\
solution:
Let $C$ and $S$ represent the set of students who opted for NCC and NSS respectively.

Then, $n(C)=40, n(S)=30, n(C \cap S)=20$

and $n(U)=60$

Now, $n(\bar{C} \cup \bar{S})=n(\overline{C \cup S})$

$$
\begin{aligned}
& =n(\cup)-n(C \cup S) \\
& =60-[n(C)+n(S)-n(C \cap S)] \\
& =60-[40+30-20]=10
\end{aligned}
$$

So, required probability $=\frac{10}{60}=\frac{1}{6}$

question:
Let $Z$ be the set of integers. If

$A=\left\{x \in Z: 2^{(x+2)\left(x^{2}-5 x+6\right)}=1\right\}$

and $B=\{x \in Z:-3<2 x-1<9\}$, then the number of subsets of the set $A \times B$, is\\
solution:
Given, set $A=\left\{x \in Z: 2^{(x+2)\left(x^{2}-5 x+6\right)}=1\right\}$

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \text { Consider, } 2^{(x+2)\left(x^{2}-5 x+6\right)}=1=2^{\circ} \\
& \Rightarrow \quad(x+2)(x-3)(x-2)=0 \\
& \Rightarrow \quad x=-2,2,3 \\
& \Rightarrow \quad A=\{-2,2,3\}
\end{aligned}
$$

Also, we have set $B=\{x \in Z:-3<2 x-1<9\}$

Consider, $\quad-3<2 x-1<9, x \in Z$

$\Rightarrow-2<2 x<10, x \in Z$

$\Rightarrow \quad-1<x<5, x \in Z$

$\Rightarrow \quad B=\{0,1,2,3,4\}$

So, $A \times B$ has 15 elements.

$\therefore$ Number of subsets of $A \times B=2^{15}$.

[ $\because$ If $n(A)=m$, the number of possible subsets $=2^{m}$ ]

question: The expression $\sim(\sim p \rightarrow q)$ is logically equivalent to\\
solution:
Since, the expression

$$
\begin{aligned}
& p \rightarrow q & =\sim p \vee q \\
\text { So, } & & \sim p \rightarrow q \equiv p \vee q
\end{aligned}
$$

and therefore $\sim(\sim p \rightarrow q) \equiv \sim(p \vee q)$

$$
\equiv(\sim p) \wedge(\sim q) \quad[\text { by De Morgan's law }]
$$

question:
The Boolean expression

$((p \wedge q) \vee(p \vee \sim q)) \wedge(\sim p \wedge \sim q)$ is equivalent to\\
solution:
Let the given Boolean expression

$((p \wedge q) \vee(p \vee \sim q)) \wedge(\sim p \wedge \sim q) \equiv r$

Now, let us construct the following truth table

\begin{center}
\begin{tabular}{ccccccccc}
\hline
$p$ & $q$ & $\sim p$ & $\sim q$ & $p \wedge q$ & $p \vee \sim q$ & $\sim p \wedge \sim q$ & \begin{tabular}{c}
$(p \wedge q) \vee$ \\
$(p \vee \sim q)$ \\
\end{tabular} & $r$ \\
\hline
T & T & F & F & T & T & F & T & F \\
\hline
T & F & F & T & F & T & F & T & F \\
\hline
F & T & T & F & F & F & F & F & F \\
\hline
F & F & T & T & F & T & T & T & T \\
\hline
\end{tabular}
\end{center}

Clearly, $r \equiv \sim p \wedge \sim q$

question: If the sum of the deviations of 50 observations from 30 is 50 , then the mean of these observations is\\
solution:
Let the 50 observations are $x_{1}, x_{2}, x_{3}, \ldots, x_{50}$.

Now, deviations of these observations from 30 are $\left(x_{1}-30\right),\left(x_{2}-30\right),\left(x_{3}-30\right), \ldots,\left(x_{50}-30\right)$

$\because \sum_{i=1}^{50}\left(x_{i}-30\right)=50$ $\Rightarrow \sum_{i=1}^{50} x_{i}-(30 \times 50)=50$

$\Rightarrow \sum_{i=1}^{50} x_{i}=50(30+1)=50 \times 31$

$\therefore$ Mean of 50 observations $=(\bar{x})=\frac{\sum_{i=1}^{50} x_{i}}{50}=31$

question: Let $S=\{1,2,3, \ldots, 100\}$. The number of non-empty subsets $A$ of $S$ such that the product of elements in $A$ is even, is\\
solution:
Given, set $S=\{1,2,3, \ldots, 100\}$.

Total number of non-empty subsets of ' $S$ ' $=2{ }^{100}-1$

Now, numbers of non-empty subsets of ' $S$ ' in which only odd numbers $\{1,3,5, \ldots, 99\}$

occurs $=2^{50}-1$

So, the required number of non-empty subsets of ' $S$ ' such that product of elements is even

$$
\begin{aligned}
& =\left(2^{100}-1\right)-\left(2^{50}-1\right) \\
& =2^{100}-2^{50}=2^{50}\left(2^{50}-1\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

question:
A bag contains 30 white balls and 10 red balls. 16 balls are drawn one by one randomly from the bag with replacement. If $X$ be the number of white balls drawn,

then $\frac{\text { mean of } X}{\text { standard deviation of } X}$ is equal to\\
solution:
Number of white balls $=30$

and number of red balls $=10$

Let $p=$ probability of success in a trial = probability of getting a white ball in a trial $=\frac{30}{40}=\frac{3}{4}$.

and $q=$ probability of failure in a trial

$$
=1-p=1-\frac{3}{4}=\frac{1}{4}
$$

Here, $n=$ number of trials $=16$.

Clearly, $X$ follows binomial distribution with parameter $n=16$ and $p=\frac{3}{4}$.

$\therefore$ Mean of $X=n p,=16 . \frac{3}{4}=12$

and variance of $X=n p q=16 \cdot \frac{3}{4} \cdot \frac{1}{4}=3$

Now, $\frac{\text { mean of } X}{\text { standard deviation of } X}=\frac{12}{\sqrt{3}}=4 \sqrt{3}$

$[\because \mathrm{SD}=\sqrt{\text { variance }}]$

question: Contrapositive of the statement "If two numbers are not equal, then their squares are not equal" is
options: a) If the squares of two numbers are not equal, then the numbers are not equal.
b) If the squares of two numbers are equal, then the numbers are equal.
c) If the squares of two numbers are not equal, then the numbers are equal.
d) If the squares of two numbers are equal, then the numbers are not equal.
solution:
We know that, contrapositive of $p \rightarrow q$ is $\sim q \rightarrow \sim p$

Therefore, the contrapositive of the given statement is "If the squares of two numbers are equal, then the numbers are equal".

question: If $q$ is false and $p \wedge q \leftarrow \rightarrow r$ is true, then which one of the following statements is a tautology?\\
solution:
Given, $(p \wedge q) \leftrightarrow r$ is true. This is possible under two cases

Case I When both $p \wedge q$ and $r$ are true, which is not possible because $q$ is false.

Case II When both $(p \wedge q)$ and $r$ are false.

$\Rightarrow$

$$
p \equiv \mathrm{T} \text { or } \mathrm{F} ; q \equiv \mathrm{F}, r \equiv \mathrm{F}
$$

In this case,

(a) $p \vee r$ is T or F

(b) $(p \wedge r) \rightarrow(p \vee r)$ is $\mathrm{F} \rightarrow$ (T or F$)$, which always result in T .

(c) $(p \vee r) \rightarrow(p \wedge r)$ is $($ Tor F$) \rightarrow \mathrm{F}$, which may be Tor F . (d) $p \wedge r$ is F .

Consider the following three statements:

$P: 5$ is a prime number.

$Q: 7$ is a factor of 192 .

$R:$ LCM of 5 and 7 is 35 .

Then, the truth value of which one of the following statements is true?\\
solution:
Since, the statements

$P: 5$ is a prime number, is true statement.

$Q: 7$ is a factor of 192 , is false statement and $R$ : LCM of 5 and 7 is 35 , is true statement.

So, truth value of

$$
P \text { is } \mathrm{T}, \mathrm{Q} \text { is } \mathrm{F}, R \text { is } \mathrm{T}
$$

Now let us check all the options.

\begin{center}
\begin{tabular}{c|c|c|c|c|c|c|c|c}
\hline
$P$ & $Q$ & $R$ & $\sim P$ & $\sim Q$ & $\sim R$ & $P \wedge Q$ & $Q \wedge R \sim Q \wedge R$ &  \\
\hline
T & F & T & F & T & F & F & F & T \\
\hline\hline
$(P \wedge Q) \vee(\sim R)$ & $P \vee(\sim Q \wedge R)$ & $(\sim P) \vee(Q \wedge R)$ & $(\sim P) \wedge(\sim Q \wedge R)$ &  &  &  &  &  \\
\hline
\multicolumn{2}{c|}{F} & \multicolumn{2}{c}{T} & F & F &  &  &  \\
\hline
\end{tabular}
\end{center}

Clearly, the truth value of $P \vee(\sim Q \wedge R)$ is T.

In a class of 140 students numbered 1 to 140 , all even numbered students opted Mathematics course, those whose number is divisible by 3 opted Physics course and those whose number is divisible by 5 opted Chemistry course. Then, the number of students who did not opt for any of the three courses is\\
solution:
\begin{center}
\includegraphics[max width=\textwidth]{2024_07_10_85683c649ecc09dca6b7g-14}
\end{center}

Let $A$ be the set of even numbered students then $n(A)=\frac{140}{2}=70$ ([.] denotes greatest integer function)

Let $B$ be the set of those students whose number is divisible by 3 ,

then $n(B)=\frac{140}{3}=46$

([.] denotes greatest integer function) Let $C$ be the set of those students whose number is divisible by 5 ,

then

$$
n(C)=\frac{140}{5}=28
$$

([.] denotes greatest integer function)

Now,

$$
n(A \cap B)=\frac{140}{6}=23
$$

(numbers divisible by both 2 and 3 )

$$
n(B \cap C)=\frac{140}{15}=9
$$

(numbers divisible by both 3 and 5)

$$
n(C \cap A)=\frac{140}{10}=14
$$

(numbers divisible by both 2 and 5)

$$
n(A \cap B \cap C)=\frac{140}{30}=4
$$

(numbers divisible by 2,3 and 5 )

and $n(A \cup B \cup C)$

$$
\begin{aligned}
& =\Sigma n(A)-\Sigma n(A \cap B)+n(A \cap B \cap C) \\
& =(70+46+28)-(23+9+14)+4=102
\end{aligned}
$$

$\therefore$ Number of students who did not opt any of the three courses

$=$ Total students $-n(A \cup B \cup C)=140-102=38$

question: Consider the statement : " $P(n): n^{2}-n+41$ is prime." Then, which one of the following is true?
options: b) $P(3)$ is false but $P(5)$ is true.
d) $P(5)$ is false but $P(3)$ is true.
solution:
Given statement is " $P(n): n^{2}-n+41$ is prime".

Clearly $P(3): 3^{2}-3+41=9-3+41$

$=47$ which is a prime number.

and $P(5): 5^{2}-5+41=25-5+41=61$,

which is also a prime number.

$\therefore$ Both $P(3)$ and $P(5)$ are true.

question:
The logical statement

$$
[\sim(\sim p \vee q) \vee(p \wedge r)] \wedge(\sim q \wedge r)
$$

is equivalent to\\
solution:
Clearly, $[\sim(\sim p \vee q) \vee(p \wedge r)] \wedge(\sim q \wedge r)$

$\equiv[(p \wedge \sim q) \vee(p \wedge r)] \wedge(\sim q \wedge r)$

$(\because \sim(\sim p \vee q) \equiv \sim(\sim p) \wedge \sim q \equiv p \wedge \sim q$ by De Morgan's law)

$\begin{array}{lr}\equiv[p \wedge(\sim q \vee r)] \wedge(\sim q \wedge r)] & \text { (distributive law) } \\ \equiv p \wedge[(\sim q \vee r) \wedge(\sim q \wedge r)] & \text { (associative law) } \\ \equiv p \wedge[(\sim q \wedge r) \wedge(\sim q \vee r)] & \text { (commutative law) } \\ \equiv p \wedge[\{(\sim q \wedge r) \wedge(\sim q)\} \wedge\{(\sim q \wedge r) \wedge r] \text { (distributive } \\ \text { law) } & \\ \equiv p \wedge[(\sim q \wedge r) \vee(\sim q \wedge r)] & \text { (idempotent law) } \\ \equiv p \wedge[\sim q \wedge r] & \text { (idempotent law) } \\ \equiv p \wedge \sim q \wedge r \equiv(p \wedge r) \wedge(\sim q) & \text { (associative law) }\end{array}$

options: c) $A \cap B=\varphi$ (an empty set) (d) neither $A \subset B$ nor $B \subset A$
solution:
We have,

$$
|a-5|<1 \text { and }|b-5|<1
$$

$\therefore \quad-1<a-5<1$ and $-1<b-5<1$

$\Rightarrow 4<a<6$ and $4<b<6$

Now, $4(a-6)^{2}+9(b-5)^{2} \leq 36$

$$

$$

Taking axes as $a$-axis and $b$-axis

question: If $\sum_{i=1}^{9}\left(x_{i}-5\right)=9$ and $\sum_{i=1}^{9}\left(x_{i}-5\right)^{2}=45$, then the standard deviation of the 9 items $x_{1}, x_{2}, \ldots, x_{9}$ is\\
solution:
Key idea Standard deviation is remain unchanged, if observations are added or subtracted by a fixed number We have,

$$
\begin{gathered}
\sum_{i=1}^{9}\left(x_{1}-5\right)=9 \text { and } \sum_{i=1}^{9}\left(x_{1}-5\right)^{2}=45 \\
S D=\sqrt{\frac{\sum_{i=1}^{9}\left(x_{1}-5\right)^{2}}{9}-\frac{\sum_{i=1}^{9}\left(x_{1}-5\right)^{2}}{9}} \\
\Rightarrow \quad S D=\sqrt{\frac{45}{9}-\frac{9}{9}^{2}} \Rightarrow S D=\sqrt{5-1}=\sqrt{4}=2
\end{gathered}
$$

question: The boolean expression $\sim(p \vee q) \vee(\sim p \wedge q)$ is equivalent to\\
solution:
Key idea Use De-Morgan's and distributive law. We have, $\sim(p \vee q) \vee(\sim p \wedge q)$

$$
\equiv(\sim p \wedge \sim q) \vee(\sim p \wedge q)
$$

$[\because$ By De-Morgan's law $\sim(p \vee q)=(\sim p \wedge \sim q)]$

$$
\equiv \sim p \wedge(\sim q \vee q)
$$

[By distributive law]

$\equiv \sim p \wedge t$

$[\sim q \vee q=t]$

$\equiv \sim p$

question:
If $S$ is the set of distinct values of $b$ for which the following system of linear equations

$$
\begin{gathered}
x+y+z=1 \\
x+a y+z=1 \\
\text { and } \quad a x+b y+z=0
\end{gathered}
$$

has no solution, then $S$ is
options: b) a finite set containing two or more elements
solution:
$\because \Delta=\left|\begin{array}{lll}1 & 1 & 1 \\ 1 & a & 1 \\ a & b & 1\end{array}\right|=1(a-b)-1(1-a)+1\left(b-a^{2}\right)$ $=-(a-1)^{2}$

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \Delta_{1}=\left|\begin{array}{lll}
1 & 1 & 1 \\
1 & a & 1 \\
0 & b & 1
\end{array}\right|=1(a-b)-1(1)+1(b)=-(a-1) \\
& \Delta_{2}=\left|\begin{array}{lll}
1 & 1 & 1 \\
1 & 1 & 1 \\
a & 0 & 1
\end{array}\right|=1(1)-1(1-a)+1(0-a)=0
\end{aligned}
$$

and $\Delta_{3}=\left|\begin{array}{lll}1 & 1 & 1 \\ 1 & a & 1 \\ a & b & 0\end{array}\right|=1(-b)-1(-a)+1\left(b-a^{2}\right)$

$$
=-a(a-1)
$$

For $a=1$

$$
\Delta=\Delta_{1}=\Delta_{2}=\Delta_{3}=0
$$

$\Delta$ for $b=1$ only

$$
x+y+z=1
$$

$$
x+y+z=1
$$

and $\quad x+y+z=0$

i.e. no solution

$(\because$ RHS is not equal)

Hence, for no solution $b=1$ only

The Boolean expression $(p \wedge \sim q) \vee q \vee(\sim p \wedge q)$ is equivalent to\\
solution:
Consider, $(p \wedge \sim q) \vee q \vee(\sim p \wedge q)$

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \equiv[(p \wedge \sim q) \vee q] \vee(\sim p \wedge q) \\
& \equiv[(p \vee q) \wedge(\sim q \vee q)] \vee(\sim p \wedge q) \\
& \equiv[(p \vee q) \wedge t] \vee(\sim p \wedge q) \\
& \equiv(p \vee q) \vee(\sim p \wedge q) \\
& \equiv(p \vee q \vee \sim p) \wedge(p \vee q \vee q) \\
& \equiv(q \vee t) \wedge(p \vee q) \\
& \equiv t \wedge(p \vee q) \equiv p \vee q
\end{aligned}
$$

question: The negation of $\sim s \vee(\sim r \wedge s)$ is equivalent to\\
solution:
$\sim(\sim s \vee(\sim r \wedge s)) \equiv \sim(\sim s) \wedge \sim(\sim r \wedge s)$

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \equiv s \wedge(\sim(\sim r) \vee \sim s) \equiv s \wedge(r \vee \sim s) \\
& \equiv(s \wedge r) \vee(s \wedge \sim s) \\
& \equiv(s \wedge r) \vee \mathrm{F} \\
& {[\because s \wedge \sim s \text { is false }]} \\
& \equiv s \wedge r
\end{aligned}
$$

question: The mean of the data set comprising of 16 observations is 16 . If one of the observations valued 16 is deleted and three new observations valued 3,4 and 5 added to the data, then the mean of the resultant data is\\
solution:
Given, $\frac{x_{1}+x_{2}+x_{3}+\ldots+x_{16}}{16}=16$

$$
\Rightarrow \quad \sum_{i=l}^{16} x_{i}=16 \times 16
$$

Sum of new observations

$=\sum_{i=l}^{18} y_{l}=(16 \times 16-16)+(3+4+5)=252$

Number of observations $=18$

$\therefore \quad$ New mean $=\frac{\sum_{i=l}^{18} y_{i}}{18}=\frac{252}{18}=14$

question: If $A$ and $B$ are two sets containing four and two elements, respectively. Then, the number of subsets of the set $A \times B$ each having atleast three elements are\\
solution:
Given, $n(A)=4, n(B)=2 \Rightarrow n(A \times B)=8$

Total number of subsets of set $(A \times B)=2^{8}$

Number of subsets of set $A \times B$ having no element (i.e. $\varphi$ ) $=1$

Number of subsets of set $A \times B$ having one element $={ }^{8} C_{1}$

Number of subsets of set $A \times B$ having two elements $={ }^{8} C_{2}$

$\therefore$ Number of subsets having alteast three elements

$$
\begin{aligned}
& =2^{8}-\left(1+{ }^{8} C_{1}+{ }^{8} C_{2}\right)=2^{8}-1-8-28 \\
& =2^{8}-37=256-37=219
\end{aligned}
$$

question: The variance of first 50 even natural numbers is\\
solution:
Here, $\bar{X}=\frac{\sum X_{i}}{n}=\frac{2+4+6+8+\ldots+100}{50}=\frac{50 \times 51}{50}=51$

$\left[\because \sum 2 n=n(n+1)\right.$, here $\left.n=50\right]$

$$

question: All the students of a class performed poorly in Mathematics. The teacher decided to give grace marks of 10 to each of the students. Which of the following statistical measures will not change even after the grace marks were given?\\
solution:
If initially all marks were $x_{i}$, then

$$
\sigma_{1}^{2}=\frac{\sum\left(x_{i}-\bar{x}\right)^{2}}{N}
$$

Now, each is increased by 10 .

$$
\therefore \quad \sigma_{2}^{2}=\frac{\sum\left[\left(x_{i}+10\right)-(\bar{x}+10)\right]^{2}}{N}=\sigma_{1}^{2}
$$

So, variance will not change whereas mean, median and mode will increase by 10 .

$\therefore \quad x \in(2, \infty)$

Let $F(x)=\int_{x}^{x^{2}+\frac{\pi}{6}} 2 \cos ^{2} t d t$ for all $x \in R$ and $f: 0, \frac{1}{2} \rightarrow[0, \infty)$ be a continuous function. For $a \in 0, \frac{1}{2}$, if $F^{\prime}(a)+2$ is the area of the region bounded by $x=0, y=0, y=f(x)$ and $x=a$, then $f(0)$ is
solution:
Since, $F^{\prime \prime}(a)+2$ is the area bounded by $x=0, y=0$, $y=f(x)$ and $x=a$.

$$
\therefore \quad \int_{0}^{a} f(x) d x=F^{\prime \prime}(a)+2
$$

Using Newton-Leibnitz formula,

$$
\begin{array}{ll} 
& f(a)=F^{\prime \prime}(\alpha) \\
\text { and } & f(0)=F^{\prime \prime}(0) \\
\text { Given, } & F(x)=\int_{x}^{x^{2}+\pi / 6} 2 \cos ^{2} t d t
\end{array}
$$

On differentiating,

$$
F^{\prime}(x)=2 \cos ^{2} x^{2}+\frac{\pi}{6} \cdot 2 x-2 \cos ^{2} x \cdot 1
$$

Again differentiating,

$$
\begin{aligned}
& F^{\prime \prime}(x)=4 \cos ^{2} x^{2}+\frac{\pi}{6}-2 x \cos x^{2}+\frac{\pi}{6} \quad \sin x^{2}+\frac{\pi}{6} 2 x \\
& +\{4 \cos x \cdot \sin x\} \\
& =4 \cos ^{2} x^{2}+\frac{\pi}{6}-4 x^{2} \cos x^{2}+\frac{\pi}{6} \quad \sin x^{2}+\frac{\pi}{6} \\
& +2 \sin 2 x \\
& \therefore \quad F^{\prime \prime}(0)=4 \cos ^{2} \frac{\pi}{6} \quad=3 \\
& \therefore \quad f(0)=3
\end{aligned}
$$

question:
The value of

$6+\log _{3 / 2} \frac{1}{3 \sqrt{2}} \sqrt{4-\frac{1}{3 \sqrt{2}} \sqrt{4-\frac{1}{3 \sqrt{2}} \sqrt{4-\frac{1}{3 \sqrt{2}} \cdots}}}$ is
solution:
Plan Use of infinite series

i.e. if $y=\sqrt{x \sqrt{x \sqrt{x \ldots \infty}}} \Rightarrow y=\sqrt{x y}$,

Given, $6+\log _{\frac{3}{2}} \frac{1}{3 \sqrt{2}} \sqrt{4-\frac{1}{3 \sqrt{2}} \sqrt{4-\frac{1}{3 \sqrt{2}} \sqrt{4-\frac{1}{3 \sqrt{2}} \cdots}}}$

$$
\begin{array}{lc}
\text { Let } & \sqrt{4-\frac{1}{3 \sqrt{2}} \sqrt{4-\frac{1}{3 \sqrt{2}}} \sqrt{\ldots}}=y \\
\therefore & y=\sqrt{4-\frac{1}{3 \sqrt{2}} y} \\
\Rightarrow & y^{2}+\frac{1}{3 \sqrt{2}} y-4=0 \\
\Rightarrow & 3 \sqrt{2} y^{2}+y-12 \sqrt{2}=0 \\
\therefore & y=\frac{-1 \pm 17}{6 \sqrt{2}} \\
\text { or } & y=\frac{8}{3 \sqrt{2}}
\end{array}
$$

$$
\text { Now, } \begin{aligned}
6+\log _{\frac{3}{2}} \frac{1}{3 \sqrt{2}} \cdot y & =6+\log _{\frac{3}{2}} \frac{1}{3 \sqrt{2}} \cdot \frac{8}{3 \sqrt{2}} \\
& =6+\log _{\frac{3}{2}} \frac{4}{9}=6+\log _{\frac{3}{2}} \frac{3}{2}^{-2} \\
& =6-2 \cdot \log _{\frac{3}{2}} \frac{3}{2}=4
\end{aligned}
$$
